DOC.HEAD: Son of Slain Couple Arrested for Murder, Second Son Sought in Israel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with police comment, details of arrests. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The son of a slain Hollywood executive was arrested Thursday in the shotgun slayings of his parents, and his teen-age brother was being sought in Israel, authorities said. Lyle Menendez, 22, was charged with two counts of murder in the deaths of Jose Menendez, 45, and his wife, Mary Louise ``Kitty'' Menendez, 44, said Deputy District Attorney Elden Fox. Menendez' 19-year-old brother, Erik, was named in the complaint, and was being sought in Israel on identical counts, Fox said. Police would not reveal a motive, but ruled out earlier speculation that drugs or organized crime were involved. Police Chief Marvin Iannone said physical evidence linked the Aug. 20 killings to the sons, whom he described as the triggermen. ``I don't know if there was one motive or several,'' Iannone said. ``As in any family, there are a lot of conflicts. Who knows what really goes on in families?'' ``The focus became very clear over the past few months that the sons did it,'' Iannone said. ``We were just waiting for the glue, binding it together.'' He declined to elaborate on information that led to the arrests. Jose Menendez was chairman of Live Entertainment Inc., a video and music distribution business affiliated with Carolco Pictures Inc., producers of the ``Rambo'' movies. Under terms of the parents' 9-year-old wills, the sons share a $10 million estate. They also were beneficiaries of a $400,000 life insurance policy. The complaint includes special-circumstances allegations that make the sons eligible for the death penalty if convicted. The couple were killed by multiple shotgun blasts at close range. Their sons, who reported the killings, said they found the bodies after a night out. In the months after the killings, Lyle Menendez traveled the country, making investments and buying stores, particularly fast-food franchises, said Iannone. Lyle Menendez was arrested at 1:20 p.m. as he was preparing to drive away from the family mansion. He had been under surveillance for the past 36 hours, Iannone said. Erik Menendez was believed to be taking part in a tennis tournament in Israel. Police were seeking help from the State Department, the Israeli government and Interpol, the international police organization. At the time of the shootings, nothing was stolen from the Spanish-style, $5 million home. There were no signs the killers forced their way in and reportedly no clues at the scene. Police said during the investigation that they were looking into the disappearance of a computerized record concerning Menendez's plans to write a new will. Family members, speaking four months after the slayings on condition of anonymity, said a relative tried to read a computer file named ``will'' after the murders, but was unable to do so. Before a computer expert was brought in, the file disappeared. The relatives would not say who might have erased the file. Iannone declined to comment in detail, except to say, ``The will was very much involved in our investigation.'' The elder Menendez had little money when his parents sent him from Cuba after Castro took power. He was an executive for RCA and Hertz before joining Live Entertainment. Companies operated by Live had been linked to organized crime and pornography before Live bought them, but company officials have rejected suggestions the deaths may have a mob link.

DOC.HEAD: Fire And Explosion Rock Day Care Center
LaserPhoto CD2
DOC.TEXT: A fire and explosion damaged a day care center after it opened Thursday, but children and staff members were evacuated with only minor injuries reported, officials said. Framingham firefighters, responding to a report of a fire at the KinderCare Learning Center at 8:39 a.m. Thursday, found the basement engulfed in thick black smoke, said dispatcher Vin Schiavi. About 30 children and 6 staff members were safely evacuated, said Deputy Fire Chief Thomas Potenza. An explosion rocked the cellar when heat from the fire reached some aerosol cans and paint cans, but no one was injured, Potenza said. Potenza said a large amount of combustible material was stacked in a basement storage room. One center staff member suffered a slight laceration on the hand from the fire, and a firefighter sustained a minor back injury, Potenza said. Damage to the center was estimated at $40,000. The cellar had structural damage from the fire, while the upper floors were damaged by the heavy smoke that billowed upwards, Potenza said. Investigators had not determined the cause of the fire Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: High-Speed Ferry to Begin Operations in June
DOC.TEXT: A high-speed catamaran ferry will link Britain and France starting in June, cutting the current sailing time nearly in half, ferry operators announced. Ferry voyages between Portsmouth, England, and Cherbourg, France now take nearly five hours. The twin-hulled Christopher Columbus, built by International Catamarans of Tasmania, will set sail for England next month and be ready for commercial sailings in June, the ferry company, Hoverspeed, said Thursday. It will carry up to 80 cars and 450 passengers, travel at up to 45 mph and cope with waves as high as 18 feet, the company said. It said other routes, and the price and frequency of voyages, will be announced later. A giant tunnel being dug under the Channel between France and England will offer 35-minute rail crossings. The $11 billion Eurotunnel, a joint project of British and French companies, is scheduled to open in mid-1993.

DOC.HEAD: Funny Business at American Comedy Network Keeps Listeners Guessing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Journalists end up in deep trouble if they blur the line between fact and fiction, but the writers at the American Comedy Network thrive on keeping people guessing about what's real and what's not. Take their recent spoof interview with the president, when a George Bush impersonator sought advice on finding a new enemy to replace the Soviet Union. Or when the ``president's'' opinion on the ``Summit at Sea'' with Mikhail Gorbachev turned into a commentary on another superpower meeting: the fight between Sugar Ray Leonard and Roberto Duran. Since 1983, the American Comedy Network has been producing zany, irreverent skits, mock interviews and fake commercials that disc jockeys around the country use to boost the insanity level of their shows. ``When you get up in the morning there are certain things you need _ what's the weather going to be like, are the highways crowded,'' said ACN general manager and co-founder Andy Goodman. ``And the other hidden ingredient is getting your day rolling, and comedy is always good fare.'' Goodman and co-founder Bob James were working at a radio station in Orlando, Fla., when NewCity Communications Inc. in Bridgeport recruited them to produce parodies for its 11 radio stations. Five months later, they hit it big with one of their mock commercials _ a parody of the AT&T breakup called ``Breakin' Up Is Hard on You,'' sung to Neil Sedaka's ``Breakin' Up Is Hard to Do.'' It got so much airplay that a Boston record company made it into a single that sold 200,000 copies and broke into the Top 80 on one of Billboard magazine's record charts. Within three years, ACN had 128 customers. Now it serves 274 stations in the United States, Canada, Australia, Ireland, New Zealand and the U.S. Virgin Islands. ACN has several competitors, including Rock Comedy Network, the Premier Comedy Network, the Country Comedy Network and the Contemporary Comedy Network. ``We started at the time when the need for comedy in radio was just beginning to build,'' Goodman said. ``We were there to answer the call, and then when everybody else jumped into the field we were considered the first and the best.'' For $1,800 to $15,500 a year, depending on market size, radio stations get 10 tapes a week from ACN's staff of 18, plus freelancers. Nothing is sacred to the writers. There was a commercial for Choke Cola for the Denver Broncos, who have been whipped in their four Super Bowl appearances. Clients got a commercial for the ``James Brown Security Alarm System'' soon after the godfather of soul's arrest. Not everyone sees the fun in some of ACN's antics. Sears Roebuck & Co. sued over a spoof commercial for a ``white sale'' at ``Fears'' department store in Johannesburg, South Africa. The nation's largest retailer eventually settled for $1 in return for destruction of the tape. When ACN did a spot on ``Infidelity Bank,'' it got a call from the chairman of the board of a Fidelity Bank in Topeka, Kan., who was afraid his customers ``were going to think the bank was saying they have sex with their customers,'' Goodman said. ``Some (people) just don't have a sense of humor,'' Goodman said. ``That's one of the risks of doing something in comedy.'' ACN writers assemble every weekday and flip through such publications as People magazine, USA Today and The New York Times, taking the nation's pulse and figuring out what will strike its funny bone. Their scripts wind up in the studio, where ACN's Ed Kelly and New York comedian Nancy Park record most of the voices. The finished product is dubbed onto tapes to be shipped Federal Express to ACN's affiliates. The pressure to be funny week after week is enormous and four of the five original contributors have moved on to other careers. Goodman, the last holdout, also is thinking to go into television writing or journalism. ``After seven years it's hard because when you sit down to write your 1,000th fake commercial or 500th song parody, you can't say it's as exciting as your first fake commercial,'' Goodman said. ``We've done it for seven years, so it just gets tough.''

DOC.HEAD: Milan Fashion Shows Feature Short and Sporty Look
DOC.TEXT: Legs are the talk of the town in Milan this week, as people try to cope with the shocking news that skirts will be shorter than ever next winter. The general consensus is that too-long legs are almost as bad as too short, but whatever the case knees must never be chubby. This spells good news for diet experts and for work-out centers and cosmetic companies which will undoubtedly be flooded with women trying to get rid of those knee dimples, so cute when they were babies, but now definitely outdated. The most extreme version of the new fall-winter 1990-1991 micro-mini, seen at Gianni Versace, played around the hip bone _ hardly a length for the office. This came at the beginning of the four-day Italian ready-to-wear fashion week, which closed here Thursday. Slightly longer versions were presente by almost every designer showing this week with the exception of Soprani, Ferre and Armani, who placed their hemlines a demure inch or so above the knee. Another novelty in the short hemline department is the introduction of sporty bermudas and short shorts into the winter wardrobe. These outfits, as well as the skirts, are usually worn with ribbed wool tights or thigh-high boots. The abbreviated hemline even creeps into fashionable night life with many elegant velvet and sequined gowns anything but floor-length. For those who don't care for the micro look, the over-30 top Italian designers showing their wares here this week revived the thin pencil pants, in light fabric or wool jersey popular in the 1950s. There is a lot of sportswear in these latest collections, with velour sweat suits, knit body suits, embroidered heavy knit sweaters and loads of fashionable parkas and duffel coats. Even Jenny, usually a safe address for the career woman, showed lots of free-time outfits and after-hours hemlines. To enoble its sporty thrust, next year's winter fashion uses a lot of gold detailing both for day and night. The new shape is the A-line, which appears in dresses and jackets alike. Shoulders are narrower in general, although there is no need to throw away your shoulder pads. In the passamenterie department there is abundant use of silk cording, wool braiding, fringe and lace trimming. The most used fabric of the season is velour, which appears around the clock. Colors are either bright shades gleaned from a New England fall landscape or icy pastels drawn from the hues of a winter morning. Christmas-bow red is the newest color. Although the traditional Milan browns, grays and blacks are still around they no longer dominate the collections. Following in alphabetical order are a few highlights from the shows: Armani _ the most graceful and feminine evening wear in delicate porcelain prints and beautiful embroidered velvet Byblos _ cozy Irish knit sweaters with gold and floral embroidery Fendi _ fur down coats, made out of puffed leather stuffed with silk. Ferre _ the Midas of the designers with gold appearing everywhere from evening gowns to parkas Genny _ suits featuring the same length for the jacket and the hemline of the skirt Krizia _ lots of comfortable winter shorts and cozy sweater dresses Missoni _ reversible quilted duffel coat with a multicolored knit print from Russian folklore Moschino _ a runway ballet show instead of a fashion show with dancers haphazardly donning clothes over skin-colored leotards to decry the state of fashion and its mega shows Mario Valentino _ beautiful, bright, tricolored shearlings Versace _ micro-mini skirts and the new 1990 A-line silhouette.

DOC.HEAD: Writers Troubled by Anti-Obscenity Guidelines for Federal Grants
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Grants are godsends for writers like Martha Collins, but she still had to think long and hard before accepting a $20,000 fellowship this year from the National Endowment for the Arts. The financial freedom was tempting, but it came with a few strings attached: Collins and 96 other writers nationwide had to sign letters promising to comply with federal guidelines, including Congressional anti-obscenity and anti-drug restrictions. ``I signed because I can live with it, but I'm concerned by the tone ... concerned that things could get worse instead of better,'' said Collins, who also directs the writing program at the University of Massachusetts at Boston. Many other artists are similarly troubled by the NEA guidelines that were imposed by Congress after the uproar last summer over exhibits of Robert Mapplethorpe's homoerotic photography and Andres Serrano's crucifix submerged in a jar of urine _ both of which were federally funded. Under the restrictions adopted as part of the NEA appropriations bill signed into law last year by President Bush, the endowment agreed to weed out grant recipients whose art might be construed as obscene. But NEA Chairman John Frohnmayer said Thursday he did not endorse the legislation, though as a federal official he was prohibited from lobbying against it. ``I'm obligated to obey the law,'' he said in a telephone interview from Washington. ``I do think that the statute is unnecessary and I hope that Congress in its wisdom will not see fit to continue it.'' Among the 1990 applicants, five writers were singled out for closer examination and all of the more than 4,000 artists who eventually were granted funds received a package containing the promissory letter, the NEA said. ``Like a lot of writers, I was in a financially desperate situation ... so I signed, but not without a lot of outrage,'' said Alison Demming, a Provincetown poet. ``The NEA is giving us freedom from economic stress, but they're saying ... we can't exercise it freely.'' That's not the perception the NEA wants its writers to have, said spokeswoman Virginia Falck. ``Our stand is `Don't let this intimidate you. ... Feel free to create as you wish,''' she said. ``When you're funding creativity, you've got to allow room for people to do all kinds of things _ warts and all.'' Unless those warts include material deemed obscene or created under the influence of drugs. Grant recipients were asked to swear off art that included, but was not limited to, ``depictions of sadomasochism, homoeroticism, the sexual exploitation of children or individuals engaged in sex acts and which, when taken as a whole, do not have serious literary, artistic, political or scientific merit.'' Some writers felt they were staring down a potential pact with the devil, opening the gates to increased censorship and state control of the arts. ``It's ironic that we've spent all these years reading about restrictions on artists in Eastern Europe and just when they're gaining freedom we're beginning to feel restricted,'' Collins said. The Cambridge-based poet also objected to ``sandwiching'' homoerotic art between images of sadomasochism and sexually exploited children. ``Everyone I've talked with feels it's alarming,'' she said. Other writers didn't take things quite so hard. Writer Ursula Hegi of Spokane, Wash., said she signed without hesitation because ``it was not in any conflict with what I'm doing.'' Mark Richard, a New York novelist, said the devil may have been dangling the money before him, but that didn't much diminish the temptation. ``I would never let anything dictate my work. Ever. But for 20 grand, I'd sign even if I were a heroin addict,'' said Richard, who earned $7,000 last year. ``Let them come after me for it.'' The NEA's Falck said the endowment has not so far developed a procedure for checking up on the thousands of photographers, dancers, urban designers, painters and other artists who each year receive federal funds. Liam Rector, who directs the Norfolk, Va.-based Associated Writing Programs, said enforcing the restrictions could prove an ``administrative art-cop nightmare.'' But enforcing them through an artistic police state would be scarier, he said. That's why the writers' coalition, an umbrella for 50 member groups including PEN America, the Modern Language Association and the National Writers' Union, plans to monitor closely the NEA's next steps. ``The (NEA) is supposed to be an arts advocate and at the same time must comply with this law,'' Rector said. ``The endowment finds it difficult to defend itself so it falls to the field and to the artists themselves to protect First Amendment rights.''

DOC.HEAD: Karpov Defeats Timman in 36 Moves in Opening World Chess Match
DOC.TEXT: It took only 36 moves for Anatoly Karpov to defeat Jan Timman in the opening game of their World Chess Candidates Final Match. Thursday's game was the first in the 12-game series, with the winner being the first player to score 6{ points. The series is to run until April 8. The winner of this match will meet Garri Kasparov in Lyon, France, to decide the world championship. The match caries a total prize of $150,000, with the winner receiving $93,750, and the loser the balance. Karpov, of the Soviet Union, handled the Black side of the Ruy Lopez Igor Zaisetv variation with such ease that Timman, of The Netherlands, stopped the clock after 36 moves to avoid being checkmated with a Queen-Bishop combination. The game opened slowly with both players following a popular line in the Spanish system. Karpov went into the above variation with Bb7 and later introduced a novelty seven moves later. According to a grandmaster present at the Malaysia match, Timman missed a chance to equalize when he moved his Queen to the g4 square. He could have taken the Pawn on d5 but instead went for a Bishop pair retention that proved to be insufficient compensation. If the score is tied after 12 games, two further games will be played. If these fail to resolve the tie, two more games will be played. If this again fails to resolve the tie, a series of sudden-death games at faster time limits will decide the match.

DOC.HEAD: Boston Brahmin Accuses GOP Rival of Waging Class Warfare in Governor's Race
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: When wealthy, Republican gubernatorial candidate William Weld accused his chief rival of waging ``class warfare,'' and using hate tactics, the jokes began immediately: About his upper-class accent, ``lockjaw.'' About his native New England foods, ``boiled.'' And his traditional dress, ``docksiders, no socks.'' Not that Weld is incapable of joking about his White Anglo-Saxon Protestant pedigree himself. Asked recently about the last book he had read, Weld quipped with a smile: ``Candle Making for Fun and Profit,'' a reference, he said, to his Yankee roots. But Weld was deadly serious Wednesday when he called a news conference to warn House Minority Leader Steven Pierce, the son of a carpenter, to lay off his blue-blood background. ``I think it's time to get this `class' issue out into the open and reveal it for what it is: the old-style politics of hate and fear,'' Weld said. Pierce said Weld was being a bit touchy on the subject. ``I think Bill is showing an incredible amount of sensitivity. In a political campaign, a lot of statements are made and things are hurled around,'' Pierce said. Weld, 44, is a former U.S. assistant attorney general who quit the Reagan administration after questions were raised about his boss, Edwin Meese II. He now lives in Cambridge, with his wife, a member of the Roosevelt clan, and works at the proper Boston law firm of Hale & Dorr. He has had memberships in exclusive clubs and has a stock portfolio worth between $850,000 and $1.5 million. He resigned from the clubs when he began eyeing the governor's race. A Pierce supporter circulated a letter Thursday around the Statehouse suggesting the Legislature pass a ``Brahmin Rights Act.'' Republican Rep. William Vernon said he wrote the letter to inject a little humor into the campaign. His tongue-in-cheek legislation would ``ensure the Brahmins' civil rights and equal access to housing employment and elective office. ... The recent travails of Bill Weld offer ample evidence of the prejudices against those individuals known as `Yankee Bluebloods,''' he said in the letter. In a state where a generation can still recall ``No Irish Need Apply'' signs, and where many remember that busing to accomplish racial integration bypassed rich, white suburbanites and people who could afford to send their children to private schools, Weld may have tapped into a lingering bias. Todd Domke, a Republican political consultant, has said Weld may be suffering from the last acceptable prejudice in the state _ against Yankees. Another political observer, Marty Linsky, a former Republican legislator who lectures at Harvard University's Kennedy School of Government, pointed out the bias hasn't hurt Yankees in the past. ``For most of Massachusetts history, Brahmins have been successful in leadership positions in public life, because people trusted them,'' Linsky said. Brahmins, in New England, are cultured people from long-established, upper-class families. Paul Watanabe, head of the political science department at the University of Massachusetts in Boston, said Weld's attack may help him. ``I think Weld is trying to turn what is presumably a liability into a strength,'' Watanabe said. ``Raising this particular issue is a good one. I think his dealing with it straight on is good.'' But former Gov. Francis Sargent, who can trace his bloodlines to the Puritans, said Weld would do better to leave the issue alone. ``The more he says about it, the more he draws attention to it,'' Sargent told The Patriot Ledger of Quincy. ``Just tell them to spell the name right.'' Sargent used to talk up a different branch of his family. ``My grandmother was Italian and I peddled that all over the state _ where she came from in Italy, what her name was,'' Sargent said.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle to Focus on Panama, Economics in Latin Troop
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf pvs, bgng: ``Panama was...'' to CORRECT date of Brazil inaugural; picks up 4th graf pvs, bgng: ``Governments in...''
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle, leaving Friday to help usher in new presidents in Chile and Brazil, said his trip will also focus on economic development in Latin America where ``we have not been as successful as we'd like.'' On the trip, Quayle also will press President Bush's effort to win Latin acceptance for the U.S.-installed government of Panama, even as both Chile and Brazil snub the Panamanian president elevated by the U.S. invasion. Panama was the only country in the hemisphere not invited to send representatives to Sunday's inauguration of Chile's new president, Patricio Aylwin, and also is excluded from the March 15 swearing in of Brazil's Fernando Collor de Mello. Governments in those nations, like other Latin countries, condemned Bush's Dec. 20 military invasion as a violation of Panama's sovereignty. They had withdrawn their ambassadors from Panama City to protest the rule of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, but retained diplomatic relations with Panama. Quayle's week-long trip also includes stops in Venezuela, Barbados, Paraguay and Argentina. Now that Chile has become the last country in South America to hold democratic elections, Quayle said he will be listening to the economic needs of the debt-and inflation-plagued Latin and Caribbean leaders. ``Political development has been successful in the hemisphere, but we have not been as successful as we'd like on economic development,'' Quayle told reporters Thursday on the eve of his departure. ``I will be asking the leaders of the individual countries for their ideas'' on trade and economic ideas, he said. Little progress has been made, except in Mexico, on the Bush administration's plan to help ease Latin American debt in part through forgiveness of outstanding loans by commercial banks. Quayle said he had called Prime Minister Michael Manley of Jamaica earlier Thursday to inform him the administration would provide an additional $10 million in food assistance for the Caribbean nation, bringing the total to $44 million for that country. Quayle also will relay Bush's plea for a common voice of support for both Panama and the newly elected government of Nicaragua. The countries that have refused to recognize Panama's President Guillermo Endara generally feel that Panama should have an election or congressional mandate to legitimize his government. ``We're moving toward hemispheric wide acceptance of the Panamanian government, general acceptance. These sorts of things will be worked out,'' said Quayle's press secretary, David Beckwith. Endara's recent announcement that he would propose a series of reforms and submit them to the electorate for approval is a step in the direction that the other Latin countries would like to see, said a State Department official who spoke on condition of anonymity. U.S. officials said they are hopeful that diplomacy spurred in part by Venezuela's President Carlos Andres Perez will result in a more generous attitude toward the Endara government. In Brazil, ``It is likely that the new government will examine the matter in a new light,'' said a Brazilian diplomat. Quayle's trip also offers a potentially interesting twist in Chile, with the expected attendance of Nicaragua's outgoing President Daniel Ortega. Quayle and Ortega are not scheduled to meet, but in a reversal of past policy, Beckwith said, ``We're certainly not opposed to it.'' The United States, in a policy begun by President Reagan, refused to meet with Nicaraguan officials. U.S. officials said Managua should meet for direct talks with the U.S.-backed Contra rebels first. That whole situation changed with the victory last month of Violeta Chamorro over Ortega and the calls from all sides for the Contras to give up their fight. Quayle will meet with the outgoing Chilean president, Gen. Agosto Pinochet, who was forced to call an election 16 years after he ousted the elected government of Salvador Allende. Although Aylwin won the election, Pinochet is insisting on retaining control of the 60,000-man Chilean army. Quayle will be accompanied to Chile by Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., who engendered ire there by pushing the current U.S. arms embargo on Chile to protest Pinochet's human rights record. When Kennedy went to meet with opposition leaders in 1986, Pinochet's police stood by while 200 rightist demonstrators threw rocks and eggs and blocked Kennedy's motorcade. Quayle will spend only a few hours in Venezuela, where anti-American protests also are a possibility. Perez said his government would not recognize Panama until U.S. invasion troops were withdrawn and the Endara government was given legitimacy by the electorate. The troops were out by mid-February, although the United States still retains its pre-invasion force of some 13,000 in Panama. In Brazil and Argentina, economic concerns are expected to be a big part of Quayle's talks.

DOC.HEAD: 3,000 Years of Fakes: From Furry Fish to Letter From Christ
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Priests in ancient Babylon faked an inscription to make their temple seem older. A modern Scottish museum had to fake a fish with fur to satisfy public demand. These are among 600 objects in a British Museum exhibition that displays 3,000 years of the forger's art and suggests that fakes often reflect what people want to believe. The objects range from a faked Roman chariot and photographs of fairies to a forged Rembrandt painting and a witch's wreath. The exhibition ``Fake? The Art of Deception,'' running through Sept. 2, contains fake jewels, coins, sculptures, fossils, furniture and porcelain. There's even a letter purporting to have been written by Jesus Christ. ``Most of the worst errors in this exhibition are our own,'' says director Sir David M. Wilson. ``It's not surprising as we have been collecting for a long time as museums go, nearly 250 years. The forgers had more than a head start as they were busy in ancient Babylon 3,000 years ago,'' he said. Wilson admits: ``There is a horrid fascination about fakes. Although we sweep them under the carpet, we talk about them all the time because we know we as experts are fallible.'' The first thing visitors see is a supposed Etruscan tomb of the 6th century B.C., made about 120 years ago. ``The British Museum bought the tomb from an Italian dealer in 1871 because the Louvre had one and we were jealous,'' said Dr. Susan Walker, an antiquities expert. ``Within a year of the purchase, the inscription on the lid was found to have been copied from a gold brooch in the Louvre, but the tomb was kept on show until 1935 and has appeared in countless books on the Etruscans and their art,'' she said. Mark Jones, an expert on coins and medals who assembled the fakes from 26 museums in Britain and abroad, said the exhibition was ``about deception, about lying things whenever and wherever they are made.'' ``It's evidence of what people saw and valued in the art of the past because a faked antique shows much more clearly than the real thing what collectors valued. Fakes often reflect what people want to believe,'' he said. ``When we fall in love we aren't totally rational in assessing our loved one's qualities,'' Jones said. ``You can fall in love with an object but others will see through it because they don't share your love for it.'' The show demonstrates how fakes are exposed by electron microscopes, ultraviolet light, X-rays and radiocarbon dating. The British Museum's own archaeologists in 1881 brought back a Babylonian inscription from what is now Iraq. It speaks of the renovation of a temple and the large revenues it received from the king and ends up saying, ``This is not a lie, it is indeed the truth.'' But modern studies showed it was a lie, written in about 1,000 B.C. and purporting to be 1,000 years older, probably by priests who wanted to strengthen their temple's claim to its rights and income. The letter of Christ appears in the ``Ecclesiastical History'' of Eusebius, known as the father of church history, who was probably born in Palestine about 313 and became a bishop. In the invented letter, Christ blesses King Abgar for his belief in Christ's miraculous cures. Then there's the furry trout. A Scotsma wrote home from Canada in the 17th century about the abundance of ``furried animals and fish.'' Asked to provide an example of furry fish he obliged _ and a modern Canadian is still at it, putting rabbit fur on stuffed trout, with a text saying fish in great depths and penetrating cold grow a dense coat of protective fur. ``One of these fish was brought to us by someone who thought it was genuine,'' said Geoffrey Swinney of the Royal Museum of Scotland. ``We said it was a hoax and sent him away but the story had got out and public demand to see the furry fish was so strong that we had to make one _ a fake twice over.''

DOC.HEAD: Swedes Demand that Norway Permanently Ban Seal Pup Hunt
DOC.TEXT: Swedish animal welfare activists demanded Norway permanently ban the hunting of seal pups, which are often bludgeoned to death to avoid damaging their pelts. Norway banned the hunt for pups last year and this year. The petitions demanding a permanent ban were signed by 80,000 Swedes and delivered Thursday to Norway's fisheries ministry, officials said. ``We can guarantee that no seal pups will be taken this year,'' Karsten Klepsvik, a ministry spokesman, told activists. Activist Staffan Persson told NTB, the national news agency, that signatures were gathered after a seal-hunting film on Swedish television a year ago.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Yippie-turned-yuppie Jerry Rubin has a new money-making scheme: selling an earth-colored drink packed with ingredients like kelp, ginseng and bee pollen. The 51-year-old Rubin, an independent marketer for the Dallas-based Omnitrition International, has been recruiting salespeople for his headquarters in Wallingford. They will sell a nutritional drink called Omni IV. ``This is the best business opportunity for the average American to make a living and break out of the corporate cocoon,'' Rubin said Thursday. ``It's going to be in the '90s what real estate was to the `80s. ``What I think the 1990s is going to be about is nutrition and entrepreneuring.'' The former Yippie was a member of the Chicago Seven, a group of radicals who were tried on charges of conspiring to disrupt the 1968 Democratic National Convention. He turned to spiritualism in the 1970s and then became a Wall Street networker. His recruits for the new venture include old friends. One is Bobby Seale, the Black Panther founder and a Chicago Seven co-defendant. Seale is sold. ``Living in a capitalist society without capital is a contradiction,'' he said.

Convicted Watergate figure Charles Colson says America is losing a generation of children because they're not being taught right from wrong. ``We have come to a point where we don't believe in absolutes. Schools are not value neutral, they're value hostile. We're losing a generation because we're not teaching them right from wrong,'' he said. He said it's not enough to teach children to just say no. ``We need to teach them why you say no.'' Colson, 58, former special counsel to President Nixon, also told the 1,200 people attending the Nebraska Leadership Prayer Breakfast on Thursday about his Prison Fellowship Ministries. It has 250 full-time employees and 33,000 volunteers. ``The love of God takes us into those dark holes, witnessing to prisoners and their families,'' he said.

Entertainer Helen Reddy believes the world would be a better place if more women were in charge. Reddy, who recorded ``I Am Woman,'' an anthem for the feminist movement, spoke to a group of about 200 people Thursday at Marshall University in recognition of International Women's Day. She listed war, poverty, hunger, children and elderly among female concerns. ``We need more shelters for battered women and children,'' she said. ``We have more shelters for animals'' than women and children. Reddy encouraged feminists to take the lead in politics. ``If you have the slightest interest in running for office, do it,'' she said.

Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti of Italy, at a ceremony in which he received an honorary doctorate of law from New York University, urged Americans to look beyond stereotypes of his country. The award coincided with the establishment of a university chair in Italian studies, to be named for Alcide de Gasperi, the architect of Italy's post-World War II recovery and Andreotti's mentor. The 71-year-old Andreotti, who has served six times as Italy's prime minister, noted Thursday that more than 70 U.S. universities and colleges have set up programs on Italy. ``The spontaneous germination of a cultural osmosis between Italy and the United States must not serve as a pretext for neglecting the development of these relations. Even today there persists in America a stereotypical vision of our country. ``We would like to offer our American friends a view of Italy as she is today, without masking her defects, without propagandizing, but by highlighting her civil, social, cultural and artistic achievements.''

Actor Bob Saget is hot, but he wants to be hotter. He wants be household-name hot. He plays the widowed father Danny Tanner on the ABC-TV comedy ``Full House'' and he's hosting and co-writing the blockbuster new show ABC's ``America's Funniest Home Videos.'' ``Kinda frightening, isn't it? I mean, people still don't know my name, but now they'll look at me in a restaurant, point and say, `That's the guy.' I guess that's flattering, but I'm not sure,'' Saget said in a recent interview. Saget has a few more opportunities to get his name out. He's a presenter on both the American Comedy Awards and People's Choice Awards telecasts, and he's writing, performing and directing a one-man ``On Location'' comedy special for HBO.

Unlike other musicians, rock 'n' roll Hall of Famer Dion doesn't grumble when asked to perform his old hits. ``I love doing old songs,'' said the 50-year-old Dion DiMucci, who performed this week as part of the ``Dave Edmunds Rock 'n' Roll Revue'' at the Ulster County Playhouse. ``In fact, they have more value to me as time passes,'' he said. ``And I see what they do to an audience. They love it. I get a big kick out of it.'' In his latest tour, Dion mixes early 1960s material like ``Runaround Sue,'' ``The Wanderer'' and ``Ruby Baby'' with songs from a comeback album released last year. ``If the song is good, it's good,'' he said.

More than 100 paintings, drawings and sculpture acquired by French actor Alain Delon over two decades went on display at the Galerie Didier Imbert to benefit cancer research. The exhibition, titled ``Twenty Years of Passion,'' opened Thursday and will run through April 13. Proceeds from the sale of the show's catalogue will be donated to the Association for Cancer Research. ``This collection came about through love and passion, and not in a commercial or speculative spirit,'' Delon said. The collection includes works by Braque, Toulouse-Lautrec, Delacroix and Millet and animal sculpture by Rembrandt Bugatti.

DOC.HEAD: First Nuclear Test of Year Scheduled Saturday at Nevada Site
DOC.TEXT: The first U.S. nuclear weapons test of the year is scheduled for detonation Saturday morning at the Nevada Test Site, the Energy Department said. The test, code-named Metropolis, will be the first nuclear weapon exploded at the nuclear proving grounds since Dec. 20. Department spokesman Chris West said on Thursday the weapon will have a yield of 20 to 150 kilotons of TNT, large enough for the agency to warn managers of high-rise buildings in Las Vegas not to have workers in precarious positions at the time of the scheduled 8 a.m. PST detonation. The weapon will be exploded 1,500 feet beneath the surface of Yucca Flat, about 85 miles north of Las Vegas. Last year, the Department of Energy exploded 12 nuclear weapons at the sprawling desert facility, where the nation's nuclear warheads have been tested since 1951.

DOC.HEAD: Dog's Owner Takes Pet for a Run _ in His Car
DOC.TEXT: Tattoo the basset hound went for an unplanned run when his owner shut one end of his leash in a car door and took off for a drive _ with Tattoo on the leash's other end still outside. Motorcycle Officer Kerry Filbert was on patrol when he noticed a vehicle that seemed to have something dragging from it, police spokesman Mark Mann said. As Filbert passed the vehicle Wednesday evening, he saw that the car was dragging a basset hound on a leash, ``picking them up and putting them down just about as fast as he could,'' Mann said. Filbert chased and finally stopped the car, but not before the dog reached a speed of 20 to 25 mph and ``rolled several times,'' Mann said. The car's occupants, a man and a woman, jumped out and Filbert told them they were dragging a dog. The couple became distressed and began calling ``Tattoo! Tattoo!'' Mann said. The couple from Renton had been visiting friends in Tacoma, and the man had taken Tattoo outside before the trip home, Mann said. When the woman called the man to help her carry something, he shut Tattoo's leash in the driver's door so the dog wouldn't wander away, but apparently forgot the animal was there before driving off, Mann said. The 8-month-old dog appeared uninjured, but Filbert suggested the couple take him to an animal clinic.

DOC.HEAD: Cat Emerges From Storm Drain After 5 Weeks
DOC.TEXT: Tootsie the cat is back in her nice, warm home after spending five weeks in a snow-covered storm drain. ``The poor, little thing looked awful when we got her out. She was just skin and bones,'' said Nicole Lonsdale, who helped find the cat for her neighbors, Peter and Teri Tyson. Tootsie disappeared Jan. 26, apparently entering an open storm drain which was sealed off by a snow plow clearing the road in this southern Maine city, the Tysons said. The Tysons and neighbors searched the area, but gave up hope of finding the 6-year-old cat until late last week. Tyson was chatting with Lonsdale in her driveway Saturday when he heard a faint meow from the nearby drain. He prided the lid off the drain with a crowbar, then got a ladder and climbed into the drain, calling Tootsie's name. The cat poked her head out of a pipe and scampered for Tyson, who wrapped her in a pillowcase. ``It's been freezing and there is no food down there and water would have been running on her,'' said Lonsdale, who carried the cat home to an amazed Mrs. Tyson. An animal hospital said no special medical attention was necessary, so the Tysons and their two children have simply been pampering their pet. ``She wants to be around us all the time now,'' Mrs. Tyson said.

DOC.HEAD: On The Light Side
DOC.TEXT: The investigation into the theft of a coat and hat was only a day old when the prime suspect, wearing his booty, waltzed into police headquarters and the arms of the law. Randolph Ferland, 53, stopped Wednesday at the police station in this west-central Connecticut town to use the bathroom, but was arrested after an alert police captain realized Ferland and his outfit matched witnesses' descriptions. The crime drama began Tuesday night when someone sneaked into the Lutheran Church of Cheshire, and stole a winter coat and knit hat from a closet. A few church members got a glimpse of the man, and described him to police. Police Capt. Gary Walberg said he was reading a report on the theft Wednesday when he happened to peer out of his office and saw the man described in the report _ jacket, hat and all. ``He matched the description to a T,'' Walberg said. The only thing missing was the victim to identify the coat Ferland was wearing as the one that had been taken. As that thought crossed Walberg's mind, the victim walked into the police station to see if the coat had been found. It had. After spending most of the day in jail, Ferland pleaded guilty in Meriden Superior Court to sixth-degree larceny by possession. A judge released him for time already served.

The 21st annual Reeking Regatta sets sail this spring, but organizers say the event will change its name because the bayou where it's held is recovering from its pungent pollution problems. ``We feel there's been a marked improvement,'' said Buffalo Bayou Coalition President Anna Martin, whose environmental group sponsors the ``anything that floats'' race held since 1969. The Reeking Regatta will be held April 7, but next year's race will be called the Buffalo Bayou Regatta. The event was launched to call attention to the mammoth pollution woes of Houston's largest bayou, due largely to the city's notoriously inadequate sewer system. But Ms. Martin said system improvements have reduced the amount of fecal bacteria, a measure of human and animal waste in water, in the bayou. The most recent city measurements, taken last week, showed bacteria levels at most monitoring stations were below the maximum considered safe for boating and other recreation that doesn't involve getting into the water. ``A lot of improvements have been made, compared to about a year ago,'' said Zaki Ahmad, an engineer in the city Public Works Department. However, Ms. Martin said coalition members would not let their guard down.

DOC.HEAD: USDA to Go Own Way on Food Labeling ^Eds: This stands for the Farm Scene column
DOC.TEXT: Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter says his department will use its own recipe when drawing up food labels to give consumers more information on what they eat. In effect, Yeutter has told Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan that a plan for requiring improved nutrition labeling for most foods may fly in the Food and Drug Administration but not necessarily in the Agriculture Department. ``We will certainly study and evaluate what HHS has suggested,'' Yeutter said Thursday. ``There's some merit in having these rules as consistent as possible, but we make our own decisions at USDA.'' Sullivan told a food policy conference on Wednesday that the grocery store has become ``a Tower of Babel'' because of so many labels confronting consumers. He said some labels omit vital information and make unfounded health claims. The FDA has label jurisdiction over foods except those containing meat and poultry products, which are the domain of the Agriculture Department. Under the FDA's proposal, which would be implemented in three steps, processors would have to disclose the fat, fiber and cholesterol content of packaged foods. Current requirements, put in place 17 years ago, call for nutrition labeling only when a manufacturer adds vitamins, minerals or proteins or makes a nutrirional claim about the product. About 60 percent of packaged foods now list nutrients. Yeutter, speaking to the same group as Sullivan, was asked if his department would follow up on Sullivan's proposal. ``We're going to proceed at what we believe is a systematic and rational way to deal with these issues,'' he said. ``We'll certainly try to reach the same fundamental objectives as all of us have in mind ... but we intend to do it our way, and we may well take part of what Secretary Sullivan suggested and apply it. But there may well be some parts that we would not apply.'' Echoing complaints by food-industry representatives, Yeutter objected to Sullivan's apparent willingness to accept ``differentiated'' labeling requirements on a state-by-state basis. ``I don't happen to think that's a good idea,'' he said. ``It seems to me that consumers will pay a significant cost if we end up with different labeling systems in 50 states. That doesn't set a good example for the world, doesn't set a good example here, in my judgment.'' Yeutter for years, including his service as U.S. trade representative in the Reagan administration, has pushed hard for liberalized trade under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. One of the aspects of the current Uruguay Round of GATT negotiations, he said, is the harmonization of international health regulations for agricultural products. Yeutter said it would set a bad example at the bargaining table if the United States is not able to harmonize its own domestic labeling regulations while seeking such uniformity on the international level. There is no disagreement at USDA with the fundamental objectives of Sullivan's plan, ``but we want to do it right,'' he said. ``If Secretary Sullivan's proposal turns out to be right, that's great,'' Yeutter said. ``But if we think there's a better way at USDA we're going to do it the better way.'' As he has many times before, Yeutter said food safety decisions should be based on scientific knowledge, not on emotional issues such as last year's controversy about the chemical Alar used on apples. The current issue in California over the use of malathion to control medflies was also cited. Yeutter said he fully supported the administration's proposal to ease back on current ``Delaney clause'' restrictions on the use of additives shown to cause cancer in laboratory animals. He said the rules should be changed to permit a ``negligible risk'' approach to substances instead of trying to eliminate all risk. ``We ought to have objectives that are achievable, not objectives that are unachievable,'' Yeutter said. ``All we do is deceive people when we lay before them objectives or goals or legislative requirements that will never be achieved.''

DOC.HEAD: Aguilar Case to Jury; Prosecutor Says Judge Lost Sense of Limits
DOC.TEXT: The case of U.S. District Judge Robert Aguilar, charged with using his office to do favors for felons, went to a federal court jury Thursday after a prosecutor described him as ``a man who had lost his sense of limits.'' ``It's a Shakespearean tragedy, a Greek tragedy,'' Justice Department lawyer said of Aguilar's case. He told the jury a conviction would ``keep the flame of justice alive for those who don't have anybody, an insider (to go) through the back door.'' But Doron Weinberg, lawyer for codefendant Rudy Tham, accused prosecutors and the FBI of ``an extraordinary misuse of government power'' and said it was the government, not the defendants, who had obstructed justice. U.S. District Judge Louis Bechtle sent the jury to begin deliberations late Thursday on eight felony charges against Aguilar and two each against Tham, a former Teamster leader, and Abe Chapman, an 83-year-old self-styled ex-mobster who was once related to Aguilar by marriage. Aguilar, 58, of San Jose, a 1980 appointee of President Jimmy Carter, is accused of approaching two fellow judges to try to influence the criminal cases of Tham and Ronald Cloud, the judge's longtime friend who was convicted of bank fraud. He also is charged with helping another friend, Vera Hoff, conceal her presence in Mexico, where she fled to avoid a tax evasion sentence; with twice tipping off Chapman about wiretaps; with telling Tham's lawyer to lie to the grand jury about Aguilar's involvement in the case, and with lying to the FBI to derail a grand jury investigation. Several of the allegations are combined in a charge that Aguilar used his office as a ``racketeering enterprise'' to obstruct justice, the first such charge against a federal judge. Aguilar's lawyer, Patrick Hallinan, claimed in his closing argument Wednesday that the prosecution was trying to ``slander and smear'' Aguilar by calling him a racketeer.

DOC.HEAD: Experts Dissect Last 13 Minutes On The Exxon Valdez
DOC.TEXT: Former skipper Joseph Hazelwood's defense tried to prove a helmsman's error grounded the Exxon Valdez by focusing expert testimony on the last 13 minutes of the tanker's shattered voyage. Using computer simulation and complicated charts, two experts tracked the ship's passage, second by second, as it moved through the Valdez Narrows into Prince William Sound on March 24. Peter Shizume and Joseph Winer showed jurors in Hazelwood's criminal trial calculations indicating the tanker would have missed Bligh Reef if the helmsman had turned the rudder right even two or three minutes before it rammed the reef and spilled nearly 11 million gallons in the nation's worst oil spill. Winer indicated that the helmsman, for unknown reasons, turned the rudder to the right, then back to the left in the last moments before the disaster, plowing right into the reef on the ship's left side. Shizume, an engineer from Hicksville, N.Y., who created a complex computer program to simulate ship accidents, said the helmsman could have saved the ship if he'd turned only half as far as called for by a third mate. Winer, a marine surveyor from Boonton, N.J., who analyzed the ship's course recorder, said he believes the grounding occurred about three minutes later than assumed and that a ``hitch'' he observed in the recorder reflects the unexplained ``counter rudder'' turn left. Shizume, who used various scenarios of what might have happened to the tanker, said it would have missed Bligh Reef by two miles if the helmsman had turned 10 degrees right 10 minutes before the ship ran aground. The third mate, Gregory Cousins, who was in control of the tanker while Hazelwood went to his cabin, said he gave the 10-degree order to helmsman Robert Kagan but didn't look to make sure Kagan was turning until it was too late. The mate suggested that the helmsman failed to follow the order because he had problems with steering. But the defense has also suggested Kagan had hearing problems and may not have heard the order. Shizume said his study of the ship's course recorder showed that Kagan's average turn during the critical period was 4 degrees. ``What is your opinion as to what he was doing?'' asked defense attorney Michael Chalos. ``He looks like he was swinging the rudder back and forth,'' apparently without any commands to do so, the retired Sperry Gyroscope Co. engineer said. Hazelwood, 43, faces up to 7\ years in prison and $61,000 in fines if convicted on all four criminal counts against him. During cross-examination of Shizume, Assistant District Attorney Brent Cole tried to shift blame back to Hazelwood. ``So if Captain Hazelwood had been on the bridge and ordered a 5-degree right rudder turn,'' he began to ask, but was cut off by a shouted objection from Chalos. ``Objection, your honor. It's independent of whether Captain Hazelwood was on the bridge or a chimpanzee,'' the lawyer said of the calculations. Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone upheld the objection.

DOC.HEAD: Researchers Develop Synthetic Gene to Attack AIDS Virus
DOC.TEXT: A molecule created in a California laboratory has shown in a test tube experiment that it can ambush the AIDS virus and keep the deadly disease from spreading, according to a study published today. Dr. John J. Rossi, a researcher at the Bechman Research Institute of the City of Hope in Duarte, Calif., reports in the journal Science that his laboratory has made a synthetic ribozyme that can genetically cripple the AIDS virus and prevent it from reproducing. The ribozyme, said Rossi, ``is inside the cell and it's waiting there like a soldier waiting for the enemy to come.'' Ribozymes eventually could be useful in combating AIDS and other virus infections, he said, but the technique is still years away from being ready to treat patients. Rossi, in a telephone interview, said his team first developed the ribozyme and then made a gene that instructed cells to make the molecule. The synthetic gene then was placed into living human cells in test tubes and the cells were exposed to the AIDS virus. Rossi said the ribozyme was able to block the AIDS virus from reproducing inside the cells. The ribozyme works like ``molecular scissors'' that slice the ribonucleic acid of the AIDS virus, thus blocking the virus from making copies of itself. Ribonucleic acid, or RNA, is used by the virus to force cells to make more virus. By cutting the RNA, said Rossi, the virus is permanently crippled. The ribozyme itself is a copy of an RNA that other scientists found in a plant virus. Those researchers discovered that a small part of the plant virus RNA acted like an enzyme and was capable of selectively cutting any part of the genetic pattern in a target virus. The term ribozyme refers to an RNA that acts as an enzyme by permitting a reaction to occur within a cell. Rossi said a major advantage of the ribozyme is that after it attacks and cuts the RNA in one virus, the molecule releases itself and then can attack other virus particles. ``It can do it again and again and again,'' said Rossi. ``It is like one soldier cutting down 10 or more of the enemy.'' The ribozyme can be designed to attack any part of the viral RNA and leave other portions alone. Rossi said he believes the ribozyme also could be used to combat virtually any kind of virus, including those that cause colds and flu. ``It could be used to treat any virus at all because they all use RNA,'' he said. ``By destroying the RNA, you can inactivate the viral function.'' Rossi said two other laboratories now plan to test his ribozyme in combating viruses in laboratory animals. Even if it proves effective in animals, Rossi said the ribozyme cannot be used against AIDS until some way is found to introduce the synthetic gene clinically into humans, a technique that could take years to develop. He said researchers must find a way to assure that the ribozyme gene goes directly to the proper place within the target cells. He said there are several theoretically possible ways of doing this, but none is ready for tests. ``We don't have any scientific proof yet that a genetically engineered cell in a living animal will do anything,'' said Rossi, but in test tube experiments the technique appears to be ``powerful.'' In addition to Rossi, scientists that took part in the study were Nava Sarver of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, a part of the National Institutes of Health; Pairoj S. Chang of Loma Linda University, and four others from the City of Hope Medical Center. The journal Science is published by the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

DOC.HEAD: Washington's Johnson Crowd Furious Over `This Loathsome Book'
DOC.TEXT: The people who worked for Lyndon Johnson in this town are buzzing _ and often furious _ about a new biography of their old boss that says he stole his election to the Senate in 1948. ``Why, why, why would a man want to spend this much of his life writing about a fellow that he can't stand and whose reputation he is so passionately bent on destroying?'' demands an injured Jack Valenti, an aide in Johnson's White House. ``I think it is a dishonest biography,'' says Bob Hardesty, who used to write Johnson's speeches and helped him write his memoirs. ``I don't think it pretends to be fair. I think it is the work of a man with a burning, unnatural hatred for his subject. It only presents a dark, evil, negative side of Lyndon Johnson.'' The book, ``Means of Ascent,'' by Robert Caro pictures a youthful Johnson who is willing to do almost anything to appease an all-consuming political appetite. It is the second of Caro's projected four-volume LBJ biography. Caro already has devoted 14 years to the task. The first volume met with equal hostility from some Johnson fans. One book critic said it demonstrated ``enraged animus against Lyndon Johnson.'' The new volume is just out, but excerpts ran in the New Yorker magazine and they were the talk of Washington's Texas community. Ex-Texas newspaperman Bob Mann, now teaching at Emory & Henry College in southwestern Virginia, says this week's mail brought three sets of Xeroxed copies of the excerpts from friends who were afraid he might miss them. Caro, in the book's introduction, acknowledges that he paints a portrait of a despicable person. While ``bright and dark'' threads run through most of Johnson's life, Caro writes, no bright thread is visible in a period when Johnson ``was all but totally consumed by his need for power and by his efforts to obtain it.'' The book covers the years from Johnson's 1941 defeat for a Senate seat in a rigged election to his 1948 victory _ by 87 votes _ in a 1948 Democratic runoff over an enormously popular former governor, Coke Stevenson. The theft by Johnson of that primary election has been fixed in Texas lore for years, but Caro provides new evidence. The book also says Johnson pulled strings in Washington to enhance the power and value of a Texas radio station that made him a millionaire. And it says Johnson made shamelessly political capital from his war career _ which amounted to flying under enemy fire for only a few minutes, then accepting a Silver Star from Gen. Douglas MacArthur. ``He didn't seize the Silver Star,'' says Horace Busby, a Johnson associate for 20 years. ``MacArthur, who was a political general, gave it to him to curry favor with Franklin Roosevelt, who liked Johnson. What was Johnson to do _ throw it back?'' As for LBJ's stolen election, Busby says: ``Johnson went before a statewide electorate seven times after that and it was never a factor.'' Caro's critics say his legwork is meticulous and his writing thrilling, but his viewpoint warped. They say he finds little good _ or balanced _ to say about Johnson and nothing bad in Stevenson's record, despite his touch of racism. History buff Jeff Patterson, an aide to Rep. Mike Andrews, D-Texas, says Stevenson comes across as ``Saint Coke.'' ``Caro sets out to make Johnson look like a real jerk,'' says Patterson. ``Give me warts-and-all, but don't try to overdo it.'' Political reporter David Broder, reviewing the book in The Washington Post, said Caro's Johnson is ``a complete scoundrel'' and ``a lying, cunning, utterly unprincipled operator.'' Caro did not respond to messages asking for a reply. ``We don't want to respond to a single review,'' said Paul Bogaards, publicist for Alfred A. Knopf, which has printed 250,000 copies of the book. Former Johnson aide Lloyd Hackler says Caro ``puts more emphasis on the negatives _ and God knows Johnson had those _ than on the positives,'' but adds: ``Its probably the best job of research that anybody has ever done on Johnson.'' Valenti calls Caro's work ``this loathsome book'' _ but admits he read every word of the serialization and now will proceed to read the book whole. Valenti mourns the impact the book is likely to have on Johnson's place in history. ``Caro writes engagingly and that torments me,'' he says. ``This may become the definitive Johnson biography.'' But Hardesty says he has no such worries: ``Over a period of time, when the historians have their say, he'll come out a full-bodied figure, flawed but an attractive man who had a great impact on the country.''

DOC.HEAD: Imprisoned Former Official Seen as Key HUD Witness
DOC.TEXT: Lawmakers say an imprisoned former official ``will open new areas'' in the probe of federal housing scandals with testimony about grants and contracts under ex-HUD Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. Congressional investigators are seeking testimony that Pierce made politically tainted contract awards while he headed the Department of Housing and Urban Development during the Reagan administration, sources said Thursday. The chairman of the House Government Operations housing subcommittee, Rep. Tom Lantos, said his panel will vote next week to grant immunity to Dubois Gilliam. Gilliam, who was a deputy assistant secretary of HUD under Pierce, is serving an 18-month sentence at the federal prison in Lompoc, Calif., for a conviction in a HUD-related case. Lantos, D-Calif., called Gilliam ``a key player'' in awarding HUD grants under several programs, including the secretary's discretionary fund, and said he will provide ``critical'' new information. ``Mr. Gilliam's testimony will open new areas not dealt with previously by the subcommittee,'' Lantos said. Lantos said the panel's Republican members would vote with the majority Democrats next Tuesday to ask a federal court to grant ``use immunity'' in exchange for Gilliam's testimony. The immunity would bar prosecution of Gilliam based on his testimony to the subcommittee or information developed from that testimony. Gilliam's testimony is planned for late April. Lantos said Arlin Adams, the court-appointed independent counsel who is investigating Pierce and other former HUD officials, told him that immunity for Gilliam would not conflict with his investigation. He said Adams' probe is limited to activities involving HUD's moderate rehabilitation program that provided renovation subsidies for low-income rental housing, and his panel was looking into other areas. Pierce has refused to testify before Lantos' subcommittee since making one voluntary appearance last spring. Several former Pierce aides also refused to testify, citing their Fifth Amendment rights against self-incrimination. Among them was Deborah Dean, Pierce's former top aide. Pierce has repeatedly denied any wrongdoing and accuses the subcommittee of targeting him despite evidence to support his position. Pierce attorney Paul L. Perito said he questioned whether Gilliam would provide truthful testimony or merely seek to curry support for a reduced sentence. Perito also said it could interfere with the independent counsel's review. Lantos said Gilliam was receiving no inducement, such as a reduction in sentence, to testify. He said Gilliam has been cooperating with the subcommittee's staff and information he has provided so far ``appears to be both accurate and reliable.'' Gilliam was a deputy assistant secretary in HUD's community planning and development office. Subcommittee staff investigators have visited him at the California prison, and sources who spoke on condition of anonymity said he could provide testimony about Pierce's role in contract awards. Former HUD officials described Gilliam as a trusted Pierce aide, and agency documents show that many funding requests were routed through him. Gilliam was quoted by The New York Times as saying Pierce ordered him to give a $300,000 grant to a longtime Pierce friend, Samuel Singletary, who had managed the secretary's unsuccessful campaigns for a New York judgeship. Pierce's order overruled HUD officials who had recommended rejection of the proposal, Gilliam said. Gilliam, as part of a plea agreement, pleaded guilty to accepting cash gifts from a HUD contractor and conspiring to use a HUD grant for personal gain.

DOC.HEAD: Pro-Investment Policy Said Raising Deficit, Tax Burden
DOC.TEXT: A tax policy aimed at encouraging investment by rich individuals and corporations is raising the federal deficit and boosting the tax burden on lower-income Americans, says a study financed by labor and endorsed by Democratic leaders. If pre-1978 fairness were restored to the income tax, nine of every 10 Americans would pay less and the government would collect an additional $67.5 billion a year, Citizens for Tax Justice reported Thursday. That would be enough to wipe out the budget deficit in two years or less. ``The real after-tax income of the richest 1 percent of the population (averaging $400,000 a year) jumped by a staggering 110 percent'' since 1977, said the a labor-financed Washington research organization. During the same period, the after-tax earnings of a $34,000-a-year family grew by 1 percent. ``We have had a massive ripoff ... and the middle class is stuck with the bill,'' Rep. David Obey, D-Wis., said in endorsing the findings. ``The arrows of fairness are pointed in the wrong direction,'' said House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo. Nevertheless, Gephardt told reporters, Democratic leaders are not ready to endorse the study's call for tax increases on profitable corporations and high-income individuals. He said the party's leadership hopes to complete work soon on a tax policy, including whether Social Security taxes should be cut. The report was the latest round in a partisan debate over whether Americans are better off than they were before Presidents Reagan and Bush took office. A recent Congressional Budget Office report concluded that since 1980, the 20 percent of Americans with the lowest incomes have seen their federal tax burden rise while the wealthiest 20 percent have seen a drop in taxes. The administration's Office of Management and Budget said the poorest 20 percent are paying the same share of the federal tax burden that they paid in 1980 while the richest, as a group, are paying a larger portion. The Citizens for Tax Justice analysis traced tax changes back to 1978, during the Carter administration. Congress approved a tax bill that year that raised exemptions and standard deductions for all Americans but also cut the tax on capital gains, which benefited chiefly those with high incomes. The new report blamed two factors for the tax shift away from the rich: Reagan's 1981 tax reduction, which cut the top individual tax rate from 70 percent to 50 percent and boosted incentives for saving and investment; and a steadily increasing Social Security tax. The 1978 and 1981 tax cuts are worth $93.1 billion to the richest 10 percent of Americans this year, while the remaining 90 percent are $25.6 billion worse off, the report said. As a result, the federal treasury has $67.5 billion less than it otherwise might have had. Robert McIntyre, director of Citizens for Tax Justice, told a news conference that as a result of those tax cuts: _``The top 1 percent of the population (with average pre-tax incomes of $549,000 each) now enjoys an average tax cut of $82,196 a year compared to the pre-1978 federal tax system adjusted for inflation _ a 36 percent drop. The cost in 1990 of the tax cut for these extremely wealthy people is a staggering $84.4 billion. _``In contrast, 90 percent of American families now pay considerably more in federal taxes than they would under the pre-1978 system adjusted for inflation. The typical middle-income family, earning $31,000, pays $409, or 7 percent, more in taxes. The poorest fifth of all families pays 21 percent more.'' The report credited the 1986 tax overhaul with partially correcting what Citizens for Tax Justice views as inequities in the federal system. However, McIntyre said, that law credited a new inequity by taxing some income of the richest people at a rate lower than applies to many earning less. The report called for raising the maximum rates on top-income individuals and corporations to 38 percent, which would bring in $30 billion more a year. Those individuals now pay a maximum rate of 28 percent; corporations pay up to 34 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Felix Bloch Seeks Reinstatement to Foreign Service
DOC.TEXT: Career diplomat Felix Bloch, suspected of spying for the Soviet Union but never charged, is appealing his dismissal from the U.S. Foreign Service. Bloch has asked for a review of his case before a three-member panel of Foreign Service officers to rebut the accusation he is a security risk. A date for the private hearing will be set later. The State Department announced on Feb. 8 that Bloch had been suspended, that his annual salary of $80,700 was being withheld and that steps were being taken to fire him. The action was taken under provisions of a law permitting the suspension or dismissal of a federal employee ``in the interest of national security.'' The review panel could vote to reinstate the 54-year-old diplomat, but State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said Thursday: ``If he is not reinstated, his employment will be terminated.'' At the hearing, Bloch will have the right to answer charges, give explanations, examine and cross-examine witnesses and present documentary evidence. The panel's recommendation will be presented to Secretary of State James A. Baker III, whose determination will be final, the department said. Bloch has been under investigation since he was placed on paid leave last June 22. Although he has not been charged with any crime, sources have said the government suspects he was recruited by the Soviet Union during the early 1970s. From 1983 to 1987, Bloch was deputy chief of mission at the U.S. Embassy in Vienna. His last job was as director of the State Department's office of regional economic policy for Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Seven Industrial Countries' Finance Ministers to Meet
DOC.TEXT: Top finance officials from the world's seven largest industrial countries will discuss volatile currency markets at a special meeting next month, but private economists question how successful the session will be. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady confirmed on Thursday that finance ministers and central bank presidents from the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada would gather in Paris on April 7. While Brady insisted there was ``no special urgency'' propelling the talks, they are coming at a time when the U.S. dollar has been rising in value against other currencies, in particular the West German mark and the Japanese yen. A higher dollar threatens to enlarge an already-huge U.S. trade deficit by making foreign products cheaper for Americans while raising the cost of U.S. goods overseas. ``The dollar's strength is of great concern to the administration,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist of the Boston Co. ``It constitutes a recession threat because it is a further risk to an already-beleaguered industrial side of the U.S. economy.'' While last year's trade deficit of $108.6 billion was 29 percent below the all-time worst deficit of $152.1 billion in 1987, progress in boosting U.S. exports has slowed in recent months because of the dollar's increases. Brady, testifying to a House Appropriations subcommittee Thursday, said the administration hoped further gains could be made this year in reducing the trade deficit. However, he conceded that ``progress isn't as fast as I would like it to be.'' The dollar's advance has occurred despite coordinated intervention by the United States and other governments to sell dollars on foreign exchange markets and buy other currencies. Some analysts suggested that since government intervention has proved largely unsuccessful, the officials of the so-called G-7 countries might discuss making coordinated moves to change interest rates. Higher interest rates in Japan and West Germany would tend to bolster their currencies, while lower interest rates in the United States would make dollar-denominated investments less attractive. But such action would need the approval of Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan, who has been resisting administration pressure to lower interest rates because of concern about inflation. Greenspan also will attend the Paris G-7 meeting. Economists also questioned the likelihood of some bold initiative to lower the dollar's value, especially in light of Brady's general caution in interfering in private market operations. ``The G-7 process is dead in the water,'' said C. Fred Bergsten, head of the Institute for International Economics. ``With exchange rates moving in the wrong direction, it cries out for more effective international coordination.'' Brady, who visited European capitals last week, led the effort to schedule the special meeting. He sees it as an opportunity to advance economic coordination among U.S. allies, said an administration official who spoke on condition of anonymity. French Economics Minister Pierre Beregovoy told reporters in Paris that he had stressed to Brady the need for greater cooperation, especially in light of the economic problems that might arise with the reunification of East and West Germany. Some private economists have expressed concern that the reunification could prove to be inflationary because of the proposal to exchange West Germany marks for East German marks on a one-to-one ratio. However, Norbert Walker, chief economist for Deutsche Bank, the largest bank in West Germany, told reporters in Washington that he believed reunification could be accomplished without a surge in inflation or a big jump in West German interest rates. Walker said increased consumer demand would not trigger higher inflation because much of the demand would be met by foreign goods, helping to lower West Germany's large trade surpluses, while sluggish economic growth in Europe would help hold down interest rate pressures. Beregovoy said the G-7 officials were scheduled to be in Paris in early April anyway to wrap up details for a new Bank for European Reconstruction and Development being created to support emerging democracies. The meeting will occur just one month before a scheduled May 7 session in Washington to coincide with the spring meeting of the International Monetary Fund.

DOC.HEAD: Two Heart Attack Drugs Work Equally Well Despite Cost Difference, Study Says
DOC.TEXT: A study of more than 20,000 heart attack patients has found that one drug saved lives as well as another that costs about 10 times as much. But officials at Genentech Inc., maker of the more expensive tissue plasminogen activator, or TPA, said Thursday that the treatment procedure in the study hampered that drug's effectiveness. Genentech is consulting U.S. cardiologists about the need for another study that follows procedures generally used in the United States, said G. Kirk Raab, the company's president and chief executive officer. The research released Thursday at a medical conference in Florence, Italy, was conducted in Italy and elsewhere in Europe. It found that a patient's risk of dying before leaving the hospital was the same whether he was treated TPA or with streptokinase, made by Hoechst AG of Germany. TPA is widely used in the United States; streptokinase is more popular in Europe. An editorial in the New England Journal of Medicine last year said one treatment with streptokinase costs $78 at a San Francisco hospital, while TPA costs $2,268. A separate report has cited a 10-fold difference. The Italian researchers found an overall death rate of 8.9 percent after treatment with TPA and an 8.5 percent rate after treatment with streptokinase. Statistically, those rates are the same. TPA and streptokinase are designed to destroy blood clots that have caused heart attacks by blocking a crucial blood vessel. The newly announced study ``bears out what a number of cardiologists have been really ... saying for the last four or five years, that there has been absolutely no scientific evidence that TPA was superior to streptokinase,'' said an American investigator familiar with the results, William O'Neill of William Beaumont Hospital in Royal Oak, Mich. ``Streptokinase would now appear to be the drug of choice based on factors of cost,'' said Dr. Claude J. Lenfant, director of the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute in Bethesda, Md. But, he said, the price of TPA might fall as technological improvements reduce production costs. The Italian study involved 20,749 patients with acute heart attack from 13 nations. They were randomly assigned to receive either streptokinase or TPA. Heparin, which keeps blood vessels open after other drugs dissolve the clot, was tested in combination with the two drugs. The death rate for the TPA-heparin combination was 9.2 percent, and for the streptokinase-heparin combination, 7.9 percent. But the patients in the study who got heparin received it much later in the course of therapy and through injections under the skin rather than intravenously, said David Stump, Genentech's director for clinical research, in a telephone interview from Florence. Stump said all major U.S. trials with TPA used intravenous heparin ``administered within four hours'' and said that was the treatment favored by nearly all U.S. cardiologists. ``The situation is confusing,'' said Raab. ``Since the results are inconclusive in regard to U.S. medical practice, the need for a new trial using the standard U.S. heparin regimen is indicated.'' TPA holds about two-thirds of the market for the drugs in the United States while streptokinase has most of the other third. Another clot-dissolving drug, eminase, is marketed by SmithKline Beecham but was not included in the Italian study.
