Clot-destroying drugs are credited with helping to improve survival and shorten the length of hospital stays among the 1.5 million Americans who suffer a heart attack each year. About half die, making heart attack the leading cause of death in the United States. Genentech, which announced a merger agreement last month with Roche Holding Ltd., the Swiss pharmaceutical giant, reported sales of TPA increased 30 percent in 1989, to $197 million. The company's stock Thursday dropped $1.12{, to $26.12{ on the New York Stock Exchange. Raab said he didn't know how the study would ultimately affect sales.

DOC.HEAD: Estimated 2 Million Now Tested in Publicly Funded AIDS Programs
With PM-Genetic Ambush, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Federal AIDS testing experts are encouraged that the vast majority of the 2 million people who have been tested for the AIDS virus aren't infected _ even among high-risk groups. From 1985 to 1989, 2.5 million tests for HIV, the virus that causes acquired immune deficiency syndrome, were performed by 63 publicly funded prevention programs across the country, the national Centers for Disease Control said Thursday. Of the tests given, 149,639, or 6 percent, were positive, the CDC said. Out of more than 1 million test subjects in the last two years whose AIDS risk groups were known, two groups accounted for more than 70 percent, the CDC said. Heterosexuals at risk, including those with high-risk partners or multiple sex partners, made up 44 percent, and 29 percent were heterosexuals who reported no AIDS risk factors, but were tested anyway. Fourteen percent were homosexual or bisexual men _ who make up the largest group of AIDS victims _ and 9 percent were heterosexual intravenous drug abusers, the second-leading AIDS risk group. Positive-test rates were highest for homosexual men who abused injectable drugs; 17 percent of such test subjects were told they were infected. The homosexual or bisexual men tested were infected at a rate of 16.5 percent. ``Still, a very high proportion (of tested homosexuals and drug abusers) are not infected,'' said Dr. Stephen Bowen, deputy director at the CDC's Center for Prevention Services. ``We still have an opportunity to protect them.'' The CDC said that 12 percent to 30 percent of AIDS tests are apparently repeat tests, leaving an estimated 2 million people tested, the CDC said. In its report, the CDC said: ``Many of the estimated 1 million HIV-infected persons in the United States remain unaware of their infection. Of persons who are aware ... a substantial proportion had their infection identified in publicly funded counseling and testing programs.'' Demand for the publicly funded tests has increased from about 80,000 in 1985 to a projected 1 million when 1989 tests are totaled, Bowen said. Health officials ``don't have a real good handle'' on the number of people who have been tested at private physicians' offices not participating in the publicly funded AIDS programs, Bowen said. Such tests are not necessarily reported to health officials. More than 120,000 AIDS cases have been reported in the United States, with more than 72,000 deaths.

DOC.HEAD: Senators to Push U.S. Aid for Family Planning
DOC.TEXT: Backers of U.S. support for a United Nations family-planning agency are seeking to reverse President Bush's decision to exclude the organization from this year's foreign aid bill. Four senators _ two Democrats and two Republicans _ told Bush in a letter Thursday that they hope for a compromise. Failing that, they said they plan to force the issue, which led to a veto of last year's foreign aid bill. Both the House and Senate voted last year to give $15 million to the United Nations Population Fund, known as UNFPA, to help carry out its family planning activities in more than 140 countries around the world. But the provision ultimately was dropped from the foreign aid bill after Bush vetoed the measure. The White House had come under heavy pressure from anti-abortion forces who complained that the agency operates programs in China, which uses forced abortions and sterilizations to carry out its one-child-per-family policy. In their letter, Sens. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt.; Barbara Mikulski, D-Md.; Nancy Kassebaum, R-Kan.; and Mark Hatfield, R-Ore., argued that Third World population growth poses ``a grave threat to our own future security'' because of the increasing pressures it places on the environment and on the political stability of poor countries. Supporters of aid to UNFPA are optimistic they can prevail this time around, in part because the population agency is willing to provide extraordinary safeguards to make sure the money is not used in China and in part because of growing GOP fear of highlighting the abortion issue. The senators told Bush that UNFPA has agreed to permit the United States to earmark its population aid for specific countries whose family planning practices are in line with U.S. values, and will allow audits to make sure the money isn't freeing other funds for use in China. The agency has received no U.S. aid since President Reagan halted it more than five years ago, and a congressional source said it is anxious to regain American participation ``for the symbolism'' as much as for the money. UNFPA expects that if the United States resumes participation, its contributions would grow in later years, said the source, who demanded anonymity. ``With the population of the developing countries projected to grow by over 900 million during the 1990s ... we cannot afford to remain outside the UNFPA,'' the senators wrote. ``Renewed confrontation serves no one's interest,'' they said, asking the administration to open discussions with Capitol Hill aimed at finding a compromise. A group of moderate House and Senate Republicans sent a similar letter last month to Secretary of State James A. Baker III calling for renewal of U.S. aid to UNFPA and chastising opponents for miscasting the argument as an abortion issue. Bush's veto last year ``sent the wrong signal to the American public and the international community regarding the Republican Party's support for international family planning services,'' they wrote. ``This is a women's issue, a family issue, an environmental issue and an international security issue,'' said the GOP group, which included two women House members running for the Senate this year _ Reps. Lynn Martin of Illinois and Claudine Schneider of Rhode Island. ``It remains an issue of great importance to the Republican Party.''

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Close Higher in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 33,993.12, up 302.23 points or 0.9 percent, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Forbes, Capitalist Ghoul, Makes Gift from the Grave
DOC.TEXT: The late Malcolm Forbes left orders to give all Forbes Inc. employees an extra week's pay, a break on personal loans and some free advice on what to do with the money: ``enjoy it!'' Steve Forbes, Forbes' son and successor as editor in chief of Forbes magazine and chief executive officer of the corporation, told staffers Thursday that ``in accordance with my father's wishes'' the company was giving each of them an extra week's pay and forgiving all debts up to $10,000. ``As Pop put it, `Like a lottery, it's pure chance as to who benefits,''' his son wrote in a letter to employees, referring to the loan amnesty. ``As for the extra pay,'' Forbes added, ``his advice should be no surprise: enjoy it!'' Don Garson, a magazine spokesman, said the bequest surprised staffers at the Forbes Building on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan. ``I didn't find out about it until you called me, and I'm the P.R. man here,'' he said in a telephone interview. ``But it was something he (Malcolm) had made clear to the kids.'' Garson said the debt amnesty was particularly generous because Forbes employees of more than a year's experience are able to borrow money from the company at relatively low interest rates. He said that many of the magazine's 750 employees had taken such loans. Asked about those thrifty souls who had not, Garson laughed and said: ``I'm sure many of us here are saying, `Damn it, why didn't I borrow something?''' Garson said he was told the Forbes family would have no comment on Malcolm Forbes' bequest. ``The letter speaks for itself,'' he said. He said the gift was in character for Forbes, who ``always had the attitude that the employees were giving to him, rather than the other way around.'' Forbes was 70 when he died Feb. 24 of a heart attack at his estate in New Jersey. Estimates of his wealth ranged into the hundreds of millions of dollars. In London, a British magazine Thursday published what it touted as Forbes' last interview, in which he spoke of his good health. ``I don't think this life is for hibernating and getting ready for the next one. I think you are given it for a purpose and that is to live it. Live while you are alive!'' Forbes was quoted as saying in Hello! magazine. Forbes spoke enthusiastically about his next adventure to Brazil in a hot air balloon during the interview at his South London home on Feb. 23, and about his love of motorcycles. ``I am very lucky to have the health to do all this because that you can't buy,'' he was quoted as saying. ``I would just like to stay around a while and keep doing more of the things I am doing!'' The magazine included seven color photographs of Forbes in his London house and earlier pictures from Forbes' 70th birthday bash in August in Morocco.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Budget Chairman Embraces Pentagon Budget Cuts
DOC.TEXT: Slicing $15 billion out of next year's defense budget would leave a strong U.S. military capable of confronting the rapidly dwindling Soviet threat, the chairman of the Senate Budget Committee says. Sen. James Sasser, D-Tenn., called for the reductions Thursday as part of a plan to pare Pentagon spending by $80 billion annually within five years. It was the latest Democratic assault on President Bush's proposal to spend $303 billion for defense in fiscal 1991, $7 billion more than this year. With easing East-West tensions, military spending _ about one-quarter of Bush's proposed $1.24 trillion budget _ has become a focus of debate in Congress this year. Most Democrats, and some Republicans, want to cut deeper into Pentagon spending and use the money to help reduce the deficit, fortify social programs or reduce taxes. Sasser embraced a plan that would cut defense spending next year to $291 billion, $5 billion below this year's level. The chairman's proposal would be $15 billion below the figure needed to keep pace with inflation, which in the unusual world of budget arithmetic translates to a $15 billion cut. Under the proposal, the current active-duty roster of 2.1 military men and women would ultimately be reduced to 1.5 million. Future purchases of Trident submarines, B-2 stealth bombers, rail-carried MX missiles and several other systems would be eliminated. But he said the reductions would still leave 529 warships, 34 fighter wings, 15 active Army divisions and 10 reserve divisions. ``That's an extremely large measure of security for a world where, as CIA Director (William) Webster has declared, the major hostile forces have `irreversibly changed,''' Sasser said. Sasser's embrace of the cuts ran into objections from the budget committee's ranking Republican, Sen. Pete Domenici of New Mexico. Domenici said there is too much uncertainty over the Soviet Union's future to begin making deep defense cuts. ``I don't know what that means in reference to the 11,000 nuclear warheads aimed at the United States'' by the Soviet Union, Domenici said. In another clue to the direction lawmakers are heading, a senior member of the Senate Armed Services Committee said that panel would also recommend lowered spending levels for the Pentagon. Sen. J. James Exon, D-Neb., told reporters that he believed his committee would recommend defense budget authority in the $291 billion to $293 billion range, compared with the $306.9 billion proposed by Bush. Budget authority is new spending, some of which occurs over several years. ``It's going to be a slowing down, a stretching out, possibly a significant reduction in some areas,'' Exon said. Across the Capitol, Democrats on the House Budget Committee completed the second of two consecutive days of closed-door meetings on the defense budget. Rep. John Murtha, D-Pa., chairman of the House Appropriations defense subcommittee told the legislators Thursday that he preferred keeping next year's military spending just below $300 billion, according to an official who attended the session. That would be nearly $4 billion less than Bush's figure. Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, met with the group on Wednesday but offered no spending recommendation, said the source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Aspin will meet with the lawmakers next Tuesday and present them with a list of possible cuts.

DOC.HEAD: Dingell Seeing End to Pentagon Surplus Accounts
DOC.TEXT: A House committee chairman is calling for legislation to put an end to Pentagon ``slush funds'' that he said totaled $43 billion last year. Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., accused the Defense Department on Thursday of laundering money through the Treasury and hiding billions of dollars in little-known surplus accunts. Dingell, chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee and its investigations subcommittee, also contended that Pentagon officials have misled Congress about the funds. ``I suggest that we ... come up with an amendment to this year's appropriations bill to terminate both of these accounts to prevent the unauthorized squandering of this enormous stash of taxpayers' money,'' he said in a letter to Rep. Leon Panetta, D-Calif., chairman of the House Budget Committee. Money appropriated by Congress must be obligated or spent during a specific time period, Dingell noted. If not, the authority to spends the funds lapses and the money is returned to the Treasury. But obligated funds that are not spent and lapse ``are then laundered through the U.S. Treasury and come back to the military services as no-year `M' accounts,'' Dingell wrote. Unobligated funds that lapse also return to the military services as ``no-year funds in another slush fund _ merged surplus accounts,'' he said. ``With the existence of these slush funds, the Congress could virtually kill a weapons program and find out years later that it was still being funded from these accounts,'' the congressman said. Dingell recently released a General Accounting Office report that said the Air Force's accounting system understated by tens of billions of dollars the cost of major weapons systems. While his investigations subcommittee was examining the Pentagon's financial management systems, Dingell said, ``we recently discovered an astonishing set of little-known _ semi-secret _ slush funds.'' A Defense Department source, who requested anonymity, disputed Dingell's assessment, saying the funds are recognized accounts, not slush funds. ``These are not funds sitting idly there and the Defense Department is using at their whim,'' the source said. Susan Hansen, a Pentagon spokeswoman, said the department would have no official comment on Dingell's assertions. Dingell said his subcommittee reviewed a series of congressional hearings last year in which lawmakers expressed shock over the existence of the accounts. In one instance, the Air Force provided a lower number for the so-called ``M'' account to Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio. ``When Sen. Glenn asked Gen. Ron Yates, the Air Force witness, about the size of the Air Force `M' account, he was misled by Gen. Yates who claimed there was only $1.7 billion in the account, not $4.6 billion,'' Dingell said. ``If the Sen. Glenn was shocked by the `M' account, he would have been bowled over if Gen. Yates had told him about the additional $6.6 billion `merged surplus account,''' the congressman said.

DOC.HEAD: Assad Says Changes In Soviet Bloc Benefiting Israel, Promises Holy War
DOC.TEXT: President Hafez Assad called for an indefinite holy war with Israel and bitterly decried the changes sweeping Eastern Europe as a boon to the Jewish state. The Syrian leader also hinted he would make some changes in his own tough brand of socialist rule. In a youth rally Thursday marking his Baath Party's 27th anniversary in power, Assad denounced the recent wave of Soviet Jewish emigration to Israel in his first public comment on the matter, saying migrating Jews would force Palestinians from their homeland. ``Let us now perceive that Israel was the first beneficiary, among all nations of the world, of the international changes that have taken place,'' Assad told about 6,500 people in a basketball arena. The rally appeared to be a cross between an American high school pep rally and a Soviet May Day parade. A brass band pounded out patriotic songs _ along with the tune ``Rock Around the Clock'' _ and the youthful spectators chanted and cheered in unison as one bank of the crowd used silk sheets to form massive portraits of Assad or to spell out patriotic slogans. The crowd interrupted the president 61 times with applause or chanting during his 95-minute speech. Assad said the jihad, or holy war against Israel ``should be as long as time.'' ``We are just at the beginning of this long time,'' he said. ``It is not we who have to ask `until when.' Rather, the enemy is the one who should ask this question.'' Assad complained that in socialist countries once resolutely opposed to Israel, ``Zionists are now active everywhere.'' Assad said pro-Israeli delegations now often visit socialist countries, an apparent reference to Israeli delegations that have won recognition for their country from some Eastern European states. Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia re-established relations with Israel in the past six months. All the Eastern European countries except for Romania broke ties over the 1967 Arab-Israeli War. He alleged that Zionists in those countries went in ``hot pursuit'' of their foes in a campaign ranging from ``attacking the ideas of their opponents'' to ``attack and assassination in the streets.'' Assad said Israel still seeks a ``greater Israel from the Nile to the Euphrates,'' referring to a radical version of Zionism that foresaw Jewish rule from Egypt to Iraq. He denounced an expected mass migration of Soviet Jews to Israel due to greater freedom in the Soviet Union He equated this freedom with aggression, calling it ``the freedom of occupying other people's territory and expelling them from their land.'' Assad did not hold the Soviet Union, a long-time Syrian ally, responsible for the Jewish exodus, however, and he repeated his assertion that ``the relationship between Syria and the Soviet Union is now as firm as ever.'' The Soviet Union has given Syria massive economic and military aid, including combat jets, tanks and missiles. Syria reportedly owes the Soviets $15 billion for weapons. Assad mourned the Arabs' inability to forge a united front. ``The danger threatens all, and the need for solidarity and unity is everybody's need,'' he said. Assad has patched up a longstanding rift with Egypt, but other Arab states, especially Egypt and Jordan, have tried in vain to ease Syrian rivalries with Iraq and the mainstream of the Palestine Liberation Organization. While he decried the changes in Eastern Europe, Assad hinted he would make some changes in his own tough brand of socialist rule. He suggested a government study on limiting use of emergency laws that have been in force for decades, and spoke of broadening parties and organizations in the National Front dominated by the ruling Baath Party. But Assad stressed that his version of ``organized freedom'' was based on community rather than just individual rights. ``Freedom and its organization go side by side,'' he said. ``If separated, anarchy and despotism prevail.''

DOC.HEAD: Defense Contractor Says Pentagon Spreading False Allegations
DOC.TEXT: The president of an Ohio company accused the Defense Department of spreading false allegations about its work on a critical part for missiles without informing the manufacturer of the charges. Documents released Thursday said the Pentagon is investigating Piqua Engineering Inc., of Piqua, Ohio, following charges that safety and arming devices produced by the company failed almost half of its tests for leaking. The devices are used on several missiles, including the Sidewinder, Sparrow, Standard and Patriot. ``It is believed that any ... of the issues can cause premature (or prevention of) detonation of the devices that could result in the failure of missiles or other weaponry containing the Piqua devices,'' said a defense contract administrative message sent to Army and Navy commands in several states. But John Scarbrough Sr., president of Piqua, defended his company's product and said the Pentagon failed to contact him about the problems. ``The Defense Criminal Investigative Service never talked to us, has never written us a letter at any time,'' Scarbrough said in a telephone interview. ``They are giving out untrue allegations without talking to us.'' Scarbrough said his 40-year-old company has been manufacturing safety and arming devices for at least 20 years and has never had a single complaint. In this instance, he believes six disgruntled employees are using the government system against the company. ``As far as I'm concerned the allegations are all wrong,'' Scarbrough said. ``Everyone wants to blow the whistle but no one wants to check. We could have told the Defense Department if they asked us.'' Pentagon spokeswoman Susan Hansen said the department would neither confirm nor deny an ongoing investigation. In a Jan. 30 memorandum, the Pentagon's Inspector General office warned that ``the potential may exist for failure of the safety and arming devices manufactured by Piqua.'' This could ``subsequently impact on the integrity of the weapons systems containing these devices,'' wrote William G. Dupree, the deputy assistant inspector general for investigations. The documents were obtained by the Project on Government Procurement and released by the independent group to The Associated Press and other news organizations. Piqua employees allegedly have been told not to reject devices even if they fail leak tests. Instead, workers are to repair the devices using epoxy resin to seal the leaks. Military specifications call for the devices to pass the leak tests to ensure that they are sealed and to prevent contamination and corrosion. ``Piqua is believed to have internally experienced as high as a 50 percent failure rate of safety and arming devices being leak tested,'' said the inspector general's document. ``The areas most commonly encountering leakage problems are either around the window of the device or in the area of the electrical connector.'' Scarbrough said that after initial checks, the failure rate was less than 1 percent and ``when they leave here they don't leak at all.'' Information on the tests have been substantiated by three Defense Department inspectors at the Ohio plant, he said. The inspector general's memo also said questions have been raised about holes in the device, to which detonators and detonator sleeves are attached. ``It is believed the holes cannot correctly accept the detonators and sleeves and that Piqua utilizes unauthorized repair and rework procedures to correct the problem,'' the document said. The memo said there had been allegations that employees were told to use hand tools to enlarge holes that were too small and resorted to unapproved oversized detonators on holes that were too large. In response to that allegation, Scarbrough said the Navy ``knew all about the bored holes.'' In addition, inspectors at Piqua allegedly approved electrical wires on the devices that had failed military specifications on solderability tests. Scarbrough said the wiring the company received was tested and rejected if defective and replaced by the vendor. Defense Department inspectors at his plant also examined the wiring, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Family Seeks to Put the President's Policy to the Test
DOC.TEXT: With a stroke of his pen last fall, President Bush invited people fleeing countries where population control is accomplished by forced abortions and sterilizations to seek asylum in the United States. But a Chinese family that is apparently the first to accept that invitation is beginning to wonder whether it was made sincerely. The order enabled Li Jin Lin and his family, who previously had been separated and threatened with jail, the right to live and work temporarily in the United States. Their application to live here permanently, however, is bound in red tape. Government officials refuse to say what's holding the case up, but the family's lawyer, Kathleen Rimar, said she is beginning to doubt Bush's commitment to protecting Chinese refugees. ``These four Chinese people came here right at the worst time,'' Rimar said. ``They seem to be the testing case for whether this is going to work. So far, I think the executive order isn't doing very well.'' Bush's directive allows foreign nationals who are fleeing forced abortion or sterilization policies to apply for political asylum in the United States. The directive, though not specifically for Chinese, was part of a Nov. 30 order allowing many Chinese citizens to remain in the United States indefinitely after the June massacre of pro-democracy demonstrators in Beijing. Bush made the order while vetoing stiff sanctions against China. Li, a 37-year-old machinist, and his 34-year-old wife, Wang Sai Zhen, fled the city of Fuzhou after Ms. Wang became pregnant with the couple's second child. She had undergone several abortions and was told another would endanger her life. The couple and their 19-year-old nephew, Chun Kong Cheung, made their way to Canada and paid smugglers about $1,500 each to get them into the United States, according to the government. Immigration officers caught them in Albany last March and sent Li back to Canada, allowing his wife to stay temporarily because of her advanced pregnancy. When Li and his nephew tried to cross the border again in October, they were thrown in jail. Li staged a hunger strike and said he would rather serve prison time in the United States than risk death or sterilization if he were forced to return to China. Anti-abortionists took up the cause. The Rev. Paul Schenck, a local minister involved in Operation Rescue, brought the case up with aides to Vice President Dan Quayle. Then came Bush's order protecting Chinese refugees. ``In a very direct sense, (the order) means lives saved,'' Schenck said. ``In a broader sense, it equates abortion as one of the tools of a repressive government. The same attitude that would bring the Chinese government to run over protesters with tanks is the same malevolence that would lead them to kill nascent children.'' Things have improved for the Lis. The Immigration and Naturalization Service allowed them to remain in the United States while their asylum application was decided. They were freed from jail, received work permits and settled in New York City. But the State Department has yet to rule on their asylum request, submitted last year, and the regional immigration court that must hear their case is in the midst of a reorganization _ meaning it may be months before the uncertainty is resolved, Rimar said. John J. Ingham, district director of the INS, said he was not free to comment on the case. Nat Kingsley, a State Department spokesman, said the department's policy is not to comment on individual asylum cases.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Stocks Rise in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: Share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange rose Friday despite the continuing appreciation of the dollar against the Japanese yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average ended the week at 33,993.12, up 302.23 points or 0.90 percent. It gained 328.55 points Thursday. The dollar closed at 151.15 yen, up 0.32 yen. It started trading Friday at 151.07 yen and ranged between 151.00 and 151.40 yen. Yields on benchmark No. 119 10-year government bonds were quoted at 7.170 percent at 3 p.m., down from 7.205 percent at the market's closing Thursday. Haruhito Ichimura, a broker with Nippon Kangyo Kakumaru Securities, said stocks drew strength from technical factors. Following Thursday's close of trading stock futures contracts for March delivery, market participants had expected dealers to sell actual stocks Friday and buy the new future contracts due in June. However, spot purchases predominated, Ichimura said, sending the Nikkei index up 600 points. But despite the morning rebound, the continuing depreciation of the yen was worrying many investors, he said. Dealers still expect the Bank of Japan will be forced to raise its discount rate to counteract the inflationary impact of the yen's decline. Higher rates tend to dampen demand for stocks. ``To some extent, investors have discounted a possible increase in the discount rate, but there is some uncertainty because no one knows whether the rise will 0.5 percent 1.0 percent,'' Ichimura said. The rate stands at 4.25 percent. ``The foreign exchange rate is the biggest problem. It will have a tremendous impact on stocks,'' he added. On the currency market, traders said the prevailing sentiment was to buy dollars, but intervention by the Bank of Japan prevented the yen from weakening too far. A trader with Daiwa Bank, speaking on condition of anonymity, said he did not know the size of the central bank's dollar-selling intervention, but added it was ``not so big.'' The Bank of Japan does not comment on its market activities. At a news conference Friday morning, Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto told reporters that the dollar's strength partly reflects the international situation. He also refused to confirm that a Group of Seven meeting to discuss exchange rates would take place next month, even though U.S. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady announced Thursday that a meeting would take place in Paris. The Daiwa trader said Hashimoto's remarks had little impact on the Tokyo market and said dealers didn't know whether to believe the Japanese minister or not. The Group of Seven countries are the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada.

DOC.NOTE: EDS: Tops with 6 grafs to update with Byrd amendment debate and adjournment. Picks up 4th graf pvs, The vote
DOC.TEXT: The Senate, in its first major vote on a compromise clean air bill, rejected a proposal to tighten controls on toxic air pollution Thursday night after Senate leaders said it threatened their agreement with the White House. The vote to kill the amendment was 65-33. Senate leaders later put off a vote on a proposal by Sen. Robert Byrd, D-W. Va., to help coal miners who lose their jobs because of tougher pollution controls. The $700 million ``safety net'' for miners was strongly opposed by the Bush administration. Sen. Bob Dole, R-Kan., said passage of the Byrd amendment would jeopardize the compromise agreement with the administration and could lead to no clean air bill being approved by the Senate. The senators adjourned early today and would resume consideration of the bill later in the day. The amendment on tougher controls on toxic chemicals from automobiles was one of a string of ``strengthening'' provisions expected to be brought to the floor by senators arguing the compromise legislation isn't strong enough. The vote was seen as an indicator on the strength of support for a compromise worked out by Senate leaders and the Bush administration to ease Senate approval for the first toughening of federal air pollution controls in 13 years. Sen. Frank Lautenberg, D-N.J., called his amendment necessary to protect citizens from cancer-causing chemicals, noting more than half of such chemical releases come from automobiles, trucks and buses. But the measure, opposed by the Bush administration because of its reported $1.5 billion price tag, was described by Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont., as a ``deal breaker'' _ meaning its passage would cause a compromise agreement with the Bush adminstration on clean air to fall apart. ``If this amendment passes the deal will be off, the deal will be busted and there very well could be no clean air act,'' said Baucus, a floor manager for the bill, shortly before the vote. Both Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, and Sen. Bob Dole, R-Kan., the minority leader, asked that the amendment be rejected. The Senate throughout the day wrestled with a stream of amendments, and more were expected. A number of senators unveiled proposals earlier Thursday for more stringent provisions, many aimed at automobiles. Lautenberg, whose amendment was among those unveiled, told reporters, ``We know the odds are heavy against us.'' The clean air measure represents the first tightening of federal air pollution control laws in 13 years, It calls for sweeping curbs on smog-causing pollution from automobiles and industrial plants and requires new cuts in acid rain pollutants from coal-fired electric power plants. A similar bill remains in committee in the House. In earlier floor action Thursday, the senators: _Approved by voice vote a requirement that the Environmental Protection Agency take into account carbon dioxide emissions, which contribute to global warming, when making urban transportation flow studies. _Approved 80-16 an amendment that requires that HCFCs, or hydrochlorofluorocarbons, be phased out by 2030. The HCFCs can sometimes subsitute for CFCs or chlorofluorocarbons, chemicals that are widely used in refrigeration and other areas but cause damage to the earth's protective ozone layer. HCFCs typically have only about 5 percent of the ozone-destroying potential of the most common CFCs. Critics of their use have cautioned that they still pose a threat to ozone depletion if relied on permanently. Meanwhile, an amendment requiring automakers to increase fuel efficiency by setting limits on carbon dioxide emissions was withdrawn by its sponsor, Sen. Richard Bryan, D-Nev. The measure had been vigorously opposed by the auto industry and the White House and deleted from an early draft of the bill. The Lautenberg amendment was the first of a series of ``strengthening'' amendments that are expected to be offered by senators who believe the Senate-White House compromise weakened key parts of the original Senate bill. The proposed amendments still to be considered would tighten controls on smog-causing pollution from automobiles and industrial sources in urban areas as well as expanding the use of alternative, clean-burning fuels. The amendments would expand the cities that would have to meet pollution standards through the use of cleaner fuels; require fleet operators to use clean burning fuels; impose a second round of auto tailpipe emission standards in the year 2003, and broaden the number of businesses that would have to comply with smog-related pollution controls so small polluters are included. Another amendment in the package would reinstate in the bill a requirement that the Environmental Protection Agency impose a pollution control program if a city fails to enact one. The EPA currently has the authority.

DOC.HEAD: Guerrilla Group Lays Down Weapons, But Other Rebels Refuse To Disarm
DOC.TEXT: A guerrilla chief says his fighters have ended a 16-year struggle that included the 1985 takeover of Palace of Justice, in which 11 Supreme Court justices and more than 100 others were killed. Other rebel groups, however, refused to follow the decision Thursday by the April 19 Movement, or M-19, to begin disarming and to accept a government amnesty. The M-19 leader, Carlos Pizarro, now is seeking power within the political structure as a candidate for mayor of Bogota in elections Sunday. He and President Virgilio Barco are to sign the final peace accord Saturday. In a ceremony Thursday, the guerrilla group turned 65 weapons over to an international committee headed by a Venezuelan general, Ernesto Uscategui. The committee included Socialist International delegates from Chile, Britain, Finland and Switzerland. Pizarro gave up his 9mm automatic pistol, Caracol radio network reported. Pizarro then told about 800 followers in the southern town of Santo Domingo to hang up their battle fatigues and prepare to fight for peace, said Hernando Correa, an Interior Ministry spokesman in Bogota. Radio reports had placed the number of M-19 followers in the town at 1,800. M-19 spokesman Ramiro Lucio told reporters all the rebels' weapons would be turned over in Santo Domingo and nearby Hobo. Radio reports said the government was planning to melt down the weapons and use the metal to forge a monument to peace. Five other guerrilla groups including the National Liberation Army, blamed for 293 kidnappings in the first two months of the year, say they will keep up their armed struggles. The National Liberation Army has pledged never to negotiate with the government. As part of its campaign to disrupt Sunday's congressional and municipal elections, the group Wednesday and Thursday kidnapped 10 people, including election officials, police and political leaders, a police statement said. But M-19's action Thursday disarms an outfit that mounted some daring rebel attacks. In 1980, it took the U.S. ambassador and 15 other envoys hostage. Five years later, its capture of the Palace of Justice and battle with security forces led to the deaths of 115 people, including 11 Supreme Court justices. The disarmament came after 13 months of peace talks with the Barco administration in Santo Domingo. M19 promised to abandon its armed struggle and transform itself into a political party in exchange for amnesty. The movement directed its campaign against capitalism and U.S. ``imperialism'' and had links with other Latin American underground groups. Pizarro had previously thanked Pope John Paul II for the Roman Catholic Church's mediation in the talks. In a message Thursday to the papal nuncio, Angelo Acerbi, the M19 leader asked the pope to pray for peace in Colombia. Acerbi was one of the 16 ambassadors taken hostage by the M19 on Feb. 27, 1980, when the group seized the Dominican Republic Embassy in Bogota. The embassy takeover ended two months later, and unconfirmed reports said the government paid up to $2 million for the release of the hostages, including U.S. Ambassador Diego Asencio. The M19, formed in 1974, takes its name from the date of 1970 presidential elections, which it claimed were fraudulent.

DOC.HEAD: New Plan Called a Throwback to ``Horse-and-Buggy Years''
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration's blueprint for the nation's transportation network will take the country back to the ``horse and buggy years'' instead of guiding it into the next century, a former transportation secretary contends. ``By forcing states to come up with more money, the administration's national transportation plan only hurts those states that can least afford it,'' Sen. Brock Adams, D-Wash., said Thursday night on the Senate floor. Adams and other Democratic critics said the plan bears the thumb prints of White House chief of staff John Sununu, who is bent on seeing that President Bush keeps his pledge of ``no new taxes.'' ``Everyone seems to be paying except the federal government,'' said Adams. ``This plan isn't a road map into the '90s. It's a road map back into the horse and buggy years'' when toll roads and turnpikes were the rule, not the exception. The criticism by Adams, who served as transportation secretary under President Carter from 1977 to 1979, was far from the only to greet the proposal developed by Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner. Skinner unveiled the 129-page plan with Bush on Thursday morning and defended it later before the House surface transportation subcommittee, which must formulate a five-year highway and mass transit spending plan. Many of the proposals in Skinner's plan, ``Moving America Into the 21st Century,'' are contained in the administration's 1991 budget proposal. The plan calls for more toll roads, local gas taxes, user fees, private investments, competition, deregulation, research into futuristic systems and openness to foreign air carriers as well as increased attention to safety and protection of the environment. Skinner said that with the higher responsibility comes greater local flexibility and room for innovation. Although rural states should end up with a greater share of federal dollars as urban areas find other financing arrangements, it is up to Congress to fight out the balance between urban and rural interests, he said. ``To make our position known, we're going to want to get a lot of advice and watch this evolve in the House and the Senate,'' he said. Skinner received Republican praise for the plan. Rep. Bud Shuster, R-Pa., called it an ``excellent first step.'' Other GOP members of the subcommittee praised the proposal to encouraging private investment. But even Republicans expressed impatience with the continued fight over the combined $25 billion in two transportation trust funds _ one for aviation and one for highways _ that comes up in any transportation debate. Both are financed from fuel and airline ticket taxes and other fees paid directly by users of the transportation system. The money is supposed to be used for capital improvemets, but the aviation fund has been used over the years to help support operations of the Federal Aviation Administration. The Republicans differed from the Democrats only over who should be blamed for holding up the funds, which like the Social Security trust fund help make the budget deficit look smaller. Subcommittee Chairman Norm Mineta, D-Calif., called the funds the administration's ``Swiss bank account'' and said they should be removed from the budget. Skinner said his plan calls for spending the money. But he argued that large amounts are earmarked for projects for which the bills will come in the future.

DOC.HEAD: Dunne Nomination Headed to Senate Floor
DOC.TEXT: John R. Dunne, President Bush's nominee to be assistant attorney general for civil rights, appears to be on a fast track to confirmation. The Senate Judiciary Committee voted Thursday to approve Dunne's nomination, and a staff aide said a vote by the full Senate could come as early as today. Dunne, a former New York state legislator, has the bipartisan backing of both New York senators, the state's House delegation and Gov. Mario Cuomo. But some committee members voiced reservations about him. At Dunne's confirmation hearing Wednesday, the committee grilled Dunne on his lack of civil rights experience, membership in clubs that excluded women, votes against school busing and stock holdings in a company that does business in South Africa. But only one committee member, Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, opposed Dunne's confirmation in Thursday's voice vote. ``I'm not going to vote for Mr. Dunne, but I'm not going to make an effort to persuade'' others against him, Metzenbaum said. Metzenbaum repeated his complaint that Dunne had done nothing to change the discriminatory policies of clubs to which he had belonged. But he added, ``I believe Mr. Dunne will probably be as good an appointee to head the division as we are going to get from this administration.'' Sen. Arlen Specter, R-Pa., also sounded lukewarm about Dunne. ``I think his temperament will be at least reasonably good,'' he said. Dunne, 60, of Garden City, N.Y., was nominated in January to be assistant attorney general for civil rights. The post has been vacant since December 1988 when William Bradford Reynolds resigned. Bush's first nominee for the job, William C. Lucas, then a Michigan county executive, was rejected by the committee by a 7-7 vote last August. Lucas, who is black, had spent most of his career in law enforcement and had little litigation experience. He was also opposed by many civil rights organization.

DOC.HEAD: Low Birth Weight on Rise Again, Says CDC
With PM-Genetic Ambush, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A major factor behind the nation's infant mortality rate _ low birth weight _ is headed the wrong way after 10 years of improvement, according to federal experts in infant health. The rate of low birth weight rose 2 percent from 1985 to 1987, the latest year for which statistics are available, after a 9 percent drop from 1975 to 1985, the national Centers for Disease Control reported Thursday. Sixty-nine out of 1,000 babies born in 1987 were under 5{ pounds _ considered low birth weight _ compared with 67.5 out of 1,000 in 1985. The 1987 figures, nonetheless, are improved from 73.9 reported in 1975. The rate of babies born at ``very low'' birth weight _ below 3 pounds, 4 ounces _ is rising even faster, up 6.8 percent from 1975 to 1987, the report said. In 1987, 12.4 out of every 1,000 births was below 3 pounds, 4 ounces, compared with 11.6 in 1975. ``This rate is a small proportion of births, but it's increasing, which makes it more difficult in the future to improve our infant mortality rate,'' said Dr. Carol Hogue, director of the CDC's Division of Reproductive Health. Improvements in the nation's infant mortality rate in the past two decades are largely because of improved means of keeping premature babies alive _ not because of improved infant health, she said. ``We're not sure we can continue to improve infant mortality by improving this very expensive technology,'' she said. ``We really need to focus on reducing the incidence of low birth weight.'' Babies weighing less than 3 pounds, 4 ounces are 90 to 100 times more likely to die in their first year than other babies, she said. Infants under 5{ pounds run at least a five times greater risk of death than babies of normal weight _ about 6{ to 9{ pounds. The rate of low birth weight among black infants is more than twice the rate for white infants: 127.1 per 1,000 blacks in 1987, compared with 56.8 for whites. The disparity has widened since 15 years ago, when the rates were 130.9 for blacks and 62.6 for whites. Low birth weight rose less than 1 percent for whites between 1985 and 1987, but 2 percent for blacks. The Atlanta-based CDC called the reasons behind the black-white gap ``complex.'' More black women are in high-risk groups for underweight babies: poor, unmarried, under 20, poorly educated, or lacking proper prenatal care, the agency said. Other factors include poor nutritional status, close-together pregnancies and higher rates of unwanted births, the CDC said. More than 16 percent of underweight black babies were unwanted or mistimed pregnancies, the CDC said. Most low birth-weight babies are premature babies; nearly six in 10 are born earlier than 37 weeks of pregnancy, compared with the standard 40 weeks. Each year, some 3.5 million babies are born in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: White Woman Has Black Baby Allegedly Because of Sperm Bank Error
DOC.TEXT: A white woman who wanted to have her terminally ill husband's baby has charged in a lawsuit that a sperm bank and fertility service mixed up its samples and she gave birth to a black daughter. The woman sued Idant Laboratories Inc. and Advanced Fertility Services, saying the girl, now 3, is being subjected to racial prejudice and taunted because she does not resemble her parents. The woman's attorney, David Gould, would not specify the charges in the lawsuit, which was filed in state Supreme Court last fall but disclosed only Thursday in an article in the New York Law Journal. ``The woman loves her daughter, but she wanted to have her husband's baby,'' said Gould. ``She's the target of scandal and discrimination where she lives, and the little girl is being teased and taunted by her playmates. Little kids are saying to the girl, `How come you look different than your mommy?''' Gould cited her emotional distress in asking reporters not to disclose the name of the woman, whose husband died of cancer in April. The couple paid Idant to store the husband's sperm in 1985 after he was diagnosed with Ewing sarcoma, a cancer that requires chemotherapy the couple feared could damage his sperm, according to the lawsuit. ``As my husband's illness progressed,'' the woman was quoted as saying in court papers, ``I decided that having his child was the bond that would link us together forever.'' In March 1986, the woman contacted Advanced Fertility Services to get the sperm samples from Idant and use them for insemination. Advanced Fertility and Idant disagree about what happened them. Robert Whittaker, a lawyer for Advance Fertility, said the sperm samples it used to inseminate the woman came from Idant. Idant's president, Dr. Joseph Feldschuh, said the sperm used by Advanced Fertility was not from the sample his company provided. The child was born in December 1986, and soon after, ``It became apparent that she was not my husband's child,'' the woman said. Feldschuh said the DNA of the husband's sperm stored at Idant does not match the child's DNA. ``The DNA tests done in this case definitively establish that the problem was not with Idant labs,'' Feldschuh said. ``The child is not from our donor.'' Whittaker refused to comment on the child's paternity, saying he had not seen any DNA test results. Under New York law, the woman will have to prove which party is at fault. If the case goes to trial, the defense could try to suggest that neither defendant is at fault, that the woman conceived the child in an extramarital affair and not as a result of an insemination procedure. Gould said that because of the likely scandal, the woman would never have sued had it been up to her. He suggested that her required cooperation in a state case against Idant resulted in her case becoming public. Frances Tarlton, spokeswoman for the state Health Department, said her agency is investigating Idant _ which Feldschuh called the largest licensed sperm bank in the country _ because of a complaint related to the woman's suit. She refused to comment further.

DOC.HEAD: Ortega Warns of Warfare If Contras Fail to Disband Before Inauguration
DOC.TEXT: President Daniel Ortega says armed citizens will fight U.S.-supported Contra rebels if they do not disband before the new government takes office April 25. But Ortega also said Thursday that even if the rebels do not demobilize, he will ``turn over the keys to the government house'' to President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro. He made the comments before thousands of people at a rally celebrating International Women's Day. ``I am convinced that in the same way that the Contras say they will not disarm ... that the people are willing to grab the arms to finish the Contras once and for all,'' Ortega said. ``Thousands of weapons are in the hands of the people,'' he said. Since the Sandinistas' Feb. 25 election loss to the United National Opposition, known as UNO, there have been numerous reports of citizens being armed and trained for combat in ``sovereignty battalions'' by the governing leftist party. Civilians proudly show their new AK-47 combat rifles to reporters. Opposition leaders point to the reports of weapons being handed out to civilians in expressing alarm over a Sandinista bill introduced this week in the legislature that would would absolve anyone of crimes committed through the end of March. The law would apply to crimes committed between July 19, 1979, the day of the victory of the Sandinista revolution that overthrew dictator Anastasio Somoza, and March 31. With the Sandinistas' present 61-seat majority in the legislature to 35 seats among six opposition parties, the law is assured passage. On Thursday the bill was remitted to a committee for review, to be followed by a vote. The Sandinistas are taking the action before they lose their majority. In the new legislature, UNO will have 52 seats and the Sandinistas 39. In his speech, Ortega repeatedly spoke both of leading the Sandinistas as an opposition force in the future and about the Sandinistas' demand that the Contras demobilize in the transition period. ``There is a calm like those before the storm,'' Ortega said. ``And we have the obligation of avoiding being swept away by the tempest of civil war.'' ``The situation in the country is very tense, very complicated,'' Ortega said. He said Contras, fighting the Sandinistas since 981, continue to attack in Nicaraguan territory ``with the complicity of the Honduran government and the United States government.'' About 10,000 Contras, most of their force, are based in Honduran jungle camps near the Nicaragua border. Both Ortega and Mrs. Chamorro have called on the Contras to demobilize before the inauguration. But rebel leaders have refused, saying she must first take office and the new government be given control of the Sandinista People's Army and the Interior Ministry forces. Ortega repeatedly has said the Sandinistas will not do that. He said Thursday he could not turn over to UNO weapons of the army and Interior Ministry. ``I don't have any weapons to give up because the weapons belong to the people,'' Ortega said. Ramiro Gurdian, acting president of Nicaragua's most important private business group, wrote Ortega expressing concern about the distribution of weapons. ``We permit ourselves to remind you that although you are ending your presidential period, the acts of these last days also will be judged by history,'' he said. The proposed law ``coupled with the handling of weapons by certain sectors of society place in imminent danger Nicaragua's incipient democracy and the loss of life of Nicaraguans who would find themselves totally defenseless physically and legally,'' the letter said. Meanwhile, transition teams for both the 14-party UNO coalition and the Sandinistas met all day Thursday for talks on the handing over of power. But neither side would release information on the talks. Mrs. Chamorro left the country Thursday for talks with Venezuelan President Carlos Andres Perez in Caracas, presumably centering on the transition of power. She was then to travel to Houston for two weeks of physical therapy for a fractured knee.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Rise on Tokyo Market, Dollar Higher Against Yen
DOC.TEXT: Share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange today climbed despite the continuing appreciation of the U.S. dollar against the Japanese yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average ended the week at 33,993.12, up 302.23 points or 0.90 percent. It was the second consecutive rise this week, following a gain of 328.55 points Thursday. During the morning session, Tokyo's principal stock index soared more than 600 points on spot purchases of index-related issues, said Yutaka Yoshino, a trader with Nikko Securities. In the afternoon, however, that kind of buying disappeared, and following a slump in the stock futures market, spot issues also fell, sending the Nikkei down some 300 points, he said. Behind the technical factors causing today's stock index to move wildly up and down, Yoshino said the depreciation of the yen was continuing to have a negative impact on the market. Dealers are generally in agreement that the Bank of Japan will be forced to raise its discount rate to counteract the inflationary impact of the cheap yen, an action expected to dampen the demand for stocks. Haruhito Ichimura, of Nippon Kangyo Kakumaru Securities, pointed out the sensitivity of the stock market to changes in foreign exchange rates. ``To some extent, investors have discounted a possible increase in the discount rate, but there is some uncertainty because no one knows whether the rise will 0.5 percent 1.0 percent,'' he said. ``The foreign exchange rate is the biggest problem (facing the market). It will have a tremendous impact on stocks,'' Ichimura said. On the exchange market, the dollar closed at 151.15 yen, up 0.32 yen. It started trading today at 151.07 yen and ranged between 151 and 151.40 yen. A dealer with Fuji Bank, who asked not to be identified, said dollar buying dominated the morning session, pushing up the U.S. currency as far as 151.40 yen. But small-scale intervention by the Bank of Japan stopped the depreciation of the yen, she said. There was little movement in foreign exchange trading during the afternoon, the trader remarked. Many dealers were waiting for the announcement of U.S. employment statistics due out in Washington later today, she said. Yields on benchmark No. 119 10-year government bonds were quoted at 7.180 percent at 4 p.m., down from 7.205 percent at the market's closing Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Sons Accused of Killing Their Millionaire Father and Mother
DOC.TEXT: A Hollywood executive and his wife were gunned down by two sons who stood to inherit more than $10 million, police alleged in announcing one son's arrest and an international hunt for the other. In an eerie twist, the one still at large had co-written a screenplay _ which his mother helped type _ about a son who kills his rich parents. Lyle Menendez, 22, was arrested Thursday and charged with his 19-year-old brother Erik with the shotgun slaying of his father, Jose Menendez, and mother, Mary Louis ``Kitty'' Menendez. The couple were slain in August while watching television in their Beverly Hills mansion. ``I've been in this business 33 years and I've heard of few killings as savage as this one,'' said Police Chief Marvin D. Iannone said. Police were seeking help from the State Department and Interpol to detain Erik Menendez, believed to be in Israel playing in a tennis tournament. Jose Menendez, a 45-year-old Cuban immigrant, was chairman of Live Entertainment Inc., a video and music distribution business affiliated with Carolco Pictures Inc., producers of the ``Rambo'' movies. Investigators dismissed earlier speculation that organized crime was behind the slayings because of alleged business links to Menendez' company. Iannone said the investigation uncovered physical evidence that linked the sons to the killings. The probe also focused on a vanished computer record concerning Menendez' will. Menendez and his wife were killed by shotgun blasts at close range as they watched television in their library one evening. Their sons reported the killings, saying they found the bodies after a night out. Nothing appeared to be stolen from the Spanish-style, $5 million home. And nothing indicated that the killers forced their way in. ``The focus became very clear over the past few months that the sons did it,'' Iannone said. ``We were just waiting for the glue, binding it together.'' Police on Thursday served search warrants to seize the records of a psychologist who had worked with the Menendez family. Some forms of communication between psychotherapists and their clients are protected under law. It wasn't known what records were seized by police. Authorities Thursday refused to give a possible motive in the killings. ``Who knows what really goes on in families?'' Iannone said. Under terms of the parents' 9-year-old wills, the sons share an estate worth $10 million to $17 million. A $400,000 life insurance policy also has been distributed to the sons. In the months after the killings, Lyle Menendez traveled the country, making investments and buying stores, particularly fast-food franchises, said Iannone. Lyle Menendez was arrested Thursday afternoon as he was preparing to drive away from the family mansion. He had been under surveillance for 36 hours, and police feared he would leave the state. Erik and a close friend had written a screenplay about a son who murders his wealthy parents and three other people and ultimately is shot himself, the Los Angeles Times reported today. The screenplay, called ``Friends,'' opens with the son reading the family will, which bequeaths to him $157 million, before he goes into his parents' luxury suite and kills them.

DOC.HEAD: No Lie: Honesty Campaign Didn't Make Everyone Honest
DOC.TEXT: A 14-month campaign to make honesty a city policy ends today, and its leader and police say they cannot tell a lie: It hasn't rid the city of liars, cheats or scoundrels. ``We haven't wiped out crime or made everybody honest, but we have made people think about it. That's what we intended to do,'' said Jeb Stuart Magruder, the former Watergate conspirator who led the ``Take an Honest Look'' campaign. The privately financed $35,000 campaign in this Midwestern city of 566,000 closes today with a speech by Atlanta Mayor Andrew Young and an awards ceremony honoring those whose honesty was exemplary. The guest list excludes those responsible for an increase in crime in Columbus last year. Homicides rose by 29 percent from 1988, car thefts by 22 percent and aggravated assaultsby 5 percent. Bank robberies dropped 50 percent last year, but already this year robbers have held up 33 banks, compared with 54 all of last year. Deputy Chief Robert Kern said neither he nor the street patrol officers he oversees have noticed an outbreak of honesty. ``Crime is up, that's for sure,'' he said. ``But I haven't noticed any more people than normal being honest. A lot of people call us with information or turn people in, but they've always done that.'' The idea for the campaign surfaced when the honesty _ or lack of it _ of Columbus residents was questioned in 1988 after the rear doors of an armored car flew open, spewing bags of cash on an interstate. Many motorists who stopped to scoop up the flying cash never returned it, although one man who returned $57,000 became a local celebrity. The all-volunteer campaign initiated by the Columbus Commission on Ethics and Values targeted city schools, churches, government and city groups. Its chief weapon against dishonesty was public service announcements. The television and radio spots, for example, showed a driver who backs into an unoccupied vehicle in a parking lot. He, of course, leaves a note explaining what happened. Another person gets too much change from a store clerk and gives it back. But Magruder, a Presbyterian minister, said the campaign's biggest success was an honesty curriculum in area school districts. It spread sincerity to 90,000 Columbus school students through workshops, essay contests and other programs. ``I think it had an effect,'' said Howard Merriman, Columbus schools assistant superintendent. ``It heightened the awareness of teachers and administrators that it's important to talk about honesty. It also helped the students.'' Other events included a symposium for corporate leaders and ``Honesty Sunday'' at churches. Andrew Altman, a philosophy professor at George Washington University in Washington, D.C., who specializes in law and morality, said it will take more than a campaign to persuade people that honesty is the best policy. ``Most people are honest most of the time,'' he said in a telephone interview. ``Restoring ethics and honesty will take a general cultural transformation about what we think is important in life ... a return to a life of simple virtues.'' Magruder, who spent seven months in prison after he admitted destroying records and committing perjury in the Watergate scandal, said he saw the campaign as making a small inroad into the problem. ``I have learned that change can occur in little increments. And change for the better is something worth doing,'' he said. Magruder said the commission is so satisfied with the effort that it plans to target another topic come fall _ prejudice.

DOC.HEAD: Whites, Blacks Meet in Program Designed to Break Racial Barriers
LaserPhoto CX1
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING to fix category code.
DOC.TEXT: In a program designed to break racial barriers, eight white college students are spending spring break at the nation's largest all-black Catholic school. ``We grow up in two totally different societies, and there's a lot of fear on both sides,'' said Sister Helen Strueder of Holy Angels School. ``Working one-on-one breaks down that barrier.'' Sister Ann Redig, director of campus ministry at Quincy College in western Illinois, where the white college students come from, organized the trip as ``an opportunity for students who wanted to do some kind of service.'' ``One of the biggest objectives is to open the eyes and broaden the horizons of the students I work with,'' she said. Quincy students spend their weeklong spring break, which started Saturdy, tutoring and teaching students who are in preschool through eighth grade. The program, in its second year, is unusual for inner-city schools, said Sister Strueder, who hopes it will produce the added benefit of becoming a source for white teachers. She said three Quincy students have already asked to work this summer as tutors at Holy Angels, a school with an excellent scholastic reputation that has a long waiting list. Meghan Hanrahan, a sophomore, said she came to Holy Angels because ``as a potential social worker, I wanted to get out and meet some of the people I someday hope to help out in some way.'' The school is in a downtrodden South Side neighborhood. Since her arrival, Hanrahan _ who grew up in Buffalo, N.Y., and St. Louis _ said she'd seen a drug deal and heard gunshots in the night. ``You know what's going on, but you rarely see it like I have this week.'' From the elementary students, Hanrahan said: ``All they want to hear is what's college like. `Do you get to stay in dorms? Do you get a lot of homework?''' Seventh-grader Victoria Williams said ``it's been an inspiration'' to have the college students around: ``You see the way they act and talk so nice _ maybe we'll do the same.'' Each morning, Victoria dons a brown plaid school uniform and commutes across the South Side on a city bus to Holy Angels, which according to Sister Strueder, is the largest black Catholic school in the country with an enrollment of 1,250 students. ``My mother says this is a very nice school and she wants me to come here. She just thinks this is the best school for me,'' said Victoria, who plans to go to college. As she tutored Victoria in division and mixed fractions, Junior Kathy Bianchi said that after a week at Holy Angels: ``You just learn to see through color.''

DOC.HEAD: Key Party Meeting Reportedly In Session
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party's Central Committee is believed to have begun a key meeting to decide economic and personnel matters before the nation's parliament convenes later this month, diplomats said today. The committee would be meeting for the first time since November, when the decision-making body approved a three-year economic austerity program and announced that senior leader Deng Xiaoping was resigning from his last party post. There was no official confirmation of the party meeting, although the street in front of the Great Hall of the People was blocked off this morning, an indication that an important event was taking place inside. Some diplomats said the meeting appeared to have opened today, while others said it started on Thursday. The Central Committee, composed of 175 regular and 108 alternate members, usually meets twice a year, once before the annual session of the National People's Congress, China's rubberstamp legislature. The meeting is likely to focus on the nation's troubled economy and policies to be outlined by Premier Li Peng before the People's Congress. The austerity program has brought down inflation and curbed excessive economic growth, but has also resulted in the closures of thousands of factories and the layoffs of millions of workers. The party, concerned about popular unrest because of the economic downturn and the harsh political climate following the military crackdown on the pro-democracy movement in June, is expected to approve some easing of austerity measures, particularly the loosening of credit to money-starved industries. The party meeting will also take up personnel changes to be approved by People's Congress. The Central Committee is also likely to discuss the rapid political and economic changes taking place in the Soviet Union and East Europe, and reaffirm China's position that it will continue along the socialist road regardless of events in other countries. Diplomats said the meeting will probably last until early next week. Communist Party General Secretary Jiang Zemin is scheduled to leave in the middle of the week on a trip to North Korea.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Democrats Meet in Gubernatorial Debate
DOC.TEXT: Ann Richards again refused to say whether she'd used illegal drugs, an issue that has hurt her campaign against six other Democrats for the gubernatorial nomination. Ms. Richards, a recovering alcoholic, said during a debate with her Democratic rivals Thursday night that the issue had never been raised in her eight years as treasurer. But the drug question has become an acid test for the Democratic candidates. Richards' refusal to answer apparently is behind her recent drop in the polls. The polls show former Gov. Mark White leading Ms. Richards, who in turn leads Jim Mattox, the state attorney general. Ms. Richards came to national prominence when she delivered the keynote address during the 1988 Democratic convention. White, Mattox and four minor candidates have said they never used illegal drugs. White and Mattox offered to take a drug test before the primary on Tuesday. White and Mattox both took Ms. Richards to task over a new series of advertisements that question their financial dealings and integrity. ``Ann, you know better than what you've been saying on television, you know it's a lie,'' White said. ``I think your advertising now is in really poor taste,'' Mattox said. One candidate with little backing, Stanley Edward Adams Jr., criticized the others for hammering Ms. Richards on the drug question. ``Too many people right now are trying to destroy this lady. Well, we are overreacting,'' he said. Adams said he favored decriminalizing drug use. Extra security was arranged for Ms. Richards when she arrived back in Austin on Thursday night, after someone made two telephone death threats against her from an Austin pay phone, police said. In another development, the Rev. W.N. Otwell, a candidate with a small following, withdrew from the GOP gubernatorial race Thursday night and endorsed Republican front-runner Clayton Williams. The winner of the general election will succeed retiring Republican Gov. Bill Clements.

DOC.HEAD: Republican Hopes to Avoid Runoff in Texas Governor's Campaign
With PM-Texas-Governor
DOC.TEXT: With a healthy lead in the polls for Tuesday's Republican primary for governor, the folksy humor is oozing out of Clayton Williams like the oil that made his fortune. The other GOP candidates seem well out of hollering range, and Williams was confident enough of victory to skip a televised League of Women Voters' debate Wednesday night in Dallas. He seemed to be enjoying himself as he made the rounds Thursday, kissing small children and signing autographs with his wife, Modesta. ``Take a good look at me, look at my profile. Now look at Modesta,'' he said. ``You think I'm not the sellingest son-of-a-gun you've ever seen?'' Recent polls have shown Williams winning about 50 percent of the GOP vote. He was asked Thursday if he thought he could avoid a runoff election for the nomination to succeed retiring Republican Gov. Bill Clements. ``As a Republican, it would be much better for our party if I were able to make it without a runoff,'' Williams said. ``We are asking all our supporters to please walk that extra block, please call on that extra house, please make that extra phone call.'' Then he flashed a grin and said: ``I must be sounding like a politician. I circled that question pretty good.'' The colorful West Texas oilman-rancher, never before elected to public office, has sunk $5.6 million of his own money in an $8 million campaign that appears to have succeeded in creating a look and feel that appeals to Texans. In the extensive TV ads that have bolstered his campaign, the cowboy hat never leaves Williams' head. He tells fans that he owns no shoes _ just boots _ and professes to worship the late John Wayne. ``John Wayne was a dream of what we all wished we were rather than what any of us mortals are,'' Williams told a incredulous out-of-town reporter. ``The good guy who whipped the bad guy, who was on the side of right, law and order.'' Williams' nearest opponent, Kent Hance, a former Democratic congressman who sponsored President Reagan's 1981 tax cut legislation, had 22 percent support in a recent poll. The two other major contenders have earned most of the endorsements from the state's major newspapers. But both _ Tom Luce, lawyer for billionaire H. Ross Perot, and former secretary of state Jack Rains _ remain in single digits in the polls.

DOC.HEAD: Government Will Ban Over-the-Counter Prostate Drugs
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration says it will ban the sale of all nonprescription drugs used to treat enlargement of the prostate gland. The agency said Thursday that its review of these products found little evidence any of them eliminates, arrests or treats the condition, called benign prostatic hypertrophy. Surgery is currently the only effective treatment, the FDA said. The condition causes enlargement of the male gland, which can obstruct the flow of urine, create back pressure in the kidneys and cause urinary tract infections that are difficult to treat, the FDA said. The over-the-counter products, which contain the amino acids glycine, alanine and glutamic acid and a plant extract called sabal, can relieve some symptoms of the condition. However, their use also could lull men with the condition ``into a sense of false security,'' which could delay their getting proper treatment, the agency said. Few of these products are being sold today, the FDA said. About 50 percent to 80 percent of men with the condition will develop unstable bladders and have symptoms of frequency and urgency of urination. The FDA said the ban will take effect in six months.
DOC.HEAD: Group Wants Anti-Smoking Spots to Balance Sports Sponsors
DOC.TEXT: A children's advocacy group has asked regulators to require broadcasters and cable TV operators to show anti-smoking messages on youth-oriented programs if they televise sports events sponsored by cigarette companies. Action for Children's Television, which was instrumental in reviving advertising limits for Saturday morning children's TV shows, on Thursday appealed to the Federal Communications Commission to close a ``loophole'' in a 1969 law that banned cigarette advertising from television. The group said cigarette companies got around the ban by sponsoring televised sports events such as tennis tournaments and car races and making their brands part of the names of the events. TV cameras also routinely show billboards advertising cigarettes behind the sports action being shown, ACT said, calling them ``hidden commercials'' that subvert the purpose of the 1969 law. Congress passed the law ``because it had concluded that it is not in the public interest to have cigarettes advertised over such unique media that reach into every household and are particularly viewed by the young,'' ACT told the FCC. ``The young are being bombarded over television by hidden messages associated with sports ... that are meant to show that smoking is attractive,'' ACT President Peggy Charren said in an interview.
DOC.HEAD: USDA Defends Flexibility Proposal, But Concedes Grain Prices Could
DOC.TEXT: Drop

Wheat-state lawmakers say a Bush administration proposal to give farmers more planting options could hurt farmers by creating lower crop prices. The Agriculture Department defended the proposal on Thursday before a Senate Agriculture subcommittee, but conceded that wheat prices probably would drop initially if farmers nationwide were given more flexibility in choosing which crops they grow. Bruce Gardner, USDA assistant secretary for economics, projected that up to 3 million additional wheat acres would be planted if the administration's proposal were implemented in 1991. Wheat prices could fall as much as 15-20 cents a bushel, he said. Wheat prices are projected to average $3.80 to $3.90 a bushel in the 1990 crop year, according to USDA. However, Gardner said ``wheat producers are going to be protected'' by federal subsidies from a drop in their incomes. Overall, he contended that farmers would benefit from more planting flexibility because they could adjust their cropping patterns to take advantage of potential higher prices in the markets. At issue is a proposal by President Bush for more planting flexibility for farmers who wish to participate in federal subsidy programs. The lawmakers said they generally agreed with the goal but differed with the administration on how best to accomplish it. The proposal is part of the administration's recommendations for new farm legislation to guide agricultural policy during the next several years.

DOC.HEAD: Settlement Reached in Prego Case; Jury Awards $12 Million to Woman in Ohio
LaserPhoto NY10
DOC.TEXT: A doctor settled a lawsuit that claimed she contracted AIDS though the negligence of another doctor, for she doubted that she would live long enough to see through a promised appeal. Dr. Veronica Prego, who claimed she contracted the deadly disease in 1983 after she accidently pricked her finger on a needle that had been used to draw blood from an AIDS patient, said she was relieved the case against the city was settled. In another case Thursday, a jury in Columbus, Ohio, awarded $12 million to Holly Sutro Lalonde, who was infected with acquired immune deficiency syndrome during a hospital-administered blood transfusion in 1985. Also Thursday, Ronald Lovgren, 26, was ordered released from jail in Syracuse, N.Y., after a private company that transports prisoners around the country refused to return him to Florida because he has AIDS. Lovgren walked away from a prison detail in Florida 40 days before his sentence was completed. Under the agreement reached in Brooklyn state Supreme Court, none of the parties named in Prego's lawsuit acknowledged guilt. The settlement, the amount of which was not disclosed, was reached as attorneys prepared trial summations. Jurors interviewed afterward said they were leaning in favor of the 32-year-old doctor. Prego's lawyer, Diane Wilner, said the settlement was reluctantly accepted because the defense said it would appeal any jury victory by Prego. ``In essence, I believe they put a gun to our head with the appeal,'' she said. An appeal would tie the matter up in the courts for two to three years. Prego's doctor had testified she might have less than a year to live. Prego, pale and looking tired during the trial, said she was happy the trial had finally ended. ``It's been extremely difficult for me,'' she said, complaining that her health had worsened because of the strain of the more than 2-month-long trial. ``Now it's time to take care of myself.'' New York City's Health and Hospitals Corp. will pay the settlement, which Justice Aaron D. Bernstein ordered both sides not to disclose, although he said it was ``between zero and $100 million.'' Prego had sought $175 million. ``It's no one's business, except the people who are paying it and the person who's receiving it,'' Bernstein said. ``It has nothing to do with the relative merits of this case.'' City lawyer Stanley D. Friedman said of the settlement, ``We're most pleased, I can't tell you the numbers, but we're most pleased.'' In her suit filed in 1988, Prego charged that while working as an unpaid doctor in training at Kings County Hospital on Jan. 12, 1983, she was injured by an AIDS-contaminated needle carelessly left on a bed by her supervising intern.

DOC.HEAD: Loose Motor Caused Philly Subway Crash
