DOC.TEXT: Investigators believe a loose motor under a subway car tripped a switch that threw part of the train into another track and slammed it into a pillar, killing three people and injuring 94. A nut holding the motor in place had apparently slipped off, causing the motor to drag under the six-car train before Wednesday's accident, John K. Lauber of the National Transportation Safety Board said Thursday. The motor, under the third car, hit a crossover switch, and the tripped switch jerked the last three cars onto a second set of tracks. The fourth car smashed into a steel pillar, Lauber said. All of the dead were in the fourth car. The accident was the worst in the 21 years the Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority has operated the regional commuter system. A 37-block section of the subway and elevated train line in the nation's fifth-largest city remained closed today as the investigation of the site continued. Sixteen people were still hospitalized, two in critical or serious condition. Lauber said the NTSB learned Thursday of three other incidents in the past 15 years when a motor apparently dropped. One occurred just six months ago, he said. A nut and cotter pin came off a vertical bolt on the motor in Wednesday's crash and there was extensive damage to horizontal bars on the car, which were supposed to catch the motor if it fell, Lauber said. Lauber said the NTSB was also told that the same motor had been replaced on Oct. 4, and had been in the shop for routine inspections in February. The regional transporation authority has ordered inspections of all older subway cars, which date from the early 1960s. An extra 120 buses were pressed into service to shuttle some of the 100,000 passengers who ride the trains each day. The closed section of track was expected to reopen Monday. Gov. Robert P. Casey inspected the accident area Thursday and asked for more federal help for the transit authority, which recently proposed raising the base fare to $1.50 _ the highest in the country _ to try to head off a $30 million deficit in the next fiscal year. But in Washington, Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner said: ``SEPTA can no longer run the risk of assuming that we're going to have a continuous federal income stream because that prevents them from living up to their responsibility.''

DOC.HEAD: IRS Has No Record of Covenant House Charitable Trust
DOC.TEXT: A tax-free charitable trust set up by the Rev. Bruce Ritter in Covenant House's name did not file annual reports two years with the Internal Revenue Service as the law requires, an IRS spokesman said. The trust was set up in 1983 to aid runaway youths, but Covenant House officials acknowledged money from the trust instead went into loans to Father Ritter's sister and two Covenant House board members. It also paid $140,000 to Ritter, some of which he said he returned, the New York Times reported today. No reports were filed with the IRS in 1987 and 1988, said spokesman Robert Kobel. He said a search for earlier filings was continuing. The trust never registered with the charities bureau of the state Attorney General's office either, new Times said. Ritter resigned as president of Covenant House after four young men who had sought his help alleged that he had sexual affairs with them.

DOC.HEAD: Najib Says Pakistan Had Major Role In Attempted Coup
DOC.TEXT:
Afghanistan today accused neighboring Pakistan of playing a major role in a thwarted coup engineered by the Afghan defense minister, who defected to a Moslem guerrilla faction. Pakistan called the allegation absurd, saying the plot to topple Afghan President Najib only exposed the cracks in his shaky government in Kabul. At least 56 people died and 200 others were injured in Tuesday's revolt by soldiers loyal to the renegade defense minister, Gen. Shah Nawaz Tanai. Tanai was supported by fundamentalist guerrilla leader Gulbuddin Hekmatyar. Tanai, a battle-hardened officer popular among the rank-and-file military, was dismissed as defense minister shortly after Afghan warplanes swooped down and bombed the capital of Kabul, causing extensive damage to the city of 2 million. Najib also replaced Tanai and other key members of the policy-making Politburo, the Central Committee and the Supreme Defense Council, which maps out the government's strategy in the 12-year-old war against the Moslem guerrillas. Among those dismissed from the Politburo were Said Mohammad Gulabzhoi, Afghanistan's ambassador to Moscow, and Gen. Abdul Qadar Aga Aka, a leader of the air force contingents that helped Mohammad Daoud overthrow the monarchy in 1973. Daoud was killed in the 1978 coup that installed the Communist government. During a news conference Thursday in Kabul, Najib declared his government had been purged of dissidents and that his ruling People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan was now more united than ever. ``The microbes, the radicals among us, have been cleansed,'' a Kabul-based diplomat quoted the 43-year-old president as saying. The diplomat spoke on condition of anonymity. Radio Kabul, monitored in Islamabad, reported the government had proof that neighboring Pakistan played a key role in Tanai's attempts to bring down Najib, the former chief of the feared secret police who was installed by the Soviets in 1986. ``The government of Afghanistan has undeniable documents of Pakistan's interference and participation in the unsuccessful coup,'' official Kabul Radio said. ``The government demands that Pakistan hand over Shah Nawaz Tanai and others who escaped to Pakistan,'' said the radio, monitored in Islamabad. The Soviet-backed government regularly accuses Pakistan of training the Moslem guerrillas, who are armed by the United States and Saudi Arabia. As it has always done, Pakistan denied the charge. ``This (coup attempt) is an internal matter. It ... shows that the government's claim of popular support is just a sham,'' said a Foreign Ministry spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity. Tanai fled Afghanistan on Wednesday, and Pakistani officials and guerrilla sources said he then defected to the guerrillas, whom he fought more than a decade. Tanai returned to Afghanistan, but his exact whereabouts were not known.
Hekmatyar's Hezb-i-Islami has split from the other six groups in the Pakistan-based resistance over leadership disputes. Leaders of the guerrillas' government-in-exile say they would never accept Tanai, a hard-line Communist, as an ally. Tanai and Hekmatyar, bitter rivals during the 12-year-old war, apparently were united in their desire to see Najib ousted. While the plot apparently failed, Western diplomats in Pakistan said, it still hurt Najib politically and militarily and bought time for the guerrillas preparing for the so-called summer fighting season. With planes diverted to Kabul from other areas, Western diplomats said, the guerrillas are now able to move weapons into Afghanistan. The Afghan air force has been credited for Najib's survival since the Kremlin ended nine years of direct military intervention and pulled the Red Army out of Afghanistan in February 1989. Najib, former chief of the feared secret police, was installed by the Soviets in 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Va. Governor Likely To Sign Anti-Smoking Bill
DOC.TEXT: Virginia, one of the biggest tobacco-producing states in the country, is poised to become one of the last states to pass a public smoking bill. The state legislature on Thursday approved a bill restricting smoking, and Gov. L. Douglas Wilder is likely to sign it, said Wilder's chief of staff, J.T. Shropshire. Virginia is among six states with no statewide limits on smoking in public. It is the nation's fifth largest tobacco producer. ``I think we can live with it,'' said Anthony F. Troy, a lobbyist for the Tobacco Institute. ``It is a major, positive step toward cleaner air in the commonwealth,'' said Jane F. Roberts, a spokeswoman for the Tri-Agency Council, a coalition of cancer, heart and lung associations. But rural lawmakers called the bill another blow to the declining tobacco industry. ``We are talking about an industry that has helped build this commonwealth,'' said Delegate Charles R. Hawkins. ``This vote will change the direction of this commonwealth forever.'' Delegate Willard R. Finney said the number of tobacco farmers in his county has declined from 1,200 in 1980 to 200 today. ``Unfortunately, the tobacco farmer doesn't have any lobbying group down here,'' Finney said. The bill would ban smoking in elevators, school buses, hospital emergency rooms, school common areas, polling places and indoor cashier lines. It would also require no-smoking areas in state offices, restaurants with 50 or more seats, retail stores of 15,000 square feet or more and educational and health care buildings. In a compromise with tobacco industry backers, the bill allows localities to regulate smoking in other public places but would limit how strict their ordinances could be. In private workplaces, localities could allow smoking to be banned if half the employees agree.

DOC.HEAD: Stalemate in Baseball Talks
DOC.TEXT: The baseball players' union dismissed an offer by Commissioner Fay Vincent's to open training camps in exchange for a no-strike pledge by players. ``We are not, unless there is some miracle, going to resolve this in the next several days,'' Vincent said Thursday night after the players' union denounced the proposal he made earlier in the day. Negotiations to end the baseball owners' lockout remained stuck over salary arbitration 24 days before opening day. Both sides have agreed that players must be in camp by Monday if the season is to start as scheduled April 2. ``I guess we've been naive enough to keep thinking we're going to reach an agreement,'' American League President Bobby Brown said. The sides talked into the night on Wednesday. The owners met Thursday and weren't interested in the union's plan. Vincent then made his announcement. ``I am asking the clubs to open the training camps in exchange for a pledge from the players not to strike during the 1990 season. In the meantime, the parties can continue to work toward the best of all results ... a negotiated agreement,'' Vincent said. Union chief Donald Fehr, at a news conference an hour later, dismissed Vincent's idea as ``silly.'' Added Eugene Orza, a union counsel: ``No self-respecting union would give up its right to strike.''

DOC.HEAD: Rain Over Gulf States; Wet Weather Out West for Weekend
DOC.TEXT: Scattered rainshowers soaked much of the area east of the Mississippi River early today, and a weekend forecast called for spring-like weather in the East and rain in the West. In Des Moines, Iowa, utility crews restored power to thousands of homes in the wake of this week's ice storm, but officials said some may be without power until Sunday. About 30,000 customers were still without electricity early today. The rain that fell from Minneapolis to Birmingham, Ala., today was the tail end of a storm that dumped snow and freezing rain in the Rockies earlier in the week. A warm front approached the Northwest, while weak storms from the Pacific Ocean were expected to bring rain this weekend to the coastal states and possibly snow to the Rockies. On Thursday, Arkansas was swamped overnight with as much as 7 inches of rain that forced evacuations in at least five counties, washed out roads and bridges in more than 10 counties and left a school bus with 46 young passengers stuck in wheel-high water for two hours. No one was seriously injured. The National Weather Service forecast says it's possible that showers will return tonight in Arkansas and last through Sunday. In Illinois and Iowa, tornadoes touched down in several spots, and damaged two apartment buildings, an office and cars in the Iowa City suburb of Coralville, police said. No major injuries were reported. Thunderstorms also brought hail in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, and in parts of Illinois. In Cheyenne, Wyo., unseasonably warm temperatures melted snow and caused some flooding in the city. High temperature records for March 8 were set in Billings, Mont., 64 degrees; and Glasgow, Mont., 63 degrees; and Sherdian, Wyo., 64 degrees. Rain fell Thursday night along the Oregon and Washington coasts as well as in southeast Idaho. Freezing rain fell in parts of Minnesota, Wisconsin and Michigan. The nation's high temperature Thursday was 91 degrees at McAllen, Texas. Other reports at 3 a.m. EST today: _EAST: Albany, N.Y., 19 fair; Atlanta 42 foggy; Boston 33 fair; Buffalo 35; Charleston, S.C., 52 partly cloudy; Chattanooga 45 foggy; Cincinnati 52 foggy; Cleveland 46 cloudy; Detroit 38 drizzle; Hatteras 42 cloudy; Jacksonville 52 foggy; Key West 72 fair; Knoxville 46 drizzle; Macon 46 drizzle; Miami 70 partly cloudy; New York 32 fair; Philadelphia 32 partly cloudy; Pittsburgh 41 showery; Portland, Maine, 29 fair; Richmond 40 rain; Tampa 59 fair; Washington, D.C., 41 cloudy. _CENTRAL: Birmingham 52 rain; Bismarck 35 cloudy; Chicago 48 foggy; Denver 47 partly cloudy; Des Moines 36 foggy; Fort Worth 69; Indianapolis 51 drizzle; Kansas City 38 fair; Little Rock 58 drizzle; Louisville 51 drizzle; Memphis 58 showery; Nashville 54 foggy; New Orleans 67 foggy; North Platte 35 partly cloudy; Oklahoma City 65 foggy; Omaha 34 foggy; Rapid City 39 fair; St. Louis 57 cloudy; Minneapolis-St. Paul 33 drizzle; Sault Ste. Marie 30 freezing rain; San Antonio 70 drizzle. _WEST: Albuquerque 45; Boise 28 fair; Casper 39 fair; Fairbanks 01 fair; Great Falls 29 windy; Honolulu 73 windy; Las Vegas 54 cloudy; Los Angeles 54 partly cloudy; Medford 34 fair; Pendleton 41 cloudy; Phoenix 63 cloudy; Portland, Ore., 41 cloudy; Reno 37 fair; Salt Lake City 41 fair; San Diego 56 cloudy; San Francisco 46 fair; Seattle 38 rain; Spokane 36 cloudy. _INTERNATIONAL: Calgary 21 fair; Montreal 21 fair; Ottawa 19 fair; Regina 34 windy; Toronto 28 cloudy; Winnipeg 34 drizzle; San Juan 75.

DOC.HEAD: Leaders Near Race Halfway Point
DOC.TEXT: Five veteran mushers vied for the lead near the midway point of the 18th annual Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race. Lavon Barve of Wasilla was the first to arrive at the checkpoint here Thursday. Barve, who has finished in the top 10 each of the past four years, mushed in at 10:21 a.m. and was the first musher out six hours later. Barve was followed by Martin Buser of Big Lake; three-time champ Susan Butcher of Manley; defending champion Joe Runyan of Nenana and DeeDee Jonrowe of Willow. The lead mushers were all into McGrath within an hour of each other, and were gone by 4:34 p.m. _ within 20 minutes of Barve _ en route for Cripple, 60 miles up the trail and the midway point in the 1,160 mile race to Nome from Anchorage, which the 70 sled teams left Saturday. The first musher in Cripple captures a halfway trophy and $3,000 in silver ingots provided by a race sponsor. But race lore has it that few leaders at Cripple ever go on to win. Earlier in the day front-runner Rick Swenson was knocked back after encountering moose on the trail out of McGrath. After some of his dogs were trampled, Swenson returned to McGrath to wait for daylight. The run-in dropped him to seventh and he arrived Thursday night in Ophir, nearly two hours behind the leader.

DOC.HEAD: Economic Crisis Drives Slumdwellers To Attack Delivery Trucks
DOC.TEXT: Hungry residents blocked roads or threw rocks in an attempt to get food delivery trucks to stop in slums in the northern city of Rosario. Police fired rubber bullets at the people. A 14-year-old boy was shot in the leg and five people were struck by the rubber bullets, reported police in Rosario, an industrial city of 1 million about 185 miles north of Buenos Aires. Twenty people were arrested. Rosario was the site of the worst violence when food riots broke out in several cities in May. At least 16 people were killed in those riots. The cost of living has soared an estimated 12,000 percent the past 12 months, and wages have failed to keep pace. Compared to the dollar, Argentina's currency is worth less than 1 percent what it was a year ago. Dozens of ``misery town'' dwellers, as Argentines call the neighborhoods, gathered before dawn Thursday at highways and tried to block the roads with tree branches and wooden posts, the Noticias Argentinas independent news agency reported. When trucks and even cars slowed down, the shantytown residents hurled rocks trying to get them to stop, police said. A 14-year-old boy was shot in the leg and five other people were struck by rubber bullets, police in Rosario reported. Police Gen. Fermin Almonacid said the majority of the 20 arrested were ``common delinquents'' taking advantage of a social situation made explosive by high inflation, increasing unemployment, shrinking wages and hunger. About one adult out of five works part-time or not at all. Border guards and federal police have patrolled downtown streets almost continually in Rosario since December. But neighborhood grocery stores and food delivery trucks still have been looted almost daily for weeks, despite the distribution of thousands of packages containing cooking oil, powdered milk, noodles, sugar, tea and other basics. In an indication the unrest may be spreading, women and children walked into two supermarkets Thursday, filled bags with food and fled. Noticias Argentinas said one merchant, seeing people gather outside, gave away bags of rice, noodles and other food to keep his store from being looted. Newspapers and an economic research group reported Thursday that the cost of living in Argentina rose by at least 62 percent last month and may reach triple digits in March. The daily La Nacion, citing unidentified government sources, put February inflation at 62 to 70 percent. Even the lower figure would mean the cost of living for the past 12 months rose by 12,231 percent. Inflation in 1989 was 4,924 percent, wildly fluctuating from a high of 197 percent in July to a low of 5.6 percent in October. Economists and monetary experts say that despite five major austerity plans implemented during the 8-month-old government of President Carlos Menem, inflation may worsen before it gets better.

DOC.HEAD: Stormie Jones Sick of Being Sick
DOC.TEXT: Tired and miffed that she had to undergo a second liver transplant, the world's only surviving heart-liver transplant patient says she wants to go home, take a bath and go to bed. ``I thought I wasn't going to have anymore problems again, but I guess I was wrong,'' said Stormie Jones, 12, during a news conference Thursday at Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh. Cuddling a stuffed koala bear that accompanied her to the operating room last month, Stormie said she hopes to return home to White Settlement, Texas, within a month. Stormie said she's forcing herself to obey doctors' orders and take short strolls around the hospital so she can return home soon. ``I guess it's just hope,'' she said of her ordeal. ``There's a thing in the back of your head that says, `Get up,''' Stormie, dressed in sweat pants and a Children's Hospital sweat shirt, teasingly sparred with her mother, Lois ``Susie'' Purcell, during the news conference. Speaking softly, she professed her dislike for being in the public eye and media interviews, her fate since the second transplant on Feb. 20. Although she and her mother are optimistic her body will accept the new liver, Stormie said there's a remote chance of rejection. ``They told me I might be having a little rejection, which made me mad,'' she said. Mrs. Purcell said she credits Stormie's seemingly fast recovery to FK-506, an experimental anti-rejection drug developed in Japan. Stormie began taking it in November. Researchers say the drug is more powerful and causes fewer side effects than cyclosporine, the anti-rejection medicine Stormie began taking after her historic heart-liver transplant on Feb. 14, 1984. Stormie required a second liver last month because the first transplanted liver was permanently damaged by hepatitis. The day after her second transplant, Stormie returned to the operating room because of internal bleeding. ``I thought, `Now what are you taking out,''' Stormie said. Stormie has been playing with other children at the hospital, reading books and building a wooden doll house. She said she also is trying to write a book for other children about her experiences but so far has completed only a page, in part because she doesn't like to write. Her first transplant was needed to control effects of a rare disease that left her cholesterol levels 10 times greater than normal and damaged her heart. Her donor heart has remained healthy, doctors said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed In Thin Trading, Gold Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was mixed in thin European trading this morning, trapped between bullish sentiment and fears of central bank intervention. The pound fell sharply on rumors that Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher had resigned. Mrs. Thatcher's Downing Street office denied the rumors. A spokesman, who wasn't identified, in accordance with British practice, called them ``utter rubbish.'' Gold prices were lower. Traders predicted the dollar would remain trapped in its current narrow range for the near future and said they doubted the release of U.S. employment figures later in the day would nudge it out of its current levels unless the figures are way outside expectations. ``The central banks have achieved what everyone hoped they wouldn't: stability,'' said Manfred Totzauer, a senior trader at Citibank AG in Frankfurt. In London, the pound fell to $1.6267 dollars from $1.6427 dollars late Thursday. Dealers said the Bank of England stepped in to provide support for the pound, with little impact. Mrs. Thatcher's Conservative government has come under widespread attack for the introduction of a new tax called the community charge next month. Over the last few days, increasingly violent demonstrations have interrupted city council proceedings throughout the country. At the same time, there has been increasing concern over the government's handling of the economy. Despite 15 percent interest rates, inflation, running at an annual rate of 7.7 percent, is expected to climb as high as 9 percent in the next month or two. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Thursday: _ 1.7007 West German marks, down from 1.7015 _ 1.5085 Swiss francs, up from 1.5080 _ 5.75 French francs, down from 5.7525 _ 1.9120 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9164 _ 1,256 Italian lire, up from 1,255.75 _ 1.18 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1792 In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose 0.32 yen to a closing 151.15 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 151.30 yen. Bullion dealers said gold trading was thin as the market waited for the release of the U.S. employment figures and further direction from the dollar. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $400.40 a troy ounce, down from $401.95 bid late Thursday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $399.70. In Zurich, the bid price was $400.40, down from $400.75 late Thursday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $1.29 to close at a bid $400.75. Silver fell in London to a bid price of $5.11 a troy ounce, from Thursday's $5.15.

DOC.HEAD: Sajudis Members Say Vote on Independence Will Come Sunday
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with Sajudis spokesman saying secession vote will go ahead. Pickup 14th graf `Pro-secession...'
DOC.TEXT: Lithuanian nationalists said today their republic's legislature still plans to vote this weekend on whether to secede from the Soviet Union, contradicting an early report that the move had been postponed. Lionginas Vasilyauskas, spokesman for the Sajudis people's movement, said the Supreme Soviet legislature will vote on a declaration of independence Sunday. Sajudis members have a two-thirds majority in the newly elected legislature. He disputed a report by Eduardas Potashinkas, an editor at Lithuanian government-run television, who said the group's governing council had decided to put off the vote at a meeting Thursday night. Potashinkas, who has previously supplied accurate information, said nationalists had dropped plans to vote on a declaration this weekend and instead seek the proclamation ``in the nearest future.'' The Lithuanian parliament is scheduled to meet Saturday, with a secession vote on the original agenda. A vote on a proclamation of independence would bring the Baltic republic into conflict with the Kremlin. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev had warned this week that Lithuania would own the central government about $34 billion in convertible currency for investments made in the 50 years since the Kremlin absorbed the once-independent state. Tass quoted Lithuania's president, Algirdas Brazauskas, as saying such a payment ``would be an extremely difficult task.'' Gorbachev reportedly indicated Moscow may demand Lithuania turn over the port of Klaipeda if allowed to secede, as well as a small section around Drushinikai in extreme south Lithuania. Sajudis, buoyed by its sweeping victories in Lithuania's recent elections, has decided to force the issue of secession, a right granted in theory by the Soviet Constitution to each of the country's 15 republics. Pro-secession sentiment in Lithuania has been swelling for months, but Sajudis moved this week to preempt Gorbachev's plans to introduce a vastly more powerful presidency with the right to crack down on restive republics. The national Congress of People's Deputies is scheduled to meet Monday in Moscow to consider the presidency proposal. The latest Sajudis decision would provide time to work out a compromise between the Kremlin and representatives from republics like Lithuania and Georgia who maintain the new presidency would give Moscow near-dictatorial powers over the republics. National lawmakers were meeting in Moscow today in legislative committees to consider the new presidency, the official Tass news agency reported. Potashinkas said Lithuania's final course of action would be ``tightly linked'' to what kind of powers the Congress confers on Gorbachev. A wave of nationalism has swept through the Baltics, the eastern republic of Moldavia and several southern republics. In December, Lithuania's Communist Party became the first to break away from the central party since the Communists took power in 1917. The national Supreme Soviet legislature is considering a proposed law that would give the republics the right to secede from the union. But settling financial issues is just one of a daunting series of requirements that the republics would have to meet in order to secede.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle Begins Week-Long South American Trip
DOC.NOTE: EDS: LEADS with 3 grafs with Quayle's departure
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle left today for a tour of South America, saying he wants to listen rather than lecture about how the United States can help its hemispheric neighbors with economic development. The vice president's trip revolves around two inaugurations _ Sunday in Chile and March 15 in Brazil. But he also will stop in Venezuela, Barbados, Argentina and Paraguay for talks on Latin debt and trade problems and on President Bush's push to win acceptance for Panama's U.S.-installed government. Quayle departed Andrews Air Force Base outside of Washington shortly after daybreak for the flight to Caracas, Venezuela. In briefing foreign reporters on the eve of his departure, Quayle offered no specifics on what the United States can do to help the Latin countries with their massive debt and inflation problems. He said he wanted to hear ideas on trade and economic development from those countries' heads of state. ``It's very important to solicit their ideas,'' Quayle said. ``At times the United States gets accused, perhaps justifiably so, of lecturing. I'm not visiting Latin America to lecture. I'm visiting Latin America to listen, to get their ideas.'' He said the administration is prepared to turn its attention more to economic affairs in the hemisphere, now that democratic elections have sparked political reform in country after country previously ruled by dictators. ``Political development has been successful in the hemisphere, but we have not been as successful as we'd like on economic development,'' Quayle told reporters. Two countries Quayle will visit, Brazil and Argentina, are among the most severely handicapped economically. Brazil's $115 billion foreign debt is the largest in the developing world. Argentina is beset by demonstrations and strikes resulting from its 8,000 percent inflation rate. There has been little progress, except in Mexico, on the Bush administration's so-called Brady Plan to ease Latin American debt by getting commercial banks to forgive outstanding loans. The other goal of Quayle's trip _ seeking acceptance of the Panamanian government installed when the U.S. invasion toppled Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega _ still faces resistance. Both Chile and Brazil refused to invite Panamanian representatives to their inaugurations. Like other Latin governments, Chile and Brazil condemned the Dec. 20 invasion as a violation of Panama's sovereignty. Many Latin governments contend Panama's President Guillermo Endara needs to gain legitimacy through a vote of Panama's citizens or its congress. But U.S. officials insist that the Latin resentment over the Panama invasion is fading. ``We're moving toward hemispheric-wide acceptance of the Panamanian government, general acceptance. These sorts of things will be worked out,'' said Quayle's press secretary, David Beckwith. He noted Endara's recent call for a vote on proposed changes in the constitution. In Brazil, ``It is likely that the new government will examine the matter in a new light,'' said one Brazilian diplomat, referring to the upcoming inauguration of Fernando Collor de Mello. Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., is accompanying Quayle as part of the U.S. delegation to the Chile inauguration of Patricio Aylwin. Kennedy was a leading critic of human rights violations under outgoing Chilean President Gen. Agosto Pinochet. Quayle will meet with Pinochet, who insisted on retaining control of the country's 60,000-man army even though he will not be president. Nicaragua's outgoing President Daniel Ortega, defeated in Feb. 25 elections by the U.S.-backed candidate Violeta Chamorro, also plans to attend the Chile inaugural. While U.S. officials have refused to meet with Ortega or representatives of his Marxist regime, the vice president now would have no objections to such a meeting, said Beckwith. However, he added that Nicaraguan officials had not sought a meeting. Quayle will remain for only a few hours in Venezuela to meet with President Carlos Andres Perez on regional issues.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Specialists Search Vietnamese Provinces, Examine Remains
DOC.TEXT: U.S. and Vietnamese specialists have searched five northern Vietnamese provinces for information on 12 American airmen missing from the Vietnam War, an official report said. The experts examined remains in Ho Chi Minh City after searching the provinces of Son La, Bac Thai, Tuyen Quang, Hai Hung and Haiphong, the Vietnam News Agency said in a report dated Thursday and seen in Bangkok today. The report did not say whether the experts had found any information about the 12 airmen. It said the Feb. 16 to March 6 project was the ninth joint search for missing U.S. soldiers. Past searhces involved examining plane crash sites and interviewing villagers who witnessed the crashes. A spokesman for the U.S. Embassy in Bangkok earlier said the U.S. team comprised 14 experts from the Joint Casualty Resolution Center and the Army Central Identification Laboratory, both of which are in Hawaii. About 2,300 Americans are rpeorted missing in action from the war, which ended in April 1975 with a Communist defeat of the U.S.-backed South Vietnam government.

DOC.HEAD: Worst Cabbie Surrenders License
DOC.TEXT: A cab driver who had racked up a record 119 rule violations surrendered his license 24 hours before he was to face a judge at a revocation hearing. ``In the future no driver will ever get the chance to approach the level that he reached,'' Jack Lusk, chairman of the city Taxi and Limousine Commission, said Thursday, the same day that Vehbi Gunduz surrendered his hack's license. Under the new policy, a cab driver's license can be suspended after two serious rule violations and revoked after three. And because of a new point system, licenses could be revoked for a lot of little violations as well as a few big ones. Taxi Commission records showed that over the past four years Gunduz insulted, bullied and threatened passengers, dispatchers and inspectors. He overcharged riders, denied them receipts and refused to take them where they want to go. His cab was filthy, his trunk a mess, and his hack license was not prominently displayed. His lawyer defended him by saying, ``He never has attacked a member of the public.'' In surrendering his license, Gunduz agreed not to reapply for one year. If he reapplies, his application would be reviewed by the commission's licensing standards committee, Lusk said.

DOC.HEAD: W. Va. Attorney General Says Strike Illegal, Teachers Can Be Fired
DOC.TEXT: The state attorney general declared West Virginia's first teacher strike illegal, and the governor declined an offer for a 48-hour cooling off period. Attorney General Roger Tompkins Thursday warned teachers they could be suspended for a year, fired or charged with a misdemeanor for walking off the job. Gov. Gaston Caperton turned down an offer by the state Board of Education for a 48-hour cooling-off period for him, the Legislature and teachers. On Wednesday, he said he would not hold talks until teachers return to the classroom and ``calm and reason are restored.'' The strike by the 16,000-member West Virginia Education Association and the 3,000-member West Virginia Federation of Teachers began Wednesday after the collapse of a proposed 5 percent teacher pay raise. Caperton and legislative leaders said they withdrew the offer when the WVEA refused to back down from a strike threat. Teachers on Thursday joined picket lines, blocked bus garages and rallied at the state Capitol. Seven teachers were charged with blocking school buses in Kanawha County, and one picket suffered torn ligaments when she was hit by a parent's car. Despite the attorney general's warning and the governor's hard-line stance, the 16,000-member teachers' union has voted to walk out in at least 40 counties and in six more by Monday if the Legislature fails to vote them a pay raise. The union struck Wednesday in 10 of the state's 55 counties. Tompkins said that teachers have no right to strike and are violating state laws by missing class and picketing schools, which carry misdemeanor charges. He also said teachers who strike can be barred from teaching anywhere in West Virginia for one year. Teachers who have been fired or allegedly resign will be classified as new employees if they are rehired and will have to pay health care premiums, said Sally Richardson, director of the Public Employees Insurance Angency. A key teacher complaint is health care premiums that were imposed in 1988 for newly hired teachers. The WVEA said West Virginia's average teacher pay of $21,904 ranks 49th in the nation, ahead of Mississippi. West Virginia's 22,000 teachers received a 5 percent raise last month.

DOC.HEAD: Blaze Destroys Former Bakker Home
DOC.TEXT: Fire destroyed the former sprawling lakeside home of PTL founder Jim Bakker early today. Fire officials searched the smoldering ruins to see if anyone was inside when the blaze broke out, but neighbors said no one had been seen near the house in the past few days, said Police Officer Russell Case. Two vehicles were parked in the driveway. ``It's just leveled,'' said Patricia Slagle, who lives next door. ``There's really nothing to find. If there had been anybody in the house they just wouldn't have survived.'' The 4,000 square-foot house on Lake Wylie had room-sized closets and an air-conditioned dog house when Bakker and his wife, Tammy Faye, lived there. Robert Rubino bought the home during the PTL bankruptcy proceedings. Rubino was believed to be in New York on business, Case said.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Jets Attack Base in Northern Lebanon
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to ADD that this first raid in the Tripoli region in nearly five years, CORRECTS spelling of Jibril and name of area attacked by Israeli warplanes. Pickup 5th pvs, `It was...'
DOC.TEXT: Israeli warplanes attacked a Palestinian guerrilla base near the northern Lebanese city of Tripoli today in the first raid in the region in nearly five years, the Israeli military command said. Targets were hit that had served as ``launching points'' for attacks on Israel by the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command headed by Ahmed Jibril, a military communique said. The communique gave no details of damage or injuries in the raid on the Khan el-Khiyat area six miles north of Tripoli. It said all Israeli planes returned safely. The communique did not point to a specific attack blamed on Jibril's militia. While Israel frequently attacks guerrilla bases in south Lebanon in retaliation for attacks on or near the Israeli-Lebanese border, the raid in northern Lebanon was unusual. The last in the area was on July 10, 1985, when Israeli jets demolished a headquarters building of the Syrian-backed Palestinian faction led by Saeed Mousa. At least five people were killed and 29 wounded in that air strike. It was the eighth air raid this year by Israeli jets against targets in Lebanon. The last raid was Feb. 23 against a base near the south Lebanon city of Sidon. Lebanese police said it belonged to the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, a Damascus-based Palestinian faction separate from Jibril's force. Last year, Israeli aircraft flew 17 raids on targets in Lebanon, and Lebanese sources reported 28 people were killed in the attacks. Jibril is a former Syrian army captain who founded the radical Popular Front in 1968. The group has hijacked several airliners. In April 1974, three of its gunmen attacked the northern Israeli town of Qiryat Shmona, killing 20 people before they were slain themselves.

DOC.HEAD: Rafsanjani Says Hoax Shows Iran's Importance
With PM-Hostage Hoax, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani said today that the phone hoax in which President Bush thought he was speaking to Rafsanjani but spoke instead to an impostor shows how important Iran is in the world. ``Iran's stature in the world is so high that the biggest bully, the most arrogant nation in the world is engaged in an effort to contact Iran,'' Rafsanjani said in a sermon. The incident ``shows that the U.S. needs to talk to Iran, but with God's grace, it is deprived (by Iran) of this blessing,'' said Rafsanjani. His comments were broadcast on Tehran Radio and monitored in Nicosia. Presidential Spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said in Washington on Thursday that Bush returned a phone call last month to a man he thought was the Iranian president, but it turned out to be a hoax. Bush spoke to the man about the release of U.S. hostages in Lebanon, according to CBS News. Fitzwater would not give details about the conversation. Asked if Bush immediately realized that the voice on the other end of the line was not Rafsanjani, Fitzwater said: ``I can't tell you how we determined it was a hoax.'' The Bush administration has said it believes that Rafsanjani's government has influence with the captors of the eight Americans and 10 other Western captives held in Lebanon. The longest held is Terry Anderson, 42, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, who was kidnapped March 16, 1985. Fitzwater and other White House officials said the bizarre chain of events began when a man identifying himself as an Iranian government official called the White House to say that Rafsanjani wanted to talk to Bush about the hostages. ``The call came in, a number was given for us to call. We were suspicious and began checking,'' Fitzwater said. ``But, ultimately, the president needed to make the call as part of the check. He did make the call.'' Fitzwater said the fact that the call turned out to be a hoax is unfortunate, but that Bush _ who frequently speaks to foreign leaders by telephone _ remains determined to ``talk to anybody, anytime, any place'' to try to gain the release of the hostages.

DOC.HEAD: Tax Protesters Attack Police, Loot, Burn Thatcher Effigy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to ADD Mrs. Thatcher's comments today, comment from opposition legislator. Further explains how tax works. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Crowds angered by a new tax battled police, looted stores, paraded effigies of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and hurled bottles and eggs in protests across Britain. Dozens of people were injured or arrested. Mrs. Thatcher today blamed a leftist group known as Militant Tendency for the violence Thursday night that left the main street in the London borough of Hackney strewn with glass. ``As you know, it is not the way to conduct affairs at all,'' she said during in appearance in Glasgow, Scotland. ``Any conduct intimidating or violent is absolutely contradictory to democracy.'' There have been four straight nights of violence against the new ``community charge,'' which replaces the system of taxing homeowners to pay for government services. Instead, municipal councils now divide the costs of services equally among all adults in their district. Charges can vary widely, depending on the level of services provided by a district. And since each adult is taxed, it means two people living in a two-room apartment would pay twice as much as one person living next door in an eight-room house. Anger over the system has sent the Conservatives' popularity plunging to its lowest level in its decade of rule. Local legislators in the district of Haringey met today to discuss their district's tax, which at $974 is one of the highest in the country. During a meeting of the council Monday night, demonstrations outside turned violent, and police had to clear shouting protesters from the spectator section. Tony Benn, an opposition Labor Party member of Parliament, said, ``This is the first major civil disobedience campaign since the suffragettes demanded the vote before the First World War.'' The most serious unrest occurred Thursday night in Hackney, east London, where 5,000 protesters gathered outside the city hall. About 300 police guarding the building charged the crowd when members of it began hurling bottles and cans and attacked a police car. Police said they made 57 arrests. They said about 30 officers and an unspecified number of protesters were injured. Police Commander John Purnell said about 200 people broke away from the main crowd and rampaged through a Hackney shopping mall, hurling trash cans through windows and looting up to 50 stores. Protesters at Hackney carried placards reading ``Break the Tory poll tax,'' ``Smash poll tax'' and ``Can't pay won't pay.'' The Labor Party and other opponents have dubbed the community charge the poll tax, after a similar per capita tax that caused a rebellion in medieval times. At Camden in north London, protesters at City Hall screamed insults at council members as 400 others blocked the road outside. A crowd of about 400 jeered council members arriving for a meeting at Ealing in west London. Police in Swindon, 70 miles west of London, linked arms to form a human chain to stop 1,000 protesters from forcing their way into the council chamber. People in the crowd there carried effigies of Mrs. Thatcher with a noose around her neck and set one of them on fire to loud cheers. At Hull in northeast England, security men ejected 50 demonstrators who screamed abuse at council members. Protesters at Dudley in central England threw eggs at council members and attacked a policeman. The new tax takes effect April 1 in England and Wales, when local districts must submit to the federal government their annual charges. The average household paying about $830 a year under the former system will pay about $1,100, the Chartered Institute of Public Finance Accountants says. Low-income and disabled people can receive rebates of up to 80 percent. But critics say that apart from this, the new tax is unfair because it takes no account of an individual's ability to pay. The community charge is already in force in Scotland amid widespread protest there. Northern Ireland has its own separate system for funding local authority spending. Mrs. Thatcher's intention in changing the tax system was to show voters that local Labor-controlled districts were spending more than Conservative-run districts. But critics say the government miscalculated the cost of local services, and some Conservative-controlled authorities are among those imposing the highest charges. In latest opinion polls, the Conservatives trail Labor by up to 19 points ahead of the next general election due by mid-1992.

DOC.HEAD: Two Germanys Start Preliminary Unification Talks In East Berlin
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with 24 parties to compete in elections. Pickup 4th pvs, `On Wednesday...'
DOC.TEXT: The two Germanys today began preliminary unification talks, preparing for next week's meeting with the four World War II allies on German unity. Ernst Krabatsch, East Germany's deputy foreign minister, was meeting with Dieter Kastrup, head of the political department at West Germany's Foreign Ministry. They declined to comment to reporters. The election commission, meanwhile, said 24 political parties will contest East Germany's first free elections on March 18, the ADN news agency said. Commission spokeswoman Petra Blaess said the final list includes the Communists, now renamed the Party for Democratic Socialism; the Social Democrats; the liberal Free Democrats; and the Alliance for Germany, a conservative coalition backed by West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democratic Union. East Germany's 12.2 million eligible voters will seat a new parliament with 400 members, 100 less than the current People's Chamber. Today's discussions are part of the so-called ``two-plus-four'' formula of unification negotiations agreed to in Ottawa last month. Under that formula the two German nations are to discuss the domestic aspects of unification. On Wednesday in Bonn, the two Germanys are scheduled to meet with low-level officials from the four World War II victors _ the Soviet Union, the United States, Britain and France _ for initial talks on how unification would affect European security and the concerns of other nations. While the talks come barely a week before March 18 elections that are expected to remove East Germany's Communist government from power, the East Berlin government is carrying out the dialogue with the approval of 15 other parties. The four World War II powers have given their blessing to the idea of German unification, but enormous problems need to be overcome. One of the thorniest stems from Moscow's insistence that a united Germany not be a NATO member. Kohl on Thursday reassured NATO members in Brussels of West Germany's wish for the new country to remain in the Western alliance. ``We will continue talks on all levels. Nobody need fear Germany will go its own way,'' he said. In addition, Poland on Thursday reiterated its demand for a role in the talks, despite a vote by West Germany's Parliament that a united Germany should honor Poland's western border. About a third of Poland was German territory before World War II. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl had come under fire abroad and at home for his previous reluctance to unequivocally state that a united Germany would never lay claim to land ceded to Poland after the Third Reich's 1945 defeat. Kohl, apparently trying to avoid offending conservative voters before federal elections in December, had insisted only the government of a united Germany could address the matter. The two Germanys have formed the front between NATO and the Warsaw Pact for over 40 years, and a united Germany would be a colossal country of over 76 million inhabitants in strategically important central Europe. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl favors allowing East Germany's states simply to join up with their western neighbor, which would be permitted under the West German constitution. That would be the quickest route to German unity. But opposition to this means of unification has been raised in both German states, and Moscow has voiced its concern as well about a hasty unification.

DOC.HEAD: Gov't Begins Indirect Dialogue With Moslem Separatists
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to UPDATE with march in Pakistan. Pickup 7th pvs, `Fernandes arrived...'; Delete last graf to conform.
DOC.TEXT: The government said today it has begun indirect talks with Moslem separatists in Kashmir, acknowledging the independence movement has reached an ``unprecedented point.'' ``We have a tough job here, but I would say I am meeting the right people through intermediaries,'' said George Fernandes, the Railways Minister who was selected by the government to lead efforts to quell the secessionist movement. ``It is too early to say what shape the dialogue will take, but at least the process has begun,'' he told reporters in a Srinagar hotel. Asked what message he had sent the militants, Fernandes said: ``We have conveyed the government of India's stand on the issue.'' He did not elaborate. The independence campaign in India's Kashmir valley has left at least 173 people dead since Jan. 20 in confrontations between security forces and the militants. There were no immediate reports of violence in Kashmir today. Across the border in Pakistan's Kashmir region, hundreds of demonstrators marched near the frontier today and demanded that residents of Indian Kashmir be allowed to decide their future. A protest leader, Sultan Mohamood, promised arms and training for the Indians. Mohamood is leader of the Azad Muslim Conference, a small opposition party in Pakistani Kashmir. The campaign for an independent Kashmir dates to the 1947 partition of the Indian subcontinent into Hindu-dominated India and Islamic Pakistan, which each ended up with a portion of Kashmir. India and Pakistan have fought two wars over the region. Fernandes arrived in Srinagar, the largest city in the valley and the focal point of the agitation, on Thursday with a 14-member delegation of political leaders who included former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi and Deputy Prime Minister Devi Lal. The other members of the delegation returned to New Delhi today, but Fernandes remained, apparently to begin talks with the militants. It was not clear which of the militant organizations Fernandes had contacted, and there were no signs from any of the groups that they had been approached. Kashmiri Moslem groups have said they will not settle for anything less than total independence. ``The mood of the people is very obvious,'' Fernandes said when asked his perception of the situation. ``The campaign for secession has reached an unprecedented point.'' Earlier Thursday, authorities tightened the already strict curfew. Unlike previous days, authorities in Srinagar did not relax the curfew this morning to enable residents to shop for food and other essentials. Jammu-Kashmir state Gov. Jagmohan, the top administrator for the region, said there would be no easing of curfew restrictions ``in view of the tension'' arising from the delegation's visit. On Thursday, about 40 residents invited to meet with Gandhi became unruly and blamed his 1984-89 government for the troubles in the mountainous northern state, where a lingering movement for secession from Hindu-majority India has escalated in recent months. Also, thousands of Moslems inside mosques shouted Islamic slogans and demanded independence as the convoy carrying the delegation drove past Thursday. Moslems make up 64 percent of Jammu-Kashmir's 6 million people. Most of the Hindus live in the plains of Jammu, but a small minority reside in the Kashmir valley. Gandhi's mother, former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, was a Kashmiri Hindu.

DOC.HEAD: Police Blame Arsonists for Fire in Taiwan Legislature
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with details on legislature fire, second fire at university also blamed on arsonists. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A fire broke out in the national legislature today and damaged several reception rooms. Police blamed activists who want Taiwan to drop its claim to be China's legitimate government. Police said the early-morning blaze, which was put out in 15 minutes, started in one of the reception rooms and may have been caused by firebombs. Nearby, police discovered a fence had been painted with the slogan: ``Burn Chinese pirates to death. Strive for Taiwanese Independence,'' and ``Bloodbath Taiwan.'' The references were apparently to elderly members of the Yuan, Taiwan's highest lawmaking body. The members were elected on the Chinese mainland shortly before 1949, when the Nationalist government fled to Taiwan after losing a civil war to Communist forces. The aging legislators, who dominate the body, have remained in office to support the ruling Nationalist Party's claim to be the sole legitimate ruler of China. Last month, the opposition called on them to retire. Many opposition members want the Nationalists to give up their claim to be the legitimate government of China and recognize Taiwan as a separate, independent country. Less than an hour after the legislature fire, a blaze occured at the faculty dormitory at National Taiwan University. Police said similar slogans were discovered painted on the building's door and they suspected that the fire was set by the same arsonists. The blaze was quickly extinguished and no major damage reported. No one claimed responsibility for either fire.

DOC.HEAD: Margarine Heiress Sentenced to 14 Years in Prison, Fined $20,000
DOC.TEXT: An heiress to the Mrs. Filbert's Margarine fortune has been sentenced to 14 years in federal prison and fined $20,000 for running a cocaine trafficking operation from her estate. Under federal guidelines, Sandra Filbert Amos could have been sentenced to a maximum 17 years and fined $4 million at Thursday's hearing. But U.S. District Judge Joseph C. Howard said Amos was ``already financially ruined.'' She was also sentenced to three years' probation. ``I've really made a mess of my life,'' a tearful Amos, 35, told Howard. ``I used drugs to live and I lived to use drugs. My life was controlled by drugs. I was totally powerless,'' she said. ``I am certainly sorry for being here today and I am certainly remorseful.'' Amos, who inherited $2 million, had spent $1,200 a week in cocaine to support her 10-year cocaine addiction, the judge said, referring to trial testimony. She was convicted Nov. 9 of one count of conspiring to distribute 50 kilograms of cocaine and two counts of cocaine distribution. Amos had helped her boyfriend, Jeremiah Dennis Case, set up the drug operation from her $750,000 home near Easton, according to testimony at her trial. Case, who pleaded guilty to drug charges in the case, was earlier sentenced to 14 years in prison and was not fined. Amos' co-defendant, Guillermo Moran of New York, was convicted of the same charges and sentenced to 19 years and fined $100,000. The operation included a cocaine network and scheme to transport 440 pounds of cocaine from Florida to New Jersey for a Colombian cocaine trafficking organization headed by Moran, according to trial testimony. Amos completed 90 days at Excel Inc. Drug-Free Treatment Center and has kept in touch with her counselor, court records show. Her attorneys, Donald Feige and Russell T. White, had already filed an appeal and will request at a hearing Monday that Amos be released on an appeal bond. Amos was returned to the Volunteers of America, where she is participating in a federal work-release program.

DOC.HEAD: IRA Claims Responsibility for Killing, Bomb Defused in West Belfast
DOC.TEXT: The Irish Republican Army today claimed responsibility for the slaying of a Protestant truck driver who delivered construction materials to police stations and military installations. Also today, police defused a two-pound bomb found in an empty house in the Roman Catholic section of Belfast, authorities said. An IRA unit in East Tyrone said its members shot Thomas Jameson, 40, Thursday. They said his employers had repeatedly ignored warnings to stop working for the security forces. The IRA is fighting to drive the British out of Northern Ireland and to unite the area with the Irish Republic. It has targeted construction firms to prevent repairs to the bomb damage it inflicts on security installations. Two other employees of the company where Jameson worked have been killed in IRA attacks. Jameson was identified as a part-time soldier in the Ulster Defense Regiment, a locally recruited reserve force that supports the police and army in Northern Ireland. But he was killed because of his work with the building firm, said IRA supporters quoted by Press Association, Britain's domestic news agency. Police said Jameson was driving a concrete mixer when men armed with machine guns killed him outside Donaghmore village, 40 miles west of Belfast. The gunmen fired at least 30 shots before driving off in a car, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Two Women Charged with Execution-Style Slaying of Marine Corporal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New material, editing throughout
DOC.TEXT: Two women face first-degree murder charges in the execution-style slaying of a Marine Corps corporal who was investigating an embezzlement scheme involving the squadron that flies the president's helicopter, authorities say. Markeithia Reeves, 24, of Suitland, Md., and Tanya Morton, 23, of Arlington, Va., were charged with killing Corporal Estella Pearson, 26, of Detroit, according to Prince William County police. The victim's body was found in her car Monday night at a shopping center. None of the people involved in the case had ``access or clearance'' for sensitive information or for the helicopters serving President Bush, said presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. Reeves, who worked with the victim at the Quantico Marine Base, was charged with first-degree murder. Morton, a civilian employee with the Navy Department, also was charged with first-degree murder. The Washington Post and The Washington Times reported today that Pearson was investigating an embezzlement scheme, said to involve payment of travel funds for trips that were not made. ``We can confirm that the possible motive the (Naval Investigative Service) is investigating is embezzlement engaged in by the two suspects and their attempt to silence Cpl. Pearson, who may have been in the process of uncovering them,'' Sgt. Marv Price told The Washington Times. Reeves has admitted being involved with the slaying of Pearson, according to a criminal complaint filed with a magistrate by Prince William County police. Reeves ``lured the victim...from the Marine Corps Base ... with the intent to kill her,'' the complaint said. Reeves admitted firing the gun while seated in the victim's car, the document said. Morton admitted taking part in the embezzlement scheme with Reeves and ``was aware that Cpl. Pearson was investigating that same embezzlement,'' according to a criminal complaint obtained by the Post. Pearson lived in the barracks at the Marine base and worked in the base's administrative offices for the helicopter squadron. Pearson was shot while sitting in her car, Prince William Police Sgt. Barry Bernard said. Her body was discovered by passersby. Reeves was being held without bond and Morton was being held on $25,000 bond in Prince William County. Preliminary hearings were scheduled for April 3 in Prince William County General District Court.

DOC.HEAD: Widespread Protests in Haiti Over Killing of Schoolgirl
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with new demonstrations, government official saying Avril not planning to resign, details, tightens. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ Hundreds of people, some throwing rocks, blocked streets in the capital today on the fourth day of protests triggered by the army's killing of a schoolgirl. The normally bustling Port-au-Prince, a city of 1 million, was virtually deserted this morning, with schools and stores closed. Protesters blocked all main streets, and rocks were thrown at cars on the seafront. On Thursday, thousands of people demonstrated in the capital and several provincial towns, setting fires and calling for the resignation of Haiti's military leader, Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril. Three people were killed in the protests Thursday, including a soldier beaten to death by a mob, independent radio reports said. Fifteen people were injured in clashes with soldiers, according to witnesses and a doctor at the state hospital in Port-au-Prince. The government has made no comment on the unrest, but a high-ranking government official said today that Avril has no plans to resign. ``Avril is ready to make concessions, but a hasty departure is out of the question,'' said the official, speaking on condition he not be further identified. He gave no indication what concessions were contemplated. Avril indicated Wednesday he would resign if it was ``the will of the people'' but said that would cause ``revolution and chaos.'' The protests were triggered by the killing of 11-year-old Rosaline Vaval Monday in the town of Petit Goave, where 10,000 mourners attended her burial Thursday. Radio Lumiere, a Protestant radio station, said today that a mob went on a rampage in Petit Goave, a town of 15,000, on Tuesday night, burning an army outpost, ransacking a government building and the mayor's house. In Gonaives, a western port city of 40,000, mobs plundered the house of Mayor Alexandre Louissaint, a Baptist pastor, and ransacked his church and a government building, according to a resident who spoke anomously. Earlier, about 3,000 people, shouting ``Liberty!'' and slogans against Avril, marched on the Presidential Palace in Port-au-Prince. Soldiers then fired in the air and beat demonstrators with billy clubs. ``The will of the people is for Avril to step down,'' said a communique released Thursday night by a coalition of 11 opposition parties that earlier had called on Haitians to rise against the military government. The marches in the capital and at least five provincial towns are reminiscent of demonstrations in November 1985 to protest the army's killing of three high school students in Gonaives. Those protests led to the downfall of dictator Jean-Claude Duvalier, who fled to exile in France in February 1986. Avril, a former Duvalier aide who came to power in September 1988 in a coup led by rank-and-file soldiers, has been under increasing pressure from opposition groups to resign. President Bush mentioned Haiti on Thursday while attending a ceremony in Fort Myer, Va., marking the U.S. invasion of Panama. ``The revolution continues,'' Bush said. ``The people have spoken in Nicaragua. When they speak in Cuba and Haiti, our Western Hemisphere will be entirely within the compass of freedom.'' The opposition in Nicaragua, backed by the United States, defeated President Daniel Ortega and his ruling Sandinistas in Feb. 25 elections. After taking power, Avril promised elections and reforms but shipped seven pro-democracy leaders into exile during a crackdown in January and arrested more than 50 opposition activists, some of whom were beaten in custody. Although Avril has promised to hold elections this year, many Haitians don't believe he can be trusted to hand over power to a civilian government. In November 1987, the first free general elections since independence from France in 1804 were canceled after attackers protected by soldiers massacred at least 34 voters. Most Haitian parties have vowed to boycott the elections unless Avril first steps down. They want a Supreme Court justice to replace him until voters choose a new leader. Students and government critics had called for a national day of mourning Thursday in sympathy for the 11-year-old girl, shot by a soldier breaking up an anti-government demonstration. Maj. Gen. Serge Saint-Eloi, the inspector general of the army, said Thursday night the girl was shot by a soldier from a passing vehicle but said an investigation would not be conducted because her parents buried her before an autopsy could be done.

DOC.HEAD: Fourteen Inmates Escape From Jail With Smuggled Hacksaw
DOC.TEXT: Fourteen inmates, including three facing murder charges, escaped from jail by cutting steel window bars with smuggled hacksaws and sliding down knotted bedsheets, sheriff's officials said today. ``We don't know how it was masterminded but our investigation shows there was outside help,'' Assistant San Diego County Sheriff Ken Wiggington said at a news conference today. Two of the inmates involved in Wednesday night's breakout were recaptured. ``Two hacksaws were used to break out the bars over the window, then inmates used bedsheets knotted together to lower themselves to the ground,'' Wiggington said. The inmates evaded perimeter guards and security cameras, and Sheriff's Capt. Charles Wood said today that the jail's alarm system is defective and wasn't working at the time of the escape. Wood, commander of the South Bay Detention facility, said the hacksaws were smuggled in through an unprotected window in a day area used by inmates during recreational periods. The inmates had been housed in a section of the jail reserved for serious felony offenders. In December, seven inmates escaped through a tiny window after lubricating their bodies with lotion and lowered themselves 80 feet to the ground with a bedsheet rope. Three remain at large from that escape, sheriff's officials said. That breakout was from a section which housed 123 inmates in space designed for 24.

DOC.HEAD: Moderate Earthquake Rattles Alaska; No Damage or Injuries
DOC.TEXT: A moderate earthquake measuring 5.5 on the Richter scale shook wide sections of south-central Alaska early today, but there were no immediate reports of any damage or injuries, officials said. The quake was centered about 60 miles northwest of Homer, said Alec Medbery of the Alaska Tsunami Warning Center. ``It was felt all the way from Kodiak Island to Anchorage, Palmer and Seward,'' Medbery said. ``But it was too small for a tsunami,'' a sea wave generated by a quake. The 1964 ``Good Friday'' Alaska earthquake that measured 8.5 on the Richter scale generated large waves that devastated several coastal communities, including Valdez, and killed 131 people as far south as Oregon and Hawaii. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. Every increase of one number means a tenfold increase in magnitude. Thus, a reading of 7.5 reflects an earthquake 10 times strong than one of 6.5. An earthquake of magnitude 3.5 can cause slight damage, 4 moderate damage, 5 considerable damage, and 6 severe damage.

DOC.HEAD: Aoun Urges Peace Talks, Drops Opposition to Arab League Plan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to UPDATE with Moslem clashes, Israeli raid. Pick up 3rd pvs, `Aoun described...'
DOC.TEXT: After more than a month of savage fighting, Gen. Michel Aoun called today for peace talks with a rival Christian warlord and with Moslem leaders to settle Lebanon's civil war. In an unusually conciliatory statement, Aoun said there will be no more clashes among Christians or between Christians and Moslems. He also dropped his rejection of an Arab League plan intended to end 15 years of civil war. In another development, police said rival Shiite Moslem militias loyal to Syria and Iran clashed in south Beirut and south Lebanon. No casualties were reported. A police spokesman said Syrian troops moved in and disengaged Shiite zealots of the pro-Iranian Hezbollah, or Party of God, and fighters of the mainstream Shiite Amal, or Hope, militia in south Beirut's seaside district of Ouzai. The firefight blocked traffic for 30 minutes along the coastal highway which links west Beirut with south Lebanon, the spokesman said. In south Lebanon's Iqlim el-Tuffah province, the two factions dueled intermittently with howitzers and mortars, the spokesman said. Also, Israeli warplanes attacked a Palestinian guerrilla base near the northern Lebanese city of Tripoli in the first raid in the region in nearly five years, the Israeli military said. It made no mention of any casualties. Aoun described as ``self-destructive'' the clashes between his troops and Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces militia, which have killed more than 750 people since they broke out Jan. 31. Aoun called on Geagea to declare his ``readiness for dialogue so we can meet. ``Once two people manage to meet, they can invite others,'' Aoun said in an invitation to non-Christian leaders to join in discussions for a settlement to the civil war. His statement appeared in the daily An-Nahar. The Arab League plan, which shifts some political power to Lebanon's Moslem majority, was worked out by Lebanese legislators in the Saudi Arabian town of Taif in October. ``Abrogating the Taif accord is not necessary to launch dialogue,'' Aoun told the independent daily, though he added that he would like some amendments. He did not elaborate. He originally rejected the accord because it did not include a fixed timetable for the withdrawal of Syria's 40,000 troops, in Lebanon under a 1976 Arab League peacekeeping mandate. Aoun had rejected the parliamentary election of President Elias Hrawi, who pledged to implement the peace plan. Aoun had refused Hrawi's order to step down as army commander and leave the Presidential Palace. Aoun's 19,000 army troops and Samir Geagea's 6,000-member Lebanese Forces militia fought each other to a standstill in a power struggle for the 310-square mile Christian enclave before accepting a cease-fire on Saturday. Police said the cease-fire was generally holding despite minor exchanges of sniper fire in some districts of east Beirut. A mediation committee of three independent Christian figures was holding a series of meetings separately with Aoun and Geagea in an effort to stabilize the truce, reopen all roads blocked by mines and barricades and disengage the combatants before starting a discussion on a political settlement. Aoun and Geagea are Maronites, the Catholic community which has dominated political life in Lebanon since 1943. The Taif accord called for distributing government posts and parliamentary seats equally among Moslems and Christians.

DOC.HEAD: Collision Between Tug and Freighter Closes Mississippi River
DOC.TEXT: A tugboat and a freighter collided today on the Mississippi, sinking at least three grain barges and setting loose up to 14 others, the Coast Guard said. A 20-mile stretch of the river was closed as tugs worked to round up the stray barges, said Petty Officer Bob Morehead. ``I'm told it looks like a river rodeo with tugs chasing barges all over the place,'' he said. No injuries were reported. ``Right now we're just trying to get the barges under control and then we'll investigate what happened,'' Morehead said. The freighter Nancy Lykes was headed upriver at 6:30 a.m. when it and the tug Coral Dawn, headed downriver with up to 30 barges of grain, collided near White Castle, 20 miles south of Baton Rouge, the Coast Guard said. Coast Guard Capt. William Loesfstedt ordered the river closed in both directions while the barges were rounded up and investigators assessed the hazard posed by the sunken barges. Morehead said he didn't know what the freighter was carrying and that it did not appear to be leaking. The Nancy Lykes is owned by Lykes Brothers and the Coral Dawn is owned by the Archer Daniels Midland Co. of Illinois.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING TO FIX TYPO IN SLUG
IRA Claims Responsibility for Killing, Bomb Defused in West Belfast
DOC.TEXT: The Irish Republican Army today claimed responsibility for the slaying of a Protestant truck driver who delivered construction materials to police stations and military installations. Also today, police defused a two-pound bomb found in an empty house in the Roman Catholic section of Belfast, authorities said. An IRA unit in East Tyrone said its members shot Thomas Jameson, 40, Thursday. They said his employers had repeatedly ignored warnings to stop working for the security forces. The IRA is fighting to drive the British out of Northern Ireland and to unite the area with the Irish Republic. It has targeted construction firms to prevent repairs to the bomb damage it inflicts on security installations. Two other employees of the company where Jameson worked have been killed in IRA attacks. Jameson was identified as a part-time soldier in the Ulster Defense Regiment, a locally recruited reserve force that supports the police and army in Northern Ireland. But he was killed because of his work with the building firm, said IRA supporters quoted by Press Association, Britain's domestic news agency. Police said Jameson was driving a concrete mixer when men armed with machine guns killed him outside Donaghmore village, 40 miles west of Belfast. The gunmen fired at least 30 shots before driving off in a car, police said.

DOC.HEAD: White House, Reagan Phone Burned Boy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout with police now saying bully told boy to take drugs, not necessarily crack, incident happened in basement, not garage, changes reference to boy to David sted Aupont throughout, UPDATES with David's companions being robbed by bully. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Former President Reagan was one of more than 100 callers offering birthday wishes to a critically injured boy who was beaten, bound and set aflame after refusing a neighborhood bully's order to take drugs. David Aupont spent his 12th birthday Thursday fighting for his life, with doctors giving him a 50-50 chance of survival following the vicious attack in an abandoned building. The 13-year-old charged with Wednesday's attack was described as a foster child with learning disabilities who dropped out of the sixth grade, and whose vicious behavior grew out of his own torment at the hands of older children. The White House and Mayor David Dinkins were among those who showered the badly burned David with cards, gifts, balloons, flowers and messages, said New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center spokeswoman Diana Goldin. Three people sent teddy bears, and Brooklyn Borough President Howard Golden sent a radio. None of the callers could speak with the boy. Reagan said he would call back when David recovers, said Goldin. The youth, who suffered burns over 55 percent of his body, was under heavy sedation in critical but stable condition, said Dr. Cleon Goodwin, head of the hospital burn unit. He should be hospitalized for up to four months and undergo skin grafts to repair the second-degree burns over much of his body. ``He's a fighter,'' Goodwin said. ``If you ask him if it hurts, he says, `No,' even when we know it does. He's tough.'' David was walking to school with five friends Wednesday when the assailant approached, said Detective Joseph McConville. Two of the boys fled but the 13-year-old robbed the remaining three. He then took David to a basement in an abandoned apartment building, doused him with gasoline and told David he would set him aflame if he did not take drugs, McConville said. David, his hands tied behind his back, was beaten with a baseball bat and set aflame while tied to a sewer pipe. He managed to escape and ran to an auto repair shop for help. Originally, police thought the attack occurred in a garage, but later attributed that report to a bloodhound's false tracking. Luther Aupont, David's father, told reporters he had spoken with his son but started crying and could not continue. David, a clean-cut boy who attended the sixth grade, is ``a normal kid. He got along with kids,'' said his stepbrother, 22-year-old Rudy LeBrun. The Auponts moved to New York from Port-au-Prince, Haiti, about 18 months ago. The suspect was charged with attempted murder second degree, assault first degree, kidnapping second degree, robbery and attempted robbery, said police spokesman Hugh Barry.

DOC.HEAD: Polish Leaders Come To France To Talk About Germany
DOC.TEXT: President Wojciech Jaruzelski and Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki of Poland arrived in Paris today to seek French backing for stronger border guarantees from a united Germany. In talks with President Francois Mitterrand, the Polish leaders are expected to stress their country's desire to play a prominent role in discussions later this year between the two Germanys and the four allied powers _ the United States, France, Britain and the Soviet Union. The Poles have been particularly concerned about West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl's vague statements on the permanence of the border with Poland, a stance Kohl changed only this week. On Thursday, the West German Parliament passed a resolution proposed by Kohl stating that the two German nations should adopt declarations saying ``the Polish people are assured (that) their right to live in secure borders will not be questioned by us Germans through territorial claims either now or in the future.'' Those declarations, Parliament said, should be the basis for a future treaty signed by a newly united Germany. ``This change is a tiny step in the right direction,'' Jaruzelski was quoted as saying in an interview published today by the Paris daily Liberation. ``There is a Polish proverb that says that one spoonful of tar is enough to ruin a barrel of honey,'' he said. ``Everybody knows that tactics must serve strategy and not the other way around. It seems that the (West German) electoral tactic dominated the strategy of historic reconciliation between our peoples.'' Officials from the four allied powers are to meet for preliminary unification talks with the two Germanys on Wednesday. Poland has been pressing to participate in the talks. The Polish president noted in the newspaper interview that Poland had participated in the Potsdam conference in 1945 and was present during the talks that set the present Oder-Neisse border between Poland and East Germany. ``Today, the Soviet Union supports the Polish demand to participate in the conference on German unity and I must say that it would be incomprehensible for us if France, a traditional friend of Poland, did not share this position,'' Jaruzelski said. Today's trip marked the first joint foreign visit by Jaruzelski, a Communist, and Mazowiecki, a Solidarity activist who became prime minister after the 1989 elections that catapulted a coaltion led by the trade union into power. Asked if the double visit had a special significance, Jaruzelski said it did. ``We wanted, in fact, to make two points in this visit,'' Liberation quoted Jaruzelski as saying. ``On the international level, to stress the importance Poland attaches to the German question (and) on an internal level, to show the very constructive character of political cohabitation in Poland on all the essential questions.''

DOC.HEAD: Doi Re-Elected to Head Largest Opposition Party
DOC.TEXT: Takako Doi was re-elected today to head the Japan Socialist Party, the country's largest opposition group, and expressed hope the party will be able to end the Liberal Democrats' 35-year rule. Ms. Doi, 61, was the only candidate for the post. She will begin her third two-year term when her election is endorsed at the party's congress April 3-5.
