Ms. Doi told a news conference she will focus her efforts on developing the Socialist Party into a force capable of taking over the leadership of the country from the conservative Liberal Democratic Party. Ms. Doi, a veteran lawmaker, became the first woman ever to head a major political party in Japan 3{ years ago when the Socialists were crushed in a lower house election and her predecessor resigned. ``I first hesitated to run for the chairmanship because I thought it's an appropriate time to step down,'' she said after her election. But Ms. Doi changed her mind after finding that no one else would run for the top job. Ms. Doi's popularity helped lead her party to an unprecedented victory in July in the upper house of Parliament. That forced the Liberal Democrats into a minority in the chamber for the first time. In the election last month for the powerful lower house, the Socialists made substantial gains, winning 136 seats in the 512-seat chamber. They previously held 83 seats.

DOC.HEAD: Canals Dry Due to Accumulated Mud
DOC.TEXT: The Venetian canals, lifelines of this lagoon city, are dangerously low largely due to accumulated mud, officials said today. While the Grand Canal and several other major waterways are open to navigation, traffic on scores of smaller canals has come to a halt this week. A city fireboat burned out its motor after getting stuck in the mud in one canal, the Milan newspaper Corriere della Sera reported. ``The canals have not been dug up in 40 years, and that is the main problem,'' said an official from the city's waterworks. Last month, a man who suffered a heart attack was taken through the streets in a baggage cart to the hospital because the ambulance corps feared their boat would get stuck in the mud, Corriere reported.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Seeks International Funding to Resettle South African Exiles
DOC.TEXT: Nationalist leader Nelson Mandela called on the international community today to provide funds to resettle thousands of exiles who plan to return to South Africa. ``We will need tremendous resources to find jobs and accomodations for thousands of exiles and political detainees'' still held in South African jails, the African National Congress leader said. ``We rely on the international community, particularly the African states, to provide the required resources,'' Mandela added. Mandela, 71, was the world's best-known political prisoner until South Africa freed him last month and legalized the ANC guerrilla group as a step toward possible white-black negotiations. The ANC estimates there are 15,000 political exiles living throughout Africa who may return to South Africa now that the ANC and several other anti-government groups are legal. Mandela interrupted a visit to Tanzania to fly to Addis Ababa for the speech in the ornate Africa Hall of the Organization of African Unity. Afterward, he returned to Tanzania to complete his scheduled six-day visit with a tour of ANC guerrilla training camps in the East Africa nation. He will leave for Sweden on Sunday. Mandela said he had received military training in Ethiopia before he was arrested in 1962 for illegally leaving South Africa. He was subsequently sentenced to life in prison for sabotage and treason. The government commuted that sentence last month. Mandela plans to travel to Sweden next week. A spokesman for Sweden's Foreign Ministry, Lars-Olof Lundberg, said today that Mandela has asked to cut two days off his planned weeklong visit. He gave no reason for Mandela's request, but the Swedish news agency TT said Mandela was concerned with unrest in South Africa's black homelands and a warning from the white-led South African government that it might intervene with emergency powers to end the violence. More than 20 people were killed this week in clashes between homeland authorities and groups demanding reincorporation into South Africa, and in factional fights over local issues in black townships in South Africa. The ANC named Mandela deputy president last week, making him the effective leader of the organization. ANC President Oliver Tambo, once Mandela's law partner in South Africa, entered a Stockholm clinic in January after suffering a stroke. Mandela was expected to spend considerable time visiting Tambo.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Who Lost Senses of Sight, Smell and Taste Awarded $3.7 Million
DOC.TEXT: A woman who claimed she was blinded and lost her senses of taste and smell because of injuries suffered when a truck ran her off a freeway has been awarded $3.7 million. ``Under the circumstances, we thought the award appropriate,'' said Arthur Tiddle, foreman of the Pomona Superior Court jury that handed down the judgment Tuesday. Elaine Fleishman, a 61-year-old mother of five who used to be a part-time nanny, now attends the Braille Institute in Rancho Mirage, her attorney, Amy C. Fisch, said Thursday. The jurors found negligence on the part of the truck driver, Robert G. Meyer, 66, his employer, Road West Express, and the company that held the trucking permits, Roadex Inc. An off-duty police officer testified he saw the truck move right and strike a pickup, then swerve to the left and strike Ms. Fleishman's car.

DOC.HEAD: Dead Horse Buried on the Spot _ in the Middle of the Street
DOC.TEXT: Two horses loose on a street were killed by a truck and a city crew was sent to remove the carcasses. But the workers found that one horse had already been buried _ on the spot in a median strip. ``Believe me, after 18 years in this business, this is one of the most bizarre things I've ever seen,'' Ulysses Ford, head of the city's Solid Waste Management Department, said Friday. ``To be honest with you, it would be unlikely for anybody to do this. I don't know why someone would do this,'' he said. ``I just can't imagine their purpose.'' Ron Blackwell said that when he arrived at work Thursday at an auto parts store he noticed a dead horse lying in the middle of the median on the street and a second dead horse across the street. Blackwell said he called the city health department and then the solid waste department. He said he and co-workers next saw a crew show up with digging equipment in yellow trucks bearing round emblems. ``They dug a hole and buried him and left,'' Blackwell said. ``I mean this is a full-grown horse. It'd stand 16 hands high at the shoulder. I'll tell you, I ain't never seen nothing like that before in my life. ``They come out with equipment and dig a hole in the middle of this esplanade out here and bury that horse. Right in the middle of the street out here. I've been in 48 states and three countries, and I ain't never seen _ not even in the uncivilized countries do they bury a horse in the middle of the road.'' Ford said some city departments, not including his, have yellow trucks with round emblems. But, he said, no one has been able to determine who buried the horse. ``There are several different public agencies that could have been involved _ state, county or city,'' he said. A private contractor or utility company could also have performed the deed, he said. Ford said his workers later removed the second horse to a landfill and his department is coordinating with the city's parks department to remove the buried horse. Dewey Senegal said the horses were kept on his land in far southern Houston and wandered into the road after someone apparently left a gate open.

DOC.HEAD: Japan-Cambodia Phone Service Resumes After 15 Years
DOC.TEXT: Telephone service from Japan to Cambodia resumed Friday after a 15-year cutoff, according to KDD, Japan's largest international telecommunications company. Service, which is routed through Moscow, will be available 24 hours a day, but customers will have to wait an average of one to two hours after placing their calls through an operator, a KDD official said. KDD was able to restore telephone service between the two countries after a new shortwave telephone link went into service late last year between Moscow and Cambodia, said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Calls will cost $19 for the first three minutes and $3.20 for each extra minute, he said. Telecommunication service between Japan and Cambodia was cut near the end of the Vietnam War in 1975, the official said.

DOC.HEAD: 6-Year-Old Turns in Gambling Father
DOC.TEXT: A 6-year-old Shanghai boy has won praise for informing police that his father was gambling, according to a local daily. Shanghai's Liberation Daily, in a Thursday report seen in Beijing on Friday, said Wang Leyi appeared at a police station last week to report that his father was playing mahjongg and ask police to ``go and take care of the situation.'' When asked by police who had sent him, the kindergarten pupil said, ``gambling is bad and I came on my own to report him.'' The report said police went to the boy's home, found the adults of the family gambling while playing mahjongg, and ``educated'' the father. The boy, on returning home, said, ``I was the one who asked the `uncle policeman' to come.'' Police and neighbors gathered to watch the scene smiled when he said this, and Wang's father and the other adults were moved by his actions, the newspaper said. They said he had done the right thing and promised to stop. Children in China are commonly told to report wrongdoings, and it is not uncommon for children to win praise for turning in relatives. There were a few reported cases of relatives turning in student activists in hiding after the military crackdown of the pro-democracy movement last spring, although in general the public was unresponsive to government demands they help track down dissidents.

DOC.HEAD: White House Says Bush Knew Caller Might Be Imposter
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts graf 6, Bush brushed, Bush brushes off questions. Editing to tighten.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush knew a caller claiming to be Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani might be an impostor but spoke with him ``on the off chance'' it might signal a breakthrough for U.S. hostages, the White House said today. ``The president's feeling was: what if it's real? I want the American people to know, and the families of the hostages to know that I am willing to check out every possibility,'' said presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. Fitzwater conceded that the phone conversation that occurred last month was an embarrassment since it turned to be a hoax. But, he added, ``This phone call is just another reminder of the fact that we will pursue every lead we can get.'' He also said the episode reflects the frustration the administration faces in its efforts to find ways to press for the release of the eight U.S. and 10 other Western hostages being held in Lebanon. Fitzwater said the administration still does not know who initiated the hoax and could not rule out the possibility that it originated within a faction of the Iranian government. Bush brushed off reporters' questions about the phone call during an event in the Rose Garden, declaring: ``Said it all.'' It apparently was a reference to statements by Fitzwater and other administration officials. Meanwhile, Rafsanjani said in a sermon broadcast on Tehran radio that ``Iran's stature in the world is so high that the strongest power in the world, and the greatest power on Earth, is striving to find an opening with your executive leader even through telephone wires.'' ``Can it be that such a global power, with all its intelligence capabilities, talks to a person it cannot identify?'' he asked. ``This is a strange occurrence.'' ``This shows the United States very much needs to talk to Iran, but, with God's grace, it is deprived of this blessing,'' he said. ``Now we must wait for explanations and witness another Irangate in the making, God willing,'' Rafsanjani said, referring to the ill-fated effort by the Reagan administration to trade arms for the release of hostages. Fitzwater, asked about Rafsanjani's statement, said it ``reflects the difficulty of the situation: One day we hear moderate points of view, the next day we hear antagonistic ones.'' ``So our position remains steadfast: we want to do everything we can to get the hostages out. The president will talk to anyone, any time,'' Fitzwater said. He and other White House officials said the bizarre chain of events began when a man identifying himself as an Iranian government official called the White House to say Rafsanjani wanted to talk to Bush about U.S. hostages held in Lebanon. Fitzwater said today that, in view of the ``unorthodox manner'' Iran has used for communicating with the West in the past, ``any communication from the leadership of Iran has to be treated differently.'' ``This call came in. It was suspicious in origin,'' Fitzwater said. Officials said there were two calls _ the initial one and a second one during which Bush talked with the impostor. Fitzwater said Bush was ``willing to make this call on the off-chance that it might be real.'' Fitzwater later was vague on whether the second call was placed or received by the White House, saying he didn't want to get into such details. The initial call came to national security adviser Brent Scowcroft, White House aides said. The episode was first reported Thursday by CBS News. Eight Americans, including Terry Anderson, the chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, and 10 other Westerners are being held hostage in Lebanon. The Bush administration contends Rafsanjani's government has influence with those holding the hostages. The disclosure of the hoax came amid a flurry of recent reports on hostage-related developments. However, U.S. officials have said they are unable to cite any actual movement toward freeing the hostages. Although he was tricked once, Bush would do the same thing again if he thought it would help win the release of the hostages, his spokesman said. ``If a call came through at some future point that we believed was real, he would take it,'' Fitzwater said. ``The president has made it known he's willing to talk to Iran at any time. And the ball is in their court. So it's up to them to signal a willingness to talk.'' Fitzwater said the administration has let Rafsanjani know ``through diplomatic channels as well as publicly, that we're willing to talk whenever they're ready. And they have come back and said, `we're not ready'.'' Fitzwater declined to go into details of Bush's conversation with the unknown caller. CBS said the president ``repeated U.S. policy that goodwill will beget goodwill but there could be no quid pro quo for U.S. hostages,'' CBS said.

DOC.HEAD: Railways Vice Minister Ousted For Taking Bribes
DOC.TEXT: A vice minister of railways has been ousted for allegedly taking bribes, becoming one of the highest-ranking officials toppled in a nationwide campaign against corruption, the government said Friday. Luo Yunguang, who had been vice minister since 1986, was the fifth Railways Ministry official accused of corruption in the past six months. The official Xinhua News Agency said Luo ignored corruption by his aides, and personally accepted a gold ring, a refrigerator and the equivalent of $465 in bribes. It did not say what he did in return for the bribes. He has returned the money and the ring, it said, and prosecutors are looking into the case. He has not yet been legally charged. Luo ``seriously discredited the reputation of the Railways Ministry and had a vile political influence,'' state TV said. Top leaders ordered a nationwide offensive against official corruption last summer, after watching student pro-democracy protesters win massive public support in large part because of their demands for clean government. In recent years, gift-giving has become an essential part of most official applications, with bribes ranging from a bottle of liquor for a scarce ticket to cash for a passport or an apartment. The government set up special hotlines for reporting corruption, and offered leniency to people who confessed. By year's end it said it had received reports of more than 216,000 cases and had dealt with more than a quarter of them. However, many Chinese remain cynical about the government clean-up efforts, noting that most of those charged are lower level officials and that no children of high officials have been charged even though several are engaged in questionable trade activities. Other high officials charged include Hainan Gov. Liang Xiang, accused of helping family members in illegal profiteering schemes, and the vice chairman of the Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region, Tohti Sabir, accused of taking bribes. Liang is widely believed to have been targeted because he was an ally of ousted Communist Party chief Zhao Ziyang. Xinhua said the State Council, China's Cabinet, ordered Luo to hand over all his illegal income, and will continue to investigate his activities. The party is conducting its own investigation, it said. Four Railways Ministry officials, including the director of the ministry's Transportation Department and his three aides, were accused in October of taking bribes to allocate rail cars for transporting goods. The demand for cars far exceeds supply.

DOC.HEAD: Five Killed, Five Injured in Rebel Attacks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with more attacks today, casualties. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Leftist rebels attacked army positions in the eastern and northern parts of the country today, and the military said at least five people were killed and five injured in fighting. An army news release said guerrillas mounted a pre-dawn attack on an army post guarding the Oromontique coffee processing plant at Santiago de Maria, a town 75 miles east of San Salvador in Usulutan province. The rebels withdrew after a six-hour gun battle, during which one rebel and three government soldiers were killed and three soldiers were wounded, the news release said. A Red Cross spokesman said an unspecified number of civilians were also wounded during the gun battles but could not give immediate details. Police in the town said the coffee plant was damaged. Coffee and cotton are El Salvador's main export crops. Another soldier was killed and two were wounded in scattered attacks early today in three towns in the northern and eastern parts of the country, a second news release said. It provided no details. On Thursday night, guerrillas attacked a power station and at least four army posts in the northern part of San Salvador, causing brief electrical outages, military sources said. The intense fire and occasional explosions during the night startled residents, but the armed forces press committee said no deaths or injuries were reported in the attacks in four densely populated northern sectors of the city. The areas also were the scene of heavy combat during a major offensive in November by the leftist Farabundo National Liberation Front. ``We do not have much information. We know they attacked guards at the Miralvalle electrical substation and army positions in Ayutuxtepeque, San Ramon, Escandia and Plan de Pito,'' an army spokesman said by telephone. Army troops moved through the area and military helicopters and planes dropped flares onto suspected rebel positions. The army spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity, said troops were patrolling the northern neighborhoods and other parts of the city ``to avoid more terrorist harassment.'' In a statement, the guerrillas said the attacks were part of a concerted campaign to show President President Alfredo Cristiani's rightist government they still have enough military power to inflict damage. The FMLN guerrillas are thought to face potential supply and command problems following the defeat of the lefits Sandinista party in Nicaragua's elections. The Sandinistas have said they will give way to the United National Opposition on April 25, when President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro takes office. The statement broadcast by the rebels' clandestinate Radio Venceremos indicated the campaign was aimed at forcing Cristiani's government into negotiations to end to decade-old civil war that has claimed more than 71,000 lives, most of them civilian. ``The FMLN is once again on a military campaign to show the armed forces, the Cristiani government and all other interested parties that it is willing to seek a negotiated solution to the conflict, but it is the fascists who continue to cling to the idea the FMLN is weak because of what is happening in other countries,'' the statement said.

DOC.HEAD: Precede OPHIR, Alaska
Mushers Reach Halfway Point; Silver Ingots Go to Leader
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with mushers reaching halfway point. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Lavon Barve won $3,000 in silver ingots and the halfway trophy at this wilderness checkpoint, more than a half-hour ahead of defending champion Joe Runyan in the 18th annual Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race. Barve arrived at the official halfway checkpoint at 10:57 p.m. Runyan was followed by three-time winner Susan Butcher, Dee Dee Jonrowe, Robin Jacobson, Martin Buser, Rick Swenson, the Iditarod's only four-time champion, and Tim Osmar. Seventy teams left Anchorage last Saturday to compete in the 1,160-mile endurance run across mountains, wind-swept rivers, Arctic Ocean ice and treeless tundra. The silver ingots awarded the first musher to reach the official halfway point have become something of a jinx. Only once since the race was organized in 1973 has the winner of the halfway money held on to win the race. The Iditarod, named for a tiny ghost town along the route, commemorates the 1925 emergency delivery by dog teams of life-saving diphtheria serum to Nome. The race in past years has taken from 11 to 18 days to complete.

DOC.HEAD: 30 Injured in Student Demonstration
DOC.TEXT: Police used tear gas and steel-tipped truncheons Friday to break up students protesting an Islamic conference in the northern town of Bogra, and at least 30 people were injured, news reports said. The protesters were demonstrating against controversial Moslem leader Maulana Belwar Hossain Saidi, who was due to speak at the conference at Bogra, 100 miles north of Dhaka, according to the independent United News of Bangladesh. The protesters complain that Saidi opposed the 1971 war in which Bangladesh gained independence from Pakistan. Saidi, a central leader of Moslem fundamentalist Jamaat-e-Islami, denied the charge. After the clash, the authorities banned the gathering of more than four people in public, and the conference did not take place, the news ageny said.

DOC.HEAD: Another Customer for Caller ID
With AM-Hostage Hoax Bjt
DOC.TEXT: That fellow who pretended to be Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani on the other end of the telephone has done a lot of damage to the American republic. He's going to make it hard for George Bush to conduct his presidency. Everybody knows of Bush's penchant for working the telephones, calling up and taking calls from other world leaders. Now that he's been stung, how will Bush know when a caller is real or an impostor? This is the way things might go in the Oval Office ... Ring-ring. ``Hello?'' ``George! This is Mikhail.'' ``Yeah?'' ``Yeah. I just wanted to let you know about some big changes here.'' ``Big changes?'' ``Yeah. We're going to let private citizens own factories.'' ``Who'd you say this is?'' ``Gorby, George. We've decided to let Lithuania go free. And we had elections in the republics. Most of the commies got beat bad. And, George, we're not raising any objections if the Germans unite.'' ``Hey, listen, buddy. Are you one of those impostors? I don't have time _ '' ``George! Don't hang up again! I want you to know we're thinking of cutting off Fidel. That ingrate is costing us millions! And _ George _ you know that fellow Gephardt in Congress says you should give us some foreign aid. That's a splendid idea!'' ``Listen, buster, I don't know who you are, but I want you to know I don't appreciate you phonies.'' CLICK. Ring-ring. ``George Bush, here.'' ``George, this is Danny!'' ``Danny. Wait a second. I thought I just sent you to South America.'' ``No, no, this is Dan Ortega, Mr. President.'' ``Oh, sure.'' ``Yeah. I just want you to know that we admit Mrs. Chamorro beat us fair and square. We don't mind the millions of dollars you gave her. I guess we were fooled by those Yankee polls that showed we couldn't lose.'' ``Who is this?'' ``Ortega, Mr. President. Just wanted to say, no hard feelings.'' ``Get off my phone, you doggone fake!'' CLICK. Ring-ring. ``Yeah?'' ``George, this is Dick Nixon.'' ``Oh, sure.'' ``Yeah, I just happened to be in town, thought I'd give you a call.'' ``Dick Nixon, huh?'' ``Yeah. I just briefed Republicans up on the Hill. And had a press conference. And, you know, not a single reporter asked me about Watergate!'' ``You expected me to believe that?'' CLICK! ``I don't know who these impostors are, but they sure must think I'm gullible. Guess I'm going to have to get Caller ID.''

DOC.HEAD: Upper West Side Named Historic District
DOC.TEXT: The city has declared a 17-block chunk of the Upper West Side a historic district, a move that would preserve hundreds of distinctive row houses and apartment buildings. ``In this constantly and rapidly changing city, it is crucial to protect the best of our architectural heritage or else it will disappear,'' Manhattan Borough President Ruth Messinger said before Thursday's vote by the Board of Estimate. The new Riverside-West End Historic District includes 265 row houses and apartment buildings reflecting the Beaux-Arts, Renaissance, Gothic and Romanesque styles. The buildings were constructed between 1884 and 1939. The designation means the facades of buildings cannot be altered without permission from the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission. At a hearing held in 1987, 62 of 71 speakers favored the designation. Those who disagreed, for the most part, were property owners who said the designation might hurt them by forcing them to pay for expensive restorations instead of less expensive repairs. In addition, they said the designation might prevent them from developing or selling their properties. The area runs from Riverside Drive between West 85th Street and West 95th Street, over one block east to West End Avenue between West 87th Street and West 94th Street. It also includes some parts of blocks between West End and Broadway.

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Bus Hit by Bullets; No Injuries
With PM-Greyhound Strike
DOC.TEXT: A Greyhound bus carrying 29 passengers was struck by at least three bullets fired from a passing vehicle early today in central Ohio, police said. No injuries were reported, and there were no arrests. The driver was from another bus company who is driving for Greyhound during a nationwide bus drivers strike against the Greyhound Lines Inc., said company spokeswoman Elizabeth Hale. The State Highway Patrol said the shooting on Interstate 71 in Madison County, about 25 miles southwest of Columbus, at 12:40 a.m. A vehicle passed the bus, allowed the bus to pass and then pulled alongside the bus. The vehicle's driver turned off the headlights and shots were fired from the vehicle, the highway patrol said. ``One shot glanced off the left side driver's window, one shot glanced off the left passenger's window, and one shot struck and lodged in the lower middle body of the bus,'' said Kathy Kral, a spokeswoman at the patrol's Wilmington post. ``The vehicle then sped away.'' The bus driver went to a truck weighing station and stopped to report the shooting. The bus continued another 40 miles to Cincinnati, where police and company officials examined the vehicle. The passengers were transferred to another bus to complete the trip from Cleveland to Louisville, Ky., Ms. Hale said from Greyhound's Dallas headquarters. She declined to identify the driver. The strike began early March 2 when the Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions and the company failed to reach agreement on a new three-year contract. Greyhound has been operating at reduced levels since the strike, using replacements hired and trained in the last two weeks plus any union members who cross picket lines.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rules Colombian's Extradition Legal
DOC.TEXT: A judge has ruled that a Colombian believed to be a high-ranking member of the Medellin drug cartel was legally extradited to the United States to face drug conspiracy charges. U.S. District Judge Thomas R. Brett also ruled that prosecutors would not be required to reveal the names of their witnesses or details of expected testimony until 48 hours before the trial. Brett cited security reasons. Jose Rafael Abello-Silva of Santa Marta, Colombia, is charged with two counts of conspiring to import drugs. He was extradited Oct. 29 from Bogota to Tulsa, where he was indicted in 1987 on drug charges. Prosecutors say Abello is the fourth-highest member of the Medellin drug cartel. Defense attorneys Patrick Williams and Richard Haynes had claimed Abello's extradition violated a 1979 treaty between Colombia and the United States. Brett's order, made Wednesday and released Thursday, maintained Abello was extradited under guidelines of a decree signed in 1989 by Colombian President Virgilio Barco Vargas that provides for extradition of suspected narcotics traffickers. Abello's trial has been scheduled to begin next week, but was postponed Thursday until March 21 because Haynes was tied up with a trial in California.

DOC.HEAD: Countries Pledge Cooperation, Consider Good Neighborliness
DOC.TEXT: Officials of the six Balkan countries pledged Friday to promote cooperation in the region in their first meeting since radical change swept Eastern Europe. Senior diplomats from Albania, Bulgaria, Romania, Turkey, Yugoslavia and Greece spent three days assessing their efforts ``to consistently promote the process of multilateral and bilateral cooperation,'' they said in a statement. ``They stressed that the work already done should be continued and the momentum of multilateral Balkan cooperation should be maintained,'' the statement said. Delegates reviewed progress since their foreign ministers first met in Belgrade in February 1988. Balkan foreign ministers are due to meet again in Tirana, Albania, in October, the statement said. In 18 lower-level meetings in the last two years, the countries have decided to cooperate in the fields of economy, trade, industry, technology, tourism, railways, health and environment. They have also discussed forming a joint front against terrorism and arms and drug trafficking in the Balkans, which form a bridge between the Middle East and Europe. During this week's meeting, Albanian Deputy Foreign Minister Mohamet Kaplani proposed a charter on principles of good neighborliness, the statement said. The proposal was one more step in isolationist Albania's opening toward its neighbors. Its ruling Communist Party decided in February to improve relations with other European countries. Stalinist Albania's participation in the Belgrade meeting in 1988 was hailed as a first step in breaking out of its isolation. Earlier this year, Albanian officials accused Yugoslavia and Greece of spreading unfounded reports of demonstrations in Albania, apparently inspired by those which toppled Europe's other Communist regimes. Delegates also discussed a proposal on freeing the Balkans of nuclear and chemical weapons, and suggested that more talks be held, the statement said. The Balkan states remain seriously divided over the treatment of minority groups that overlap their borders. They also belong to rival military alliances: Greece and Turkey are NATO members, Bulgaria and Romania belong to the Warsaw Pact, and Yugoslavia and Albania are independent. Greece is the only member of the European Community in the Balkans.

DOC.HEAD: Military Announces Plan to Expand Role in Drug War
DOC.NOTE: EDs: UPDATES throughout with additional detail; adds byline
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon today announced plans to expand its role in the Bush administration's war on drugs by deploying a wide array of warships, aircraft and communications equipments in the Atlantic, Pacific and Caribbean. ``We will act swiftly, methodically and in accordance with our nation's laws and traditions,'' Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said in a prepared statement. Stephen M. Duncan, Cheney's coordinator of drug enforcement policy, told a news conference the plan, as developed by regional commanders, would cost nearly twice the $450 million appropriated by Congress for Pentagon anti-drug efforts this year. He said the services would have to ``cough up out of their hide'' the extra funds. The administration has asked Congress to approve $1.2 billion in Pentagon spending on the drug war next year. Duncan said the new strategy does not give the Defense Department any new missions in the drug-interdiction effort, but amounts to ``substantially more of the same'' kinds of actions the military has been performing in recent years. ``We're not going to become a law enforcement agency,'' Duncan said. Duncan outlined the following plans for increasing military action in the drug war: _The U.S. Atlantic Command this year will use four or five Naval ships daily expressly for tracking and stopping the flow of drugs in international waters in the Caribbean and Atlantic. It previously had none dedicated to this use. It also will increase its use of Airborne Warning and Control Systems, or AWACS, aircraft. The Atlantic Command's use of ships in the drug war will increase this year by 78 percent over 1989, as measured by days at sea. Aircraft use, as measured by flight hours, will increase by 219 percent, Duncan said. _The U.S. Atlantic and Pacific commands each plan to use more than eight classes of aircraft and six classes of ships for the drug-interdiction strategy. The aircraft include E-2 Hawkeyes, P-3 Orions, F-4 Phantoms and F-14 Tomcats. Ships include destroyers, frigates, guided missile frigates, guided missile destroyers, aircraft carriers, patrol hydrofoils and a variety of amphibious and logistic support ships. _The North Atlantic Aerospace Defense Command will use a network of 44 ground radars designed to warn of high altitude penetrations of U.S. airspace. It also will increase its patrol of the U.S. southern border and coasts by using AWACS aircraft and 50 interceptor alert aircraft positioned at 25 locations nationwide. _All Pentagon anti-drug operations will be coordinated by the Forces Command at Fort McPherson, Ga. Absent from the list of military actions is a proposal to operate a U.S. naval flotilla off the coast of Colombia in search of drug smugglers. In the wake of the U.S. invasion of Panama, Colombian leaders balked at the proposal, which they said amounted to a ``blockade.'' President Bush then withdrew the plan.

DOC.HEAD: Collision Between Tug and Freighter Closes Mississippi River
DOC.TEXT: Tugboats on Friday worked to round up as many as 14 runaway grain barges, closing a 20-mile stretch of the Mississippi, the Coast Guard said. ``I'm told it looks like a river rodeo with tugs chasing barges all over the place,'' said Petty Officer Bob Morehead. There were no reports of injuries. The barges got loose after a tugboat and a freighter collided. The freighter Nancy Lykes was headed upriver at 6:30 a.m. when it collided with the Coral Dawn, which was headed downriver towing as many as 30 barges carrying grain. At least three barges sank after the collision, Morehead said. The freighter did not appear to be leaking, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Italian Communists Seek to Avoid Perils to Unity
DOC.TEXT: Italian Communists who have resolved to create a new party focused Friday on how to achieve that goal and avoid the perils it poses for their unity. Party leader Achille Occhetto has the votes he needs at the party's extraordinary congress for the approval of his proposal to revamp the party, a move that is expected to lead to a change of its name and the elimination of its hammer and sickle symbol. But former party leader Alessandro Natta, one of the ``old guard'' communists who led the campaign against creating a new party, cautioned Occhetto and his followers not to take steps that would split the West's largest Communist Party. Those who oppose the change will not estrange themselves from the party, said Natta, but ``neither will they tolerate being put aside.'' Although Occhetto controls almost 67 percent of the 1,092 delegates, he still needs to negotiate with the impassioned minority that fought against his proposal. Occhetto's proposal was sprurred by the collapse of communism in eastern Europe and by his party's steady decline in both membership and electoral strength. The Communists nearly came to power in 1976 when they won 34 percent of the vote, but they dropped to about 27 percent in the last parliamentary elections in 1987. Occhetto hopes a new party formation can help reverse the membership and electoral slides, bring the party into the mainstream of European socialism and challenge the domination of the Christian Democrats and their allies in Italy by uniting the country's fractured political left. But the entire plan could backfire if Occhetto only succeeds in splitting his party of 1.4 million members. His opposition has come from the old guard emotionally tied to ther name and symbol and from young members who want a more militant party _ one that would, for example, oppose Italy's membership in NATO. ``I have said that it would not displease me if ours remained the only party in the world to call itself communist,'' Natta told the delegates. ``The fight involves political questions and the most relevant of these is the fate of the party. A change is possible but there is no need to lower our flag,'' argued Natta. ``We in the minority believe that the Italian Communist party has in itself the reasons, the resources and the capacity for a renewal that will allow it to confront, in this historic phase, the demands for the struggle for democracy and for the alternative (to the Christian Democrats),'' Natta said later. While the plan to revamp the party is assured, the shape of that new party and its name are uncertain. That will be left to the party leadership, to be elected Sunday, who then will present their proposals to another party congress for approval. The battle lines between Occhetto and his opponents at the congress are drawn in committee rooms, where delegates are considering the makeup of the leadership that will draft the proposals for that next congress. Occhetto and his allies want to create a new executive body in the party to streamline the decision-making. His opponents, who have seen their numbers increase in the 300-member Central Committee, want to keep the party structures as they are. One possible compromise would give Occhetto the new executive body but one in which the ``no'' forces would still have a voice. Occhetto's allies repeatedly have stressed to the congress they want to avoid any split in the party, but that they understand the risks and want the direction of the new party to be determined by all the members. ``We must decide to assume the responsibility of a courageous, exceptional political initiative. None of us underestimates the difficulties and the risks,'' said Giorgio Napolitano, an old guard Communist who has supported Occhetto. In building the new party, said Napolitano, ``we must do our work but in a free and open way. We need the support of everyone.''

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: Lots of kids like to take their wheels and go cruising late at night, but they usually start at a later age than Candy Lewis' 3-year-old son. Police officer Jeff Lacey said he was riding on patrol at 3:45 a.m. Friday in the rural southwestern Ohio community when he spotted the boy riding his tricycle. The tyke, who was not identified, had gotten up, dressed himself and pushed a wooden table against the front door of his mobile home so he could reach the latch and let himself out, Lacey said. ``He was just riding around,'' the officer said. ``He'd been down a couple of streets and had gotten lost.'' Lacey took the boy back to the police station. A few hours later, a panicked Ms. Lewis telephoned police to report that her child was gone when she awoke. Police promptly reunited the boy with his mother. They did not release his name.

When people have too much cash on hand they take it to a bank. But what does a bank with too much money do? New England banks with money to burn send those megabucks to the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston. The reserve bank's primary function is to be a banker for other New England banks _ lending money to those that need it and storing funds for those with excess cash, said Edward A. Romkey, an assistant vice president of the bank. It also detects filthy lucre _ worn and dirty bills _ and takes them out of circulation. New England banks usually have too much cash during the ski season, summer vacations and Christmas, he said. ``Any time currency use is up, counterfeiting is up. Counterfeiters have seasons, too,'' Romkey said. He said the bank sends 200 to 300 fake bills daily to the Secret Service. The cash that arrives from New England banks is fed into eight Currency Verification and Counting System machines, which process 72,000 greenbacks hourly. The machines scan the back of each bill much like a supermarket scanner reads a bar code and decide whether it is real and in good enough condition to go back into circulation. Clean bills get counted and shrink-wrapped. Worn, torn and soiled bills _ about $1 million worth daily _ are shredded into confetti and handed out to bank visitors.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Complicates Israeli Consideration of Peace Talks
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS two grafs after 6th graf pvs, That suggests, with Fitzwater comment today; picks up 7th graf pvs, A twice-postponed
DOC.TEXT: An unprecedented statement by President Bush opposing the settlement of Soviet Jewish refugees in East Jerusalem could make it more difficult for the Israeli Cabinet to approve U.S. proposals for Mideast negotiations this weekend. By coupling East Jerusalem with the West Bank and Gaza as off-limits to settlers, Bush appeared to question Israel's retention of the predominantly Arab part of the city. All week, U.S. officials have danced around Bush's statement, insisting there is no change in U.S. policy on Jerusalem or on the West Bank and Gaza. They voiced approval of Jews living in both the predominantly Jewish and mostly Arab parts of the city. But many questions were left unanswered. In fact, new questions were raised. A White House statement on Jerusalem on Monday, for instance, said U.S. policy ``backs the right of Jews as well as others to live there in the context of a negotiated settlement.'' That suggests Jews, who have lived in Jerusalem for more than 3,000 years, need Arab acquiescence to remain in the older part of the city. On Friday, White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater, having tried all week to persuade reporters there was no change in policy, admitted: ``There are some words you can't use in describing this policy and some words you can use.'' The spokesman insisted ``there is no special motivation'' behind the president's words. ``There was no special purpose or attention there.'' A twice-postponed showdown in the Israeli Cabinet is now set for Sunday when the cabinet takes up a formula by Secretary of State James A. Baker III that has split the conservative Likud and the dovish Labor parties. Baker's goal is to have Israelis meet with Palestinians in Cairo as the first step toward settlement. ``Without a dialogue between Israelis and Palestinians we can never move forward to peace,'' he said Tuesday. Baker's formula tries to bridge differences between Israel, on the one hand, and Egypt and the Palestine Liberation Organization, on the other. It would permit a Palestinian Arab resident of East Jerusalem and one or two Palestinians deported by Israel from the West Bank to participate in the talks. But Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and other leaders of the Likud coalition are worried that might clear a way for the PLO to dominate the agenda. Labor, on the other hand, is impatient to proceed with negotiations. Amid this political debate, first Baker and then Bush made statements that stirred controversy in Israel and may have hardened Likud's resistance to the U.S. formula. Baker told a House subcommittee last week the administration wanted assurances a U.S. $400 million housing loan guarantee would not be used to settle Soviet Jewish refugees on the West Bank. Only about 100 of the thousands of Jews who have poured into Israel have been settled on the West Bank. But their presence is taken by the Arabs as evidence that Israel does not intend to relinquish the territory. Baker's thrust at Shamir's settlement program irritated the prime minister. And members of both Likud and Labor were upset by Baker's statement at the same hearing that there is no evidence PLO chairman Yasser Arafat is violating his December 1988 renunciation of terrorism. Then, at a news conference Saturday in Palm Springs, Calif., the president weighed in with a statement opposing new settlements on the West Bank or in East Jerusalem. His intention may have been to discourage Israel from expanding East Jerusalem to its suburbs and to settle Soviet Jews there. That would have been consistent with longstanding U.S. policy against further Jewish settlements on the West Bank as an obstacle to Mideast negotiations. But Bush, by linking East Jerusalem and the West Bank, may have had something else in mind: that he considers East Jerusalem occupied territory and Jews living there as settlers, as well. The President had not been asked about East Jerusalem, and his statement upset Israelis who see the predominantly Arab part of their capital and the West Bank as completely different. Many Israelis would surrender most of the West Bank as part of a peace agreement with the Arabs. But very few would be willing to relinquish any part of their capital. In more than two decades of U.S. diplomacy, Jerusalem and the West Bank have been approached as separate issues. Jerusalem is touchier, and American presidents and secretaries of state have tried to keep their distance, usually by saying ambiguously that the city should never be divided again _ and not saying whether Israel ought to retain exclusive control over Jerusalem. Bush's statement is a problem, then. The White House and State Department tried on Wednesday to soften its impact by asserting support for Jews living in Jerusalem and insisting U.S. policy on the city and on the West Bank had not changed. Maybe it has and maybe it hasn't. That depends on what Bush has in mind. But gaining Israel's approval Sunday of Baker's formula for negotiations is now tougher than ever.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Barry Schweid has covered U.S. Mideast diplomacy for The Associated Press since 1973.

DOC.HEAD: Hong Kong, Taiwan Entertainers Set U.S. Tour for China Rights
DOC.TEXT: Popular singers from Hong Kong and Taiwan will perform in six U.S. and Canadian cities in May to mobilize the support of North American Chinese for human rights and the pro-democracy movement in China, tour sponsors said Friday. The ``Concert for Democracy in China 1990'' tour will begin May 1 in Vancouver, British Columbia, and will include appearances in Los Angeles, San Francisco, New York and Toronto before ending May 12 at the Kennedy Center here. The tour is sponsored by the North American Coalition for Chinese Democracy as part of worldwide observances of the first anniversary of the Beijing government's massacre of pro-democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square last June 4. Alex Wai of the Federation of Overseas Hong Kong Chinese in Washington, one of the coalition's six North American tour sponsors, said former Beijing student activist Wuer Kaixi will speak at each concert. The list of entertainers includes singers Tayu Lo from Taiwan and Maria Cordero, Deenie Ip, Cally Kwong, Tina Liu, Lowell Lo and Danny Summer from Hong Kong. All are donating their services, Wai said. Ticket sale proceeds from the Washington concert will be given to the Tiananmen Memorial Foundation in New York and to the 40-member Washington federation for its human rights activities, officials said.
DOC.HEAD: rma
Police Seeking Motive in Shooting Spree; One Victim Dies
DOC.TEXT: Police say a man who fired at 10 people apparently picked his victims at random as he drove around the city. A newspaper delivery man who was shot in the head died today and seven others were injured. Police did not know what provoked the shooting spree Thursday morning. ``It's just a completely senseless, random shooting,'' Police Lt. Mike McKenna. ``This was an unprovoked attack on each of these individuals.'' William F. Brown, 41, died today at HCA Wesley Medical Center. An employee of The Wichita Eagle, Brown was shot as he was stocking a coin-operated newspaper box outside a restaurant. Police surrounded the gunman's red Volvo and arrested him after he pulled into a fast-food restaurant. Police found a bomb and a fresh carcass of a goose in the suspect's car. The bomb was later detonated. McKenna said the man, who had not been charged, was sent to a hospital for a mental evaluation. He said there had been several complaints about the man's violence in the past. There were at least 10 shooting incidents in east Wichita in a little more than an hour starting around 4:30 a.m., McKenna said. Two people were hit by bullets and the rest by flying glass, police said. Lee Bunch was heading for work when he noticed a red Volvo with its bright lights on following close behind. At an intersection, Bunch said, he looked toward the driver. ``He had a revolver pointed at my head. I took off and he followed me ... The bullet hit my left rear window and passed through and blew out my right passenger window,'' Bunch said. ``I believe it just missed my head.''

DOC.HEAD: Quayle Arrives for Talks with Venezuelan President
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 8 grafs new with today's talks; also CORRECTS that Venezuela has already announced improved relations with Panama, contrary to comments of U.S. officials earlier that announcement would be today; picks up 8th graf pvs, The countries
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of Venezuala and Spain urged Vice President Dan Quayle today to press for rapid disbanding of the Contras, saying Nicaragua's Sandinista government should be trusted to give up power, U.S. officials said. Quayle stated the U.S. position that the Contras should disband but that their security must be ensured first, said a U.S. official who spoke on condition of anonymity. In what one official called ``kind of a rolling summit on Nicaragua,'' Quayle's talks with Venezuelan President Carlos Andres Perez came between Perez's meeting yesterday with incoming Nicaragaun President Violeta Chamorro and Saturday's arrival in Caracas of outgoing President Daniel Ortega. They are disacussing how a peaceful transfer of power can occur with the Sandinistas still in control of the 70,000-man Nicaraguan army and the Contra rebels massed at the Honduran border. Spanish Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez also met with Quayle and Perez today. He was in Venezuela en route to Chile. More talks on Nicaragua were expected when Gonzalez takes Ortega and Perez and Costa Rican President Oscar Arias to Sunday's Chilean inaugural, the U.S. official said. Quayle's aides had said the Perez talks would focus on President Bush's push to gain acceptance for the U.S.-installed governmment in Panama. But the morning's talks were solely on Nicaragua. U.S. officials said Perez has been helping diplomatically to influence other South American nations to accept the government of Panamanian President Guillermo Endara. Perez, following Endara's March 1 announcement that he would hold a vote on the Panamanian constitution, said he would normalize relations with Panama. Venezuela was joined by Colombia, Argentina, Peru and Ecuador in moving to accept Endara's government. The countries that remain to be convinced include Brazil, Uruguay, Mexico and Chile. Quayle, whose trip also will include attendance at inaugurations Sunday in Chile and Thursday in Brazil, left shortly after daybreak today from Andrews Air Force Base outside of Washington. In briefing foreign reporters on the eve of his departure, Quayle offered no specifics on what the United States can do to help the Latin countries with their massive debt and inflation problems. He said he wanted to hear ideas on trade and economic development from those countries' heads of state. ``It's very important to solicit their ideas,'' Quayle said. ``At times the United States gets accused, perhaps justifiably so, of lecturing. I'm not visiting Latin America to lecture. I'm visiting Latin America to listen, to get their ideas.'' He said the administration is prepared to turn its attention more to economic affairs in the hemisphere, now that democratic elections have sparked political reform in country after country previously ruled by dictators. ``Political development has been successful in the hemisphere, but we have not been as successful as we'd like on economic development,'' Quayle told reporters. Brazil's $115 billion foreign debt is the largest in the developing world. Argentina is beset by demonstrations and strikes resulting from its 8,000 percent inflation rate. There has been little progress, except in Mexico, on the Bush administration's so-called Brady Plan to ease Latin American debt by getting commercial banks to forgive outstanding loans. The other goal of Quayle's trip _ seeking acceptance of the Panamanian government installed when the U.S. invasion toppled Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega _ still faces resistance. Both Chile and Brazil refused to invite Panamanian representatives to their inaugurations. In Brazil, ``It is likely that the new government will examine the matter in a new light,'' said one Brazilian diplomat, referring to the upcoming inauguration of Fernando Collor de Mello. Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., is accompanying Quayle as part of the U.S. delegation to the Chile inauguration of Patricio Aylwin. Kennedy was a leading critic of human rights violations under outgoing Chilean President Gen. Agosto Pinochet. Quayle will meet with Pinochet, who insisted on retaining control of the country's 60,000-man army even though he will not be president. Nicaragua's outgoing President Daniel Ortega, defeated in Feb. 25 elections by the U.S.-backed candidate Violeta Chamorro, also plans to attend the Chile inaugural. While U.S. officials have refused to meet with Ortega or representatives of his Marxist regime, the vice president now would have no objections to such a meeting, said Beckwith. However, he added that Nicaraguan officials had not sought a meeting.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS name ``Antonia'' in lead
DOC.HEAD: Bush Swears In Surgeon General
DOC.TEXT: Dr. Antonia Novello was sworn in Friday as the nation's surgeon general, and President Bush made it clear he expects no letup in the anti-smoking and anti-drug abuse crusades of her predecessors. In a brief White House ceremony, Bush saluted both the new appointee and Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan, himself a fervent critic of tobacco use. ``My respect and appreciation of my good friend Lou Sullivan grows every day as he fights for the good health of our people,'' Bush said. ``In the few minutes we've been here, 11 people have died from smoking, 390,000 people each year.'' Novello declared her motto would be ``good science and good sense,'' and thanked President Bush for an appointment she said should be an inspiration to women and minorities. ``The American dream is well and alive,'' Novello, the first woman and first Hispanic to serve as surgeon general, said at a White House ceremony. ``Once a dream, it is now my pledge: to be a good doctor for all who live in this great country.'' Novello, who succeeds C. Everett Koop, is a pediatrician who has specialized on AIDS and kidney disease in children. The surgeon general officially is the leader of the 6,500 member Public Health Service, but Koop and others have used the post as a bully pulpit to influence government policy on smoking, AIDS and other health-related issues. Bush also mentioned drug and alcohol abuse and AIDS as among the challenges facing Novello. ``The tasks ahead are difficult,'' he said. ``Because so many of these problems begin with our children, it is only right that we ask a pediatrician to help.'' Novello, 44, is a native of Puerto Rico. On hand for the ceremony was the governor of Puerto Rico, Rafael Hernandez Colon, who told Bush, ``I'm here representing the pride of all the people of Puerto Rico at this moment.''

DOC.HEAD: Lithuania in Weekend Showdown with Kremlin
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania's newly elected lawmakers pressed on toward a showdown with Moscow, caucusing Friday on how to take the reins of power after the declaration of independence expected by parliament this weekend. A secession vote by the Lithuanian Supreme Soviet would confront Mikhail S. Gorbachev with what could be his greatest crisis: the breaking away of one of the 15 Soviet republics, with the possibility of the rest of the multinational empire following suit. ``Moscow is menacing us. We hope it's only with words,'' said Anderus Kubilus, secretary of Sajudis, Lithuania's pro-independence movement. ``We don't think there will be an acute economic blockade. It wouldn't be profitable for them, either economically or in terms of international opinion. But we don't know.'' However, in comments reported Wednesday by official Radio Vilnius, Gorbachev appeared to accept Lithuania's right to secede, although cautioning that the once independent state on the Baltic Sea would have to pay $34 billion in compensation for factories built and money invested during a half-century of Soviet rule. With the legislature's opening session scheduled for Saturday night, secession activists reported from the capital of Vilnius that the stance of Lithuanian President and Communist Party leader Algirdas Brazauskas was still unclear. As chairman of the 141-seat chamber, Brazauskas conceivably could stave off immediate confrontation with the Kremlin by using his office to delay debate on the secession issue, which is expected to begin Sunday. ``His position is that we should act step by step, that there's no need to do it hastily,'' Alvydas Medalinskas, Sajudis executive director, said by telephone. He said Brazauskas' most recent appearance on state-run Lithuanian TV Wednesday showed his position has not changed. Kubilus, however, noted that the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet, or legislature, that Brazauskas heads has included the independence issue on the legislative agenda, which he took to be a sign of tacit support from the Lithuanian leader who masterminded his Communist Party's December declaration of independence from the Soviet party that Gorbachev heads. Forcing the pace, the governing council of Sajudis declared the independence issue ``cannot be delayed'' and called on the incoming legislature to restore the sovereignty lost in 1940 when Red Army tanks rolled in. The statement, issued after the Sajudis council met Thursday, carried enormous clout, since candidates supported by the grassroots nationalist movement won at least two-thirds of the seats in the Supreme Soviet in elections that began Feb. 24. In response to a call from Sajudis, election committees moved up the dates of runoffs so the new legislature could convene before the national Congress of People's Deputies, which is to meet in Moscow on Monday, can confer vastly greater presidential powers on Gorbachev that activists in the Soviet republics say would imperil their campaigns for sovereignty. The Lithuanian legislature will be asked to reaffirm the 1918 act that declared the West Virginia-sized state independent. On Feb. 7, lawmakers voided Lithuania's 1940 incorporation into the Soviet Union, calling it illegal, so the incoming parliament will vote on ``a restoration of statehood,'' Kubilus said. They will also be asked to restore the 1938 Constitution that was swept away by Josef Stalin's Kremlin in favor of a Soviet-style law. Anticipating the vote, a commission of newly elected deputies representing the KGB, police and Lithuanian lawyers met Friday to work out proposals on how to handle defense, law enforcement and security in an independent Lithuania, Medalinskas said. ``There are big preparations under way to assume power,'' said Kubilus. A commission of the outgoing legislature has prepared proposals for an independent economy, but Medalinskas said further negotiations on that score were expected with Moscow. In remarks reported by the official Tass news agency, Lithuanian economist Bronislovas Zaikauskas, an adviser to the republic's government, said his homeland, poor in natural resources, could exploit its location on the Soviet Union's western fringe to become a ``trampoline'' for Western firms seeking entry to the Soviet market. Official Soviet statistics show Lithuania imports $2.5 billion more in goods from the other Soviet republics than what it exports. But Zaikauskas pointed out the illogic of a state-run economy where the most industrially developed Soviet republics _ Lithuania and its Baltic neighbors of Estonia and Latvia _ run a debt with the rest of the country. Opposition to the independence declaration from ethnic minorities living in Lithuania was likely, but Medalinskas said there have been no recent statements from the ethnic Russian-led Intermovement or a rump faction of the Communist Party still loyal to Moscow. Ethnic Lithuanians make up 80 percent of the republic's 3.7 million population, with Russians totaling 9 percent and Poles 7 percent. Independence will also be on the agenda in Estonia this weekend as the so-called Estonian Congress convenes Sunday in Tallinn, the republic's capital, to discuss negotiations with Moscow. The 499-member non-governmental body represents people who lived in Estonia before the 1940 Soviet takeover and their descendents. The delegates will cooperate with Estonia's legislature on independence ``and are determined to press Moscow for the soonest possible settlement of the issue,'' said Tonis Avikson, a spokesman for the Estonian People's Front.

DOC.HEAD: Dates Announced For Shevardnadze Visit
DOC.TEXT: Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze will meet in Washington with Secretary of State James A. Baker from April 4-6, the State Department announced Friday. The talks are designed to further preparations for the summit meeting President Bush will hold here with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev sometime in June. Shevardnadze and Baker are expected to concentrate on arms control issues, hoping that a treaty to reduce U.S. and Soviet long-range nuclear missiles would be ready for signing at the summit. They will also discuss regional issues and human rights, among other subjects, Margaret D. Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman, said.

DOC.HEAD: North Hostile Witness To Prosecution At Poindexter's Trial
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 16 grafs further North testimony; picks up 15th graf pvs, U.S. District ...
DOC.TEXT: Oliver North took the stand as the leadoff witness at the Iran-Contra trial of John Poindexter today and grudgingly admitted he ran a secret Contra resupply operation on orders from Poindexter and others. North, testifying as a ``hostile witness'' for the prosecution,'' acknowledged that he controlled the covert Contra supply operation and said he ``never'' acted on his own. ``At no time, as you were running your operation, you never tried to conceal or hide what you were doing from either Admiral Poindexter or Robert McFarlane?'' prosecutor Dan Webb asked. ``I did not,'' the retired Marine lieutenant colonel said. ``Were you ever trying to direct that operation on you own, independent or your superiors?'' Webb asked. ``Never,'' North replied. ``Didn't you keep them apprised of all of your Contra-related activities?'' Webb asked. ``Yes,'' North said. Prosecutors called North to the stand to butress their contention that he worked with Poindexter to cover up the Iran-Contra affair. Poindexter is charged with conspiracy, two counts of obstructing Congress and two counts of making false statements to cover up North's military assistance and fund-raising for the Contras and U.S. knowledge of a 1985 shipment of Hawk missiles from Israel to Iran. On Thursday, Poindexter's lawyer said the former national security adviser may be guilty of bad memory but did not deliberately lie to Congress about secret arms shipments to Iran. Today, North initially denied that he controlled the Contra resupply operation, in which retired Air Force Maj. Gen. Richard Secord played a key role. ``To say that Secord worked under my direction would say a major general is working for a lieutenant colonel and I don't think that's accurate,'' North testified. Webb then handed North a copy of testimony he gave at his own trial last year in which North was asked who gave Secord his orders. ``I suppose I did,'' North replied at the time. Asked again by Webb whether he had run the operation, North replied: ``I gave him a lot of requests and if you want to call it direction and guidance I guess that's what we're stuck with.'' U.S. District Court Judge Harold Greene at one point referred to North as ``a hostile witness'' and gave Webb permission to ask leading questions of the former White House aide. Quoting from North's earlier testimony at his trial, Webb asked if ``the ball'' had been passed to North in terms of taking care of the Contras' needs after Congress prohibited the CIA from providing it. ``I don't recall those specific words,'' North said, but later conceding he had said ``words to that effect.'' North's role as overseer of the Contras' needs beginning in late 1984 took place while Poindexter was the deputy to Robert McFarlane, who was national security adviser at the time. ``Was Admiral Poindexter one of your superiors?'' asked Webb. ``In that general time frame he was one of the people who assigned me to'' assist the Contras, replied North. Defense attorney Richard Beckler has denied that Poindexter engaged in a criminal coverup of the Iran-Contra affair, declaring that he was acting under President Reagan's orders. Beckler said Congress was fully informed of North's secret Contra resupply network and that Poindexter labored to provide Congress the story of the Reagan administration's Iran initiative once it became public during November 1986. ``Why would anybody have to hide and deceive?'' asked Beckler. ``The answer is that Poindexter didn't have to hide. The answer is there was nothing illegal.'' Earlier Thursday, Webb said, ``John Poindexter and Oliver North decided to rewrite the history of the Iran-Contra affair'' through a conspiracy of ``coverup, deception and concealment.'' Poindexter and North tried to cover up the 1985 shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran and the diversion of profits to the Nicaraguan rebels to ``avoid tarnishment of the Reagan administration,'' Webb said. But Beckler told the jury Poindexter simply forgot when he gave incorrect information to members of the House and Senate intelligence committees about his involvement in the November 1985 Hawks shipment. The then-national security adviser told the congressional committees that he found out about the delivery in January 1986, when in fact he had known of the shipment at the time it occurred. ``After 30 years in the U.S. Navy and the White House they want to nail him on a five-week mistake'' for obstruction and making false statements to Congress,'' Beckler told the jury, nearly shouting. Hours after making the alleged false statements, Poindexter tore up a politically embarrassing presidential paper that depicted U.S. involvement in Iran arms sales as a straight arms-for-hostages deal. The December 1985 finding retroactively authorized the November 1985 CIA-assisted shipment of Hawks from Israel to Iran. ``Sometimes you do things to protect'' the president, Beckler said. ``When you work for the president of the United States, part of your job is ... to protect the president.'' ``What was driving this man was not a conspiracy, but ... the orders of the president of the United States,'' said Beckler. ``He met with him sometimes seven days a week, sometimes four, five and six times a day. And he was carrying out the policies of the United States and that is what this case is about. It is not about criminality.'' North met with members of Congress on Aug. 6, 1986, and denied assisting the Contras militarily. Poindexter later sent a message telling his aide, ``Well done.'' Prosecutor Webb told jurors that North lied at Poindexter's direction during the Aug. 6 meeting. Webb said Poindexter later congratulated North on lies that the prosecutor said ``worked like a charm.''

DOC.HEAD: Skull Was Aboard Atlantis
DOC.TEXT: A human skull was carried on the recent mission of the space shuttle Atlantis to help scientists determine how much radiation penetrates astronauts' heads when they are in space. The skull, owner and gender undetermined, had been carried into orbit once previously and will also be placed aboard the shuttle Discovery when it is launched next month, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said. The industry magazine, Aviation Week and Space Technology, said ``the phantom head, as it is officially designated, was mounted on the right wall of the shuttle middeck near the lower end of an astronaut sleeping bag.'' For the experiment, the skull was sliced apart, filled with more than 100 instruments, reassembled and covered with a plastic material formulated to act like human skin. Researchers needed an actual human skull to obtain the best data on how much space radiation penetrates the head, according to Aviation Week. The magazine quoted a Johnson Space Center document as saying that ``it is anticipated that a full torso will be flown in future shuttle missions'' to determine how much of a radiation dose the body gets during space flight. The tests are for use in planning extended space station missions and lengthy stays on the moon and Mars. Aviation Week said the skull was provided by the Air Force and came from someone who had willed it to science. Researchers assumed it was from a woman because of its small size.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Gerald Wallace, younger brother of former Alabama Gov. George C. Wallace, was fined $100,000 Friday and given a suspended two-year prison sentence for income tax evasion. He also was placed on five years' probation. Wallace, 68, a once influential lawyer who is suffering from cancer, pleaded guilty in October to two counts of failing to report $165,195 in federal taxes for 1984 and 1985. U.S. District Judge Joel Dubina ordered Wallace to pay the first $20,000 of the fine by the end of March and the rest within five years, though he doubted Wallace would be able to repay the full amount. ``I have heard you are the most powerful man in Alabama,'' the judge said. ``I don't know if that is true, but it is a tragedy to see you before me.''

Will Steger and five fellow adventurers who completed a seven-month, 3,800-mile trek across Antarctica on skis and dogsleds said they had a hair-raising time getting off the frozen continent. Lifeboats carrying the team to a waiting Soviet ship at Mirnyy on the Indian Ocean coast of Antarctica had to dodge ice floes when an iceberg split apart Thursday. ``The most dangerous part of the expedition was getting here and getting out,'' Steger said from Mirnyy. ``Thank God we didn't lose anyone.'' The six men, 29 sled dogs, two dog handlers and 13 journalists were loaded by ropes down a steep, icy embankment into the lifeboats. For the mushers, it was their first time off the ice since arriving by Soviet airplane at King George Island on the continent's western tip last July. Steger, who is from the Minnesota town of Ely, was a co-leader of the St. Paul-based expedition.

Sir David Lean, the 81-year-old director whose films have won 27 Academy Awards, says his ``Life Achievement Award'' from the American Film Institute took him by surprise. Lean, director of such classics as ``The Bridge on the River Kwai'' and ``Lawrence of Arabia,'' said he never thought of himself ``as anything so special.'' But actors and directors including Anjelica Huston, Martin Scorsese, Gene Kelly and Gregory Peck were fulsome in their praise at Thursday night's tribute. Lean chuckled through it all. If anybody had told him when he started in the business that he was going to be a director, he said, ``I would think they were mad.'' Previous winners include Peck, Kelly, Jimmy Stewart, John Huston and Alfred Hitchcock.

Attorneys for comedian Bill Cosby and his wife, Camille, pressed a judge for an early start to the bankruptcy trial of the couple's fired business manager. They said they wanted to prevent her from depleting assets estimated at $10 million. Cosby, once called ``the richest man in show business'' by Forbes Magazine, claims Mary Waller cheated him out of more than $8.5 million, court records show. After heated arguments Thursday, U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Arthur Greenwald ordered attorneys to return Tuesday, when he would decide the trial date. The lawyers are arguing whether fraud and embezzlement allegations brought by the Cosbys merit an early trial. The trial will decide whether Ms. Waller can manage her own assets while she reorganizes under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code, or whether her estate should be placed under a court-appointed trustee. Ms. Waller, 46, recently filed for bankruptcy protection after eight years serving as chief financial officer to the Cosbys. She was earning $1 million annually when fired in July, according to the Cosbys. Cosby says Ms. Waller misspent millions of the couple's money, buying among other things, a $44,551 Range Rover automobile and $28,610 in jewelry. She denies the allegations.

A ranch owned by actress Greer Garson would become a national park under a bill introduced in Congress by three New Mexico lawmakers. Sens. Jeff Bingaman and Pete Domenici and Rep. Bill Richardson said the bill introduced Thursday would allow the National Park Service to preserve and interpret the history of the entire Pecos area near Las Vegas, N.M. The planned Pecos National Historical Park would stand on what is now the 5,865-acre Forked Lightning Ranch owned by Ms. Garson. It would include the 25-year-old Pecos National Monument, which includes a village dating from the Pecos Pueblo Indians of 1450, the lawmakers said. ``The many prehistoric and historic resources located on the Forked Lightning Ranch would add significantly to the Pecos National Park,'' Richardson said. Negotiations were under way for the land, which may be purchased by a third party and then donated to the federal government, he said. Under the legislation, land may be bought, exchanged or donated. Ms. Garson recently halted negotiations to sell the land to a developer after learning of its plans to create a resort.

DOC.HEAD: State Department Charges Sandinistas With Post-Election Abuses
DOC.TEXT: The State Department called on Nicaragua's defeated Sandinista government on Friday to cease alleged abuses of government resources and fully cooperate in a transition of power. Margaret Tutwiler, the department spokeswoman, said that actions by the Sandinista legislature to drop charges on unprosecuted crimes and provide a legal basis for the party's confiscation of state property contradict promises made by President Daniel Ortega after his defeat by President-elect Violetas Chamorro. ``Throughout their 10-year rule and during the election campaign, the Sandinistas made no distinction between state and party resources,'' she said. ``Now they are trying to provide a legal sanction for their abuse of government property,'' Ms Tutwiler said. ``Meanwhile, reports flood in about Sandinista theft of government office equipment and other state resources,'' she said and added: ``If the Sandinistas are serious about respecting a popular mandate, as President Ortega has promised, they will cease these actions immediately and cooperate with the incoming government to ensure a smooth transition.'' Since the Sandinistas' Feb. 25 election defeat by the United National Opposition, known as UNO, there have been numerous reports of citizens being armed and trained for combat in ``sovereignty battalions'' by the governing leftist party. Opposition leaders express concern over a Sandinista bill introduced this week in the legislature that would would absolve anyone of crimes committed through the end of March. The law would apply to crimes committed between July 19, 1979, the day of the victory of the Sandinista revolution that overthrew dictator Anastasio Somoza, and March 31.

DOC.HEAD: State Officials Don't Like Bush Transportation Plan
DOC.TEXT: Many state and local officials aren't buying President Bush's proposed national transportation policy, which would shift more of the cost to states. One critic called the proposal ``all flash and no cash.'' The critics are demanding release of billions of dollars from the Highway and Aviation trust funds. ``The states are going to have to do their part and we are, but the federal government has got to do its part. It's got to be a partnership,'' said Massachusetts Gov. Michael Dukakis, who lost to Bush in the 1988 presidential election. But some hailed it for giving the states greater freedom. ``The president's policy offers excellent promise for future transportation decision-making and gives states more flexibility over control of federally assisted projects, and it encourages use of innovative financing by the states,'' said Illinois Gov. James R. Thompson, a Republican. The administration plan, ``Moving America Into The 21st Century,'' calls for more toll roads, local gas taxes, user fees, private investments, competition, deregulation, research into futuristic systems and openness to foreign air carriers as well as increased attention to safety and protection of the environment. The policy, unveiled Thursday by Bush and Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner, contains no strategy to increase federal funding beyond what's already in the president's budget. Thompson said he agreed with user fees, but added that ``it is essential that the users have confidence that their fees are going to be used, promptly, for improvements to the transportation system. As a result, I emphasize again the need to spend down trust fund balances as quickly as practical to put user fee revenue to work on transportation projects.'' Arnold Oliver, engineer-director of Texas' Department of Highways and Public Transportation, said his agency is ``very concerned about shifting the financial burden.'' ``We're already stretched to the limit,'' Oliver said. ``The president had a chance to hit a home run for transportation by agreeing to spend some of the $23 billion already collected in the Highway and Aviation Trust Funds. But being held hostage to reduce the federal deficit, he missed the ball on that one. But hopefully the game isn't over,'' said James Pitz, director of the Michigan Department of Transportation. Hal Rives, commissioner of the Georgia Department of Transportation, said $66 billion is spent on highways across the country each year and the federal government only pays $12 billion. ``We're already paying the larger share. It's time for the federal government to back up what they need with federal money, and they have the money,'' he said, referring to the trust funds based on taxes on fuel and airline tickets. Robert R.
