Kiley, chairman of New York City's Metropolitan Transportation Authority, also blasted the proposed reduction of federal spending on transportation. ``Reading this policy, you would never know we have serious congestion and infrastructure decay problems which need to be boldly addressed,'' Kiley said. ``Like the national education and national drug policies, this is another case of all flash and no cash.'' Washington state officials said the proposal could mean higher taxes will be needed to fund transportation improvements in the state. Washington state lawmakers last week approved a $1.1 billion tax increase over five years for transportation, including a 4-cent gas-tax increase this year and another penny in 1991. At 22 cents a gallon, Washington's tax will be among the highest in the nation. In Massachusetts, Dukakis repeated his call for the Legislature to increase the state's gasoline tax, now at 11 cents a gallon one of the nation's lowest. Tennessee Gov. Ned McWherter has backed increased taxes for transportation and the state gasoline tax has been raised from 14 to 21 cents per gallon over the past six years, said his spokesman, Ken Renner. ``At the same time, Tennesseans have been paying federal taxes that go into the Highway Trust Fund and the Aviation Trust Fund and the governor believes it is time that the money in these funds is spent for the purposes for which it is intended,'' Renner said.

DOC.HEAD: Aoun Calls for Peace with Rival Christian and Moslem Leaders
DOC.TEXT: Gen. Michel Aoun appealed Friday for an end to Lebanon's 15-year-old civil war, making a conciliatory move to Moslem leaders and a Christian warlord he has tried to crush in more than a month of battles. Aoun also dropped his outright opposition to the peace accord and power sharing agreement worked out by Lebanon's parliament in October. Police said a week-old cease-fire between Aoun's 19,000 troops and the 6,000-member Lebanese Forces militia of Samir Geagea was holding despite minor exchanges of sniper fire. At least 750 people were killed and 2,089 wounded during the inconclusive showdown between the two forces for mastery of the 310-square-mile Christian enclave. In another development, police said rival Shiite Moslem militias loyal to Syria and Iran clashed in south Beirut and south Lebanon, but there were no reports of casualties. The police spokesman said Syrian troops moved in and disengaged Shiite zealots of the pro-Iranian Hezbollah, or Party of God, and fighters of the mainstream Shiite Amal militia in south Beirut's seaside district of Ouzai. In south Lebanon's Iqlim el-Tuffah province, the two factions dueled with howitzers and mortars, the police spokesman said. The Shiite clashes came two days after a Beirut firefight between the two groups that left two people dead and three wounded. The two factions have been fighting sporadically for more than two years for dominance among Shiites, the nation's largest sect. The war between the two Shiite militias has left 1,030 people dead and 3,046 wounded. Also Friday, Israeli warplanes attacked a Palestinian guerrilla base near the northern Lebanese city of Tripoli in the first raid in the region in nearly five years, the Israeli military said. A guerrilla group, the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command, said six Israeli warplanes rocketed one of its naval bases, killing two guerrillas and wounding a Lebanese farmer. The bases hit served as ``launching points'' for attacks on Israel by the guerrilla group, the Israeli military said. The military did not point to a specific attack blamed on Jibril's militia. While Israel frequently attacks guerrilla bases in south Lebanon in retaliation for attacks on or near the Israeli-Lebanese border, the raid in northern Lebanon was unusual. It was the eighth air raid this year by Israeli jets against targets in Lebanon. Aoun, in an unusually conciliatory statement to the newspaper An-Nahar, said there will be no more clashes among Christians or between Christians and Moslems. Aoun told An-Nahar he wanted ``dialogue with everyone'' to find a settlement to more than a month of clashes between his troops and Geagea's militia. He stressed there will be ``no more clashes'' in the Christian enclave or along the areas separating Christian territory with the Moslem sectors. The general also dropped his rejection of an Arab League peace plan brokered last year in the Saudi Arabian city of Taif. ``Abrogating the Taif accord is not necessary to launch a dialogue,'' Aoun said. He did call, however, for unspecified amendments to the plan. Aoun originally rejected the accord because it did not include a timetable for the withdrawal of Syria's 40,000 troops from Lebanon. Aoun's army and Geagea's militia fought each other to a standstill before accepting a cease-fire on March 3 called by a mediation committee of three independent Christian figures. The committee said Friday it was holding a series of meetings with Aoun, Geagea and Maronite Catholic Patriarch Nasrallah Sfeir to ``consolidate the cease-fire and move into addressing the political reasons for the crisis.'' It did not elaborate. Aoun and Geagea are Maronites, the Catholic community that has dominated political life in Lebanon since its independence from France in 1943. Aoun described the inconclusive intra-Christian showdown as ``self destructive'' and called on Geagea to declare his ``readiness for dialogue so we can meet.'' ``Once two people manage to meet, they can invite others,'' Aoun said. The statement was considered to be an invitation to Moslem leaders to meet with him and discuss a settlement to the civil war. Moslems have been demanding political reforms giving them an equal share in Lebanon's political life. The Taif accord called for distributing government and parliamentary seats equally among Moslems and Christians.

DOC.HEAD: Actress Jennifer O'Neill Calls it a Day after Six Marriages
DOC.TEXT: Actress Jennifer O'Neill says that after six marriages, she's had enough. ``When I say that (about being married six times), I feel absolutely ridiculous because my parents have been married 44 years and they still bossa nova around at lunch,'' the 42-year-old actress is quoted as saying in a taping of ``The Joan Rivers Show'' to be broadcast Tuesday. ``The only thing I can say is I don't give up. I think I have now, though. I've given (marriage) up for Lent.'' O'Neill, who has been in 27 films and hit stardom with ``The Summer of '42,'' first married at age 17. She has three children, ranging from age 2 to 22, and is currently separated from her sixth husband, Richard Allen. ``I know Elizabeth Taylor said this, but I'll have to repeat it: `I didn't date them, I married them,''' she said. ``Obviously every time (one marries), you think that this is going to be right. I believed it every time.''

DOC.HEAD: Quayle Meets in South America on Nicaragua
DOC.TEXT: Venezuela and Spain on Friday told Vice President Dan Quayle the United States should trust Nicaragua's outgoing Sandinista government to peacefully give up power and should hasten demobilization of the Contra rebels, U.S. officials said. In what one aide described as ``a kind of rolling summit on Nicaragua and the peaceful transfer of power,'' Quayle met with Venezuela's President Carlos Andres Perez the day after incoming Nicaraguan President Violeta Chamorro met with Perez. President Daniel Ortega is also due to arrive in Venezuela on Saturday. Spanish Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez joined the talks Friday, as did Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., who is accompanying Quayle to Sunday's presidential inauguration in Chile. Kennedy told the Latin leaders there's considerable skepticism in Congress about Ortega and they ``should not put confidence totally in Ortega,'' said U.S. officials who were in the meeting. Quayle concurred, stressing the United States prefers to trust Mrs. Chamorro. He said the Bush administration also wants the Contras to disband but said their security must be ensured. Quayle, on the first day of a week-long trip to the region, spoke by telephone with Mrs. Chamorro Friday morning from Air Force Two. U.S. officials said all agreed further negotiations are needed on the transfer of power and demobilizing the rebels before Mrs. Chamorro's April 25 inauguration. More talks were expected when the Spanish prime minister travels in his plane from Caracas with Ortega, Perez and Costa Rican President Oscar Arias to Sunday's inauguration. Spain and Venezuela agreed with Quayle that they should provide trade and economic aid to help rebuild Nicaragua's languishing economy. Perez and Gonzalez insisted the Contras pose a potential security problem for the elected Chamorro government, but Quayle noted there have also been attacks since the Feb. 25 election by roaming bands of Sandinista supporters. ``We all agree the Contras should be demobilized,'' one official said, adding, ``There has to be a process but the security of the Contras has to be guaranteed.'' Quayle was flying to Barbados later Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Minister Urges Officers to Halt Decline in Morale
With AM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's defense minister urged army officers Friday to try to halt a decline in morale in the once-feared front-line force of the Warsaw Pact. ``I have asked my commanders to ensure duties are carried out by the book,'' Adm. Theodor Hoffmann said at a news conference. The East German army has been facing a drain on human resources and declining morale and readiness since the hard-line Communist leadership fell in October and borders to the West were opened, according to military sources and Western officials. Hoffmann described Western reports that his troops had lost as many as 80,000 soldiers, or 50 percent of the active force, as ``exaggerated,'' contending instead that between 500 and 1,000 mainly young soldiers had deserted. He stressed that most were doing their duty conscientiously, but added: ``The number of young people leaving this land is high, and that includes soldiers.'' He said troops' worries about their future had prompted many to opt for migration to West Germany. ``The question (they) always ask is ... `What's going to happen to us?''' he said. Hoffmann added he was concerned about reports he had received that recruits had burned their military ID cards and refused to take part in exercises. ``We can't say we're totally satisfied when soldiers are demonstrating and refusing to carry out orders ... a new motivation must be built up,'' Hoffmann said. Other Defense Ministry sources have put the number of deserters in the thousands. According to Hoffmann, 130,000 soldiers were in active military service, with an extra 12,000 performing special duties in the economy and health services, also ailing since the Communist ouster. He said 28,000 soldiers, who had taken planned retirement, made up the difference to what officially is a 170,000-man fighting force. Army officials from East Germany's Warsaw Pact allies had privately expressed concern about the reports of flagging discipline, but had made no official complaints. As the Germanys move toward unification, Hoffmann said he supported a united Germany's membership in a European security system that would embrace East and West and surpass the Warsaw Pact and NATO as military alliances. The West insists that a single Germany adhere to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, while the Communist-led East German interim government, backed by the Kremlin, has ruled out NATO membership. Hoffmann, a member of the Communist Party who is likely to be replaced as minister after March 18 elections vote in a new government and parliament, said he looked forward to working with what would probably be his civilian successor. He said East Germany could replace conscription with a voluntary professional army and recommended both German armies should increase cooperation in coordinating activities such as disaster clean-ups and other emergency operations.

DOC.HEAD: White House Says Hostage Hoax Embarrassing but Shows Bush Concern
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's phone conversation with an impostor claiming to be Iran's president was ``a little embarrassing'' but underscored his commitment to winning the release of U.S. hostages in Lebanon, Bush's spokesman said Friday. Presidential press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Bush believed the contact, purportedly from Hashemi Rafsanjani, was probably a hoax but decided to involve himself anyway on the chance that it wasn't. ``The president's feeling was: `What if it's real? And I want the American people to know, and the families of the hostages to know, that I am willing to check out every possibility,''' Fitzwater said. A caller identifying himself as an Iranian official phoned the White House several weeks ago and asserted that the Iranian president wanted to discuss the hostages with Bush, administration officials said. Bush spoke to the impostor during a second phone call. White House officials declined to go into details of the conversation. ``Suffice it to say it was a hoax phone call and that's all that matters,'' Fitzwater said. He said the administration does not know who initiated the hoax and could not rule out the possibilty that it might have originated within a faction of the Iranian government. Rafsanjani, meanwhile, ridiculed Bush in a sermon broadcast on Tehran radio. ``Can it be that such a global power, with all its intelligence capabilities, talks to a person it cannot identify?'' he asked. ``This is a strange occurrence.'' The Iranian leader said the episode showed how important Iran was to the United States and added that it was ``God's grace'' that U.S. officials had not been able to make contact with him. Fitzwater's statement said Rafsanjani's statement ``reflects the difficulty of the situation: One day we hear moderate points of view, the next day we hear antagonistic ones.'' ``Our position remains steadfast: We want to do everything we can to get the hostages out. The president will talk to anyone, any time,'' Fitzwater added. Was Bush, with his reputation for nonstop telephone diplomacy, angered by the hoax? ``No, actually the president thinks it's probably useful to have the American people know he's willing to follow up on these kinds of things,'' Fitzwater said. ``While hoax phone calls are always a little embarrassing and difficult to deal with ... it's important to the hostage families to know that President Bush's policy is firm but he is personally committed to follow up every opportunity to get release of the hostages,'' the spokesman said. Asked how a person whose identity could not be verified ended up talking to the president of the United States, Fitzwater said: ``It (the call) got through because we wanted it to get through.'' He said Iran has a history of seeking to communicate with the West in an ``unorthodox manner'' and that ``any communication from the leadership of Iran has to be treated differently.'' Fitzwater said the caller first talked to National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft. ``This call came in. It was suspicious,'' he said. But the spokesman said Bush was ``willing to make this call (the second one) on the off-chance that it might be real.'' Fitzwater initially said that the caller left a number, and that the White House returned the call using that number. However, he later was vague on whether the second call was placed or received by the White House, saying he didn't want to get into such details. The episode was first reported Thursday by CBS News. Eight Americans, including Terry Anderson, the chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, and 10 other Westerners are being held hostage in Lebanon. Most of them are being held factions loyal to Iran. The Bush administration contends Rafsanjani's government has influence with those holding the hostages. In the past, officials have said that the United States has had no direct contact with Iran on the matter, although there has been considerable activity through non-governmental channels. Fitzwater, asked whether the call would have constituted such a government-to-government contact had it really been Rafsanjani, allowed that it would have been. So in the future ``we won't talk about contacts,'' he said. The spokesman said just because one prankster got through to Bush doesn't mean it's open season for hoax calls. ``Let me make it clear ... before people start calling the White House,'' he said. ``All of these kinds of phone calls are checked out very carefully.''

DOC.HEAD: Hughes Pleads Guilty In Pentagon Documents Case
DOC.TEXT: Hughes Aircraft Co. admitted Friday that it unlawfully obtained classified Pentagon budget documents, and agreed to pay the government $3.67 million, officials said. Hughes, which pleaded guilty to two felony counts, is the fourth major defense contractor to admit to such charges. Three to six other Pentagon contractors remain under investigation, said Michael J. Costello, special agent in charge of the Defense Criminal Investigative Service's Washington field office. The two counts against Hughes concern five-year defense program documents issued in 1983 and 1984 summarizing resources planned, programmed and budgeted by the Department of Defense, according to a statement by Susan J. Crawford, the Pentagon's inspector general. The documents were classified secret and they were not releasable to Defense Department contractors, the statement said. Hughes, through former employee Frank J. Caso, unlawfully acquired these and other classified Pentagon documents from employees of other defense contractors between 1978 and 1985, according to a statement from U.S. Attorney Henry E. Hudson of the eastern district of Virginia. Caso has not been charged, said Costello, who added that he could not confirm nor deny whether Caso was the subject of a criminal investigation. The Crawford statement said Hughes tried to hide the fact that it had the documents. Before 1978, Hughes did not enter the documents into its classified document accountability system. From 1978 through 1985, the documents ``were logged into the system but not under their actual titles in an attempt to hide their receipt,'' the statement said. Richard Dore, a spokesman for the Los Angeles-based Hughes, did not immediately return a phone call seeking comment on the case. Hughes agreed to pay $3.55 million in settlement of any civil liability which may arise out of its actions, plus $50,000 for investigative costs, $50,000 from its overhead account, and a total of $20,000 in penalties stemming from the actual charges. Each charge carries a maximum penalty of $10,000. The company will make the payment within five days, according to the plea agreement entered before U.S. District Judge James C. Cacheris. Costello said he was not certain how much money, if any, Hughes earned because of its access to the documents. ``We would have to make an assumption that they did make money,'' he said. ``That's the reason for the $3.5 million settlement.'' Negotiations with Hughes had been under way for several months, he said. The probe of defense contractors _ begun in the mid-1980s and code-named Operation Uncover _ has resulted in guilty pleas from three other major defense contractors as well: GTE Government Systems Division, The Boeing Company and RCA Corp, Costello said. The investigation has been carried out by DCIS, the Defense Department Inspector General's investigative arm. GTE paid about $300,000 in fines in 1985, he said. The Boeing Company paid fines and restitution of $5.2 million, and a Boeing employee, Richard Lee Fowler, was convicted last December of 39 counts of conspiracy, conveyance without authority, conversion and mail fraud and sentenced to two years in prison, the Hudson statement said. On Feb. 5, RCA Corp. was ordered to pay fines and restitution of $2.75 million, and former RCA employee Leonard Kampf and current RCA employee Ronald Stevens each pleaded guilty to one felony count of conveyance without authority. Each faces up to 10 years in prison and fines of up to $10,000. Sentencing for the two is scheduled for April 6, the Hudson statement said.

DOC.HEAD: Back in Hospital
DOC.TEXT: An Wang, founder and chairman of Wang Laboratories, has been readmitted to Massachusetts General Hospital but is working from his bed. Wang, 70, underwent chemotherapy treatments and surgery for cancer of the esophagus last summer, and then returned to daily work at the company. Wang was readmitted Tuesday and has called several times from his hospital room for documents to be brought to im, company spokesman Paul Guzzi said Friday. The hospital on Friday declined to give Wang's condition, referring all calls to Guzzi. Wang returned to daily work at the computer company after undergoing surgery last July.

DOC.HEAD: Indians Regain Land From Jackie Onassis with Ancient Credo: `Stand Firm'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Wampanoag is pronounced wam-pa-no'-ahg
DOC.TEXT: The Wampanoag Indians, who have lived on these red cliffs for centuries, follow a simple creed that explains how they regained 400 acres and successfully battled Jacqueline Onassis in a decade-old land dispute. They call it ``Iootash,'' meaning ``stand firm,'' a word that was relayed to tribal members by the legendary chief Annawon when the Pilgrims arrived in 1620. That philosophy has sustained them over the years, spurring their fight for valuable acreage here that they say is of historical significance to the tribe. They also ended the fight with Mrs. Onassis last week when she agreed to give them a larger piece of land and $100,000 in exchange for their shares of a tiny beachfront site on Martha's Vineyard that figures in tribal legend. ``We tend to be stubborn,'' said Donald Widdiss, president of the Wampanoag Tribal Council. ``We tend to think very seriously about strategy and about what we want.'' There may be only about 250 Wampanoags on the island just south of Cape Cod, but the tribe is tenacious. The Wampanoags were eking out a living on the clay cliffs around 1100 when Leif Erickson became the first white man to make contact with them. Some tribal members fought Mrs. Onassis' attempt to buy them out of the 1.5 acre site, a tangled web of litigation that began in 1980. Mrs. Onassis owned a one-sixth share of the land, which is surrounded by her 400-acre estate. But 25 Wampanoags, the descendants of William Vanderhoop, an original owner of the site, were determined to get another piece of land in exchange. Tribal legend has it that the site is where the great chief Moshup threw his children into the sea when he foresaw the coming of the white man. ``We didn't want to give up something that had belonged to our great-great grandfather,'' said Thelma Vanderhoop Weissberg, 62, in an interview at her home after the settlement was announced Wednesday in Dukes County Probate Court. ``I have a very special feeling about the land here. It's a feeling only an Indian can have. It was important we get more land in return, not just money.'' Charlie Vanderhoop, 68, who was born at the Gay Head lighthouse when his father was the lighthouse keeper, stood on the cliffs a few hours after the Onassis settlement and pointed at a stretch of ocean known as the Devil's Den in Wampanoag lore. ``Everything here means something to me,'' said Vanderhoop. ``I want to keep as much land as we can for our children.'' The Wampanoags have made their living from the sea for centuries. Not long ago, it was whaling and swordfishing. Now those who can afford boats go shellfishing. Many of the women work in souvenir shops on the picturesque cliffs. Just how tough the Wampanoags were was made clear in 1974, when they filed suit against the town of Gay Head for land they said was tribal property. They claimed that the 1790 Indian Nonintercourse Act, forbidding transfer of Indian lands without federal approval, was violated in the 1870s when the state redistributed tribal lands to residents. They won the land settlement several years ago, just as they received federal recognition as a tribe. The Wampanoag were given $4.5 million to buy back land in Gay Head. Beatrice Gentry, 79, another member of the Vanderhoop family, initiated the first lawsuits in the 1970s. ``We wanted the land because it's part of our culture,'' said Gentry, who worked her way through college by making pots from the cliffs' clay. Gay Head, on the southwestern tip of Martha's Vineyard, is one of the poorest communities in the state, although it's just a few miles up the beach from the sprawling, shingled summer homes of the wealthy and the well-known. During the past 100 years, only two non-Indians have been elected to the town council. Many Wampanoag are wary of outsiders and some believe all the land in Gay Head should be returned to them. They refuse to use the term ``Pilgrims'' to describe the early white settlers. ``They were invaders,'' said Widdiss.

DOC.HEAD: State Department Lambasts Assad
DOC.TEXT: The State Department said Friday that Syrian President Hafez Assad, in denouncing democratic change in Eastern Europe and calling for an endless war against Israel, ``is out of step with the enormously promising changes unfolding around the world.'' Margaret Tutwiler, the department's spokeswoman, said the people of the Middle East, including the people of Syria, have ``no need for more bellicose rhetoric.'' Rather they need ``real statesmanship and commitment to the practical steps needed to bring about a Palestinian-Arab dialogue leading to a comprehensive peace settlement,'' she said. Assad, addressing a youth rally in Damascus on Thursday, called for an infinite holy war against Israel and said the changes sweeping Eastern Europe are a boon to the Jewish state. Assad denounced the recent wave of Soviet Jewish emigration to Israel, saying migrating Jews would force Palestinians from their homeland. ``Let us now perceive that Israel was the first beneficiary, among all nations of the world, of the international changes that have taken place,'' Assad said. He said the jihad, or holy war against Israel ``should be as long as time.'' Ms. Tutwiler said: President Assad's criticism is ``out of step with the enormously promising changes unfolding around the world as well as with the serious effort to move toward peace in the Middle East.'' ``President Assad ought to be commiting himself to peace, not war,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: China Buys More Wheat
DOC.TEXT: China has bought an additional 396,300 metric tons of U.S. wheat under a price subsidy program, the Agriculture Department said Friday. F. Paul Dickerson, general sales manager for the department's Foreign Agricultural Service, said two private exporting companies made the deals under the department's Export Enhancement Program, or EEP. Delivery of the wheat is scheduled for July and August, he said. The sales were part of 1 million tons authorized China under EEP on Feb. 8. Previous allocations had been exhausted except for 1,050 tons. A metric ton is about 2,205 pounds and is equal to 36.7 bushels of wheat. The latest sales would be about 14.5 million bushels. At current prices estimated by USDA at around $4 per bushel, the wheat would have a farm value of around $58 million. Under EEP arrangements, private exporters can sell U.S. commodities at reduced prices to meet foreign competition in selected overseas markets and then collect free government surpluses of grain or other commodities as bonuses, or subsidies. Dickerson said the latest subsidies averaged $4.43 per ton, or about 12 cents per bushel. The subsidized sales were handled by Mitsubishi International Corp., 30,000 tons; and Continental Grain Co., 366,300 tons. With the latest sales, China has bought about 700,000 tons of U.S. wheat for delivery in the 1990-91 wheat marketing year that will begin June 1, compared with more than 5.7 million tons in 1989-90.

DOC.HEAD: Rostenkowski Derides Bush and Democratic Tax Cut Proposals
DOC.TEXT: Proposals to cut Social Security and capital gains taxes are in a tight race for an award for dumbest ideas of the year, Congress' chief tax-writer said Friday. ``I was left nearly speechless by this competition until I finally decided to simply call both proposals political junk food and just let them go at that,'' Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said in a speech in Boca Raton, Fla. Rostenkowski took jabs at President Bush, who wants to cut taxes on capital gains, and some senior Democrats, led by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, who want to cut Social Security taxes. Democratic leaders are weighing how to respond to Moynihan's proposal, which has particular appeal in an election year. Their response on that issue will be included in a plan, expected in the near future, setting out the party's policy on an array of tax issues. Rostenkowski has written a piece to be published in Sunday's Washington Post in which he spells out his own suggestions on taxes and deficit reduction. He is expected to rely on one of his favorite ideas _ a sharp increase in the gasoline tax _ and on raising taxes on tobacco, alcohol and oil. Bush's proposed cut in taxes on capital gains, which are profits from the sale of investments, is worse than the one the president recommended last year, Rostenkowski said in the speech. ``At a time when the deficit is too big, he suggests cutting taxes,'' Rostenkowski said. ``At a time when people are concerned about erosion of the tax system's progressivity, he wants to make it less progressive,'' meaning it would be based less on the ability to pay. A copy of Rostenkowski's Florida speech was made available in Washington. The congressman ridiculed Moynihan's conclusion that Social Security taxes should be cut because surplus taxes are being used to hide the true size of the overall budget deficit. The 1983 reform plan Moynihan helped write was not broken, Rostenkowski said, but ``he decided to fix it by suggesting that Social Security taxes be cut.'' ``If there were an Academy Award for the worst idea of the year, we'd be watching a very tight race here,'' Rostenkowski said. Since he was speaking to a meeting of the Futures Industry Association, whose members trade in commodities, Rostenkowski added a third candidate for the dubious award: Bush's proposal to tax transactions in the futures markets. He promised to oppose that proposal vigorously but predicted it might fare better in the Senate Finance Committee. In Washington, meanwhile, Rostenkowski's senior aides told reporters ``we don't think we have the votes now to beat a capital gains cut.'' The aides, who spoke on condition of anonymity, also released the latest in a series of reports concluding that cutting capital gains taxes would continue to shift more of the tax burden away from upper-income Americans. The report is based on Congressional Budget Office analysis of trends in taxation since 1977. The basic conclusion is that major tax laws enacted in 1978 and 1981 cut taxes significantly for the wealthiest Americans but not nearly so much for those who earn less. Rostenkowski, in a statement on the new report, said the reduction in tax burdens for the wealthy was ``staggering.'' The CBO conclusion is essentially the same as that in a study by Citizens for Tax Justice that was made public Thursday. That study found if tax laws were made as fair today as they were in 1977, all but the richest 10 percent would pay less and the government would still collect $67.5 billion a year more. The Bush administration prefers to point out to figures showing the richest Americans pay a greater share of the total tax burden than they were in 1977. Congressional economists agree _ but say that's because incomes of the wealthiest 10 percent have soared during the same period.

DOC.HEAD: Rafsanjani Calls Phone Hoax `Disaster' For Bush
With AM-Hostage Hoax, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani said Friday that the telephone hoax in which President Bush thought he was talking to Rafsanjani was a ``disaster'' for Washington. Speaking in a sermon in Tehran, Rafsanjani marveled at the fact that Bush could be duped by an impostor. ``Can it be that such a global power, with all its intelligence capabilities, talks to a person it cannot identify?'' he asked. ``This is a strange occurrence. ``This shows the United States very much needs to talk to Iran, but, with God's grace, it is deprived of this blessing,'' he said. Standing behind a podium with his hands resting on the barrel of an AK-47 rifle, Rafsanjani said: ``Iran's stature in the world is so high that the strongest power in the world, and the greatest power on Earth is grappling to find an opening to your executive leader even through telephone wires.'' He said Iran expected the United States to answer such questions as ``who was the intermediary, who did they talk to and what did they talk about.'' ``Now we must wait for explanations and witness another Irangate in the making, God willing,'' Rafsanjani said, referring to the Reagan administration's ill-fated attempt to sell weapons to Iran in return for the release of the U.S. hostages in Lebanon, and then giving the money to the Contra rebels in Nicaragua. Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said in Washington on Thursday that Bush returned a phone call last month to a man he thought was the Iranian president, but it turned out to be a hoax. Fitzwater did not give details of the conversation or say how it was discovered the call was a hoax. CBS News said the two men spoke about the release of the U.S. hostages. Rafsanjani said the incident provided a glimpse of the ``confusion of leaders inside the White House.'' ``There is a new disaster in Washington, which I think is a wonder,'' he said in the hour-long sermon, which was broadcast on Tehran Television and monitored in Nicosia. The Bush administration has said it believes that Rafsanjani's government has influence with the captors of the eight Americans and 10 other Western captives held in Lebanon. The longest held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, who was abducted March 16, 1985. The disclosure of the hoax came amid a flurry of recent reports indicating movement on the hostage issue. However, U.S. officials have said they are unable to cite any progress toward freeing the hostages. Fitzwater said that although Bush was tricked once, he would do the same thing again if he thought it would help win the release of the hostages. ``If a call came through at some future point that we believed was real, he would take it,'' Fitzwater said. ``The president has made it known he's willing to talk to Iran at any time. And the ball is in their court.'' In a related develoment, a previously unknown group threatened to kill one of two Swiss hostages in Lebanon unless two Lebanese jailed in France and Switzerland are freed. The threat by the Action Group for the Release of (Mohammed) Hariri was made by an anonymous phone caller to a Western news agency in Nicosia. Mohammed Hariri was jailed for life in Switzerland in February 1989 for hijacking an Air Afrique jetliner in 1987 and killing a French passenger after the aircraft landed in Geneva.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Faulty On Delay for Lab Rules
DOC.TEXT: Members of Congress scolded the Bush administration Friday for failing to meet the deadline for setting out regulations to assure the quality and accuracy of all medical laboratory tests. Lawmakers were not appeased by the Health Care Financing Administration's announcement that final rules to bring 12,000 medical labs under uniform national testing standards would be published next week and could go into effect after a 60-day comment period. By HCFA's own estimate, there are between 300,000 and 600,000 medical testing facilities _ including labs in physicians' offices, employer health units, public health departments, blood banks and public screening labs. Most of those would be covered by other rules HCFA is drafting, but has not yet formally proposed. ``It is critical that all laboratories be regulated,'' said Sen. Brock Adams, D-Wash. ``Each month the implementation ... is delayed, more cases of cancer go undetected, more men and women receive erroneous laboratory reports and more tragedies result.'' ``We need a sense of urgency,'' added Sen. Barbara Mikulski, D-Md., at the joint hearing of the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee and the Governmental Affairs subcommittee on oversight of government management. Gail Wilensky, who recently took over as head of HCFA, told the lawmakers the rules covering 12,000 labs that receive payments from Medicare and Medicaid ``will make a tremendous difference'' in the way those labs operate. She said those rules were already being drafted when Congress passed a law in 1988 giving HCFA authority to regulate all testing labs and directing the agency to have rules in place to implement the law by Jan. 1, 1990. The main reason for the delay in meeting that deadline, she said, was ``major unexpected dissension within the scientific community'' over which tests should be subject to the least regulation because of their simplicity and low risk to the patient, and which ones should meet tougher standards. She said HCFA expected to propose rules to meet the 1988 law in three stages. The first set of rules, which she expected to be proposed by mid-April, would define three levels of testing and the personnel, quality assurance and proficiency testing requirements for each level. Pressed by lawmakers to estimate when the law would be fully implemented, Wilensky said it would depend on how many comments the agency receives on the proposals but that she hoped it would be within two years. Lawmakers have been particularly concerned about Pap tests used to detect cervical cancer. Reports about inaccuracies in these tests helped spur passage of the 1988 law. Rep. Carl Levin, D-Mich., estimated that up to 40 percent of Pap test results are done incorrectly. Wilensky said 75 percent of Pap tests are performed by the 12,000 labs that will soon be regulated, but Leven said that will still leave as many as 20 million Pap tests each year being read by unregulated labs. ``That's still a huge number waiting for some kind of assurance,'' Levin said. Under the regulations HCFA expects to propose next month, some tests would be waived from regulation because they are simple, low risk and have little margin for error. Rep. Ron Wyden, D-Ore., who testified at the hearing, said he was concerned that tests for strep throat, sickle cell anemia, blood clotting and gonorrhea would be exempt. Cholesterol screening would be subject to a higher level of oversight and regulation because the test is more complex and involves a greater degree of risk to the patient if performed incorrectly, Wilensky said. The highest level of regulation would be imposed for tests such as the Pap smear and for AIDS infection, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Hungary, Soviet Reach Agreement on Total Withdrawal of Red Army
DOC.TEXT: Hungary and the Soviet Union have agreed on a timetable for the total withdrawal of Red Army troops from Hungarian territory, state radio reported Friday. According to the broadcast, the heads of delegations negotiating the terms of a withdrawal initialed a final agreement in Moscow Friday. Hungarian Foreign Minister Gyula Horn is due to travel to Moscow on Saturday, when he is to sign the agreement with his Soviet counterpart, Eduard Shevardnadze. The pullout is scheduled to begin Monday, the radio said. Hungarian Premier Miklos Nemeth said Tuesday that agreement on the withdrawals was being held up by a difference of only a few months on the schedule for the pullout. But Ferenc Somogyi, secretary of state in the Hungarian Foreign Ministry and the head of delegation to the negotiations, was quoted by the Hungarian state news agency MTI as saying in Moscow that the Soviet side agreed to the proposed deadline for the completion of the pullout favored by Hungary. The total withdrawal is to be completed by June 30, 1991, MTI reported. The Soviets were reported to have preferred setting the final pullout date for Aug. 31 of next year. Nemeth had said the Soviets wanted the extra two months for dismantling of military stockpiles. Somogyi said that under the terms agreed between the two delegations, no Soviet soldiers or equipment would remain in his country after June 30, 1991, MTI reported. The text of the agreement was initialed by Somogyi and the head of the Soviet delegation, Deputy Foreign Minister Ivan Aboimov, MTI said. There are 49,700 Soviet soldiers in Hungary, according to Hungarian Deputy Chief of Staff Jozsef Biro. Moscow also has 27,146 combat vehicles, including 860 tanks, 600 artillery pieces and 1,500 armored personnel carriers, stationed on Hungarian territory, Biro disclosed last week. Biro said 2,029 military transport trains would be required to transport the troops, non-military personnel and their families and the equipment back to the Soviet Union. The Soviet pullout from Czechoslovakia began last month, with the last of 73,500 Red Army troops there scheduled to depart next year.

DOC.HEAD: Census Information Director Reassigned
DOC.TEXT: The man who had directed public relations for the Census Bureau since 1983 has been moved out of that job just three weeks before the national head count gets into gear. The transfer of James Gorman came after a news story about confusion over how the Commerce Department would observe the moment the nation's population reached 250 million, according to Census employees who spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity. Gorman was quoted by The New York Times as saying ``we couldn't get it together,'' when asked about confusion over staging the event last week. Gorman declined to comment on his transfer to a new post as a senior adviser to the deputy director of the bureau. Officials of the Commerce Department, parent agency for the Census Bureau, were not immediately available. The bureau calculates the nation inceases by one person every 14 seconds, and thus estimated that the quarter-billion population figure was reached March 6. A news release was issued and a photo opportunity scheduled involving Commerce Department officials. But that was later rescheduled from March 6 to March 8 and the site moved from the bureau office in Suitland, Md., to the Commerce Department in downtown Washington. Eventually, the event was dropped altogether. Gorman's comment to the newspaper apparently provoked his transfer, Census employees said, from the public relations post in which he had supervised planning for the current national head count over the last several years. Gorman's post is being filled by an assistant on an acting basis.

DOC.HEAD: Barry Said Planning Early Return to Washington for Election Talk
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry plans to return to the nation's capital from substance abuse treatment in South Carolina on Saturday to talk about the possibility of running for re-election, city government sources said Friday. After a month of treatment at a separate location in Florida, Barry began a 30-day treatment program at Fenwick Hall Hospital outside Charleston two weeks ago. Last weekend, the District of Columbia's non-voting delegate in Congress, Walter Fauntroy, said he would run in November for the mayor's post now held by Barry, who faces an eight-count federal indictment on drug and perjury charges. ``He's very upset about Fauntroy entering the mayor's race, and he's been hurt by the defections of his top advisers,'' said one source familiar with Barry's thinking. ``He plans to talk to these people, and also meet with his people on the ward level to see if he can run again.'' The sources commented on condition of anonymity. Anita Bonds, Barry's campaign manager, acknowledged that Barry was ``disappointed'' by Fauntroy's decision and upset with former supporters who have jumped to Fauntroy's side. ``At this point, he has very little feeling for them,'' Bonds said. ``You will remember, on the weekend following his arrest, a lot of those same people now backing Fauntroy were trying to get Jesse Jackson to run.'' Jackson has since declined to run. Barry was indicted last month on three perjury charges and five misdemeanor counts of cocaine possession. He was arrested Jan. 18 at a downtown hotel by federal agents who said he was smoking crack cocaine. He had told aides privately during the weekend following his arrest that he had abandoned all hopes of running for a fourth four-year term, but he delayed making any public announcement of his plans. Aides have since predicted the mayor would be reluctant to stay out of the race. ``He's got to have some time to get the lay of the land,'' Bonds said. ``I don't believe he will have crystallized his plans in a day or two or anything like that.''

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher Blames Leftists for Tax Revolt Violence
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher on Friday blamed leftist militants for violent protests of a new tax that has sparked a popular revolt, and the opposition leader said the demonstrators were playing into the government's hands. Authorities in the east London borough of Hackney were cleaning up after Thursday night's rampage by opponents of the tax, called the community charge by the Conservative government but popularly known as the poll tax. The revolt is presenting Mrs. Thatcher with a serious political setback, and rumors circulated Friday that she would resign or be fired as Conservative leader. ``We are not at the peak of our popularity,'' said Sir Geoffrey Howe, deputy prime minister, in a radio interview. But he added, ``We have to keep our nerve.'' The crisis also is dividing the opposition Labor Party. Some Laborites are urging a campaign of civil disobedience against the tax, but leader Neil Kinnock said all opposition must be within the law. Mrs. Thatcher blamed a leftist group known as Militant Tendency for the violence that left Hackney's main street strewn with glass, and police have said the disturbances were caused by people from outside the boroughs. ``As you know, it is not the way to conduct affairs at all,'' the prime minister said in Glasgow, Scotland ``Any conduct intimidating or violent is absolutely contradictory to democracy.'' Police arrested about 60 people, nine of whom appeared in court Friday on charges including assault and criminal damage. They said 20 of those arrested gave addresses outside the borough. About 30 police officers were injured, and the extent of the damage was being assessed, police said. The community charge replaces the system of taxing homeowners to pay for government services. Instead, municipal councils will now divide the costs of services equally among all adults in their districts. Charges vary widely, depending on the level of services provided by a district. And since each adult is taxed, it means two people living in a two-room apartment would pay twice as much as one person living next door in an eight-room house. Local legislators in the borough of Haringey met Friday to discuss their district's tax, which at $974 is one of the highest in the country. During a meeting of the council Monday night, demonstrations outside turned violent, and police had to clear shouting protesters from the spectator section. On Friday, about 50 people peacefully protested outside. Both Mrs. Thatcher and Kinnock were in Scotland, which has had its own poll tax for the past year and an estimated half a million people are being prosecuted for failure to pay. Kinnock told the Scottish Labor Party's conference that a Labor government would abolish the poll tax, which he dubbed ``Maggie's tax,'' and replace it with a tax based on property and the ability to pay. But he urged that opposition to it stay within the law. ``We who seek, through democracy, the power to rule by law, cannot pick and choose which laws we obey,'' Kinnock said. He said the demonstrators were helping the Conservatives' cause by using violence to protest. But fellow Laborite Tony Benn said he would not pay the tax, which he called unjust. Mrs. Thatcher tried to dismiss rumors of worries within her government that the poll tax would make the Conservatives lose the next election. ``I find no nervousness in the Cabinet at all,'' she told the BBC. The new tax takes effect April 1 in England and Wales, when local districts must submit to the federal government their annual charges. Disabled people and those with low incomes can receive rebates of up to 80 percent. But critics say that apart from this, the new tax is unfair because it takes no account of an individual's ability to pay. In latest opinion polls, the Conservatives trail Labor by as much as 19 points.
U.S. Applauds Aoun's Call for Ceasefire in Lebanon

The State Department said Friday it is encouraged by the decision of Gen. Michael Aoun to abandon Lebanese warfare for dialogue, and called on him to submit to the authority of the country's government. ``We hope that Gen. Aoun is serious about abandoning violence; the Lebanese people have suffered enough,'' said Margaret Tutwiler, the department's spokeswoman. Aoun called Friday for a ceasefire after a month of bloody fighting and said he was ready for peace negotiations with a rival Christian leader and with leaders of Lebanon's Moslem majority. Aoun also dropped his rejection of the so-called Taif accord, an Arab League plan aimed at settling the 15-year civil war. ``The general should now finally submit to the authority of his country's legitimate government,'' Ms. Tutwiler said. She said the United Sttes is encouraged that Aoun ``may be interested in resolving his diferences through dialogue.'' ``We urge all Lebanese, particularly those elements of the Lebanese army who were misled into using violence, to support (the Lebanese government) and the process of peaceful reconciliation,'' she said and added: ``We continue to belive that the Taif accords represent the best course for settling Lebanon's problems.''

DOC.HEAD: Lights Return, Des Moines Stacks Branches
DOC.TEXT: Tree limbs were stacked head high along curbs in many Des Moines neighborhoods Friday as the metropolitan area cleaned up from what the state climatologist said may have been the ice storm of the century. Two days after central Iowa was glazed with thick ice, temperatures were in the 60s and rivers were rising. The storm stuck at least an inch of ice on tree limbs and power lines Wednesday, cutting electrical service to 91,000 customers _ more than half of the metropolitan area. Iowa Power spokesman Chuck Seel said the company hoped the remaining customers would be hooked up by Sunday. The utility had restored power to all but about 14,000 customers by Friday morning. ``We're tickled to death at how well it's gone,'' Seel said. ``A lot of those who are without service have the toughest repairs,'' he said, such as service lines ripped out of houses by falling limbs. Hundreds of linemen and their boom trucks were brought in from other cities and nearly all were working double shifts. ``There are at least 330 linemen or tree men out there, and 150 worked through the night,'' Seel said. State climatologist Harry Hillaker said other ice storms have caused damage but none were as severe. ``I've checked other storms that were called the worst of this century, and this one was more widespread,'' he said. Rivers were swollen with runoff Friday as the ice melted but no flooding was reported. The storm also iced sections of states north and west of Iowa. Two days earlier it dumped as much as 50 inches of snow on Colorado and Wyoming. Major highways in southeastern Wyoming weren't reopened until late Thursday. Des Moines and its suburbs urged homeowners to haul tree limbs broken by the weight of the ice out to the curb, where they would be hauled away within several weeks. Huge stacks of twisted branches began to appear Thursday, sometimes spilling on to street or sidewalks. One woman said the experience was enough to make Californians thankful that all they have to worry about are earthquakes. ``People are always telling me that they wouldn't live in California because they don't want to be in an earthquake. What I went through here, trees crashing and everything, was as bad as going through an earthquake,'' said Mary Marie Scatterlee of San Jose, Calif., who was visiting Des Moines when the storm hit. Although falling trees hit practically everything and traffic lights did not work, no serious injuries or deaths were attributed to the storm. Melted ice cream drooled out of freezers and meat spoiled as many residents and businesses saw their third day without electricity. Businesses without power simply shut down, as did Des Moines schools and Drake University for a second day Friday, but some improvised to serve their customers. Tait's Super Valu, a grocery store, opened for five hours Thursday after an employee donated a generator to run lights and coolers. But there wasn't enough power to run the checkout computers and price scanners. Customers were asked to remember what things cost and checkers punched adding machines. ``It's hard to tell how much we lost, but people who shop at grocery stores are generally honest,'' said grocery manager Tim Harrington. ``It worked pretty well. And people weren't buying large quantities of things, since they didn't have refrigeration at home, either,'' he said. Des Moines Cold Storage Co. Inc., housing 20 million pounds of perishable goods, was able to save most of its stock. ``It's perishables of all descriptions,'' said President Chuck Muelhaupt. ``That's meat, ice cream, vegetables. We were scared to death. If it hadn't come on, you would have seen the biggest mass of melted ice cream. You would have had the world's largest garbage dump.''

DOC.HEAD: JANA Appeals to Arab News Agencies to Fight `Campaign of Lies'
DOC.TEXT: The official Libyan news agency appealed to Arab news agencies on Friday to combat a U.S. ``campaign of lies'' regarding a plant outside Tripoli that Washington says produces chemical weapons. ``The Rabta plant in Great Jamahiriya (Libya) is a plant for the production of medicines and medical equipment,'' the general secretary of the news agency, JANA, was quoted as saying. His comments were in a telex sent to directors of the Federation of Arab News Agencies and the agencies of the Arab Maghreb Union and the Arab News Federation. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater alleged this week that the plant 60 miles south of Tripoli was producing poison gas. Other U.S. officials said the plant was making limited amounts of mustard gas and nerve agents. West German Foreign Ministry spokesman Hanns Schumacher said Friday there are ``vague indications about a possible production of a limited amount of about 30 tons of mustard gas'' at the plant. The information came from West German intelligence early this year, and U.S. officials were immediately informed about the report, the spokesman said. Relations between Bonn and Washington were strained early last year after U.S. officials accused West German companies of helping Libya build the plant. The West German government first denied the allegations but later launched its own probe which is still pending. ``The U.S. administration ... leads a campaign of lies and false accusations from which it aims to mislead the world public opinion claiming that this cultural medical plant is a plant for chemical weapons,'' said the JANA director, who was not identified. JANA said its director called on the Arab agencies to join in ``Arab solidarity in the face of the biased informational media campaign and to foil the whole U.S. aggressive scheme.'' U.S. officials have said they want the Rabta plant dismantled. West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher has called for international inspections to be carried out at Rabta. Libya has repeatedly denied the Rabta plant is designed to produce chemical weapons or that it has begun manufacturing poison gas.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Panel Allows Pentagon to Shift Funds, But House Balks
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Armed Services Committee has voted to grant the Pentagon part of the authority to transfer money to military personnel accounts and avert massive layoffs, the panel's chairman said Friday. But the action should have little overall effect on the department's request since Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, has refused to take up the issue in his panel. Such shifting of funds must be approved by the House and Senate armed services panels and the House and Senate appropriations committees. The Defense Department originally asked Congress for the authority to transfer $935 million from weapons and other accounts to personnel to avoid laying off tens of thousands of men and women, freezing promotions and holding up transfers. The drastic steps are required under the Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction law. But Aspin said President Bush could have exempted personnel from the law back on Aug. 15, as past administrations have done, and declined to take up the Pentagon's request. ``Putting weapons before people was their decision and now they're stuck with it,'' Aspin said late last month. Nevertheless, the Senate committee voted in executive session Thursday to approve 85 percent of the Pentagon's request, or $795 million from weapons to personnel accounts. The action would force the Defense Department to take some voluntary steps, including reducing the number of new recruits during the rest of fiscal 1990 and allowing some people to leave 90 days before their service ends. The department would be spared involuntary, adverse personnel actions. ``We voted on the side of the men and women in the military who were put at risk by the administration's decision not to use its authority to exempt the military personnel accounts,'' Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., the Armed Services chairman, said in a speech on the Senate floor Friday. In a related development, Aspin said Friday significant cuts in defense spending are possible over the next several years, but initial cuts will have to be small. A ``concerted and strategic effort is needed to restructure our armed forces consistent with the imperative to buy the right combination of forces, equipment, operational readiness and research in this time of great change and uncertainity,'' he said. In a letter to the Rep. Leon Panetta, D-Calif., chairman of the House Budget Committee, Aspin declined to reveal his overall figure for the fiscal 1991 defense budget. The Bush administration has proposed a budget of $306.7 billion, including funds for defense, the Department of Energy and military construction. In a Republican response to Aspin's letter, Rep. William Dickinson, R-Ala., expressed his support for the administration's budget and warned against deep cuts in defense spending. ``Although most of us feel more secure when assessing Soviet military intentions, Soviet military capability, even after the pending CFE and START agreements are concluded, remains formidable,'' said Dickinson, the panel's ranking GOP member. Nunn, in a letter to the Senate Budget Committee, said he couldn't provide an overall figure for the fiscal 1991 defense budget because the Pentagon hasn't produced a comprehensive five-year defense plan. In addition, Nunn noted the Pentagon is currently reviewing several big-ticket programs such as the B-2 stealth bomber, the C-17 transport plane and the Strategic Defense Initiative. ``In order for the Armed Services Committee and the whole Congress to make decisions on the fiscal 1991 defense budget, we must have a clear picture of where our defense policies are going over the next three to five years,'' Nunn said in a three-page letter.

DOC.HEAD: Moscow Embassy Official Discloses Wider Dissemination For Terror Warning
DOC.TEXT: An official from the U.S. Embassy in Moscow testified Friday that a terrorist warning prior to the December 1988 bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 was widely distributed to Americans in Moscow and given to Soviet officials. The State Department previously acknowledged only that the notice was improperly posted in the embassy a week before Flight 103 blew up over Lockerbie, Scotland, killing 270 people. Officials said the posting violated a policy against notifying government workers when other prospective passengers are not told of a threat. Raymond F. Smith, who was acting deputy chief of mission in Moscow at the time, told the Presidential Commission on Aviation Security and Terrorism that he felt a ``moral obligation to let people know'' about the threat against Pan Am flights between Frankfurt and the United States. Smith said, in sworn testimony, that he knew of no other embassy that disseminated the notice publicly. State Department officials have said the threat turned out to be a hoax orginating in Helsinki, Finland, despite the fact it fit the Lockerbie bombing. Smith said embassy officials decided in a top-level staff meeting to give the notice the widest distribution possible, posting it at several strategic places around the compound and sending it to a company that contracted work?z????
DOC.HEAD: ?ld see it and
DOC.TEXT: to the Soviet government. The official, who is now Moscow embassy political counsellor, said he also notified the Federal Aviation Administration, which had originated the advisory, that the notice was being posted, and received no response. The embassy notice said employees were left to their own discretion on whether to change travel plans but noted they still were required to fly on an American carrier. Pan Am was the only U.S. carrier flying out of Moscow, although other airlines could be used from Europe to the United States. Also at the hearing, the commission disclosed a Telex from Pan Am's Moscow office saying that 80 percent of Moscow passengers were changing their bookings as a result of the posted threat. But the official who sent the internal Telex, the airline's former Moscow manager Jennifer S. Young, testified that she had no direct knowledge of any cancelations and used the 80-percent figure to give her missive more impact. Ms. Young said a part-time reservations clerk at Pan Am's office in the embassy had told her there were several inquiries about the notice and she got the impression there also were cancelations. Commission Chairwoman Ann McLaughlin said the panel staff has yet to find hard evidence of any changes in bookings as a result of the threat but has asked Pan Am for passenger data and is continuing its investigation. Relatives of some of the U.S. victims of the Dec. 21, 1988, bombing have questioned why the plane had more than 160 empty seats on a flight during a busy holiday period and say they believe government workers canceled because of the selective warning. Family members of victims filled the first three rows at the hearing, which is the commission's fourth since it began its work last September. Mrs. McLaughlin, former labor secretary, said the commission has conducted 150 interviews in the United States, England, Germany, France, the Soviet Union and Turkey and has accumulated thousands of pages of testimony. The panel, which has a $1 million budget, has until May 15 to complete a report to President Bush that will recommend government actions to combat aviation terrorism. In addition to former Labor Secretary Mclaughlin, members include Sens. Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y., and Frank Lautenberg, D-N.J., Reps. James Oberstar, D-Minnesota, and John Hammerschmidt, R-Ark., retired Air Force Gen. Thomas C. Richards and lawyer Edward Hidalgo.

DOC.HEAD: Settlements Grow With Government Incentives
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1st graf to ADD dropped word ``for.''
DOC.TEXT: Many Israelis are lured to the West Bank by cheap land, low or interest-free mortgages and the desire for the space they lack in most of the country's crowded cities. Such benefits have played a significant role in attracting 75,000 Jews to 143 settlements in the past two decades. They are also a selling point in efforts by settlement leaders to attract Soviet Jews who are flooding into Israel. A new controversy erupted over the settlements following Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's suggestion _ which he quickly withdrew _ that Israel might need the land captured in the 1967 Middle East War for settling tens of thousands of new Soviet immigrants. His remark set off Arab fears of Israel annexing the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip and prompted U.S. warnings that Israel would not receive $400 million in requested housing guarantees if it settled Soviet Jews on occupied land. Shamir stressed there was no policy of settling Soviet Jews in occupied areas, and ``there are no special incentives'' beyond those given to development towns in remote areas of Israel where tax breaks are provided to encourage growth and industry. Israel Harel, editor of the settler magazine Nekuda, said a drive to bring Soviet immigrants to the territories has been ``without much success.'' He said that only about 200 have been placed in the West Bank and even they had not made a final decision to live there. The reasons varied. ``Most of the settlements are religious, and the immigrants are secular. They like to go to cities, not small villages like ours. The intefadeh (uprising) doesn't help the cause, either,'' he said. Meron Benvenisti, an ex-deputy mayor of Jerusalem who has studied the territories for a decade, said even without new enticements existing benefits for any West Bank settler were considerable. He estimated the government and the World Zionist Organization have spent $2.5 billion in the past 20 years building and maintaining the settlements. The government has paid for roads, lighting and other site preparations. It also allocates more money per pupil to educate settlement children and covers the cost of their busing, Benvenisti said. Settlers enjoy a 7 percent reduction in income taxes and industries opening in the territories receive a 40 percent grant for the purchase of equipment, he said. Also, Benvenisti said, the Israel Lands Authority sells settlers building plots from land expropriated from Arabs for 5 percent of the assessed value. About 40 percent of the West Bank was taken over by the state under a 1980 decree that expropriated all unregistered and uncultivated land. Settlement leaders are eager to recruit and have mounted a campaign to attract both Soviet immigrants and native-born Israelis. Color glossy brochures promise day-care centers, ``clear mountain air'' and ``activities for all ages.'' A flyer from Beit Abba, near Tel Aviv, pictures a spacious swimming pool. One from Beit Aryeh advertises a community ``for people with initiative and creativity ... in the center of the country,'' although it is not in Israel but in the West Bank. And in the West Bank settlement of Ariel, where 8,000 people live about 25 miles north of Jerusalem, a program has been set up to help Soviet immigrants. It provides temporary housing free of charge and arranges for a family to adopt newcomers to help get them through government red tape. Language classes and assistance in finding jobs and permanent housing are also available. ``We make them feel very wanted,'' said Dina Shalit, a mayoral assistant for immigration affairs. She said Soviet immigrants interested in settling in Ariel usually have family or friends among the 150 Russian families who were among the original founders in the 1970s. In the past six months, about 55 Soviet Jewish families have come to Ariel. But not all the efforts are successful, one reason being that the Palestinian uprising means most settlers carry arms and have to be alert constantly for attackers with stones and firebombs. Leaders of the Gush Katif block of settlements in the Gaza Strip recently organized a tour for Soviet newcomers, but spokesman Menachem Beit Halachmi conceded there have been no takers so far. But the settlements have succeeded in attracting Israelis, mostly ardent nationalists who believe living on the war-won land will help in making it a permanent part of Israel. The settlements have grown by 15 percent in the past two years despite the uprising in which more than 600 Palestinians and 43 Israelis have died. ``Most of the people who come to us are coming for ideological reasons despite the intefadeh,'' Harel said. But a main attraction for many, especially in the Jerusalem and Tel Aviv areas, is a better standard of living than can be found in cramped city apartments. In the hilltop settlement of Har Adar, six miles northwest of Jerusalem, 240 families have built luxurious carved stone villas for the price of a three-bedroom apartment in Jerusalem. ``We moved out here because we wanted to live in a house and we couldn't afford it in the city ... and here we are only 20 minutes from downtown,'' said Debbie Zuberi, 33, who emigrated from San Francisco 12 years ago and lives in a three-story home with a view of Jerusalem. Shalit of Ariel explained the trend: ``It's like the one-time American push to the suburbs. People are looking for cleaner air, less traffic, bigger homes and better schools,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Unemployment in 11 Major States
With AM-Unemployment Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are the February unemployment rates for 11 large states as reported Friday by the Labor Department: California, 4.9 percent, down from 5.2 percent in January. Florida, 6 percent, up from 5.5 percent. Illinois, 5.9 percent, down from 6.4 percent. Massachusetts, 5.3 percent, up from 4.5 percent. Michigan, 7.7 percent, down from 8.4 percent. New Jersey, 4.5 percent, down from 4.6 percent. New York, 5 percent, up from 4.7 percent. North Carolina, 3.6 percent, down from 3.7 percent. Ohio, 5.8 percent, down from 6.7 percent. Pennsylvania, 5.7 percent, up from 5.2 percent. Texas, 6.4 percent, up from 5.2 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Collision Between Tug and Freighter Closes Mississippi River
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with barges rounded up, other details
DOC.TEXT: Tugboats on Friday rounded up as many as 14 runaway grain barges that had broken loose during a collision. A 20-mile stretch of the Mississippi River was kept closed, hwoever, to enable the Coast Guard to determine whether three sunken barges endangered navigation. ``I'm told it looks like a river rodeo with tugs chasing barges all over the place,'' Petty Officer Bob Morehead said before private tugboats rounded up the barges in three hours. There were no reports of injuries. The barges got loose after a freighter heading upriver at 6:30 a.m., collided with an oncoming tugboat, the Coral Dawn, which was towing as many as 30 barges carrying grain. Three barges sank after the collision, Morehead said. The freighter, the Nancy Lykes, did not appear to be leaking, he said. Coast Guard Chief Joe Gibson said the river would probably reopen later Friday. Investigators must first determine that the sunken barges are not a danger to other vessels, he said. The collision occurred near White Castle, about 20 miles south of Baton Rouge. Coast Guard Capt. William Loesfstedt, captain of the port for the New Orleans-Baton Rouge area, ordered the river closed from mile marker 180 to mile marker 200.

DOC.HEAD: 19 Killed in Factional Fighting, Whites Blame Gov't Concessions
LaserPhoto JOH2
DOC.TEXT: Police said Friday that 19 blacks were killed in factional fighting near Johannesburg, and right-wing whites blamed government concessions to blacks for the upsurge in violence nationwide. ``This country is burning literally and figuratively ... and you are responsible for it,'' Moolman Mentz of the pro-apartheid Conservative Party told President F.W. de Klerk at a Parliamentary debate in Cape Town. De Klerk legalized more than 60 opposition groups Feb. 2 to help clear the way for negotiations on ending white-minority rule and sharing political power with the black majority. In the past month, violence in black townships and tribal homelands has left 200 people dead in some of the worst fighting since the nationwide black unrest of 1984-86. Mentz, whose party is the official opposition in the white chamber of Parliament, said the reforms had emboldened black nationalist groups to try to seize power. Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok told Parliament the government was determined to end unrest and was prepared to use its extensive powers under the 3{-year-old state of emergency to quell the violence. The worst fighting was in Kathlehong, about 12 miles east of Johannesburg, where five people were killed overnight and 14 more bodies were found during the day Friday, police said. The fighting began several days ago between rival black taxi groups over control of routes and other local problems not directly related to politics. The dispute has escalated and groups of black youths have been waging running battles against each other, according to police and witnesses. Houses have been attacked with fire bombs, vehicles have been stoned and set on fire and there has been sporadic gunfire. Most of the dead were stabbed or hacked to death, police said. Also, police said they detained 53 blacks without charges in the central Orange Free State Province. Police said the blacks were picked up during an overnight sweep through the townships, but declined to elaborate. Police said they arrested 67 whites armed with whips and other weapons who tried to disrupt a legal march by black teachers in the central town of Welkom. The South African government charged Thursday that some anti-apartheid groups arebehind the outbreak of violence in tribal homelands because they are not ready to participate in negotiations with the white government. But ANC leader Walter Sisulu said Friday the government was reverting ``to the old approach of looking for scapegoats and hidden instigators.'' ``The primary reason for the unrest, conflict and confrontation has always been the poverty and violence caused by apartheid,'' Sisulu said. Benny Alexander, leader of the Pan Africanist Congress, a rival black guerrilla group, said his organization would neither confirm nor deny that it was behind the recent violence. Meanwhile, residents in the nominally independent black homeland of Bophuthatswana said Friday that scattered clashes with security forces were continuing. Seven people were killed and up to 500 hurt in Bophuthatswana earlier this week after police fired on protesters demanding the resignation of the homeland's authoritarian government and the territory's reintegration into South Africa. The authoritarian president of the Ciskei homeland was ousted Sunday in a coup by its own military. Four of South Africa's 10 black homelands are considered independent by the Pretoria government, but none is recognized abroad. South Africa established the homelands in the 1960s in an attempt to create separate, tribal-based states for blacks, while whites would retain control of national politics and the economy. About 14 million of the country's 28 million blacks live in the territories.

DOC.HEAD: Orange Crop Prospects Improve
DOC.TEXT: Orange harvest prospects continue to improve but production is still down sharply from last season because of widespread freeze damage in late December, the Agriculture Department said Friday. The new estimate of 172 million boxes was based on March 1 indications and is up 2 percent from the February forecast of less than 169 million boxes. But the freeze-damaged crop is expected to be down 18 percent from 209 million boxes in 1988-89. Most of the reduction was attributed to a 30 percent decline in the Florida crop. Florida's orange harvest was estimated at 103 million boxes, down from 146.6 million last season but up from 100 million forecast last month. The Texas crop was indicated at 1.2 million boxes, down from 1.85 million in 1988-89 but unchanged from the February forecast. California production, estimated at 66 million boxes, is up from 58.8 million last season but unchanged from last month. Arizona production, indicated at 1.7 million boxes, was carried forward from the earlier forecast and is the same as last season. Total grapefruit production was forecast at 41.6 million boxes, unchanged from February but 36 percent below last year, reflecting the freeze in Florida and Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Kabul Devastated By Coup
With AM-Afghanistan, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Najib had just finished lunch when a series of bombs exploded several yards from where he was sitting, signaling the start of a coup attempt that almost toppled his government. Explosions rocked the Presidential Palace shortly after 1 p.m. Tuesday, killing four soldiers from the elite presidential guard. One cluster of three small bombs gouged out two craters and gutted an adminstrative office 12 feet from where Najib was working. The force of the blast cracked the walls of Najib's office, said Lt. Col. Mohammad Hussan, who was on duty at the time. Windows shattered around the president but he apparently emerged unscathed. Interviews Friday with government officials and witnesses, both soldiers and civilians, painted a vivid picture of the bloody attempt to topple Najib's Soviet-installed government. The attempt was the eighth since Najib became president in 1988. Despite its failure, the coup is expected to damage Najib, who also faces continued pressure from U.S.-backed anti-Communist guerrillas. Tension had been mounting before the bombing began. On Tuesday morning, Najib talked to Defense Minister Shah Nawaz Tanai and urged him not to attempt the coup, Najib told a news conference Thursday. The main disagreement, according to government officials, was that Tanai opposed the arrests of 127 people who were being placed on trial for an alleged coup attempt in December. Government spokesman Naqib Sameer said Tanai opposed the trial because it would reveal his links to the plot. But Tanai supporters said the defense minister was worried about driving another wedge between the already faction-ridden ruling party, the People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan. On Monday, the trial started. The next day Najib called his defense minister and suggested negotiations. Tanai refused. The rebel bombing began shortly after 12:30 p.m. as the city settled down to lunch. The first bombs hit the city center, near two empty high schools closed due to lack of funds for education and fuel to heat the school. As many as five jets at a time sped over the capital. One dropped a 500-pound bomb in the old city near the serpentine streets of the grain bazaar. ``I was sitting here fixing watches when the houses across the street just collapsed,'' said Haji Mallem, a watch-mender who works on the main old city thoroughfare. ``Everybody started screaming and running. Glass flew everywhere. I saw about 15 people blown apart.'' ``Whoever did it wasn't a good Moslem,'' one man shouted from a crowd that had gathered around Mallen to help tell the story. More bombs fell throughout the afternoon. From his headquarters at the Defense Ministry, Tanai sneaked to Bagram air base north of the city, another cener for renegade forces. The early hours of the coup appeared to favor the mutineers. Bombs at Kabul Radio forced officials to switch broadcasting locations. Parliamentarian and alleged coup participant Saleh Mohammad Zeray went to Radio Kabul to announce that Tanai's forces had won. He was arrested with the statement in his pocket, a government source said. Bakhtar reported Friday that he had been purged of his party posts. The government was fighting back.
