Withering fire from loyalist tanks and rockets destroyed the coup headquarters at the Defense Ministry located in the pastel-colored Darulaman Palace, built after 1919 to house an Afghan king. Loyalist tanks and footsoldiers with hand-held rockets surrounded the building during a 24 hour assault. On Friday, the building was a shell of its former self, with huge holes gaping from its facade. An onslaught of gunfire destroyed another palace, the Tajbig near the Darulaman. A fire gutted most of the marble building. Food lay rotting in an open oven. Government troops also attacked Bagram air base, another rebel stronghold. By Tuesday night, government forces were firing Scud and Katyusha rockets at the base, destroying it. By Wednesday afternoon, most of the fighting had stopped. Arrests began. Five members of the Politburo, including Tanai, were purged from their posts. Some escaped and some have disappeared. Two Central Committee members, including Zeray, also were removed. Squads of security forces entered government housing projects and arrested scores of alleged participants, government sources said. One trial began Thursday. A special tribunal set up by Najib will handle the case. The Bakhtar news agency promised punishment ``in accordance with Afghan tradition.'' Death sentences were expected.

DOC.HEAD: Barbecue Grills Have Defective Parts
DOC.TEXT: A major manufacturer of outdoor barbecue grills and accessories is warning consumers to check their equipment before firing up because a part may be defective. The Illinois-based Thermos Co. said this week it is voluntarily replacing a component part of its ``Thermos'' and ``Structo'' gas barbecue grills because it might leak gas and cause a fire. Thermos said it would replace the hose, valve and regulator assembly of the two models. Approximately 87,600 grills sold since April 1989 may be involved, the company said. The company said the retrofitting program applies only to models stamped ``Taiwan Pao-An Ind. Co.'' with serial numbers between 721791 and 886390. The stamp can be found on the round metal regulator which connects to the liquid propane gas tank that sits on a shelf under the grill. Consumers with the defective grills should call the Thermos Co. at 1-800-446-0475 between 9 a.m. and 5:30 p.m. EST weekdays.

DOC.HEAD: Mongolian Communists Agree to Consider Resignation of Leadership
DOC.TEXT: The Mongolian Communist Party Central Committee bowed to mass demonstrations Friday and agreed to consider ousting the entire ruling Politburo, Tass reported. The announcement by Mongolian President and Communist Party leader Zhambyn Batmunh on the land-locked nation's television marked the first time that the revolution sweeping through the Communist bloc has threatened a regime in Asia. Friday's events brought the wave of political reform to the doorstep of China, which has crushed its own democracy movement last spring with the army attack on protesters in Beijing. Protesters crowded the vast central square of Ulan Bator, the Mongolian capital, on Friday to demand a new constitution and creation of a provisional congress with the participation of all public forces, the Soviet news agency said. It gave no estimate of the size of the crowd, but said the site is normally deserted on a workday. Demonstrators in the square also demanded an emergency party congress and change in the party's leadership. Many speakers called for a general strike starting Saturday, Tass said. Batmunh responded Friday evening on national television with the promise that the Communist Party's Central Committee will meet Monday to consider the resignation of the top leaders in the Politburo and the convening of a special party congress, Tass said. Batmunh also promised a referendum so the people could cast a vote of confidence, or lack of it, in the Great People's Hural, or congress. Tass said members of the Mongolian Democratic Union and other public movements ended their three-day hunger strike after the announcement Friday, because their demands had been met. Tass apparently was referring to the group's immediate goals, because the Democratic Union also is calling for an end to the Communist Party's 69-year monopoly on power, a multiparty system and resignation of the premier, Cabinet and congress. Premier Dumaagiyn Sodnom said Thursday the government would cooperate with the Democratic Union on reforms. Foreign sources estimated 8,000 to 10,000 Mongolians demonstrated Sunday in the central square in front of the congress building. Speakers at that rally demanded the Communist Party give up its 69-year monopoly on power. Protesters also have been complaining about long-term Soviet domination of their nation of 2 million people, accusing their enormous neighbor of ``pushing Mongolia into a debtor's prison'' by forcing it to build enormous, unprofitable construction projects with Soviet help and paying poorly for Mongolia's valuable natural resources, said the Soviet newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda on Wednesday. Western economists estimate Mongolia's debt to the Soviet Union at nearly $6 billion. Komsomolskaya Pravda was defensive about the history of Soviet relations with Mongolia but said the protesters were just in criticizing the bureaucratic system and demanding faster ``perestroika.'' The Soviet newspaper used the same word for ``reconstruction'' that Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev uses for his reform program. Mongolian protesters also have demanded the removal of 60,000 Soviet troops and 50,000 Soviet advisers and their families. Soviet officials agreed last week to withdraw all their troops from Mongolia by 1992, as part of Gorbachev's announced pull-back of Soviet forces around the world.

DOC.HEAD: Nintendo World Championship Opens in Dallas
LaserPhoto DN7 of March 8
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of nimble-fingered competitors lined up to be mesmerized, Tetrisized and bamboozled at the Nintendo World Championships, and an 11-year-old video-game whizkid had an advice line open for strugglers. Organizers expected more than 40,000 people to attend the four-day championships that opened in a Dallas exhibition hall Thursday night. More than 1 million people are likely to try their luck during a 34-city tour that ends in Orlando in November, the organizers said. It was a time of heartbreak and joy for youngsters taking their first jab at video glory. John Mulhausen looked a cinch to win his age bracket. As others struggled to score 150,000, the 11-year-old breezed through the quarter-finals with scores of 410,000 and 343,700. The game master told the crowd John was visiting from outer space. Winning is simply a matter of concentration. ``The thing is, to keep your mind clear and alert and try to go for it,'' he said. His father, also named John, acknowledged that ``it's pretty exciting watching him.'' ``A lot of kids call him and ask him questions about games,'' he said. Organizers set up a ``power walk'' where visitors can play Nintendo video games on about 250 hand-held and full-size terminals. That is, until they can't take it anymore. Kathy Prather described the $2 million show as ``a Las Vegas setup of video game entertainment.'' ``With 20 million Nintendo households nationwide, everybody plays it at home, so why not have a video game showdown?'' she said. Nintendo Entertainment Systems, produced by Japanese-owned Nintendo of America Inc., has led the resurgence in home video games, with a unit in one out of every four American homes. It has sold more than 100 million game cartridges, and expects to hit 171.5 million by the end of the year. Nintendo was the No. 1 selling toy last year, with estimated sales of $2.7 billion. Nintendo features hero characters Mario and his brother Luigi, who seek to rescue Princess Toadstool in the popular Super Mario Brothers games. For an admission price of $12.50 for adults and $9.50 for under 18-year-olds, visitors get unlimited playing time on the games, most of which are not yet available commercially, Ms. Prather said. Advisers were on hand to help stumped enthusiasts. For an additional $3, you can try your fingers in the competition, which features three games: the original Super Mario Brothers, Rad Racer and Tetris, one of the current favorites. The top scorers advance to succeeding levels of competition, with city champions competing in Orlando. Rad Racer is a racing game and Tetris, developed by a Soviet programmer, is a geometric puzzle where players try to fit different shapes into straight lines. The exhibition will be packed into 54 trailer trucks and hauled to Cleveland next week. Other stops include Philadelphia, Pittsburgh, Detroit, Indianapolis, Boston, New York and Chicago.

DOC.HEAD: Karpov, Timman Draw Second Game
DOC.TEXT: Anatoli Karpov of the Soviet Union and Jan Timman of the Netherlands on Friday drew their second game in the World Chess Championship Candidates' match after 42 moves Karpov, playing white, offered the draw after Timman managed to neutralize Karpov's queenside majority. The second game of the 12-game match started off as a King's Indian Defense with Karpov playing the Fianchetto variation. Timman then adopted a Gruenfeld set-up. Black was able to mobilize his pieces quickly and freed his position. There soon followed a series of exchanges leaving a level knights and pawns ending. Karpov arrived at Kuala Lumpur City Hall auditorium looking rested and confident after Thursday's win. With Friday's draw, Karpov has 1{ points, while Timman has {. The first to reach 6{ points will move on to challenge world champion Garri Kasparov for the world crown in Lyons, France, in October. Saturday will be a rest day, and the third game resumes Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Clean Air
Coloado, Virginia, South Carolina Park Study Says Polluters Escaping
DOC.TEXT: The Environmental Protection Agency's program to reduce air pollution over national parks and wilderness areas is so riddled with shortcomings that most polluters escape federal regulation, a congressional study said Friday. Only about 1 percent of all the pollution sources studied, accounting for about 10 percent of the pollution, are regulated, the General Accounting Office said in a report on pollution of five parks and wilderness areas. A dozen years after enactment of laws to preserve clean air over national parks and wilderness areas ``the federal program set up to do the job have either failed or have never been tried,'' said Rep. Mike Synar, D-Okla. Synar is chairman of the Government Operations subcommittee on environment, energy and natural resources, which asked for the study by the General Accounting Office and conducted a hearing on it Friday. The GAO is the investigatory arm of Congress, William Rosenberg, the EPA's assistant administrator for air and radiation, acknowledged that some national parks are experiencing poor air quality because of pollution from nearby urban areas or in some cases pollution that may originate hundreds of miles away. The EPA pollution control program for parks and wilderness areas ``was never designed or envisioned to affect sources which existed prior to 1977 unless or until they undergo major modification ... (and) was structured to focus primarily on major sources,'' Rosenberg told the subcommittee. The five areas studied were affected by 2,330 stationary sources of pollution, the GAO said, but only 27 were regulated. The rest were exempt either because they were too small to come under the statute or had existed before enactment of the 1977 law, although they together accounted for some 90 percent of the pollution over the parks and wilderness grounds. Among the pollutants found in the air at the five sites were sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, carbon monoxide, smoke, dust and soot and ozone. The investigators said that although only five locations were examined, similar pollution likely exists in most of the other 153 national parks or wilderness areas singled out for special air quality control treatment under 1977 amendments to the Clean Air Act. The five locations examined by the GAO were the Rocky Mountain National Park and Flat Tops Wilderness Area, both in Colorado; the Shenandoah National Park and James River Face Wilderness Area in Virginia; and the Cape Romain Wilderness Area in South Carolina. At Shenandoah, where ozone levels in 1988 exceeded national health standards, 83 percent and 95 percent of two chemicals that create smog came from sources that were exempt from the regulations, the GAO said. At the two Colorado sites nearly two-thirds of the smoke, dust and soot found in the air came from small sources not covered by the regulations, the agency continued. The GAO recommended that the EPA review air quality programs at more parks and wilderness areas and if similar situations are found, ask Congress to tighten the provisions so smaller and older sources of pollution are covered by the control requirements.

DOC.HEAD: Disabled Cargo Jet Lands in Georgia After Flight From Panama
DOC.TEXT: An Air Force cargo jet carrying 26 people lost partial use of its landing gear during takeoff from Panama on Friday and landed at Robins Air Force Base, officials said. The C-141 jet landed at 3:45 p.m. It came in on its left landing gear, which was functional, and only brief sparks and smoke were visible as the right side of the plane came down on the runway. Emergency crews sprayed firefighting foam on the plane as a precaution. There were no immediate reports of injuries. The plane was ``bringing military people out of Panama, back to their bases,'' when it lost its right main landing gear upon takeoff at Howard Air Force Base, said Cliff Tyler, a Robins spokesman. The four-engine plane originally was headed for Charleston Air Force Base in South Carolina and is based at McGuire Air Force Base in New Jersey, Tyler said. Robins is a major repair center for C-141s.

DOC.HEAD: Rain Across The East, More Snow In Northwest
DOC.TEXT: Rain was scattered across much of the East on Friday, and rain also fell in the Northwest, with snow at higher elevations. Rain fell across North and South Carolina, western Virginia, southern West Virginia, southern Kentucky, Tennessee, northern Georgia, northeastern Alabama, western New York state, eastern Ohio and western Pennsylvania. Heaviest rainfall during the six hours up to noon was 0.61 of an inch at Chattanooga, Tenn., and 0.56 of an inch at Athens, Ga., the National Weather Service reported. Rain also extended over the northern Pacific Coast, changing to snow in the higher mountains. Overnight snowfall included 3 inches at Timberline, Ore., and 2 inches at Mount Hood Meadows, Ore. On Thursday, 8 inches of snow fell at Stampede Pass, Wash., bringing total snow cover there to 101 inches, or about 8{ feet deep. Elsewhere, light rain fell across southeastern Minnesota. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 33 at Duluth, Minn., and Sault Ste. Marie, Mich., to 86 at Harlingen, Texas. Friday's low for the Lower 48 states was 4 above zero at Saranac Lake, N.Y.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinians Hold General Strike; Girl Dies of Wounds
DOC.TEXT: A 10-year-old Arab girl died Friday, one day after being wounded during a clash with Israeli soldiers, as Palestinians held a general strike to mark the beginning of the 28th month of their uprising, Arab reports said. Fourteen Palestinians were reported wounded in clashes in the occupied Gaza Strip on Friday, hospital officials there said. Doctors at Jenin Hosptial in the occupied West Bank said the girl, Ibib Zekarneh, was admitted Thursday after being hit in the head with a steel pellet. The army said it was checking the reports. Her death brought to 660 the number of Palestinians killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians since the uprising against Israeli occupation began in December 1987. Forty-three Israelis have also died in the violence. In the Bureij refugee camp in the Gaza Strip, Israeli troops fired tear gas and plastic bullets to break up an anniversary demonstration and at least eight Palstinians were wounded, hospital officials said. They said one casualty was an 18-year-old youth who was shot in the head and was transferred to a hospital in Israel in critical condition. At least six other Palestinians were wounded during stone-throwing clashes with Israeli troops in the Gaza Strip, hospital officials said. Also Friday, a 29-year-old Lebanese man suspected of collaborating with Israel was found strangled in a prison shower, Israeli reports said. Neither Israel radio nor the national news agency Itim identified the man, but said he was serving a life term in Ashkelon prison for security offenses. The reports said prison authorities suspected his cell mate, a Palestinian from the Gaza Strip, killed the prisoner in the belief he was a collaborator. Prison officials could not be reached for comment. At least 194 Arabs have been killed by Palestinians during the revolt, most on suspicion of collaborating with Israeli authorities. The general strike was called by the underground leadership of the insurrection and the Islamic Resistance Movement-Hamas, and was widely observed throughout lands seized from Jordan and Egypt in the 1967 Middle East war, Arab reports said. In Bethlehem, shops closed and most workers stayed home. Among the slogans that appeared throughout the city, one read, ``The Unified National Command commits its people to continuing the uprising,'' Arab reports said. Entrances to many villages were blocked with stones and burning tires to prevent people from going to work and students stayed out of schools. Arab reporters said the streets of Nablus were deserted and transportation came to a halt. Only military jeeps and trucks could be seen moving. Security forces in the Gaza Strip sealed one room of a three-room house in the Bureij camp belonging to 21-year-old Hamed Salem, who was arrested early this year and charged with throwing stones at Israeli cars.

DOC.HEAD: President's Challenger Drops Out of Election
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS five grafs after 13th `Chiang Wego...' with fires set in national legislature, campus dormitory; pickup graf 14 pvs `Also Friday...'
DOC.TEXT: Taiwan's justice chief said Friday he will drop his challenge to President Lee Teng-hui in this month's presidential election, defusing a crisis that threatened to split the ruling party. The announcement leaves a clear path to election for Lee, who was endorsed last month as the official candidate of the ruling Nationalist Party. The party's elder members are uncomfortable with Lee, a native Taiwanese, because they fear he does not share their intense desire to return to the Chinese mainland and believe he is trying to amass too much power. Lin Yang-kang, the popular 62-year-old judiciary chief, made the announcement he would drop from the race after a 20-minute meeting with eight party veterans who Lee had asked to find a resolution to the political battle. ``I decided that I should not do anything to hurt the nation and people's welfare,'' Lin told reporters afterward. About 200 aging members of the electoral college had thrown their support behind Lin for president and Chiang Wego, the sole surviving son of Nationalist leader Chiang Kai-shek, for vice president. The 752-seat electoral college, known as the National Assembly, is dominated by politicians who fled the Chinese mainland to Taiwan with the rest of the Nationalist government in 1949 after losing a civil war to Communist forces. They have not faced re-election since then, frozen in office to support the Nationalist government's claim to still be the legitimate ruler of all China. Lin said he would soon ask the elderly politicians ``to drop the idea'' of endorsing him. ``I was told that people felt uneasy about the emergence of a second ticket in the election because it would force them to take sides.'' The official radio reported that Lee thanked Lin for his decision. The electoral college is expected to officially chose the president March 21. Lee, 66, succeeded President Chiang Ching-kuo when he died in office in 1987. The late president was another son of Chiang Kai-shek. China made a public expression of concern over the political bickering this week, but it was not clear if those statements affected Friday's developments. Beijing, which seeks reunification with Taiwan, condemned the ``instability'' caused by the Nationalist rift. Chiang Wego, viewed by many of the older assemblymen as the defender of their dream of returning to the mainland, was not available Friday for comment. In the past, he has said he would not actively campaign but would not discourage the electoral college from supporting him. A fire meanwhile broke out in the national legislature Friday, and police blamed activists who want Taiwan to drop its claim to be China's legitimate government. Police said the early morning blaze may have been caused by firebombs. Several reception rooms were reported damaged. Nearby, police discovered a fence painted with the slogan: ``Burn Chinese pirates to death. Strive for Taiwanese independence'' and ``Bloodbath Taiwan.'' The references were apparently to elderly members of the Yuan, Taiwan's highest lawmaking body, who fled mainland China decades ago. Less than an hour later, a blaze occurred at the faculty dormitory at National Taiwan University, with similar slogans left behind. No one was reported injured in either fire, and there was no claim of responsibility. Also Friday, Chiang Hsiao-wu, son of late President Chiang Ching-kuo, said he would resign as head of Taiwan's mission to Japan because he was disappointed over ``our leaders' fighting over power without any regard to the nation's future.'' He criticized Chiang Wego for ``wanting to be elected but claiming he would not campaign.'' But he said he would not ``waste my time'' to persuade his uncle to pull out of the race. In an effort to placate his critics, President Lee said Wednesday that party members would be consulted over whether he should continue as party chairman as well as head of government. Newspapers reported that Lin, backed by the aging conservatives, wants Lee to step down as party chairman to allow a collective leadership after the presidential election. The 3-year-old opposition Democratic Progressive Party does not have enough members in the National Assembly to nominate its own candidate for president. It has demanded all the mainland Chinese assemblymen retire and that the president be chosen by popular election.

DOC.HEAD: Sperm Banks: Safe as Savings Banks?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Gardineer is cq, 21st graf.
DOC.TEXT: Sperm banks keep records so detailed it's unlikely a bank is to blame in the case of a white woman who says she was impregnated with a black man's sperm rather than her dying husband's, experts said Friday. But if the nation's three dozen major sperm banks are as safe as savings banks, they aren't nearly as regulated. New York is the only state to license sperm banks, and the federal government lacks control over them. The issue arose this week after it was disclosed a New York woman is suing a fertility clinic and a sperm bank, claiming her late husband's sperm was switched with that of a black man. The woman says that after she was fertilized with the sperm she gave birth to a girl who appears to be half black. David Gould, the attorney for the Queens resident, asked that her name be withheld because of emotional distress. The girl, now 3, has been taunted because she doesn't look like her parents. In 1985, the couple paid Idant Laboratories, the nation's oldest and largest commercial sperm bank, to store the husband's sperm. He had cancer, and the couple feared chemotherapy could damage his sperm. Such concerns, Idant says, account for about half its deposits. The woman later contacted Advanced Fertility Services to get the sperm samples from Idant and use them for insemination. Advanced says the sperm it used came from Idant; Idant says the sperm it sent was definitely the husband's, and couldn't be the sperm that impregnated the wife. Dr. Jerome Sherman, chairman of American Association of Tissue Banks' reproductive council, said sperm banks' identification procedures are designed to avoid such confusion. ``The chance of this happening is extremely remote, if not impossible,'' he said. ``I've visited that facility (Idant) and seen their identification procedures. It couldn't be run any better, as far as labeling is concerned.'' It was much more likely, he said, that a woman lodging such a complaint had sexual intercourse with someone other than the sperm donor. Steven Salzman, another attorney for the woman, denied Sherman's suggestion, but said it was not yet clear if fault rested with the fertility clinic or the sperm bank. At most sperm banks, a man ejaculates into a container that is marked with his personal identification code and the date. Then it is tested, divided into small units, placed in small plastic straws, and frozen. The straws are lodged inside an aluminum container that looks like a cigar tube, which also bears a label with the donor's code. It, in turn, is placed in a large tank of liquid nitrogen, which keeps the sperm at minus 320 degrees. Meanwhile, a log of the sperm's history _ when, how and where it was donated, tested, frozen and stored _ is compiled. Any withdrawal also is marked down. An inventory of all sperm deposits is taken periodically. In the case at issue, Idant says its records show the sperm it sent to the clinic was the husband's _ five straws are gone from his cigar tube and no one else's straws are missing _ and that a test showed the baby's DNA didn't match the husband's. Sherman, a University of Arkansas medicine professor who directs a sperm bank in Little Rock, said his facility stores donor sperm of different races in different vaults. Idant uses colored plastic straws to indicate a donor's race. ``You have had situations where technicians have goofed and the semen was thawed, but mixups like the one this woman claims, never,'' Sherman said. William Andrews, medical director of the American Fertility Society, said the labeling errors that periodically complicate blood transfusions don't crop up in artificial inseminations because sperm banks aren't responding to emergencies and have more time to double- and cross-check. He also noted that since the vast majority of sperm samples are donated by whites, the odds against a switch like the one alleged are particularly long. Given the absence of government regulation, however, consumers must be sure a sperm bank follows record-keeping procedures recommended by the federal Center for Disease Control and the fertility association. Mary Anne Gardineer of the state Health Department said the New York sperm bank regulations that took effect in October weren't prompted by any problem, but by a concern that inadequate screening of anonymous sperm donors might lead to the transmission of AIDS. She said she had never heard of any mixup like the one alleged in the lawsuit, but said her department would review the regulations to see if a more definitive identification of a donor's sperm should be required. Her colleague, Dr. Jean Linden, concurred: ``As in any other form of banking, record keeping is very, very important.''

DOC.HEAD: Massachusetts Republicans Optimistic as They Open Convention
DOC.TEXT: Massachusetts Republicans, long considered politically dead, gathered Friday for their state convention in an upbeat mood, sensing a chance to win the governor's race for the first time since 1970. Ron Kaufman, the Republican National Committeeman from Massachusetts and an White House aide to President Bush, summed up expectations. ``Quite frankly I think the folks in Washington for the first time really believe that the Republican Party can actually win this state,'' he said. The Republicans have been boosted by Democratic Gov. Michael S. Dukakis' heavy defeat in the 1988 presidential election and by the state's financial woes. The ``Massachusetts Miracle'' that Dukakis used as a cornerstone of his campaign has evaporated. The latest bad economic news came Friday with the announcement that the state's unemployment rate jumped from 4.5 percent to 5.3 percent in February. State government faces a budget deficit this year in excess of half a billion dollars. Polls show Dukakis' popularity has dropped to an all-time low. Although the governor is not seeking re-election, Kaufman and other GOP leaders said they hope to channel dissatisfaction into votes for the GOP in a state where Democrats still outnumber Republicans by 3-1 in party registration. Endorsements will be the major task facing the more than 5,000 delegates expected to attend the convention. The delegates will vote Saturday on who to support for governor, lieutenant governor, U.S. Senate and other statewide offices. Candidates need not win the endorsement to appear on the Sept. 18 primary election ballot, but must win support from a minimum of 15 percent of the delegates. The weeks before the convention have been marked by sharp campaign rhetoric between the party's two front-runners in the governor's race, House Minority Leader Steven Pierce and former federal prosecutor William Weld, and between Senate contenders Dan Daly and Jim Rappaport. Kaufman said he was not upset by the tough campaigning. ``In terms of Massachusetts politics what's been going on in our party is kind of weak, kind of mild,'' he said. ``Basically the whole thing's been a plus. It's been a good thing for our party.'' He said it has boosted the name recognition of the candidates. Under Republican rules, if a candidate wins a ``super majority'' of the delegates, a margin of 15 percent in a three-way race and 20 percent in a two-way race, the GOP will provide aid before the primary. But Kaufman said he still would favor a primary election campaign. ``I've always been in favor of a good primary,'' Kaufman said. Otherwise, he said the Democrats, who hold their convention in June and are guaranteed a primary, could dominate media coverage until after the primary. And that could put the GOP at a disadvantage, he said. The last time the Republicans won the governor's race was in 1970 when Francis Sargent defeated Kevin White. Dukakis defeated Sargent in 1974 and has been in charge since, except for a four-year period when then Democrat Edward King defeated him in the primary and won the governorship. Since leaving office after losing to Dukakis in 1982, King has switched to the GOP.

DOC.HEAD: Marine Who Helped Buddies Honored After 21 Years
DOC.TEXT: Their lives are linked by a common memory: a cool Vietnamese river on a steamy day, gunfire, then chaos. Each thought the other had died. But this weekend in St. Louis, 21 years later, the paths of Jim Lahr and Denver Lawson Freeman cross once again. Lahr is to receive the Bronze Star for pulling his wounded buddy, Freeman, and another Marine from the river's green waters to safety. Lahr was shot and paralyzed from the waist down as he returned to the river for a third wounded man. One of the men rescued by Lahr died. The captain who that day began the paperwork to commend Lahr was wounded in another raid the same week. Lahr believed Freeman was dead; Freeman thought the same of Lahr. But at a Marine Corps reunion last summer, Freeman learned that Lahr had survived, and set out to see that his friend receive the honor he deserved. ``That started the ball rolling,'' Marine Sgt. Major Wallace Poyner said Friday from St. Louis. Freeman ``started letters going and petitioned this. They wrote it up, sent it into the awards section of the Marine Corps, and it went to the Secretary of the Navy, who approved it.'' The retired colonel who headed Lahr's unit in Vietnam was to present the award at a ceremony Saturday, Poyner said. On March 21, 1969, while on patrol, Lahr, Freeman and other Marines walked out of the jungle to fill their canteens at the river, the citation says. Bullets and grenades began to fly, and ``Corporal Lahr, with complete disregard for his own safety ... assisted several Marines to safety. ``Despite the heavy fire, he made several trips ... until he himself was wounded and unable to continue,'' the citation says. Freeman and his wife were en route Friday from their home in South Charleston, W.Va., to the ceremony, said his mother, Juanita Freeman. ``My son was so excited about it. ... This has really been a great lift in both of their lives,'' Mrs. Freeman said by telephone. ``He knows he can never, never, repay Jim. But he feels that somehow, now that he knows he's alive, he'll be able to do some things to return the favor to Jim.'' Lahr downplayed his heroism during a telephone interview Friday from his home in the central Illinois community of Lincoln. ``I did it on an impulse,'' said Lahr, who is confined to a wheelchair. ``I knew there was danger involved, but I went ahead. Like I said, it was done on an impulse to get the men out of the area.'' After he was wounded, Lahr recalls hearing one of his commanding officers call him by his nickname _ ``Where ya at, Little Bit?'' But he remembers nothing more until he awoke on a hospital ship some days later. His injury came 16 days before he completed his 13-month tour in Vietnam. Freeman also was seriously injured and remained in a full-body cast for months, his mother said. ``They thought he was going to lose his life, but oh, he just came out great,'' Mrs. Freeman said. ``Honey, listen, I just thank God over and over for Jim.'' She said she met Lahr this summer while he was visiting her son. ``The first thing I told him, I said, `I always hoped that someday I could tell you just how much we love you.'' Today, Lahr spends most of his time in activities with local veterans' groups. ``It feels real good,'' he said of the upcoming ceremonies. ``The Bronze Star _ I wish all the rest of them could get them too.''

DOC.HEAD: Jim Bakker's Former PTL Parsonage in Ruins After Fire
DOC.TEXT: The mansion where TV evangelists Jim and Tammy Bakker once luxuriated amid his-and-hers bathroom suites, three kitchens and an air-condition doghouse was destroyed by fire early Friday. The 10,226-square-foot home on a hill overlooking Lake Wylie _ which once featured exercise rooms and as many as 25 room-sized closets _ was bought and remodeled by New Jersey businessman Robert Rubino in 1988. Rubino, who paid $685,000 for the house after the collapse of the Bakkers' religious empire, was out of town and the house unoccupied when the fire was reported at 2:15 a.m., said Tega Cay Volunteer Fire Department Chief Bill Kruysman. ``It looked like a volcano spewing up,'' said Kruysman, adding that the five-level home's the layout hampered firefighters. ``This house is huge. It has been added on and added on, and there have been additions to the additions.'' The now-bankrupt PTL ministry bought the home in one of Tega Cay's most exclusive sections in 1981 as a parsonage, and enlarged it four times while it was home to the Bakkers and their two children. The Bakkers moved out of the home when they left the ministry in June 1987, three months after Bakker admitted to a sex-and-money scandal in 1980 with church secretary Jessica Hahn. Bakker 50, was convicted of defrauding his followers of $3.7 million, and is serving a 45-year federal prison sentence in Rochester, Minn. Tammy Faye Bakker lives in Orlando, Fla., where she is started a successor ministry to PTL. Neither were available to comment Friday on the fate of their former home. The South Carolina Arson Task Force was investigating the cause of the fire, said Kruysman. That doesn't indicate arson is suspected, but rather is standard procedure in fires of unknown origin, he said. At one point, the home's master bedroom had his-and-hers bathroom suites connected by a sunken whirlpool tub. The tub was flanked by a glass-enclosed rock garden. Faucet handles were shaped like swans. A 600-square-foot carpeted clothes closet adjoined Mrs. Bakker's dressing room. The main kitchen had industrial-grade appliances, and the home also featured two additional kitchens and electronically controlled drapes and curtains. The grounds included an air-conditioned doghouse, two-story heated and air-conditioned playhouse, guardhouse, boardwalks to a white sandy beach at the water's edge, and a large dock where the Bakkers once kept their 58-foot houseboat and small power cruiser. Mrs. Bakker and her followers are building a home for her New Covenant Church in a 15,200-square-foot building outside Orlando. Donnie Beck, who oversees New Covenant's direct-mail fund-raising, said the ministry was in the process of buying the building, but refused to give a price.

DOC.HEAD: Vargas Llosa, Peruvian Intellectuals Urge Castro to Call Elections
DOC.TEXT: Presidential candidate Mario Vargas Llosa and several other intellectuals on Friday declared communism dead and urged Fidel Castro to call free elections in Cuba. The group, in Lima for a conference entitled ``The Liberty Revolution,'' said if the Cuban president refuses, then ``history will condemn you for all of eternity.'' The three-day meeting was organized by the Liberty Movement, a group of politicians and businessmen that formed around Vargas Llosa as he entered the race for presidency. Vargas Llosa, a celebrated author who is favored to win the April 8 presidential election, is the candidate for the Democratic Front, a coalition of center-right parties and the Liberty Movement. The theme of the conference was the political changes taking place in Latin America, Eastern Europe and elsewhere. The letter to Castro, issued Friday by conference participants, accused the Cuban leader of proposing a ``holocaust'' by promising to destroy the island before abandoning Communism. ``What has been sunk throughout the world, Comandante, is communism,'' the letter said.

DOC.HEAD: Bank Trouble Reported in Nicaragua
DOC.TEXT: A Central Bank official refused Friday to confirm or deny President Daniel Ortega's statement that uncertainty over next month's transfer of government to the United National Opposition caused a run on banks. But people reported their bank accounts were frozen and bank officials said earlier that funds simply weren't there to cover withdrawals in dollars or cordobas, the national currency. The newly elected 14-party UNO coalition meanwhile issued a communique warning that giveaways of government property ``will be reviewed in detail to ascertain their legality and origin'' _ presumably once President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro and her government take over April 25. It was referring to reports that government property from file folders to vehicles is being given away or sold off to leave UNO an empty shell of a state structure and make it harder for the coalition to function as a government. It also referred to a proposed law that would enable tenants of public housing to obtain legal ownership. Much of the property was confiscated from ousted dictator Anastasio Somoza and the people around him during the Sandinistas' 10{ years in power. But other property was seized from Sandinista critics who ran afoul of the government or from citizens who left Nicaragua for more than six months. The Sandinista-dominated National Assembly is to vote on the law Saturday. Ortega said Thursday night that refusal of the U.S.-supported Contra rebels to disband before Mrs. Chamorro is inaugurated was creating tensions. Concern over a peaceful transfer of power increased after Ortega warned in his speech that ``there are thousands of weapons in the hands of the people'' and that he ``could not guarantee'' the situation will be normal come April 25. Ortega said jittery customers cleaned millions of dollars and billions of cordobas out of their bank accounts after UNO defeated his Sandinistas in national elections Feb. 25. The black market rate for the cordoba is about 70,000 to the dollar. The pro-Sandinista newspaper El Nuevo Diario ran a front-page story Friday that spoke of more than $100 million being withdrawn from bank accounts. ``If he (Ortega) says it's so, then I'm nobody to deny it,'' said Orlando Mogollon, banking services director at the Central Bank. But when pressed, Mogollon backed off. ``I can't confirm or deny it,'' he said of the reported run on banks. Nicaragua's banking system is nationalized and controlled by the Central Bank. Emilio Mayorga, an official of the National Development Bank, denied there was a run on his bank. ``Withdrawals are normal,'' said Mayorga. ``We don't understand this thing about a drain'' on accounts. A secretarial worker who tried this week to withdraw the equivalent of $300 from her savings account said she was told by a bank teller her account was frozen until May. No further explanation was offered. She admitted she wanted to have the cash ``because things have become so insecure.'' A foreign diplomat reported that bank officials told him this week that there weren't enough funds in an account from one of the best hotels in Managua to cash a check for $500. A private foreign citizen said officials at his bank told him he could not withdraw money from his dollar account because the bank lacked funds. All three spoke on condition of anonymity. One of two government-controlled money exchange houses in Managua shut down Friday. Telephone calls to its offices were unanswered.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Readies Aid Package to Nicaragua, May Send Contras to Camps
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is preparing a Nicaragua aid package focusing on agricultural help and is discussing moving the Contra rebels to enclaves under United Nations supervision, officials on Vice President Quayle's trip said Friday. The enclaves would provide an interim refuge for the Contras to be safe from militant remnants of the Sandinista army, said one administration official. ``That might be a way station to disarmament,'' he said when asked whether the administration envisions having the Contras keep their weapons in such camps. The Nicaragua aid package will be formally announced next week, Quayle said at a news conference following his meeting with Venezuelan President Carlos Andres Perez. Agricultural assistance, providing such necessities as seed and fertilizer for the April planting season, also will help the Contras resettle in their homeland since most are from rural backgrounds, said the first official. Quayle discussed with Perez and Spain's Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez the possibility of having the Contras move into enclaves in Nicaragua with United Nations peacekeeping forces to ``separate the armies'' that have been warring for a decade, the official said. The future of the U.S.-built Contra army has been a key issue since the Feb. 25 election of opposition candidate Violeta Chamorro over Sandinista President Daniel Ortega. Demobilizing the Contras and a peaceful transfer of power were the chief topics of the meeting between Quayle, Perez and Gonzalez. Quayle and Gonzalez are both on the way to Sunday's inauguration in Chile, which Ortega will also attend. Perez and Gonzalez pressed Quayle ``very hard'' on the need to disband the Contras at once, said Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., who is accompanying Quayle to Chile and was in Friday's meetings. The United States also wants the Contras to disband before Mrs. Chamorro is inaugurated on April 25, but the Bush administration has insisted their security be insured. The administration envisions the Contras beginning to demobilize at the same time as the Sandinistas relinquish their control of the army, said the official who briefed reporters. The Sandinistas have been taking steps to retain control of some aspects of the government, and Ortega has said the Sandinistas will keep control of the 70,000-man army, Central America's largest. Kennedy said he told Perez and Gonzalez there was ``heavy skepticism'' in Congress about Ortega's willingness to turn the government over to Mrs. Chamorro. Participants in the meeting hosted by Perez at his summer beachfront home said there were disagreements over whether Ortega could be trusted. Quayle, who said he spoke to Mrs. Chamorro from Air Force two on Friday morning, held that he would rather put his trust in her. The U.S. official who briefed reporters said Perez was looking into the possibility of having his government join the U.N. peackeeping force that already is assigned to Nicaragua. The U.S. officials did not disclose how much aid President Bush will propose for Nicaragua. Chamorro's government has said it needs some $200 to $300 million to get Nicaragua's ailing economiy back on track. After the meeting and news conference, Quayle flew to Barbados for talks with Caribbean heads of state and is flying on Saturday to Chile. Earlier, Quayle aides had said they anticipated the Perez meeting would also focus on Bush's push for Latin governments to recognize the U.S.-installed government of Panama. But that did not come up, said Quayle's press secretary David Beckwith. Perez was one of the region's most vocal critics of the Dec. 20 invasion, which was widely deplored in the Latin world. Thanks in part to diplomatic effots by Perez, however, recent days have seen restoration of normal ties with Panama by Venezuela, Argentina, Colombia, Ecuador and Peru, said Beckwith. Their actions came after President Guillermo Endara on March 1 called for a national vote on changes he proposed to Panama's constitution. That, along with withdrawal of the U.S. invasion troops by mid-February, was seen as fulfilling calls by Panama's neighbors for an election to give Endara's government an electoral stamp of approval. The countries that are still holding out against recognizing Endara are Brazil, Uruguay, Mexico and Chile, said Beckwith.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Georgia Condemns Annexation, Seeks Independence Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with details on Tass report, Georgia background, Tbilisi killings in April. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The parliament of the Soviet republic of Georgia on Friday condemned its forcible annexation to the Soviet Union more than a half-century ago and demanded talks on restoration of its independence, a local news agency reported. Georgia thus becomes the fourth of the 15 Soviet republics after the Baltic states of Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia to take action condemning its being incorporated into the Soviet Union. Lithuania's parliament is expected to vote on a formal declaration of independence on Sunday. The Georgian parliament, called the Supreme Soviet, also condemned the proposal made by Mikhail S. Gorbachev to create a strong Soviet presidency, according to Tass and a transcript of the resolution read to The Associated Press over the telephone by the Independent News Agency of Georgia. Tass in its four-sentence report said nothing about the sections of the resolution condemning the Red Army's occupation of Georgia in February 1921 and the subsequent treaties that made Georgia part of the Soviet Union. Georgia has long had an active independence movement, but has not pushed its case through parliamentary means. Many Georgian independence leaders said that would be tacit admission of Soviet power even though the Baltics have won greater autonomy and edged closer to independence by using Gorbachev's reforms to elect trusted local leaders. According to the Georgian independent news agency, the resolution's text says, ``The Supreme Soviet of Georgia denounces the occupation and annexation of Georgia by Soviet Russia and considers it to be an international crime.'' It calls the entrance of troops ``a military interference, intervention and occupation with the aim of overthrowing the existing political order.'' ``It is necessary to start talks on restoration of an independent state of Georgia,'' the resolution says. The southern Caucasus republic has 5 million residents. Georgia, mountainous and on the eastern shore of the Black Sea, first became a part of the Russian empire in the early 1800s. It was briefly independent again after the Bolshevik revolution. Last April, Soviet troops armed with gas and shovels killed 19 pro-independence demonstrators while chasing them off the main street of Georgia's capital Tbilisi. The Georgian resolution also says it is ``inadmissible'' to adopt the section of the law that allows the president to declare a state of emergency and martial law, ``and to introduce an authoritarian presidential rule, which may be interpreted as the president's right to remove organs of power in a union republic and thus to completely eliminate the republic's sovereignty.'' Gorbachev hopes to win approval of the constitutional amendment in Monday's special session of the Congress of People's Deputies, despite progressives' complaints that the draft would give him ``dictatorial'' powers. The Georgian resolution says it is inadmissible for the republic's deputies to participate in approving the draft. The resolution also says presidential measures taken to protect the nation's territorial unity ``should not conflict with the realization of a republic's right to secede from the USSR.'' Lithuania moved up its vote on declaring independence to Sunday precisely because activists fear Gorbachev will use his new powers to forcibly prevent them from splitting from the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Idaho House Approves `Birth Control' Bill
DOC.TEXT: The state House approved a bill Friday that would give Idaho the nation's most restrictive abortion law and anti-abortion activists the test they want for a U.S. Supreme Court stand on the issue. The measure passed 47-36 and was forwarded to the Senate after more than three hours of sometimes emotional debate witnessed by anti-abortion and pro-choice advocates packing the House gallery. The bill is scheduled to face a hearing Wednesday in the Senate State Affairs Committee. It could come to a final floor vote as early as Friday, and even opponents concede it stands a good chance of passing. The bill, like legislation rejected in Minnesota and Utah, would outlaw abortion as a method of birth control. The measure allows abortions only in cases of rape, incest, ``profound and irremediable'' fetal disabilities, or to save the life or prevent ``severe and long-lasting physical health damage'' to the mother. Sponsors contend that would prevent more than 90 percent of the approximately 1,600 abortions performed each year in Idaho. Penalties for ``civil contempt'' up to $10,000 for a first offense, $30,000 for a second and $50,000 for each additional violation could be assessed against any physician performing or attempting to perform an abortion, but women undergoing the procedure would not be held legally responsible. Gov. Cecil Andrus has not commented on the bill, but he has come out strongly against abortion except in cases of rape, incest and a threat to the life of the mother. Along with a Pennsylvania anti-abortion law, which has been partially blocked by a federal court injunction, the Idaho bill would be the most restrictive in the nation, according to its sponsors and the National Right to Life Committee. ``I'm just so proud that Idahoans are taking the lead in returning protection to our unborn children,'' said Kerry Uhlenkott of Grangeville, legislative coordinator for Right to Life of Idaho Inc. ``The Supreme Court is inviting us to send up legislation, and that's what we're doing.'' Pro-abortion forces were disappointed that legislators ignored arguments that the measure would not pass constitutional muster, and that most Idaho residents want the Legislature to stay out of the issue, said a spokeswoman for the Idaho group Freedom Means Choice. ``I consistently heard the word `morality' used, always ascribed to the life of the unborn,'' said Sally Trott. ``I never heard it used in reference to the state's obligation if it's going to coerce a woman to carry a pregnancy to term.'' On Thursday, the House approved and sent the Senate legislation repealing the state's controversial ``trigger law,'' which sets criminal penalties including prison terms up to five years both for physicians performing and women receiving abortions. The trigger statute would have taken effect only if the U.S. Supreme Court ever completely overturns its 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision legalizing the procedure through the first two trimesters of pregnancy. After nearly 17 years of relative inactivity on abortion, Idaho got back into the fray after last July's U.S. Supreme Court ruling in a Missouri case. The case, Webster vs. Reproductive Health Services, effectively invited more strident challenges of the underlying law created by Roe vs. Wade, anti-abortion advocates contend. The July decision was the focus of Friday's debate. ``We ought not to fall victim to the idea that this bill is unconstitutional,'' said Rep. L. Ed Brown, a Republican who is the primary House sponsor. ``No one knows what's constitutional in this case.'' But opponents cited objections raised by Richard Wilkins, a Brigham Young University law professor who is anti-abortion but contends the birth control bill goes too far in challenging the Supreme Court's stand. He said it would be found unconstitutional on a number of grounds. ``I am honestly and geniunely convinced that if we pass this bill, it will hurt the pro-life movement, that it will be struck down,'' said Democratic Rep. Patricia McDermott, a Pocatello attorney.

DOC.HEAD: Prego Settles AIDS Suit for $1.35 Million
DOC.TEXT: A physician who maintains she contracted AIDS from a contaminated needle settled her lawsuit for $1.35 million in an agreement negotiated with the city hospital agency, the trial judge revealed Friday. Veronica Prego, 32, will receive two-thirds of the award, or $900,000, when it is paid by the city in about two weeks. The remainder will go to the lawyers who represented her. After a trial that lasted more than two months, Prego unexpectedly dropped her lawsuit and agreed to the out-of-court settlement as the jury was scheduled to hear closing arguments. The settlement was announced Thursday. Prego was unavailable Friday for comment on the settlement, one of her lawyers said. The day before, Prego said she would use the money to help her family and to provide for her medical expenses in ``the tough days ahead.'' Brooklyn state Justice Aaron D. Bernstein on Friday reversed his order to participants not to disclose the amount after the New York Post sued to have the settlement unsealed. The judge said he had issued the gag order to spare Prego the embarrassment of being questioned by reporters about why she settled for such a seemingly small sum. ``It was something that touched a chord with Dr. Prego. She didn't want people to think that the value of the case was that little,'' Bernstein said. ``I didn't want Dr. Prego to be questioned about the reason she took that amount of money when she sued for so much more,'' he said. Prego initially sought $175 million when she sued the city Health and Hospitals Corp. and two physicians, but the dollar figure was later removed from the lawsuit, filed two years ago. In her lawsuit, Prego contended she had developed AIDS after puncturing her finger with a contaminated needle carelessly left amid soiled refuse on a patient's bed at Kings County Hospital. Bernstein, who considered the agreement ``fair,'' said Prego reluctantly agreed to settle because she didn't want the case to be tied up in the courts any longer. Hospitals Corp. lawyers had promised they would appeal if the jury found for Prego, and an appeal could take two years or more. During the trial, Prego's personal physician said she might have less than a year to live. ``It's our belief they played hardball with a dying woman,'' one of Prego's lawyers, Susan M. Karten said. ``I'm happy for her it's over. I'm relieved. I'm just sorry for what she went through.'' She said Prego was ready to settle for a lesser sum before filing her negligence lawsuit two years ago, but the city refused. The Hospitals Corp. said it was pleased with the settlement.

DOC.HEAD: North: Guided Contra Operation at Poindexter's Direction
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Eds: RECASTS first two grafs for clarity; INSERTS grafs 20-21 to explain obstruction count
DOC.TEXT: Oliver North testified Friday that John M. Poindexter overrode his misgivings and let him be questioned by lawmakers about covert aid to Nicarguan rebels, something that could not ``be revealed to anyone.'' The former White House aide, testifying as a reluctant leadoff witness at the Iran-Contra trial of his boss and national security adviser to President Reagan, admitted he lied when questioned by House members about whether he was covertly helping arm the Nicaraguan Contras. The retired Marine lieutenant colonel, declared a hostile witness by the judge, insisted that ``no one ever told me to lie to Congress'' about the covert operation to help the rebels after Congress shut off money. But North said that when he told Poindexter his misgivings about attending the meeting he was told: ``You can handle it, you can take care of it.'' North said he was ``concerned by the kind of questions they might ask'' because ``I'd been told by two national security adviers and their deputys, by the director of central intelligence that that information was not to be revealed to anyone.'' North said ``I didn't walk into the meeting intending to lie.'' But the former National Security Council aide staff officer admitted that he ``did not tell the truth'' during Aug. 6, 1986 session with members of the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence. ``I recall deceiving them about the full measure of my involvement,'' said North. Poindexter, a retired Navy rear admiral who was national security adviser for President Reagan in 1986, is accused, among other things of putting North up to lying at the meeting. Compelled to testify by Iran-Contra prosecutors, North conceded few points without a struggle during a day of relentless questioning by prosecutor Dan Webb. When Congress banned U.S. military aid to the rebels, North said he was told ``in so many words'' he was responsible for the Contras. North said he kept Poindexter fully informed of his work to help buy and ship arms to the rebels. North reluctantly admitted he supervised the arms-supply operation put together by retired Air Force Maj. Gen. Richard V. Secord. ``At no time, as you were running your operation, you never tried to conceal or hide what you were doing from either Admiral Poindexter or Robert McFarlane?'' Webb asked, the second reference being to Poindexter's predecessor. ``I did not,'' North said. ``Were you ever trying to direct that operation on you own, independent of your superiors?'' Webb asked. ``Never,'' North replied. ``Didn't you keep them apprised of all of your Contra-related activities?'' Webb asked. ``Yes,'' North said. Poindexter, who succeeded McFarlane in late 1985, is charged with conspiracy, two counts of obstructing Congress and two counts of making false statements. The charges concern accusations that he tried to cover up North's military assistance and fund raising for the Contras as well as White House knowledge of a 1985 shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran. One obstruction of Congress count relates to Poindexter's assurances in July 21, 1986 letters to three legislative committees that his staff was ``in compliance with the spirit and letter'' of the law restricting Contra aid. It was sent two months after North warned Poindexter in a memo that the secret operation was becoming more ``visible'' to curious lawmakers with the infusion of $6 million in profits from the U.S. arms sales to Iran. North testified that Poindexter, while he was McFarlane's deputy, was among those who told him to work to provide assistance to the Nicaraguan Contras as Congress was shutting off direct U.S. military aid. Poindexter ``told you you were becoming the person who would replace the CIA'' as the source of military support for the Contras? he was asked. ``I don't want to put those words in his mouth,'' North said, but ``in that general time frame he was one of the persons.'' ``You were told, were you not, that you were supposed to go fund and arm the Contras?'' Webb asked. ``In so many words, yes,'' North said. But he disputed Webb's suggestion that he set up an ``enterprise'' with Secord and others to buy and ship arms to the Contras. ``It began as something small, it evolved over time,'' North said. Webb asked North if he could recall the late CIA Director William Casey telling him ``the ball is in your hands'' after Congress shut off funds for the rebels. ``In words to that effect,'' North replied. North, earlier convicted of aiding and abetting the obstruction of Congress and destroying or altering key Iran-Contra documents, testified under a grant of immunity from prosecution. But the former Marine was clearly uncomfortable taking the witness stand against his former boss, frequently professing ignorance or forgetfulness of conversations with Poindexter and of key points from testimony North had previously given. U.S. District Judge Harold Greene frequently overruled defense objections that the prosecutor was asking the witness leading questions, calling North a ``hostile witness'' trying to be loyal to Poindexter. Webb repeatedly produced sworn testimony that North had given in the past that he gave orders to Secord, directing the resupply operation from the White House. North initially resisted the suggestion he was directly in charge, saying, ``Under my direction would be saying a major general worked for a lieutenant colonel _ I don't think that's correct.'' But when confronted with his own words from a transcript, North admitted that during his trial last year, he said he gave Secord orders and ran the operation from Washington. ``Did you give him direction and guidance?'' Webb said. ``I gave him a lot of requests, if you want to call it direction and guidance, I guess that's what we're stuck with,'' North said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S., Soviets Working to Get Emergency Food Into Ethiopia
DOC.TEXT: The United States and Soviet Union have joined forces to try to get emergency food supplies into Ethiopia, where up to 5 million people are in danger of starvation, a U.S. lawmaker said Friday. Thomas Foglietta, D-Pa., said U.S. and Soviet officials are pressuring leaders of two rebel movements in northern Ethiopia and the Marxist-government to allow safe passage of relief supplies. ``There is action, a cooperative action between the Soviet Union and the United States of America to get this accomplished,'' Foglietta said at a news conference. ``There has been some movement along those lines.'' He said he could not provide details of the joint efforts, calling them ``extremely secretive and classified.'' Earlier Friday, Foglietta and Byron Dorgan, D-N.D., met with U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar to press for increased international help to provide famine relief in Ethiopia. ``We are very concerned that the people of Ethiopia face their third famine in seven years,'' Foglietta said. ``Five million people are at risk of starvation. But they will not just die of hunger; they will die because of politics unless we can persuade the warring parties to let the food through.'' Dorgan said, ``We will see dire consequences unless somehow the international community is mobilized to say to those fighting in that region and to say to others who are capable of helping that we cannot allow this kind of tragedy to happen in the world.'' Foglietta said Ethiopian President Mengistu Haile Mariam is ``reluctant to give too much leeway into the situation, fearing that it would hurt him militarily.'' ``So that's what we have. We have a conflict between the military interest between these various groups and the humanitarian interest that we have,'' he said. Foglietta said Ethiopians have started to migrate because there is no food available in some areas. Relief agencies try to prevent mass migrations because it adds to the hardships for famine-stricken people and makes it more difficult to reach them if arrangements are made for shipments into the troubled areas. Rebels in the northern Ethiopian provinces of Eritrea and Tigre seeking autonomy have been fighting the Marxist government in Addis Ababa for years. In 1984-85, up to 1 million people starved to death in Tigre and Eritrea; in 1987-88, a massive international relief operation prevented a similar tragedy during another crop failure. The U.S. Agency for International Development, the foreign aid branch of the State Department, has estimated 750,000 metric tons of emergency food are needed in Ethiopia this year.

DOC.HEAD: Small Planes Collide Over Suburb; Three Dead
DOC.TEXT: Two small planes, one trailing an advertising banner, collided and crashed into a residential neighborhood during rush-hour traffic Friday. All three people in the two planes were killed, a federal official said. The planes crashed into homes about a block apart in this Fort Lauderdale suburb, but there were no reports of injuries to anyone on the ground, Miramar police officer Grace Cooper said. Fire trucks doused the wreckage to prevent explosions and police sealed off several streets in the neighborhood. The collision occurred at an altitude of 900 to 1,000 feet near North Perry Airport, but it was unclear how it happened, authorities said. Jack Barker, spokesman for the southern region of the Federal Aviation Administration in Atlanta, said a Cessna 152 flying westbound southeast of the airport struck a Piper Super Cub coming from the southeast at 4:35 p.m. EST. The pilot of the Super Cub and both people aboard the Cessna died, Barker said. Witnesses said the Cessna apparently carried a student pilot and trainer, while the other plane trailed a banner. The accident is under investigation by the National Transportation Safety Board, Barker said. It was the latest of several fatal plane accidents in recent years at North Perry Airport, which serves small planes in the neighboring city of Pembroke Pines. ``North Perry's a very busy training airport,'' Barker said. Resident Marcy Crawford said she was driving home when she saw the two planes out of the corner of her eye, at first thinking they were birds. ``But I looked closer and I saw one falling off to the right ... and the one plane spiral down like in slow motion and above it, a banner just floating down,'' she said. Michael Hentz, a photographer for the Key West Citizen, was driving on the nearby Florida Turnpike when he saw one plane crash. ``It like dropped out of the sky,'' Hentz said. The photographer said he thought he saw a body fly out, and another body inside the plane, which he found ``buried into the house'' when he drove to the scene. Scott Harrison, a resident of the neighborhood, said there was a body on the roof of the house.

DOC.HEAD: Police, U.S. Army Soldiers Sweep Panama City
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of police backed by U.S. troops swept through Panama City on Friday, confiscating firearms and drugs, and arresting suspects to stamp out a crime wave. Vice Minister of Government and Justice Ramon Lima said 760 people were arrested during the sweep, which was launched at dawn. But he said the raids were not as successful as hoped. ``We did not confiscate the amount of weapons we had expected,'' Lima said in a news conference. He said police confiscated 47 shotguns, pistols and revolvers but no military weapons. Undisclosed amounts of cocaine, marijuana and crack also were confiscated, he said. Vice President Ricardo Arias Calderon, who is also the justice minister, said the suspected drug dealers, illegal aliens and other fugitives were taken to Federal Judicial Police headquarters, which was surrounded by U.S. armored cars. Arias said the suspected drug dealers, illegal aliens and other fugitives were taken to Federal Judicial Police headquarters, which was surrounded by U.S. armored cars. William Ormsbee, a spokesman for the U.S. Southern Command, said about 260 American soldiers were deployed ``in support of the Panamanian police.'' About 400 Panamanian law enforcement officers took part in the operation. The United States has 12,000 troops stationed in the area to protect the Panama Canal, down from about 28,000 on Dec. 20, when the United States invaded to oust dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega. Noriega was flown to Miami, where he is being held for trial on drug trafficking and money-laundering charges. Noriega's Panamanian Defense Forces, which included police and other law enforcement agencies, was disbanded after the invasion. The new administration of President Guillermo Endara has been shying away from establishing a military organization but has been slowly building a police force. The new police force, which includes some elements from the old Defense Forces, has been having a hard time combatting a growing crime wave in the capital since the invasion. Arias said the sweep began at dawn, with the troops cordoning off the tough neighborhoods of Curundu, Viejo Veranillo and Brooklincito near the Panama Canal with barbed wire barricades. Two hovering helicopters located people trying to flee. Police and American soldiers in battle fatigues followed up, backed by armored personnel carriers, combed the area house to house, Arias said. He said there were no casualties in the operation. Residents in Curundu said they heard some shooting. Five busloads of suspects were seen leaving the neighborhoods. Lima said there apparently had been a leak about the raid, which began at 6 a.m. Residents said many people began leaving the neighborhoods before 5 a.m. Jose Maria Infanzon, a fugitive also known as ``Half Moon,'' was among those arrested Friday, together with two of 76 inmates who had escaped from the national women's prison, Arias said. Infanzon was wanted on three charges of murder and four of assault and battery. Arias said the operation was launched when people in the neighborhoods opened fire on law enforcement officers earlier in the week, wounding two police. Several vehicles heading for the canal area also were fired upon, including some belonging to canal employees. Arias said the illegal aliens will be deported, and the operation will continue until the crime wave subsides.

DOC.HEAD: Florida School Flooded With Calls About Scholarships
DOC.TEXT: A small university that announced it had enough money to offer scholarships to black freshmen was flooded with calls from far more students than it can serve, school officials said Friday. Florida Atlantic University officials said they were having trouble explaining to callers from across the country that they planned to expand the tuition aid program to just 45 spots in the fall, up from 30 last year. ``We got a mass of calls from people who said they are angry,'' said James Spear, executive assistant to Anthony Catanese, president of the state university. A news report, which was carried by The Associated Press on Thursday, said all the black freshmen who met admission standards at FAU would be offered free tuition. The report did not note the number of scholarships available, but in it officials spoke of expanding the program and seeking donations from the community if demand surpassed expectations. Spear says the school probably could have met the goal of giving all black freshmen scholarships this fall, based on earlier numbers of black applications for scholarships. But the 11,500-student school cannot take an endless line of applicants who might respond after their program got national notice, Spear said. The $1,350 scholarship covers tuition and fees, but doesn't pay for housing, books and other expenses. Out-of-state students can apply, but Florida residents get preference under the program, which will be financed with school funds and private donations. Based on the number of scholarships awarded last year, and the number of black freshmen expected, officials believed there was plenty of money so every every qualified black applicant to get a scholarship, Spear said. ``It's almost a Catch-22,'' Spear said. ``We offered 30 Martin Luther King scholarships last year as a part of our overall scholarship programs. We had 28 (black freshmen) apply who met our admission standards.'' He said the school is doing the best it can to attract and hold the top high school graduates from south Florida. Officials were shocked when they started getting calls from as far away as Denver and Toronto. Some callers wanted to apply, but others were angry. ``One caller said: `I'm black and my wife is white, does that mean we pay 50 percent?' '' Spear said. On the bright side, Spear noted the attention could attract some bright students from outside the area. Said the spokesman: ``We got a million-dollar PR campaign.''

DOC.HEAD: Residents Blast Group's Charge: Street's Italian Colors Promote Racism
DOC.TEXT: A neighborhood that paints a street's divider stripes red, white and green in tribute to the Italian flag is promoting ethnic bias and exacerbating racial tensions, a minority group charges. ``It causes racial unrest because it depicts territory,'' said Kathie Townsend-Hurk of the Martin Luther King Coalition Against Racism, a group formed after a December attack on a Hispanic family in Federal Hill. ``They claim the neighborhood to be theirs.'' Residents don't buy that. ``This is an Italian neighborhood. We're not racist. The line, it's a tradition,'' said Angelo Quaranto as he stacked bags of macaroni in Anthony's Fruit and Vegetables. ``They do something in their neighborhood, you think we'd protest?'' The stripes along Atwells Avenue were first painted in Italy's national colors a decade ago for a Columbus Day parade and the annual St. Joseph's Day Festival. The tradition continues, at city expense. ``They come in and want to take our colors off the street? That's ridiculous, that's bull,'' said Loretta Scivola. ``They come here and they want everything. I think they're just looking for something to complain about.'' ``You look at the stripes and you're automatically intimidated,'' responded coalition member Holgar Streu. ``Why not put up flags on the day of the festival? Why do they have to leave the stripes all year?'' In a message to Mayor Joseph R. Paolino Jr. two weeks ago, the coalition demanded the divider stripes be scrubbed off. But the mayor, a Federal Hill resident, says the stripe-painting tradition ``makes Providence the great city it is. They should realize the intent of the pride that the Italians have in the neighborhood.'' Paolino, a likely Democratic candidate for governor this year, said a cut in state aid to cities and towns forced him to cut Providence's street-painting budget. He said the city was looking for a private group to finance a new paint job for the dividing line this May. ``I don't think it causes any racial tension,'' said Jason Wong, a Chinese immigrant who manages Chef Ho's Chinese Restaurant. ``This area is mostly Italian. It represents a tradition.'' The city hires a private company every two years to repaint the stripes for $2,000. Irene Testa, director of Providence's Department of Engineering, said the Italian colors aren't unique in the city. Smith Street is decorated with a green stripe for St. Patrick's Day; Laurel Hill and Union avenues in the Silver Lake area are painted with Italian colors for the St. Bartholomew's Feast; the center lines on Branch Avenue and Charles Street are painted green, white and red for St. Ann's festival; and the line on Wickendon Street in Fox Point once was painted blue and white to celebrate a Portuguese festival. The dispute ``is just going to alienate people who want to help'' combat racism, said Joseph DeGiulio, president of the Federal Hill Merchants Association. ``It will cause unnecessary strife. This street belongs to everybody, but you've got to be proud of where you came from.''

DOC.HEAD: Second Son Said Heading Back to Face Murder Rap in Parents' Death
DOC.TEXT: An aspiring tennis pro headed home from a tournament in Israel on Friday to face charges that he and his brother shot their millionaire parents to death, friends and relatives said. Erik Menendez, 19, who with his brother is heir to a $14 million estate, left a house in a Tel Aviv suburb Friday morning, saying he was going to Ben-Gurion International Airport, said his Israeli host, who asked not to be identified. His 22-year-old brother, Lyle, was arrested Thursday and held without bail. He was expected to be arraigned Monday on murder charges, with ``special circumstance'' counts that potentially carry the death penalty, district attorney's spokeswoman Sandi Gibbons said. Erik will be arraigned on identical charges if he returns or is captured, Ms. Gibbons said. Jose Menendez, 45, and his wife Mary Louise ``Kitty'' Menendez, 44, were slain Aug. 20 in their $5 million Spanish-style Beverly Hills mansion. In another development Friday, the Los Angeles Times reported that Erik Menendez once co-wrote a screenplay with a high school buddy about a pampered 18-year-old who murders his rich parents and three other people. The boys had reported finding the bodies after returning from a night out. The slayings were so bloody, and clues so scarce, that many in Hollywood believed they were ``message'' murders by mobsters Menendez had crossed in the course of his business. An uncle, Carlos Baralt, said the family finds it inconceivable the sons could have killed their parents. He said he spoke briefly by phone with Erik on Thursday. ``I think what he would like to do is be permitted to present himself, rather than be arrested and be brought in in chains.'' Menendez, a Cuban who fled the Castro regime with little money, wound up the chairman of Live Entertainment, a video distributor and retailer affiliated with Carolco Pictures. Carolco is best-known for the ``Rambo'' movies. Friends, including former California Lt. Gov. Mike Curb, said Menendez made it to top jobs at RCA, Hertz and Live through tenacity and aggressiveness that sometimes rubbed people the wrong way, His sons shared his good looks and self-confidence, but had it easier. They grew up loving the good life, attending a private school in New Jersey, touring the amateur tennis circuit. Lyle attended Princeton University, bought a condominium near the campus, and dreamed of owning a string of restaurants. Eric co-wrote a 66-page screenplay two years ago that opens with the 18-year-old protagonist, Hamilton Cromwell, reading a will that bestows $157 million on him. ``Hamilton smiles sadistically,'' the script states. Cromwell's five victims are found frozen in a basement, after which a friend shoots Cromwell to death. Cromwell's tape-recorded voice is played later at a trial: ``You must understand ... that the price a player pays for failure in the game of life is death.'' Beverly Hills Police Chief Marvin D. Iannone said Thursday that detectives had circumstantial evidence against the sons early on in the investigation. He said the seven-month investigation uncovered physical evidence that showed the sons were the trigger men. The family had been undergoing counseling, and a key break came Thursday with the seizure of records of the psychologist. Such seizures are allowed only rarely under California law protecting patient-therapist relationships. Lyle Menendez's lawyer, Gerald Chaleff, said he would probably object strongly to the search, although he hadn't seen the paperwork justifying the warrants. Chaleff also said he expects Erik to turn himself in. Under terms of the parents' wills, made nine years ago, the sons were to share the estate if both parents died at the same time.
