For Release Mon PMs Mar 12
EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court's nine members are among the most private of public officials. They wield enormous political power, but rarely hold news conferences or give interviews. Recent polls indicate only one in three Americans can name any of the nine. This, the fourth in an occasional series, offers an up-to-date look at one member of the nation's highest court.

Antonin Scalia often seems impatient with the pace of change on an increasingly conservative Supreme Court, but time could be on his side. The comparatively youthful justice may be using his keen intellect and missionary zeal well into the 21st century to pull the court farther to the right. The prospect delights conservatives and alarms liberals. His supporters call him a man of principle unwilling to accept half-measures. Detractors say he is an extremist bent on undoing key liberal precedents. Both sides agree that Scalia, who turned 54 Sunday and is 30 years younger than the court's oldest member, is assuming the role of conservative point man played by William H. Rehnquist before he became chief justice. ``There is no question that since Rehnquist has become chief justice he has seen his role as less of an advocate than a consensus-builder. A vacuum was created and Scalia filled that void,'' said Rich Samp of the conservative Washington Legal Foundation. Scalia's confrontational style was on display last year when Justice Sandra Day O'Connor stopped short of voting to overturn the court's 1973 ruling in Roe vs. Wade that created a constitutional right to an abortion. Calling O'Connor's position ``irrational,'' a frustrated Scalia said, ``We can now look forward to at least another term with carts full of mail from the public and streets full of demonstrators.'' American University law Professor Herman Schwartz said Scalia, an ardent foe of judicially created rights, was showing his pique. ``I think he was angry, and I think he feels (O'Connor) may have betrayed the cause. And he's a man who believes in causes,'' Schwartz said. Judge Abner Mikva, a former colleague on the federal appeals court here, on which Scalia served before former President Reagan named him to the high court in 1986, has described Scalia as warm and engaging _ and unyielding in fighting for what he believes. ``He understands the doctrine of collegiality and has in fact found middle ground,'' Mikva said. But once Scalia has made up his mind, ``there's no shaking him loose.'' Scalia, sticking to his general policy, declined to be interviewed for this article. Gregarious and quick-witted, he normally revels in being the center of attention. Before a reception held for him by reporters when he joined the high court, he said, ``I can have more fun if it's off the record.'' Assured he would not be quoted for publication, he engaged in a lively dialogue for hours as reporters peppered him with questions. On another occasion, Scalia was asked why he was wearing a tuxedo to an informal evening get-together at the court. He was headed for another party, Scalia said, adding, ``esteemed jurist by day, man-about-town by night.'' The same playfulness is apparent at the court's argument sessions, the justices' only regularly scheduled public appearances. Scalia is among the court's most forceful, persistent and frequent interrogators of the lawyers who argue before the court. Using the attorneys as foils, he often appears to be trying to persuade other justices to see his views. Sometimes the tactic backfires. Justice Harry A. Blackmun said after the court's 1987-88 term that Scalia ``asks far too many questions. He takes over the case from counsel.'' Rehnquist once indirectly scolded Scalia from the bench after the junior justice persisted in quizzing a lawyer about a procedural matter. ``I hope when you're given an opportunity to do so, you'll address some of your remarks to the question on which the court voted to grant'' review, Rehnquist told the attorney. Scalia's critics worry that he has an agenda for overruling past decisions, particularly ones that expanded civil rights and individual liberties. ``It is as though he made a list of all the things he didn't like that the court has done in the last 50 years,'' said American University's Schwartz. ``Essentially, he sees himself as the agent of major change to root out these constitutional errors. In many ways, he's the most radical member'' of the court. But Alan Slobodin of the Washington Legal Foundation said Scalia's only agenda is adhering to the original intent of the framers of the Constitution and reducing judicial intervention in decision-making by the executive and legislative branches. ``I might call him the originalist conscience of the court,'' Slobodin said. ``He's less interested in vote-counting than in forcing the justices to confront first principles. He's trying to make the court more accountable, more principled.'' Scalia, the court's first Italian-American and father of nine children, has a strong academic background. He is the only son of an Italian immigrant father who was a professor at Brooklyn College and a mother who taught elementary school. Scalia graduated first in his class from Georgetown University and won high honors with his Harvard University law degree. He taught law for 10 years. The impact of his brilliance on the Supreme Court remains uncertain. University of Chicago Law School Dean Geoffrey Stone, who admires Scalia's boldness, said, ``The thing to keep in mind about Scalia is he does have very strong intellectual skills that will lead him to be out in front. The real question is, Will there be anyone behind him?''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Mon PMs Mar 12

DOC.HEAD: St. Patrick Is Buried in Downpatrick, Maybe
DOC.TEXT: A rude slab of granite inscribed with a Celtic cross and the name ``Patric'' proclaims the grave of Ireland's patron saint. The stone, rough and broken, looks as old as Ireland itself, but the marker was placed outside the Anglican cathedral around 1900. ``I don't feel people should be let down by that,'' said Brian Turner, curator of the Down County Museum nearby. ``You need a focus of attention. ``It is quite likely that the man who was St. Patrick is buried somewhere around here.'' Canon Brian Mayne, a prebendary of the Cathedral of the Holy and Undivided Trinity, said he was ``99.9 percent certain'' Patrick was buried somewhere on the hilltop, which attracted 20,000 visitors last year. Turner called it ``95 percent likely that he is buried in Down, or in Saul,'' two miles away. He is assured by a tradition that can be traced to the 7th century, although even that remote date is two centuries after Patrick's death. The hills around Downpatrick are dotted with sites related to Patrick in very iffy ways. Legend say Patrick landed at Saul, and 432 came to be the accepted date. Another legend claims he received last rites from St. Tassach, who is associated with a ruined church at Raholp, near Saul. A few miles south, at Struell Wells, more ruins mark the pools where Patrick is supposed to have immersed himself all night, singing psalms. Patrick stories are found all over Ireland. The Roman Catholic and Anglican primates have their seats in Armagh because, it is said, Patrick chose the place. Thousands of pilgrims fast and pray in the summer on a little island in Lough Derg, County Donegal, where, as the story goes, Patrick wrestled with demons. Many more climb Croagh Patrick in western Ireland, retracing a saintly journey. Based on Patrick's own writings, not one place in Ireland can definitely be associated with him. All he says about himself is that he was born in Britain, was taken captive in Ireland, escaped and later returned as a missionary. Patrick probably lived in the 5th century. The traditional dates are 432 for the beginning of his mission and 461 for his death. The first lives of Patrick were written in the 7th century and collected in 807 in the Book of Armagh, now a treasure of Trinity College, Dublin. The Book of Armagh says Patrick's grave was chosen by two oxen that were allowed to wander where they would, pulling a cart bearing the body. It's a good story, and so is one Turner found, which was written down in the 19th century. Sometime in the 1700s, it seems, a barber played a prank on the cathedral's sexton by leaving him half-shaved. The humorless sexton vowed that the barber never would rest in his family gravesite. The sexton had an old cross erected over the barber's family plot, then spread the word that it marked the grave of St. Patrick. Pilgrims came flocking and further burials were impossible. ``You know, the Irish always have to make a good story better,'' said Canon Joseph Maguire at the Roman Catholic cathedral.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PMs Friday March 16

DOC.HEAD: Crippled Navajo Fights for Compensation
DOC.TEXT: For years each school day, Lorraine Begay was flung from side to side as the van from the local high school bumped over the 10 miles of rutted dirt roads leading to her Navajo reservation home. The girl, crippled by severe arthritis, wanted to attend a nearby federal Bureau of Indian Affairs boarding school, but the bureau would not install the wheelchair ramp and special toilet she needed. Ms. Begay still is being bounced around, this time in federal court, where she filed suit for unspecified damages after experiencing what one judge called ``bureaucracy at its worst.'' Because Ms. Begay cannot sue the federal government directly, she has sued individual BIA employees ranging from an agency superintendent to a head custodian, who face financial ruin if she wins, their lawyers say. Both sides are hoping the federal government will reimburse the employees if Ms. Begay wins a judgment, but the government has refused any payments so far, though it likely will spend more on attorneys' fees than it would have cost to settle out of court. In addition to the lawyers' fees, the government could be forced to reimburse the employees for whatever Ms. Begay wins at trial. U.S. District Judge Carl Muecke said in a January ruling that an assistant U.S. attorney who represented them early in the litigation may have botched the case so badly that they will be able to sue the government for damages. No trial date has been set, and the case has dragged on for years despite general agreement that Ms. Begay suffered unneccessarily. The modifications the school needed to accommodate her wheelchair would have cost no more than a few thousand dollars at most, according to court records, and were supposed to have been made under a federal law mandating access for the handicapped. School officials give conflicting reasons as to why the work wasn't done. No records are available detailing how much the lawsuit has cost the government, but one defense attorney estimates the legal bill for the four private lawyers alone already has reached $80,000 and could double or triple if the case goes to trial. Ms. Begay, now 23, graduated from high school two years late, largely because of pain-induced absences. She still lives at home, with no electricity or running water, in the tiny community of Many Farms deep inside the sprawling Navajo Reservation. Arthritis has confined her to a wheelchair since age 13, and she often doesn't even have the muscle strength to sit up. ``Her mind is wasting away, and that's all she has because her body obviously doesn't do much for her,'' said Pamela Liberty, who took on Ms. Begay's case while a legal aid attorney and stuck with it after moving to private practice. ``We're not trying to make this into a million-dollar lawsuit,'' Ms. Liberty said. ``We want what it would take to get her through college.'' Ms. Begay's problems began in 1980, but she tried to resolve them with school officials and did not file suit until July 1985. She was offered placement in a distant school for the handicapped but chose to stay with her family and commute to the high school while waiting for the local boarding school to install the ramp and toilet. As late as May 21, 1985, she still hoped for an out-of-court resolution. ``I am writing to you to see if you can help me go to school at Many Farms Boarding High School,'' she said in a handwritten letter to Sen. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz. ``They say there is no ramp for my wheel chair,'' she wrote. ``They have told me they would fix the school up so I could go there but they never have. ``I cry a lot because of pains from traveling the reservation roads. That's why I want to go to a boarding school. I do not want to go to a handicap school. I am a regular child and want to be in school with all my brothers and sisters.'' Government officials made an offer _ $25,000, according to sources _ relatively early in the case. But Ms. Begay's lawyers wanted $100,000, figuring that's what it would take to finance four years at a good, out-of-state college. Ms. Begay's acceptable minimum has been rising as the legal maneuvers by defense attorneys continue. Ms. Liberty's former boss at Southern Arizona Legal Aid, Bill Morris, now figures the minimum at $250,000. The judge has scoffed at defense claims that Ms. Begay is to blame because she did not fill out applications after being told the school couldn't admit her. The school telling her to ``forget it'' was like having somebody ``stand at the door with a gun,'' Muecke said. Of defense attorneys' claims that only top-level officials in Washington are at fault, the judge said, ``I find that rather astonishing. I find that bureaucracy at its worst.'' ``I don't think any of the defendants have done anything wrong,'' said Dan Rosenfelt, an Albuquerque, N.M., lawyer who represents some of the employees, including a school principal who says he never talked to Ms. Begay and didn't even know about the problem. ``It's not clear that the government did anything wrong,'' Rosenfelt said. ``This is not a case, in my opinion, where justice cries out for a settlement.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Tuesday PMs, March 13

DOC.HEAD: Idealism and Voyeurism and Volker Schlondorff
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ``The Handmaid's Tale'' opened in New York and Los Angeles and limited theaters elsewhere March 9.
DOC.TEXT: In 1954, Volker Schlondorff was a 15-year-old living in Wiesbaden, West Germany, when he saw Elia Kazan's film classic ``On the Waterfront.'' After the movie was over, he walked out of the theater and kept walking _ for hours. Schlondorff couldn't stop thinking about how effective movies were at showing injustice in the world, how well he related to Marlon Brando's fight against corrupt union officials, how film seemed larger than life yet completely believeable. The same week, Schlondorff saw Alfred Hitchcock's thriller ``Rear Window'' and took another walk. This time he thought of suspense, watching and being watched, of James Stewart unable to move out of his wheelchair because of a broken leg, making up stories about the neighbors on whom he spied. Idealism and voyeurism have been a major part of the director's own work, never more effectively than in the 1979 film, ``The Tin Drum,'' Schlondorff's acclaimed adaptation of Gunter Grass' novel about Nazi Germany as seen through a young boy's eyes. So Schlondorff had no difficulty agreeing to direct the movie version of Margaret Atwood's best-selling ``The Handmaid's Tale,'' in which a young woman (Natasha Richardson in the movie) observes and eventually escapes the horrors of ``Gilead,'' a society ruled by right-wing fundamentalists. ``While we were doing it, we were strongly reminded of `The Tin Drum,''' Schlondorff said in a recent interview. ``The main character of Natasha Richardson and the way she goes through life, first trying to understand before even reacting. The so-called passive character, as if to watch and to think wasn't an activity, is very similar to `Tin Drum,' where he's mostly the witness of what's happening to others and what's happening to himself.'' In Gilead, women live in a strict caste system, their rank indicated by the color of their clothes. Richardson, dressed in red, is a handmaid, her sole function to conceive children. Robert Duvall is the Commander, whose child Richardson is to bear; Faye Dunaway is his wife, and Aidan Quinn is the Commander's chauffeur, with whom Richardson falls in love. Schlondorff viewed the characters as archetypes, representing different aspects of society _ the patriarch, the matriarch, etc. _ and thought the story had an epic structure, in line with the operas he loves to produce. ``The whole idea that every character has his aria, then from time to time there's an ensemble piece. And it's important to have changes of pace, you can not be fast all the time,'' he said. ``There is also the idea of a crescendo and a high point. I like to work on screenplays some times in terms of music, thinking of music, and to get the musicians involved in it.'' Schlondorff emerged in the mid-1960s as part of the Junger Deutscher Film movement (Young German Film movement), which included Rainer Werner Fassbinder, Werner Herzog and Wim Wenders. His first feature film, ``Young Torless,'' came out in 1966 and shared the International Critics Prize at Cannes. He has since directed ``The Lost Honor of Katharina Blum'' and ``Coup de Grace,'' among others, and also directed the American television adaptation of ``Death of a Salesman,'' which starred Dustin Hoffman. Schlondorff begins his 1981 film, ``Circle of Deceit,'' with an explanation to the audience that the film, about the civil war in Lebanon, is just a work of the imagination, only fictional, though the scenes were shot on location. ``The Handmaid's Tale'' is also a work of the imagination, of course, but Schlondorff had little trouble finding a realistic setting for a society that supposedly doesn't exist. ``We said, `What would an American dictatorship be like?' First of all, it would be run by advertising people who would try to make the most gruesome things look comfortable. ``This future society would be a cheap society, a K mart society. You wind up with a world of supermarkets and shopping malls, and then you go to North Carolina, and you say, `Well, it's all there.' So we gave up all this big elaboration, and said, `Let's just shoot the existing world and say it's our future.''' Schlondorff considers each of his films a personal creation, no matter who first developed the story. Noting that Atwood began the book in Berlin, the director adds his own touch, including a reconstruction of the Berlin Wall in the opening scene. ``I think culture has to do not with reinventing from scratch all the time, but with reflections and variations on things other people did before. We are just in a chain of people working again and again with the same material. It may seem minor to some people, but it's major enough for me.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv

DOC.HEAD: The Sweetest Sounds of Richard Rodgers
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: If any phrase could sum up the career of Richard Rodgers, it is a lyric from ``No Strings,'' the only musical for which he wrote both words and music. ``The sweetest sounds I'll ever hear are still inside my head,'' sing its lead characters, played originally on Broadway by Diahann Carroll and Richard Kiley. That search for the perfect melody echoed throughout Rodgers' career of more than 60 years in the American musical theater, years that were divided into three distinctive parts. The composer's career _ first with Lorenz Hart, then with Oscar Hammerstein II and finally with a variety of younger lyricists _ is celebrated in ``Music by Richard Rodgers,'' to be shown Friday, March 16, on PBS' ``Great Performances.'' The show, narrated by Shirley Jones, is studded with film clips from many Rodgers shows _ as different as ``The Garrick Gaities,'' ``Pal Joey'' and ``The Sound of Music.'' And there is an appreciation of Rodgers, who died in 1979, by other composers including Andrew Lloyd Webber, Burton Lane, Jerry Herman and Charles Strouse, as well as remembrances by his widow, Dorothy Rodgers. ``He really was a theater writer,'' she said the other day in an interview at her Fifth Avenue apartment. ``Unlike some other great writers _ Irving Berlin, for instance, who was the greatest songwriter who ever lived _ Dick wrote only for the theater or film or television.'' Rodgers gave the impression of being a fast writer, able to dash off music quickly. That wasn't so, Mrs. Rodgers insists. Before he began composing he would carefully consider what he wanted to express _ the emotion he was trying to convey and what he wanted to say to advance the plot. He also considered practical matters, such as the musical ability of his stars. ``Just before he died, he wrote `I Remember Mama,' for Liv Ullmann who had a range of very few notes,'' Mrs. Rodgers said. ``It was quite a difficult thing to do, but he accepted all such challenges.'' Rodgers always looked for something new to do. ``He felt the greatest way to insure failure was to repeat yourself,'' Mrs. Rodgers said. His quest for innovation led to four of his best musicals with Hart, written after an unsatisfying sojourn to Hollywood in the early 1930s. These landmarks were ``On Your Toes,'' 1936, with its use of extended ballet sequences created by George Balanchine; ``Babes in Arms,'' 1937, which starred one of the youngest group of performers ever to appear on Broadway; ``The Boys From Syracuse,'' 1938, one of the most successful musical adaptations of a Shakespeare comedy, and ``Pal Joey,'' 1940, a sophisticated, sardonic show with Gene Kelly as its charming anti-hero. Rodgers always wrote at home. He didn't have an office until after ``Carousel'' in 1945 when he and Hammerstein started to produce shows themselves. ``Larry Hart and Oscar Hammerstein worked in totally different ways,'' Mrs. Rodgers recalled. ``Larry could not be forced to put a word on paper until he heard the tune. But Oscar wanted the freedom to write the lyric first. Dick didn't care. He could work either way. ``Sometimes he would close open doors because he preferred not to feel that people were listening until he finished writing. We all entered into a conspiracy of pretending that we couldn't hear him until he was done. And he went along with that. He allowed himself to be fooled.'' If there was any question about a tune, Rodgers simply threw it away and wrote another one, Mrs. Rodgers said, although Hart and Hammerstein mostly used what their partner wrote. ``Once in a while, my daughters and I wouldn't let him forget something we were crazy about that got lost in the tryout period,'' she said. ``One example is `Getting to Know You' which was called `Suddenly Lucky' when it was in `South Pacific' and then dropped. `There's a Small Hotel' was written for `Jumbo' and producer Billy Rose didn't like it, so it was taken out. Later Dick used it in `On Your Toes.' But it was rare that he used a song again. He felt that he could always do better writing a new song for a new situation.'' The Rodgers and Hart partnership ended in 1943 with Hart's death at the age of 48 of acute pneumonia complicated by alcoholism. ``Larry was brilliant but he was basically a very unhappy man,'' Mrs. Rodgers said. ``And if you read his lyrics, that sadness is there.'' Even before Hart's death, Rodgers had begun work on a new project _ which Hart turned down _ to adapt ``Green Grow the Lilacs'' into a musical play. His partner was Hammerstein and the show became ``Oklahoma!'' ``Oscar was a very methodical man. If he said he would finish the lyric in a week, it would be finished in a week,'' Mrs. Rodgers said. ``Once Dick and Oscar decided on the musical they would do, they spent endless hours discussing every aspect of what kind of show it would be.'' After ``Oklahoma!'' the Rodgers and Hammerstein partnership lasted 17 years, and out of it came such classics as ``Carousel,'' ``The King and I'' and ``The Sound of Music.'' Hammerstein died in 1960 of cancer, and Rodgers plunged on alone with ``No Strings.'' Besides writing both music and lyrics, he did several interesting things with the show. He put the orchestra on stage with the actors and took the show's title literally. There were no stringed instruments in the show. Even though Rodgers' last shows, ``Two by Two,'' ``Rex'' and ``I Remember Mama,'' were unsuccessful they contained soaring melodies. Such songs as ``I Do Not Know a Day I Did Not Love You,'' ``Away From You'' and ``You Could Not Please Me More'' are among his most haunting. But even the master had self-doubts about his work. ``Oh, yes,'' his wife said. ``at least until he began to work on the next show. Once he got the first song out, which he called the first olive out of the jar, then he relaxed and felt confident.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv
For Release Weekend Editions, March 23-25, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: C.C.H. Pounder Plays Boston Mother in School-Busing Drama `Common Ground'
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The turbulent events of Boston's school busing years are told in the two-part CBS miniseries ``Common Ground'' through three families whose lives cross only at the schools. ``Common Ground,'' based on the Pulitzer Prize-winning book by J. Anthony Lukas, will be broadcast Sunday and Tuesday, essentially telling three separate stories of how each family is affected by the busing of the 1960s and '70s. The children occasionally pass each other on the ``common ground'' of the schools. Heading one family is Rachel Twymon, a black divorced woman with six children. ``Basically, all she was after was the best education she could get for her children,'' said C.C.H. Pounder, who plays Mrs. Twymon. ``She wasn't a spokesperson. She wasn't a radical. At that time, she wasn't a member of any organization. She was on welfare.'' Jane Curtin plays Alice McGoff, a widow dismayed that her seven children might not be allowed to attend neighborhood schools. She joins an anti-busing group eventually called Powder Keg. Richard Thomas is Colin Diver, an idealistic young lawyer whose liberal attitudes and hopes for a racially mixed society are challenged by reality. The three performers never met in production because their stories were filmed at different times. ``Rachel was a very strong woman, extremely forceful,'' said Pounder. ``I think she ruled, and not necessarily with a velvet glove, as she tried to keep her children straight. She was definitely the strong arm. But her daughters rebelled. She had a stricter standard for her daughters. The boys got to do what they wanted.'' The miniseries, written by Edward Hume and directed by Michael Newell, was filmed on location in Toronto, Canada, because it was felt the wounds had not yet healed in Boston. The McGoffs and Twymons visited the sets during filming. Mrs. Twymon died in January. Pounder, who was born in Guyana and raised mostly in England, worked closely with a voice coach to learn the colloquial Boston black accent. ``My mother had wanted me to become a newscaster so I wouldn't lose my British accent,'' she said. ``I now reserve my British accent exclusively for my family. ``Whenever I'm working and doing another accent, I avoid calling my family. It's hard to switch it on and off. You have to be afflicted with a parrot tongue, as my mother says.'' Pounder called the miniseries more than just a story of the busing issue. ``To say that `Common Ground' is about busing in Boston is to say that `Moby Dick' is about whaling,'' she said. ``Lukas went off to document each family. He got a story that's really more about Boston itself.'' Pounder, whose full name is Carol Christine Hilaria Pounder, attended a Roman Catholic boarding school in England. She went to college in this country when her mother, who had worked at the U.S. Embassy in London, took a job with a New York newspaper. ``I started acting at the age of 9 in England,'' she said. ``I played a lot of pages. I don't think I played a girl until I was 20. It took me the longest time to say out loud that I was an actress. It seemed to be closely linked to the oldest profession. When I began, people were skeptical and would ask, `Oh, yeah, what have you done?''' She's done plenty. She's probably best known for her starring role in the movie ``Bagdad Cafe'' and a featured role in ``Prizzi's Honor.'' She's starred in two other miniseries, ``If Tomorrow Comes'' and ``The Atlanta Child Murders,'' and such TV movies as ``Murder in Mississippi'' and ``No Place Like Home.'' She was a regular on the comedy series ``Women in Prison'' and has been a guest on ``L.A. Law'' and ``Hill Street Blues.'' Pounder was asked to reprise her role as Brenda in the CBS series based on ``Bagdad Cafe,'' but declined. Whoopi Goldberg plays the role in the series. ``I may do another series, but I felt I had done `Bagdad Cafe,''' she said. ``If I had done it, I would have done it just for the money. Brenda's walking a very thin line on being just your basic hands-on-loudmouth. It could become shallow in a series if you don't have good writing.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Weekend Editions, March 23-25

DOC.HEAD: Sub-Sahara Has Bumper Harvest, But Problems Persist
DOC.TEXT: Timbuktu was lucky last year. It rained, the locusts stayed away and, with some help from the outside, farmers produced one of the best harvests in half a century. Farmers in nearly all the countries that hug the southern Sahara Desert's harsh border produced similar bumper crops that filled graneries and children's bellies from Senegal east to Niger. The good fortune of 1988 and 1989, welcome as it is, also illuminates the profound problems facing these poor nations struggling to feed themselves _ problems that range from a birthrate that outpaces production to a marketplace that stacks the deck against even the hardest-working farmer. Experts note that, even with the bountiful harvest in most countries, sub-Saharan Africa imported nearly 9 million tons of cereal grains in 1988. ``Nonetheless, the 500,000-ton grain surplus is spectacular news,'' said U.S. Ambassador Robert Pringle. ``Now everyone is wondering how to export what they have grown.'' Abduleh al Kalifa, hip-deep in a field of emerald-green wheat rippling in a desert wind near Timbuktu, doesn't worry about exporting. He just wishes he could sell his surplus 30 miles away, in Timbuktu. ``Five years ago there was no rain, nothing to eat,'' said Kalifa, 36, already middle-aged in a nation where the average life expectancy is 49. ``Foreigners gave us everything. These last two years, the harvests were good. We have hope and two warehouses are full. ``We have more than we can eat, more than we can store and we can't sell the rest,'' he said. ``How can we get our grain to town if there are no roads? How can we compete with grain from other countries? How can we earn enough money to buy food when there is another drought?'' Mali's last drought left its mark on the children. Two-year-olds are solid and round, but children born in the drought of 1984-1985 are spindly, apt to suffer from chronic malnutrition. ``If you are malnourished, a few good meals will make you feel better, but you are still malnourished,'' said Leo DeVos, director of the United Nations Children's Fund in Mali. ``The whole country is like these children. It will take more than a couple of good harvests to put the country back on its feet. ``Still, it's nice to see the green,'' he said. ``It is the color of hope.'' When UNICEF arrived five years ago with emergency food, the government was in chaos, people were starving and huge numbers of refugees arrived in cities each day from the barren countryside. Enormous need remained when the crisis ended, so UNICEF and others stayed on to help. The United States, which spends about $30 million a year in Mali, now helps entrepreneurs and small farmers. West Germany built warehouses for reserves and a highway that spans a nation as large as Texas and California combined. France, Italy and others fight the advance of the desert, dig wells, organize cooperatives and help in dozens of other ways. UNICEF has concentrated on Timbuktu, a once-mysterious oasis that still evokes romance and adventure. Centuries ago, Timbuktu was a crossroads of caravans, a center of learning and a garden in the desert, where the river ran deep and trees hung heavy with fruit. Now, the advancing desert has tied a noose of dunes around it and many donors have written the city off as a lost cause. With funds donated by Italian labor unions, UNICEF installed pumps to make use of Niger River water and drilled wells to tap ground water for irrigation. ``We wanted to set an example, to show what could be done in even the most precarious situation,'' DeVos said. One result of the five-year project was the field where Kalifa and his neighbors grew a 15-ton grain surplus, little of which can be sold. The Malian government used to have price controls, which kept food costs down and made urban voters happy, but discouraged farmers because of the low return on their labor. Controls were abolished at the insistence of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund. International donors and lenders also demanded that Mali eliminate protectionist measures and subsidies to farmers. Their message was simple: No open markets, no aid. ``We have a long-term commitment to food aid, in return for which we ask that the entire cereal market be freed,'' said Dennis Brennan, director of the U.S. Agency for International Development in Bamako. With the market wide open, rice from Thailand and Louisiana costs less in the Timbuktu bazaar than grain grown down the road. ``The little guy works like crazy to grow something, pulling grain from soil that is poor, in primitive conditions and in a climate that is never favorable, even when there is no drought,'' said Giovanni Fiore, director of UNICEF's Timbuktu project and an Africa veteran. Then, when the farmer produces a surplus, there are no buyers. No one in the villages has any cash and consumers in Timbuktu buy whatever is cheapest. ``It comes from Europe or the United States where farmers receive subsidies,'' Fiore said. ``How can a Malian compete? He has no subsidy. All he has is taxes and the high cost of the pump, gasoline, oil, fertilizer, all of which has to be imported at double, triple, 10 times the cost to an American. ``Meanwhile, the donors tie aid to an open market in which farmers from developed countries can sell their surplus. So our farmers eat what they can, store a little, which will last a year or two, and when there is another extended drought, there will be famine.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Wed AMs, March 14

DOC.TEXT: The Federal Communications Commission took another big step toward a deregulated interstate long-distance phone business and proposed to loosen rules on AT&T because the onetime monopoly company now faces ``significant competition.'' The commission, in a 4-0 vote Thursday, adopted a staff proposal that, if finally approved, would give the American Telephone & Telegraph Co. the freedom it says it needs to maneuver against some 500 long-distance companies in the $55 billion long-distance marketplace.

Takeover strategist Carl Icahn's proposal that USX Corp. spin off its steel division will be put to a vote of shareholders. In exchange for the vote, Icahn agreed Thursday not to wage a proxy fight or submit other matters for consideration at the steel, oil and gas giant's May 7 annual meeting, USX said. Stockholders will be asked whether USX should incorporate a separate steel business and sell at least 80 percent of it, Icahn said in documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The new company would carry no more than $1.5 billion in long-term debt.

Campeau Corp., the financially distressed owner of U.S. department stores operating under bankruptcy-court supervision, said it will not pay $5.2 million in interest due on loans from two major lenders. Failure to pay the interest, due Wednesday under special arrangements made last week postponing earlier payment deadlines, meant Campeau went into default Thursday on loans from Olympia & York Developments Ltd. and Edward J. DeBartolo Corp. But the lenders have agreed they will not move to collect their collateral without notifying Campeau nine days in advance.

Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. stockholders have filed about 20 class action lawsuits seeking to block parent American Express Co. from buying all publicly held shares of the firm, alleging the price is too low. In one lawsuit, shareholders also claim that Primerica Corp. offered to invest $900 million in exchange for a 40 percent stake in Shearson during talks that ended last week without a deal and preceded the stock buyback proposal. American Express officials said Thursday the suits were ``totally without merit.'' The company announced the stock buyback March 4 as part of a plan to take control of its ailing Wall Street subsidiary.

Futures exchange leaders slammed a regulatory agency's plan to restrict dual trading and instead backed congressional proposals that emphasize better surveillance of their markets. Karsten Mahlmann, chairman of the Chicago Board of Trade, said Thursday the dual-trading restrictions being considered by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, together with other reform proposals that would increase trading costs, constitute a ``death threat'' to the futures industry. Dual trading is the legitimate practice among floor brokers of trading for their own accounts after executing any orders from their public customers.

President Bush announced a national transportation policy that would cost travelers more and increase local governments' share in meeting air, land and sea travel needs into the next century. Just as the Model T and the Wright brothers' plane ``prepared the way for today's millions of cars and thousands of passenger jets, so it is now our turn to invest in America's future,'' Bush said Thursday in unveiling the policy with Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner. Bush said it would help keep the United States ``the world leader in transportation.''

A major children's advocacy group asked federal regulators to require broadcasters and cable TV operators to present anti-smoking messages on youth-oriented shows if they televise sports events sponsored by cigarette companies. Action for Children's Television, which has been instrumental in reviving advertising limits for Saturday morning children's TV shows, asked the Federal Communications Commission on Thursday to close a ``loophole'' in a 1969 law that banned cigarette advertising from television.

Several big specialty retailers and department store chains reported strong February sales growth as demand heated up for spring apparel. The results from the nation's major retailers indicated consumer interest in shopping hasn't cooled despite a lukewarm economy. Among the retailers reporting Thursday were department store groups, specialty clothing chains, discounters and mass merchandisers.

The government is suing Burger King Corp. for alleged violations of federal child-labor laws, in the first major suit since Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole announced a campaign for tougher enforcement of regulations protecting young workers. The suit, filed Wednesday in U.S. District Court, charges the nation's second-largest fast-food chain with assigning workers under 16 to more hours per week than permitted under federal laws and allowing the young employees to work at times of the day not allowed under the Fair Labor Standards Act.

The stock market climbed to an eight-week high Thursday, resuming its late-winter rally. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 26.58 points to 2,696.17, its highest close since it stood at 2,760.67 on Jan. 11. The dollar finished mostly higher. Gold prices slipped in New York after finishing mixed overseas. Bond prices finished mixed. Livestock and meat prices surged for the third consecutive session at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange amid concerns about tight hog supplies. On other futures markets, grains rallied, but gold, energy products and orange juice contracts all declined.

DOC.HEAD: Good February Sales Gains Favorable Omen for Retailers
DOC.TEXT: Specialty apparel stores appear poised to outrun their mass merchandising competitors again this year, retail analysts say. Results reported Thursday by several nationwide retailers indicated women's, men's and children's clothing sold faster in February than other goods, continuing a year-long trend. Kurt Barnard, a New York-based consultant, said the February reports ``show that the American public is willing to buy provided they're given an incentive in terms of moderate prices and exciting merchandise displayed in a very exciting ambience.'' Although February tends to be one of the slowest times for shopping, analysts said the retailing results for last month looked promising and were better than expected given current weakness in the economy. ``Certainly retailing is not dead,'' said Karen Sack, an analyst at Standard & Poor's Corp. in New York. Linda R. Morris of PNC Financial Corp. in Philadelphia said the February figures ``signal that the consumer is continuing to spend. Although it's not a robust retail environment, it certainly bodes well for a decent year.'' Among the retailers reporting Thursday were department store groups, specialty clothing chains, discounters and mass merchandisers. Other national chains posted their February results a week ago including the nation's largest general merchandiser Sears, Roebuck and Co., discounter Wal-Mart Stores Inc., department store operator J.C. Penney Co. Inc. and others. Variations in fiscal-year calendars have caused retailers to have differing sales reporting schedules. Last week's reports _ with the exception of the ones from Sears and Montgomery Ward & Co. _ showed solid sales increases. Thomas Tashjian, an analyst at Seidler Amdec Securities Inc. in Los Angeles, noted that this year's results from the later reporting retailers weren't exactly comparable with last year's. Their 1990 periods ended one week later _ closer to spring _ so they benefited more from a seasonal pickup in shopping. Retailers specializing in apparel fared the best. In times of sluggish economic growth, purchases of expensive items, such as furniture and home appliances, are typically the first things to go. Tashjian said apparel shoppers responded favorably to bold prints, Chinese-look florals, short skirts for juniors, and denim sportswear _ especially in white. Stores in malls had heavier traffic than ones located elsewhere. The Limited Inc., the largest specialty apparel retailer in the country, reported a 21 percent gain in total sales for the four weeks ended March 3 while sales at stores open a year or longer were up 16 percent. Results at stores open at least a year, called same-store or comparable-stores sales, are considered the best reflection of a retailer's performance. Based in Columbus, Ohio, The Limited operates its flagship stores plus Victoria's Secret, Abercrombie & Fitch, Lane Bryant and others. San Francisco-based Gap Inc., another apparel retailer, said its sales surged 29 percent while its same-store sales gained 20 percent. Meanwhile, May Department Stores Co., based in St. Louis, said sales went up 10.6 percent and 7.7 percent on a comparable-store basis. One of May's best known department store chains is Lord & Taylor. Dayton Hudson Corp., a Minneapolis-based owner of department stores and the Target discount chain, said sales growth at all three of its operating units surpassed projected levels. Total sales rose 13.1 percent and sales at stores open at least a year increased 6.3 percent. Chairman and Chief Executive Officer Kenneth A. Macke said: ``These increases are strong against a solid February last year.'' Mass merchandiser K mart Corp.'s overall results also benefited from good gains in women's, men's and children's clothing lines. K mart, based in Troy, Mich., said its sales for the four weeks ended Feb. 28 grew 14.7 percent and same-store sales were up 4.4 percent. The retailer, second in 1989 sales volume behind Sears, also owns the Waldenbooks bookstore chain, Pay Less Drug Stores and other chains. ``Strong gains were seen in ladies', men's and children's apparel lines as good initial customer response to our early spring merchandise contributed to the excellent sales in these classifications,'' said Joseph E. Antonini, chairman and chief executive officer. K mart recently said it is speeding up plans to open additional stores and refurbish others as it attempts to capitalize on the weakness at Sears and to stay ahead of fast-growing rival Wal-Mart. Wal-Mart is widely considered a powerful contender for the No. 1 ranking in terms of annual merchandise sales revenue in the United States. Currently, it is No. 3, but it is growing at a much faster clip than Sears or K mart.
