DOC.HEAD: On Capitol Hill: Experts Debate Junk Bond Market Problems
DOC.TEXT: Debt experts testifying about junk bonds before a House panel looked at their tea leaves and said things will get better _ unless they get worse. They also suggested Congress shouldn't try to restrict junk bonds even though they predicted more companies are likely to default on their obligations. Representatives from the venerable bond rating agencies Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's Corp. were among the witnesses testifying Thursday before a subcommittee of the House Energy and Commerce Committee. While the credit-happy 1980s saw corporations leverage their operations heavily by taking on ever more debt, ``deleveraging is the future trend of the early 1990s,'' said Mark Bachman, senior vice president of S&P's corporate finance department. ``Unfortunately, there are reasons to be concerned that the process of deleveraging may not proceed smoothly,'' he added. The main reason: the economy. ``While a mild recession would not necessarily pose major problems, a severe one could,'' said Bachman. An S&P publication released earlier this week said U.S. companies defaulted on $6 billion of publicly issued debt last year, up from $4.4 billion in 1988. ``Annual defaults could approach $15 billion in a difficult economic environment,'' it predicted. The Congressional testimony provided a short-course in corporate finance, especially concerning the high-yield, high-risk bonds dubbed ``junk.'' ``A junk bond is a shaky debt. It is the promise to pay of a debtor who is just getting by,'' said James Grant, editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer. Most bonds are, in effect, corporate IOUs, promising to pay back borrowed money at a later date while paying a regular, fixed interest. Junk bonds, however, are considered by agencies like S&P and Moody's to be speculative, carrying a significant risk of default. To compensate for the greater risk, they pay a much higher rate of interest than more stable bonds. Proponents of junk bonds says that the high yields more than compensate for the risk of default _ if your portfolio is diversified. Pioneered by financier Michael Milken at now-defunct Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., junk bonds helped small or fledgling companies expand and also assisted corporate raiders take over huge corporations with little or no cash. But the $200 billion junk bond market has been rocked repeatedly in recent months by Milken's indictment on racketeering charges, corporate defaults, the withdrawal of many savings and loan institutions as buyers and the bankruptcy filing by Drexel's parent company. Thomas J. McGuire, director of Moody's corporate department, said the default rate for junk bonds has risen to 5.4 percent, ``the second-highest rate since 1970. And the outlook _ given the increase in lower rated issuers and the potentially unfavorable economic environment _ is for still higher levels of defaults in the early 1990s.'' ``A jittery market and the self-destruction of Drexel Burnham Lambert Group have raised new questions about the role of junk bonds in our economy,'' said Rep. Edward Markey, D-Mass., chairman of the telecommunications and finance subcommittee. ``Is there anything for Congress to do about this?'' Markey asked. Not necessarily, economists said. ``Legislation is more likely to worsen than help the problem,'' said David A. Wyss, chief financial economist for DRI-McGraw-Hill. ``Leverage is a response to the incentives in the tax law, and unless those incentives change, attacking the symptoms will just cause problems elsewhere,'' he said. Moreover, Wyss said, ``If investors can hold on to the bonds for an extended period, riding through the current storm, we believe their patience will be rewarded.'' ``The junk bond problem is really a junk credit problem,'' said Grant, a prominent critic of the growth of debt in recent years. ``In the 1980s we had an explosion of the credit supply.'' With the junk market battered by the developments of recent months, ``I would advise the subcommittee to be wary of pushing the market toward even greater stringency,'' Grant said.

DOC.HEAD: Government Sending ``Death Threats'' To Futures Markets: CBOT's Mahlmann
DOC.TEXT: Government plans to increase taxes and regulation on futures trading are ``death threats'' that could imperil the industry, the head of the world's biggest futures exchange says. In a speech Thursday to the annual meeting of the Futures Industry Association, Chicago Board of Trade Chairman Karsten Mahlmann said America's share of worldwide futures trading volume has dropped by 17.5 percent over the last five years. Proposals to restrict and tax futures trading will make overseas exchanges even more attractive, he said. During a panel discussion, Mahlmann and officials of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and the New York Mercantile Exchange complained about several proposals including: _ A plan by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission to restrict dual trading; _ A Bush administration proposal for an 11-cent fee on every futures trade to fund increased CFTC surveillance of futures markets; _ A push by the Securities and Exchange Commission to gain regulatory authority over stock-index futures, a market that is now regulated by the CFTC. The proposals grew out of the federal investigation of futures trading fraud in Chicago and the stock market crash of October 1987. Mahlmann said he, too, is seeking ``a healthier environment in which to conduct business,'' but ``one in which we can work with our regulators rather than one in which we stand the distinct possibility of being killed.'' Chicago Mercantile Exchange President William Brodsky and New York Mercantile Exchange Chairman Lou Gutterman also lashed out at the CFTC's dual-trading proposal. Brodsky told CFTC Chairman Wendy Gramm, who also sat on the discussion panel, ``in this particular case, you used a sledgehammer instead of a scapel.'' Mrs. Gramm avoided the dual-trading controversy in her remarks. Instead, she urged the industry to fight harder to keep regulation of stock-index futures under the CFTC's jurisdiction and away from the SEC. The SEC, which oversees stock trading, has been gaining congressional support for its view that the stock and stock-index futures markets are so closely linked that they should be regulated by one agency. Dual trading is the practice among floor brokers of trading for their own accounts after executing any orders from their public customers. Critics contend dual trading enables floor brokers to take advantageous market positions ahead of large customer orders that they know are likely to move prices. That illegal practice, known as front-running, is among the fraud schemes alleged in the indictments of 48 traders at the Board of Trade and the Chicago Merc. But futures exchange officials maintain that dual trading increases the efficiency of their markets by increasing the number of buyers and sellers. Since November, the CFTC has been gathering public comments on its proposals for a test ban on dual trading in selected markets regardless of the exchanges' ability to detect fraud. The CFTC plan is based on an agency study that found no statistical support for the exchanges' claims that dual trading increases market liquidity. Exchange officials involved in the panel discussion cited other studies that dispute the CFTC's findings. Mahlmann said the Board of Trade opposes any restrictions on dual trading. Even so, he said, the CFTC proposal is especially galling. ``The CFTC plan to ban dual trading has no basis in fact,'' he said. ``It appears to be designed for the sake of political expediency rather than logic.'' The Chicago Merc has voluntarily restricted dual trading in one of its most active markets, the Standard & Poor's 500 stock-index futures pit. Brodsky said the Merc supports a CFTC reauthorization bill passed last year by the House of Representatives that would ban dual trading in the most active futures markets but would allow it to resume at exchanges that have a failsafe system for detecting abuses. A similar measure is pending in the Senate. The Merc and the Board of Trade are working together to develop an ``electronic trading card'' that would replace the paper cards on which traders record their trades. Such a system, the exchanges say, would create a foolproof means of detecting dual-trading abuses.

DOC.HEAD: Replacements Likely To Make Greyhound Strike Harder To End, Experts Say
DOC.TEXT: Greyhound Lines Inc.'s hiring of replacements for its striking bus drivers reflects a trend toward tougher management stances in labor squabbles, and some experts say the hardball tactics will make it harder to settle the week-old walkout. Hiring replacements ``is far different from the old strikes we used to have,'' said Mark Kahn, a labor arbitrator and professor emeritus at Wayne State University in Detroit. In the past, he said, there has been ``a clear-cut understanding that whenever the dispute is ironed out, those workers will go back to work and the company will resume its operations. That tends to create a relatively civilized atmosphere in which answers can be worked out.'' Replacements are ``indicative of some of the more bitter, confrontational disputes that we are seeing,'' said Mike Jadell, an arbitrator and a professor at Georgia State University in Atlanta. ``It's become an additional tool in the arsenal of those employers who feel that they are in adversarial relationships,'' he said. Some labor experts trace the confrontational approach to the start of the pro-business Reagan administration and its decision in 1981 to fire striking air traffic controllers and replace them with new hires. Greyhound's strategy is similar to that of Eastern Airlines, which sought to rebuild as a smaller carrier with lower costs by hiring new, non-union workers after its machinists, pilots and flight attendants struck a year ago. ``We don't have a lot of options,'' said P. Anthony Lannie, Greyhound's executive vice president and chief negotiator. ``This union has us backed into a corner.'' The at-times violent strike began early March 2 when the Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions and the company failed to reach agreement on a new three-year contract. The union represents 9,435 of Greyhound's 11,825 employees, including 6,300 drivers, 1,600 office workers and 1,475 maintenance workers. The company says it can afford no more than its original $63 million offer; the union says its last proposal is less than Greyhound's, but the company values it at $205 million. There has been little contact between the two sides since, although federal mediators Thursday asked for a fact-finding meeting with the union next week followed by a similar session with the company. Greyhound has been operating at reduced levels since the strike, using replacements hired and trained in the last two weeks plus any union members who cross picket lines. Lannie said Thursday 800 permanent replacements, plus an additional 368 union drivers, are behind the wheels of the company's buses. The company says it received more than 6,500 applications for jobs and will be able to operate a full schedule by the end of the month. In other words, ``a total of 3,468 of the most junior people that are striking right now do not have jobs,'' he said. Because demand is expected to be lower immediately after the strike, Lannie said the company will need fewer drivers initially, leaving only about 2,000 regular, full-time openings left to be filled. The union has vowed to regain the jobs for its members. ``When management is prepared to enter into good faith negotiations, their union will ensure that their jobs and seniority are secured,'' said union spokesman Jeffrey Nelson. The management team that took over the only nationwide bus service three years ago is taking a much harsher stance than its predecessors. In a 47-day walkout in 1983, Greyhound _ then owned by Phoenix-based conglomerate Greyhound Corp. _ hired replacements during the strike but then fired them to make room for returning union members. Experts say the company's new position is bolstered by events since then, including a Supreme Court decision last year concerning a strike against Trans World Airlines Inc. That decision upheld a company's right to keep union members who crossed pickets lines, Lannie said. Most companies have had the right to hire replacements for decades, although few exercised it, Kahn said. ``It's a very contentious issue,'' he said. ``It's a way an employer can beat the strike, but it's the antithesis of sensible and rational efforts to resolve the dispute. ``The outcome's got to be very bad, especially for the employees who lose their jobs.'' The use of replacements also raises the stakes for the union, he said, and ``makes it far more difficult for the union to agree to a settlement under which many of its members won't come back to work.'' Two bills have been introduced in Congress that would limit the use of permanent replacements, but Kahn and others doubted they would pass. Just Wednesday, the House failed to override President Bush's veto of a bill to create a commission on the year-old Eastern Airlines strike. Replacement workers also have been used International Paper Co., Boise Cascade, Phelps Dodge and Eastern's sister carrier, Continental Airlines. Charles M. Rehmus, a labor law professor at the University of San Diego, said it was the 1981 air controllers strike that gave replacements legitimacy. ``It encouraged employers generally to operate through a strike and employees to cross picket lines,'' he said.

DOC.BYLINE: Shareholders Sue To Stop American Express Buyback ^By STEFAN FATSIS
DOC.TEXT: American Express Co. has labeled ``totally without merit'' a series of class-action lawsuits by Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. shareholders charging the two firms with setting low a price in a huge stock buyback. One lawsuit filed in Delaware Chancery Court claims the buyback price of $12.50 per Shearson share _ little more than one-third the price at which American Express sold the shares to the public three years ago _ is ``grossly unfair.'' It claimed the stock is below its true value because of recent problems at the firm. American Express announced earlier this week it was purchasing the publicly held shares of its ailing securities unit as part of a plan that included a management overhaul, 2,000 layoffs this month and a $1 billion capital infusion. American Express initially had sought to reduce its 61 percent stake in Shearson. The lawsuit claims that the company timed its reversal ``in an effort to cap the market at its currently depressed level.'' American Express officials said a total of about 20 class-action lawsuits had been filed in Delaware and New York courts. ``We have reviewed several of the original complaints and we believe them to be totally without merit,'' American Express spokesman Lawrence Armour said Thursday. He added that the lawsuits were expected to be consolidated into one complaint in each state. Under the proposed buyback, which must be approved by a special committee of three outside Shearson directors, American Express will exchange $350 million of its own shares for 28 million publicly held Shearson shares, or 32 percent of the firm. Each outstanding share of Shearson will be exchanged for 0.426 of a share of American Express. The deal is based on March 2 closing New York Stock Exchange prices of $12.50 a share for Shearson and $29.37{ for American Express. Shares of both companies have fallen since, with Shearson closing down 12{ cents at $11.75 Thursday and American Express unchanged at $27.87{. At that price, the stock swap would value Shearson at $11.87{ a share. Shearson shares were offered to the public at $34 each in March 1987. The complaints claim the American Express buyback undervalues the firm's assets and potential worth. Lawsuits say American Express violated a duty to shareholders to maximize the value of the firm. They claim the offer price was not based on an evaluation of the company or on negotiations, and therefore was unfair to shareholders. One lawsuit claims American Express used ``coercive and manipulative practices'' in a scheme to eliminate minority shareholders. Another says Shearson is ``poised for future growth and earnings'' that public shareholders will miss out. The lawsuits ask the courts to stop or reverse the stock buyback or award damages to shareholders. A suit made public Thursday in Delaware, where Shearson is incorporated, claims that Primerica Corp. offered to invest $900 million in exchange for a 40 percent stake in Shearson during talks that ended last week without a deal and preceded the stock buyback proposal. No figures about the negotiations with Primerica, which is headed by former Shearson and American Express executive Sanford I. Weill, have been released by the companies. But individuals with knowledge of the talks said the $900 million figure represented not an offer price but an estimated value of Primerica's Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. unit, which would have been merged with Shearson. Weill also offered to buy all of Shearson, but Shearson's new chairman, Howard L. Clark Jr., former chief financial officer of American Express, opposed the deal, according to the lawsuit.

DOC.HEAD: Suit Accuses Burger King of Violating Child Labor Laws
DOC.TEXT: Stunned by allegations of child labor law violations, Burger King Corp. said it maintains strict policies regarding young employees but will review work rules in its U.S. restaurants. An executive at the nation's No. 2 fast-food chain called the government suit ``a complete surprise'' and vowed to look into the charges. ``This is the first time we have received any indication of alleged violations,'' said Nigel Travis, senior vice president for human resources at the company. ``We fully support the spirit and letter of the law,'' he added. Burger King, a subsidiary of Britain's Grand Metropolitan PLC, was charged in a lawsuit Wednesday with violating federal child labor laws in its more than 800 company-owned restaurants in the United States. It was the first major suit since Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole last month announced a campaign for tougher enforcement of regulations on young workers. ``This action serves as a notice to employers that we will not hesitate to use available legal processes, in addition to investigative efforts, to protect America's children,'' Mrs. Dole said Thursday. The suit, filed Wednesday in U.S. District Court, claims Miami-based Burger King assigned workers under 16 to more hours per week than permitted under federal laws and allowed the young employees to work at times of the day not allowed under the Fair Labor Standards Act. The U.S. Deparment of Labor suit also claims Burger King had workers under 16 handling prohibited duties, such as most cooking and baking activities. Violations extend back to at least Sept. 12, 1986, the suit claims. But no charges were made against Burger King's nearly 4,600 U.S. franchise outlets, which are independently owned and operated. Burger King has about 6,000 restaurants worldwide. Federal officials say the number of child labor violations has doubled since 1982 as worker shortages in some areas pushed employers to hire more high school-age employees. The Bureau of Labor Statistics estimated about 901,000 14- and 15-year-olds were employed in 1988. Numbers for last year have not been released. Under federal laws, 14- and 15-year-olds can't work more than three hours on a day when school is in session and a maximum of 18 hours during a five-day school week. On weekends, an eight-hour work day is permissible, and a 40-hour work week is allowed during summer and school vacations. Employees under 16 can work only between 7 a.m. and 7 p.m. or up to 9 p.m. from June 1 to Labor Day. Different standards apply for farm labor. The suit seeks to enjoin Burger King from all child labor law violations in its U.S. restaurants. It also asks the company to pay all legal costs associated with the suit. Civil fines for violations are assessed in separate proceedings, but the Labor Department would not disclose whether any action has been taken, said spokesman Dan Fuqua in Atlanta.

DOC.HEAD: GAF To Pay $1.25 Million To Settle Civil Securities Charges
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Sentencing scheduled for 2:15 pm.
DOC.TEXT: GAF Corp., facing up to $4 million in fines on a criminal conviction for stock manipulation, has agreed to pay $1.25 million plus interest to settle related civil charges involving the trading of Union Carbide Corp. stock. GAF and its vice chairman, James T. Sherwin, did not admit or deny allegations in the civil complaint, which alleged that it manipulated the price of Union Carbide stock in 1986. The chemical manufacturer and Sherwin were to be sentenced today in New York for their criminal conviction. Sherwin, 56, faces up to 40 years in prison and up to $2 million in fines, but a jail term is not expected to approach the maximum term. GAF, a New Jersey-based chemical and building materials manufacturer, could be fined as much as $4 million. As a convicted felon, it also could be forced to sell its classical radio station in New York City, WNCN-FM. Under the civil settlement filed Thursday in federal court in Washington, D.C., GAF and Sherwin consented to injunctions that prevented them from manipulating stock. The company agreed to pay $1.25 million plus interest dating from Oct. 30, 1986, to the Securities and Exchange Commission. The funds will be placed in escrow for investors who were affected by GAF's actions, SEC enforcement division attorney Kevin McEnery said. ``The settlement was made with the SEC in order to resolve this matter promptly and avoid protracted and costly litigation,'' GAF said in a statement. Company officials declined to comment further. The SEC and a federal grand jury accused Sherwin and GAF of manipulating the price of Union Carbide stock in collaboration with former stockbroker Boyd L. Jefferies in October 1986. They sought to push up the share price before selling a large block GAF had amassed in a failed takeover attempt, the complaint alleged. After two mistrials, GAF and Sherwin were convicted in Manhattan federal court in December of eight counts of stock manipulation, securities fraud, wire fraud and conspiracy. Two GAF subsidiaries were acquitted. The conviction marked the first time that a company off Wall Street was convicted in the government's insider trading investigation that stemmed from disclosures by former stock speculator Ivan Boesky, who paid $100 million in fines and was sentenced to three years in prison. Lawyers for Sherwin and GAF have said they plan to appeal. The case initially attracted wide attention as the first criminal trial in the government's securities fraud and insider trading crackdown in the 1980s, but dragged on through 1989 and was upstaged by other cases. In the case, Jefferies testified he agreed to bid up the price of Union Carbide at Sherwin's request. GAF was trying to sell five million Union Carbide shares after the takeover for the larger chemicals concern failed. The SEC said the $1.25 million represents ``certain benefits received by GAF as a result of purchases of Union Carbide stock by Jefferies & Co.,'' Jefferies securities firm. The government alleged that Sherwin and Jefferies agreed to have Jefferies close the price of the common stock of Union Carbide at $22 or higher, and Sherwin agreed to compensate Jefferies for any losses. Testimony showed Jefferies & Co. bought 190,100 shares of Union Carbide on Oct. 29 and 30, which helped raise the stock price 12.5 cents to $22, and sold the stock a week later for a reported loss of $40,000. GAF later sold five million Carbide shares for $23 to Salomon Brothers Inc. Jefferies was forced to resign from his company after pleading guilty to two securities law violations. He named GAF as part of his cooperation with federal prosecutors, received a suspended sentence and was fined $250,000 last year.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Lower At Midday
DOC.TEXT: Share prices were lower at midday Friday amid investor caution about the pound's weakness. Political turmoil in the British government over the new poll tax weakened the currency, which in turn impacted the stock market, traders said. In addition, a rumor that Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher had resigned, since denied, contributed to dampening market sentiment, they said. Prices advanced strongly in the opening minutes of trading, then quickly collapsed as the pound was hit with a wave of selling. The sterling's losses were checked by intervention from the Bank of England, but not before the pound had lost 2 cents from its levels at the opening of the European day to fall to around its current level of $1.6245. ``The minute sterling came under pressure, trading stopped,'' said a dealer with the London investment firm Hoare Govett Ltd. At about 12:15 p.m. London time, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was down 13.2 points, or 0.6 percent, at 2,236.8. The market had been as high as 2,263.3 when trading officially opened at 9 a.m. Volume improved to 330.3 million shares by midday, compared with 247.9 million shares at the same time Thursday. Even so, ``it's still pretty lame,'' said Jonathan Hill, a director of the London investment firm Henderson Crosthwaite and Co.

DOC.HEAD: CBS To Pay More Than $1 Billion Over Four Years For NFL Contract
DOC.TEXT: The National Football League seems to be living proof that the rich keep getting richer. The league's television income soared to nearly $3 billion on Thursday when CBS agreed to a four-year contract that maintains its Sunday NFL package. The deal, which cost the network $1.06 billion, or $265 million a year, includes rights to the 1992 Super Bowl in Minneapolis. ``We are tremendously pleased to continue our 34-year association with the NFL and NFC games,'' CBS Sports president Neal Pilson said. ``Retaining our Sunday package was a key element in our long-term corporate strategy of providing broadcast coverage of dominant sports franchises.'' No matter, apparently, what it costs. Pilson had previously dipped into the CBS coffers for $1.06 billion for four years of baseball, $1 billion for seven years of the NCAA basketball tournament and $543 million for the next two Winter Olympics. The CBS contract followed the NFL's $900 million deal with ABC for the Monday night package, an extra tier of playoff games which the league provided, and the silver anniversary Super Bowl at Tampa in 1991. As appetizers for those two fancy network agreements, NFL commissioner Paul Tagliabue and his television negotiators completed twin $450 million cable contracts with ESPN and TBS for Sunday night games. Still to be heard from is NBC, locked in negotiations for its piece of the NFL pie following expiration of its three-year, $360 million deal. Including the NBC pact, which the Wall Street Journal reported could be signed as early as today, the NFL could reap some $3.6 billion in total for four years of television rights _ a 90 percent jump over the annual cost of the previous football contracts. Consider the increases in fees the league has already forged. Under its previous deal, ABC paid $120 million a year. That's gone up to $237.5 million per year in the new contract. CBS previously had a three-year, $450 million contract. The price tag on the current contract amounts to a 76 percent increase. ESPN was paying $150 million for 24 regular season games and three Pro Bowls. Now, with TBS added to the equation, cable television antes up six times that figure.

DOC.HEAD: Unemployment Dipped To 8.6 Percent in January
DOC.TEXT: The average unemployment rate in the 12 European Community nations dipped to 8.6 percent in January from 8.7 percent in December, the EC statistics agency said Friday. Henning Christophersen, EC commissioner for the economy, said ``two very positive trends can be drawn from the recent unemployment statistics. First, unemployment is now falling or static in all Member States, and second, youth unemployment is falling even faster.'' The unemployment rate for people under 25 has fallen almost one percent over the last six months dropping from 17.2 percent to 16.3 percent. This compares with a more modest drop in unemployment as a whole from 8.9 to 8.6 percent over the same period. Unemployment was highest in Ireland where 16.7 percent of the potential work force was out of work in January. Spain also has a high unemployment rate at 15.9 percent. Luxembourg, with only 1.8 percent of its work force out of a job, had the lowest rate, followed by Portugal at 4.9 percent. Rates in other countries were: Belgium, 9.1 percent; Denmark, 6.4 percent; West Germany, 5.4 percent; France, 9.4 percent; Italy, 10.9 percent; Netherlands, 9.0 percent; Britain, 6.1 percent. Figures for Greece were unavailable. Christophersen said the Community had ``the possibility over a few years to eliminate mass unemployment as we have known it since the end of the 70s, particularly against the background of both the coordinated economic policy mix in the Member States and in the light of the events and opening markets of Central and Eastern Europe.''

DOC.HEAD: USX Agrees to Hold Shareholder Vote
DOC.TEXT: Carl Icahn plans to spend as much as $10 million on a campaign to convince USX Corp. shareholders that everyone will benefit from his proposal to sell the company's steel division. ``I feel it's very compelling, and I certainly hope they will,'' he said in a telephone interview. ``I feel it will not only enhance shareholder value but also be good for other constituencies.'' Icahn's proposal will be put to a non-binding shareholder vote under an agreement announced Thursday. In exchange for the vote, Icahn, USX's biggest shareholder, agreed not to wage a proxy fight or submit other matters for consideration at the steel, oil and gas giant's May 7 annual meeting, USX said. Stockholders will be asked whether USX should incorporate a separate steel business and spin off at least 80 percent of it, Icahn said in documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The new company would carry no more than $1.5 billion in long-term debt. Icahn, chairman of Trans World Airlines Inc., said in the filing he will spend $5 million to $10 million on the campaign to persuade shareholders. USX, which will not be bound by the outcome, said in a statement it opposes the resolution as not in the best interest of stockholders but would ``give due consideration to the results of such vote in determining its future course of action.'' USX stock rose $1 to $36.62{ a share Thursday in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Under a bylaw amendment approved by the company's board in January, Icahn was required to tell USX by the close of business Thursday whether he would nominate his own slate of directors at the annual meeting. Icahn owns nearly 34 million, or 13.26 percent, of the company's outstanding common shares. He has long been unhappy with USX management and believes the company's stock price is too low. Icahn had argued in favor of the sale of USX's Marathon Oil & Gas subsidiary, which USX management does not want to sell. In 1988, he waged an unsuccessful proxy battle at Texaco Inc., hoping to unseat the oil company's board and force a restructuring to boost Texaco's stock price. Charles A. Bradford, a steel industry analyst, said this may be a bad time to sell the steel division, known as U.S. Steel. ``It would be quite difficult to get a good value for the steel division today with the state of the stock market today, he said. Bradford said potential buyers could be scared off by USX's $5.7 billion long-term debt. About 65 percent of USX's revenues comes from its energy division, while about 31 percent comes from steel, USX spokesman William Keslar said. The steel division's operating income totaled $430 million in 1989, compared with $501 million in 1988. The reduced income was due partly to the sale of the Lorain, Ohio, steel works to a 50 percent-owned joint venture in the second quarter of 1989. The annual meeting will be held at Marathon's headquarters in Findlay, Ohio.

The stock market was mixed today in an ambivalent response to the latest statistics on employment. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 1.80 to 2,697.97 in the first half hour of trading. Losers outnumbered gainers by about 5 to 3 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 378 up, 620 down and 484 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 27.57 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. The Labor Department reported that the civilian unemployment rate held steady at 5.3 percent in February, while nonfarm payroll employment swelled by 372,000 on top of an upward-revised increase in January. The pace of job growth substantially exceeded advance estimates, suggesting that the economy had regained more momentum than many analysts had thought. That was interpreted as a plus for the outlook for corporate profits, which have been weak lately. But brokers said it also raised new worries about upward pressure on interest rates, and seemed to dim whatever chances might have existed for any easing of the Federal Reserve's credit policy. Among actively traded blue chips, International Business Machines rose ] to 107]; American Telephone & Telegraph was steady at 41}, and Texaco dropped \ to 59\. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell .18 to 187.17. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .17 at 361.34. On Thursday the Dow Jones industrial average climbed 26.58 to 2,696.17, its highest close since it stood at 2,760.67 on Jan. 11. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 2 to 1 on the NYSE, with 986 up, 495 down and 476 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 170.90 million shares, against 163.58 million in the previous session.

The stock market gave ground mixed today in the face of stronger-than-expected employment news. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell 10.58 to 2,685.59 by 11 a.m. on Wall Street. Losers outnumbered gainers by about 3 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 491 up, 734 down and 496 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 56.97 million shares at midmorning. The Labor Department reported that the civilian unemployment rate held steady at 5.3 percent in February, while nonfarm payroll employment swelled by 372,000 on top of an upward-revised increase in January. The pace of job growth substantially exceeded advance estimates, suggesting that the economy had regained more momentum than many analysts had thought. That was interpreted as a plus for the outlook for corporate profits, which have been weak lately. But brokers said it also raised new worries about upward pressure on interest rates, and seemed to dim whatever chances might have existed for any easing of the Federal Reserve's credit policy. NCNB fell 2{ to 41[. The company said it might see an increase of as much as 25 percent in its problem loans during the first quarter of the year. Among actively traded blue chips, International Business Machines dropped \ to 106}; American Telephone & Telegraph \ to 41{; Philip Morris | to 37{, and Texaco { to 59. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell .75 to 186.60. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .53 at 360.98.

DOC.HEAD: Aid to Coal Miners Issue Stalls Senate Passage of Clean Air Bill
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 3rd graf to CORRECT `assistant' to `assistance;' SUBS 4th graf to restore dropped word ``to''
DOC.TEXT: Senate leaders today abandoned efforts to complete key parts of a clean air bill before an upcoming weeklong recess after a dispute emerged over whether the government should provide $700 million in assistance to coal miners. The coal miner assistance proposal, aimed at helping workers who lose their jobs because of tougher acid rain emission controls, threatened a compromise agreement on clean air legislation with the White House, which has vigorously opposed the measure as being too expensive. ``It has become apparent that we cannot complete action on the bill ... this week,'' said Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine. He said he expected the remainder of the day to focus primarily on the coal miner assistance proposal. Senate leaders had been prepared Thursday night to bring the amendment, offered by Sen. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., to a vote, but when debate dragged beyond midnight action was postponed. Mitchell said negotiations were under way with the White House to attempt to work out an agreement. But he said he was opposed to the assistance plan and said he accepts the view of Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., that the issue could scuttle the compromise agreement with the Bush administration. The delay on the Byrd amendment prompted speculation that Mitchell did not have the votes to block the proposal. Mitchell told reporters today he did not know what the vote count was. Mitchell had threatened all week to hold the senators in session into Saturday if necessary to work out key provisions of the clean air legislation. But he said today that a list of remaining amendments would be assembled for action after Senate returns March 20 after its weeklong recess. He said he did not anticipate action on other major amendments, including several strengthening auto pollution control proposals, until the coal miner issue was resolved. Byrd called the measure a ``safety net'' for as many as 5,000 miners who will lose their jobs because stringent controls on sulfur dioxide will force Midwest utilities to shift to other than high-sulfur coal to power their plants. The amendment was one of several before the Senate that conflicts with the compromise agreement reached last month between Senate leaders and the White House on the scope of the air pollution control bill. The administration has been adamant in opposing provisions that would increase the expense of the legislation, which in its present form would cost the economy about $21 billion a year. Earlier Thursday, the Senate in a 66-33 vote rejected an amendment to require additional toxic emission controls on automobiles. Senate leaders called it a ``deal breaker'' because of strong opposition by the White House, which objected to its reported $1.5 billion price tag. But the Byrd coal miner ``safety net'' amendment prompted the strongest debate and behind-the-scenes maneuvering. ``If this amendment is passed, it's over,'' declared Sen. Bob Dole, R-Kan., referring to the Byrd proposal. ``The administration doesn't like this amendment one bit and that would be an understatement.'' Mitchell said discussions were continuing with the White House on a compromise that would satisfy both the administration and Byrd and clear the way for a vote on the proposal today. The clean air measure represents the first tightening of federal air pollution control laws in 13 years. It calls for sweeping curbs on smog-causing pollution from automobiles and industrial plants and requires new cuts in acid rain pollutants from coal-fired electric power plants. A similar bill remains in committee in the House. Byrd, who for many years when he was majority leader blocked acid rain legislation to protect West Virginia miners, had been seeking $1.3 billion to provide miners who lose jobs because of the new pollution controls with full or partial salaries for six years. He later cut back the proposal to four years, with an estimated cost of $700 million. The senator argued that his proposal was no different than the federal government's bailout of New York City, its assistance program for railroaders after the Penn Central went bankrupt, or federal aid to victims of the San Francisco earthquake and Hurricane Hugo. ``A disaster is a disaster and I'm talking about a disaster that is going to hit the coal fields,'' Byrd told his colleagues. But Dole and other senators said that if the coal miners are helped, so should workers in other industries who might lose their jobs because of the sweeping pollution controls envisioned by the clean air bill.

DOC.HEAD: White House Denies Report That Bush Upset at Fed Chief
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The White House today denied a report that President Bush is unlikely to reappoint Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan when his term expires in August 1991 because of Greenspan's refusal to push interest rates down further. The Los Angeles Times today quoted an unidentified longtime Bush adviser as saying the president is ``mad as hell'' about Greenspan's position on interest rates and will seek a new Fed chief. ``I deny the story,'' Bush spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said at the regular White House briefing. ``We're not angry.'' Also at the briefing was Michael Boskin, chairman of the president's Council of Economic Advisers, who said of the story: ``It's out of left field.'' Boskin said ``there hasn't been any discussion'' about whether Bush should reappoint Greenspan. ``I have not even begun to think about that issue nor, do I think, has the president,'' Boskin said. ``The president and Chairman Greenspan as well as (Treasury) Secretary Brady and myself and others in the administration have good working relations with the Federal Reserve,'' Boskin said. The administration has on occassion publicly called for lower interest rates, comments widely interpreted as an attempt to pressure the Fed to ease monetary policy as part of an effort to spark the economy, which since last year has shown signs of weakness. Greenspan told Congress two weeks ago that the threat of recession has faded and that he was unlikely to encourage rates to fall, a move that could push inflation higher.

DOC.HEAD: Soybean, Corn Futures Mostly Higher
DOC.TEXT: Futures prices for soybeans and corn were mostly higher, with wheat lower in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade. Lower-than-expected figures in a private planting service report issued Thursday and an active soymeal cash market overnight in Europe supported soybean futures, analysts said. Corn was simply following soybeans higher, while wheat prices were depressed by rain forecasts for this weekend over U.S. growing areas, traders said. In early trading, wheat was { cent to 1\ cent lower, with the contract for delivery in March at $3.83 a bushel; corn was { cent to 1 cent higher, with March at $2.43 a bushel; oats were \ cent to 1{ cents higher, with March at $1.46 a bushel; and soybeans were { cent to 3} cents higher, with March at $5.84{ a bushel. On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, pork futures were mostly lower and cattle prices were mixed. In early trading, cattle were .12 cent lower to .30 cent higher, with the contract for delivery in April at 77.50 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .15 cent lower to .05 cent higher, with March at 81.92 cents a pound; live hogs were .10 cent to .32 cent lower, with April at 51.90 cents a pound; and frozen pork bellies were .10 cent higher to .52 cent lower, with March at 52.10 cents a pound. On Thursday, livetsock and meat prices finished higher.

Fixed-rate home mortgages are currently averaging 10.29 percent, up from 10.23 percent last week, according to a national survey released Friday by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. On one-year adjustable rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.50 percent this week, up from 8.48 percent the week before.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Union Submits Formal Request for Observer Status
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union has formally applied for observer status with the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, a spokesman for the 96-nation world trade forum said Friday. David Woods said Evgeny Makeyev, Soviet ambassador in Geneva, submitted the application Thursday and asked that the request be considered at the next GATT Council meeting scheduled for April 3. Observer status would enable the Soviet Union to examine GATT and the preconditions for full membership, while also keeping trading partners up to date with Moscow's economic restructuring program, Woods said. Members of the market-orientated organization, which draws up agreements to liberalize global commerce and mediates trade disputes, account for more than four-fifths of world trade. Diplomats who spoke on condition of anonymity said there was wide support for Moscow to become involved in GATT before the end of the year. But they added the application was unlikely to be approved as quickly as next month. Although observer status would not automatically entitle the Soviet Union to multilateral trading concessions enjoyed by full GATT members, it would give Moscow first-hand knowledge of changes in the world trading system. Such information is necessary to back up Soviet economic and trade reforms. But the Soviet Union would not be privy to talks on comprehensive new agreements to liberalize trade in areas such as agriculture and textiles that are being drawn up as part of the ambitious Uruguay Round of negotiations scheduled to end in December. Around 30 countries are observers at GATT, including China, which is seeking full membership. At last December's Malta summit U.S. President George Bush said he would back Moscow's bid for observer status. The United States had previously opposed any Soviet involvement on the grounds that the Soviet economic system was incompatible with GATT's free trade principles.

DOC.HEAD: National Lampoon Being Acquired by Video Producer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to spell out two-thirds.
DOC.TEXT: National Lampoon Inc., the magazine publisher and movie producer, has agreed to be acquired by J2 Communications in a stock swap valued at approximately $4.67 million, the companies announced today. J2, a home video producer and distributor, will exchange two-thirds of a share of its common stock plus a warrant expected to be worth $1 for each share of National Lampoon stock, the companies said in a statement. J2's shares, which did not immediately begin trading at the opening of the over-the-counter market today, closed at $3 on Thursday. National Lampoon also did not begin trading immediately today after closing at $3.50 a share Thursday. Actor Tim Matheson and his business partner, Daniel Grodnik, who acquired a controlling stake in National Lampoon last year, will continue to run the company as a division of J2. James P. Jimirro, J2's president and chief executive, said the acquisition would give National Lampoon, which has been losing money, capital for its publishing and movie projects. Last month, National Lampoon reported a third-quarter loss of $435,300 on revenue of $1.38 million. For the first nine months of the year, the company reported a loss of $915,000 on revenue of $3.8 million. National Lampoon publishes National Lampoon magazine and produces movies. Its most recent hit was ``National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation.'' J2 is an independent producer of home videos. The deal announced today must be approved by shareholders of both companies. Matheson and Grodnik took control of National Lampoon _ which had been running in the red for some time _ from its founder Matty Simmons. Matheson appeared as the college Don Juan in National Lampoon's first hit film, ``Animal House,'' in 1978.

DOC.HEAD: Leo Melamed Trading Up and Out of Futures Leadership
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: It was an unlikely snapshot of Chicago Mercantile Exchange chief Leo Melamed, sauntering past a turquoise swimming pool sporting a black silk shirt and pale yellow slacks. He was smiling and tossing a small package, perhaps a giveaway from a vendor at the Futures Industry Association convention in the sprawling pink Boca Raton Hotel. Melamed is known more for operating in hyperdrive, whether he's proclaiming the global importance of the financial futures he fathered, defending his industry against critics, creating new worlds of science fiction or imagining new ways of managing risk. Trader, lawyer, author, visionary _ Leo Melamed is considered the renaissance man of the futures markets, once the domain of pork farmers and grain merchants. His surprise retirement at year's end from the dual role of special counsel to the Merc and chairman of the board's executive committee will leave a void in the leadership of an industry fighting to preserve turf and reputation. ``Time will allow us to find other people,'' Melamed said when he announced his retirement March 5. ``They're around and they will come forward.'' Even his main competitor, Chicago Board of Trade Chairman Karsten Mahlmann, says Melamed's contributions will be missed: ``If he wants to become more of a private citizen, the whole industry will feel his loss.'' Melamed, graying but fit-looking at 57, says his only plans are to write memoirs, publish a sequel to his science-fiction novel ``The Tenth Planet,'' do some trading and spend more time with his family. But he is not likely to stroll far from the scuffling heart of the markets he nurtured. Robert Wilmouth, president of the National Futures Association, an industry-funded watchdog agency that Melamed helped found in 1982, predicts that if the industry needs someone to lead it through tomorrow's thickets, Leo ``is going to be holding the light.'' Melamed said he will be around to offer advice and, when pressed on possible career moves, said: ``I'll see what comes along the way.'' His most notable achievement was the creation in the early 1970s of financial futures contracts, risk-management tools used by large institutional investors around the world. Pension funds, banks, even governments rely on Melamed's invention to lock in returns on stocks, bonds and currency trades. These high-finance instruments are traded exactly the same way as pork belly and soybean futures from Chicago to Sydney: traders crowd pits, yell bids and furiously flash hand signals. It is raucous, adrenalin-pumping and confounding. It is, Melamed said in a speech last week at the convention, ``an industry I loved from the very first moment that, by sheer accident, I came upon it.'' That was around 1953 when Melamed, son of Polish immigrant schoolteachers, took a job at the Merc as a runner for Merrill Lynch to earn his way through law school. Egg futures were the Merc's main product line then. But as he rose from runner to trader to chairman in 1969, Melamed saw a dead-end in limiting futures trading to the world of basic commodities. He saw an opportunity to exploit fluctuations in currency exchange rates, freed to float by an international agreement in 1971. A disciple of economist Milton Friedman's free-market philosophy, Melamed envisioned a market for international currency futures, where you could ensure a guaranteed price in yen for your dollars, or pounds for your francs. He took his idea to Washington. There, at 33, Melamed called on then Treasury Secretary George Shultz, Federal Reserve Chairman Arthur Burns and Alan Greenspan, then head of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, for reaction. They liked it, he said. In Greenspan's office, ``I suggested that the markets we were creating in Chicago might be beneficial to the American economy. In an instant, he stood up from his desk and literally reeled off a litany of uses that I had never dreamed possible for futures markets in Treasury bills, certificates of deposit, T-bonds and the like.'' The Merc launched its first currency futures contracts in 1972, when annual U.S. futures trading volume totaled 18.3 million contracts. Last year, more than 267 million futures contracts were traded on U.S. exchanges, and more than 60 percent were products such as currency, bond and stock-index futures. Melamed's biggest project in recent years has been guiding the development of Globex, an electronic trading system that he sees linking U.S., European and Far Eastern financial markets to create a 24-hour exchange. He expects it to begin operation by midyear. Melamed's creations have not been free of controversy. Stock-index futures, for example, which allow investors to control large amounts of stock at low cost, have been blamed by some experts for volatility in the stock market. The Securities and Exchange Commission appears to be advancing in its quest to wrest regulatory control over index futures away from the less intrusive Commodity Futures Trading Commission. Melamed finds the prospect distasteful, though he's willing to compromise; others in the futures industry abhor it, fearing the SEC will regulate them out of business. In another blow to the industry, 26 traders from the Merc's Japanese yen and Swiss franc pits were among 48 people indicted last year on fraud charges stemming from an FBI sting operation at the Merc and the Board of Trade. But Melamed has not been sullied. He was praised by Washington and the industry for quickly responding to the crisis. ``If I were to do it all over again,'' he said, ``this is what I would do and that is how I would do it and I would regret nothing along the way.''

DOC.HEAD: British Firm to Pay $1.25 Billion For American Home Products Division
DOC.TEXT: Reckitt and Colman PLC, a British food and household goods group, has agreed to pay $1.25 billion for the Boyle-Midway home products unit of New York-based American Home Products Corp., the companies said today. The acquisition of Boyle-Midway, whose products include Woolite laundry soap and Easy-Off oven cleaner, would make Reckitt and Colman a major international household products manufacturer. Boyle-Midway is about half the size of Reckitt and Colman's household products and toiletries division. Boyle-Midway had $667 million in sales last year in the United States, Canada, France, West Germany and Spain and a pretax profit of $91 million, the companies said. Similar Reckitt and Colman businesses had pre-tax profit of 117 million pounds, or $191 million, on sales of 817 million pounds, or $1.3 billion, last year. The move ``will result in a major increase in the size and scope of Reckitt and Colman's business in North America and Continental Europe,'' the British company said. Analysts said they had been expecting Reckitt and Colman to make either a single major purchase or a string of acquisitions in household goods. Such a move is necessary ``if it wants to make double-digit growth'' in the years ahead, said Steve Plag, an analyst at the London investment firm Barclays de Zoete Wedd Ltd. The groups' existing products, which range from mustards to home cleaning products, are in mature, slower growing sectors of their markets. American Home Products also manufactures over-the-counter and prescription drugs. Its other units include Whitehall and Fort Dodge laboratories.

DOC.HEAD: Oversight Panel With Creditors Input To Run Company
DOC.TEXT: Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc. and its creditors agreed today to a plan to operate the company and its subsidiaries during bankruptcy proceedings for the collapsed Wall Street firm. Also, attorneys for the committee of unsecured creditors said they would oppose an attempt by the Securities and Exchange Commission to be admitted to the committee. Drexel still owes the SEC $150 million to settle securities fraud charges brought last year. Under the oversight scheme, which was was approved by U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Howard Buschman III, a panel of three Drexel board members would oversee the firm's liquidation. Four representatives of Drexel's committee of unsecured creditors would attend daily board meetings, receive information about the company's operations and have input into the liquidation. Drexel's creditors dropped a plan to ask Buschman to appoint an examiner to run the company during the bankruptcy case, which Drexel said would have hamstrung operations such as the time-sensitive sale of securities. The compromise agreement follows more than a week of negotiations in which Drexel forestalled the appointment of an examiner and the creditors gained access to the firm's liquidation. It applies to the parent company and subsidiaries, principally the brokerage Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. The deal also prevents for now the creditors from trying to force the subsidiaries, which are not subject to the bankruptcy case, into a Chapter 7 liquidation monitored by the court. Drexel still is trying to sell off about $1 billion in junk bond holdings and other assets. Creditors have said they are concerned that the company was not receiving fair value for its assets. Under the agreement, creditors with access to Drexel's inner workings will not have veto power over deals made by the firm but can file protests with the bankruptcy judge. The three-member Drexel panel is comprised of chairman John S.R. Shad, a former SEC chairman; Roderick Hills, a Washington lawyer and former SEC chairman; and Ralph Saul, a former American Stock Exchange president. Drexel filed for bankruptcy protection Feb. 13 after defaulting on $100 million in short-term debt and failing to raise new credit. The firm was hard-hit by a drop in the junk bond market. The SEC has the largest claim in the case but was not included on the 17-member creditors committee. It has filed a request with the judge to be appointed. But Marc Kirschner, a lawyer for the committee, said creditors would oppose the move. Buschman indicated the SEC should play some role on the panel but said the final decision rested with the U.S. Trustee's office.

DOC.HEAD: Digital To Expand Voluntary Severance Program
DOC.TEXT: Digital Equipment Corp. will substantially expand its voluntary severance program to eliminate thousands of employees and slash expenses as it contends with a slumping U.S. computer market, officials said Friday. Digital officials would not give specific figures on how many employees might be cut, saying the plan was still being prepared. But Brad Allen, manager of shareholder relations, said the number was ``in the ballpark'' of previously estimated figures. Industry analysts have said Digital, which employs about 125,900 people worldwide and more than 70,000 in the United States, wants to pare its staff by at least 5,000 and eventually redeploy as many as 15,000 employees in new jobs. ``The momentum has picked up, the program definitely will be expanded,'' Allen said, adding the program was to be implemented by the end of the company's fiscal year on June 30. Digital spokeswoman Nikki Richardson said the program will be similar to a package offered last year to 700 employees at the company's manufacturing plant in Salem, N.H. In that plan, which has been accepted by 260 workers so far, employees choosing to participate received a cash payment based on years of service, as well as medical, dental and life insurance coverage for one year. Workers with up to two years of service, for example, received 40 weeks of pay. Those with three to 10 years got 40 weeks, plus three weeks for each year between three and 10 years. ``We are looking at all transition programs on a business-by-business basis,'' Richardson said. ``What is implemented will be based on the Salem model.'' Digital, the world's second-largest computer company behind International Business Machines Corp., saw its earnings fall 39 percent for the six months ended Dec. 31. The company, based in suburban Maynard, blames the drop on a lackluster computer market in the United States, which has forced other companies to make cutbacks as well. Digital also has reassigned hundreds of employees from manufacturing to sales.

DOC.HEAD: Troubled Bank Of New England Names New Chairman
DOC.TEXT: Bank of New England Corp. named Lawrence K. Fish as its chairman and chief executive Friday as officials continued restructuring the troubled company in an effort to restore financial health and public confidence. ``While there has been considerable speculation about candidates, Mr. Fish was our first choice, and the only one to receive an offer from us,'' Peter L. Scott, head of the executive search, said in a statement. Analysts generally praised the decision to hire Fish, a former Bank of Boston Corp. executive vice president, but they warned he might not be able to rescue the bank. ``He's coming into a situation that's very grave,'' said Gerard Cassidy, an analyst with Tucker Anthony Inc. ``If the economy does not cooperate, a miracle worker is going to have a hard time. A major part of it is out of his hands.'' Fish, whose hiring was expected for more than a week, replaces Walter Connolly, who oversaw the bank's dramatic growth in the 1980s but was ousted this year after the company suffered massive losses. Much of the trouble has been traced to the bank's aggressive lending practices during a construction boom in the mid-1980s. When the economy slowed near the end of the decade, the real estate market tumbled, and the bank was saddled with a mountain of problem loans. Last month, the bank announced it lost $1.11 billion in 1989 and disclosed it was reviewing financial data from previous quarters to see whether larger provisions against bad loans should have been made earlier in the year. The bank also is operating under federal consent orders signed last week, which place the corporation under strict government oversight while it takes steps to fix its problems. Under the orders, the bank must tighten its lending practices, withhold stock dividends and review the work of its senior level management to see where changes should be made. ``(Fish) has to come down like a ton of bricks on some situations,'' Cassidy said. ``It's fresh blood. He can come in and make the decisions.'' Fish, 45, left Bank of Boston in 1988 to become president and chief operating officer of Columbia Savings & Loan Association in Beverly Hills, Calif. Part of his job at Columbia was to produce a plan to make the institution less reliant on high risk, high yield junk bonds. Fish resigned last August, and since then Columbia has suffered with a crash in the junk bond market. The newly appointed chairman said in a prepared statement Friday that he believed in the Bank of New England's ``soundness and strength,'' but acknowledged the road to financial recovery could be long. ``We ... have significant problems. I plan to be thoughtful but to make decisions promptly,'' said Fish, who was also named chairman and CEO of the Bank of New England's Massachusetts subsidiary.

DOC.HEAD: Sultan Of Brunei Denies Role in House of Fraser Bid
DOC.TEXT: The Sultan of Brunei on Friday denied any role in the $1 billion takeover of Harrods owner House of Fraser PLC by the Al-Fayed brothers in 1985. The sultan said in a statement that he had no part in the takeover, nor did he provide funds to Mohamed, Salah and Ali Al-Fayed to help them buy it. The ruler of Brunei acknowledged that a power of attorney privilege was granted to Mohamed Al-Fayed to buy the Dorchester Hotel for the sultan. If this privilege was used for something else, it was done so totally without the sultan's authority or knowledge, the statement said. On Wednesday, the government released a report by Department of Trade and Industry inspectors saying the Al-Fayeds lied about their wealth and background to succeed with the bid and that it was likely they used their association with the sultan to enable them to obtain funds toward the takeover. They said they believed the Al-Fayeds did not have enough money of their own to buy the retailing group. ``The evidence pointing to Brunei is very strong indeed,'' the report said, ``and we have conveyed our findings to the sultan. Our views stand.'' The Al-Fayeds deny they misled anyone and maintain that they paid for House of Fraser with their own cash. Trade Secretary Nicholas Ridley said Tuesday he would not seek disqualification of any of the company's directors. The Serious Fraud Office and the Director of the Public Prosecutions announced last week they would not pursue a criminal prosecution in connection with the takeover.

DOC.HEAD: Lugar Introduces Farm Bill With Administration Proposals
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Richard Lugar, the ranking Republican on the Senate Agriculture Committee, introduced a farm bill Friday that would freeze at current levels the target prices for crops regulated by the government. The measure reflects most of the proposals laid out in February by the Bush administration for the 1990 farm bill. It goes a step further, however, by speaking to target prices, which the administration avoided. Financial analysts have said that even keeping the prices steady could push the farm bill beyond the administration's proposed budget, depending on the world commodities market. ``We may need to find savings in agricultural programs this year, but we cannot yet estimate how much,'' said Lugar, R-Ind. ``My purpose today is to introduce a farm bill, and not a budget reconciliation bill.'' He said his bill had no price tag, but estimated it could cost less than the approximately $10 billion currently spent on agriculture programs if market conditions are right and no weather disaster occurs. Target prices are what the government decides a farmer should get in the marketplace for wheat, corn, sorghum, barley, oats, rice and upland and extra-long staple cotton. These commodities often are called ``program crops'' because farmers that grow them participate in the federal commodities program. If the market price is below the government's target price, the government pays the farmer the difference, known as a deficiency payment. Congress sets target prices every five years when it passes a farm bill. Lawmakers say they want to send the 1990 legislation to the president by the end of the summer. Lugar's bill, which also emphasizes flexible planting options for farmers who grow program crops, is similar to legislation introduced Wednesday by Sen. Rudy Boschwitz, R-Minn., another member of the agriculture committee. Boschwitz calls his bill the Farm Flexibility Act of 1990. It also calls for a freeze on target prices. Flexibility has been stressed by Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter in promoting the administration's proposals. He says the government will save money on deficiency payments if farmers are allowed to let market demand determine their planting decisions. His proposals and the Lugar and Boschwitz bills safeguard farm income by allowing the farmer to collect deficiency payments based on whatever program crop dominates the acreage, even if the market losses are on another crop the farmer has decided to experiment with that year. Yeutter says farmers also would be encouraged to rotate crops, which will be good for the soil and reduce the need for chemicals. ``Today, rigid planting rules often lock farmers into planting the same crop on the same land, year after year,'' said Lugar. ``Past farm legislation has encouraged planting of so-called `program crops' such as corn, even when market demand calls for more production of non-program crops such as soybeans. As a result, the United States loses foreign markets.'' Boschwitz said he came up with his proposal after holding 150 meetings on farms across Minnesota. ``Farmers have told me that they would enjoy having the freedom to adjust their crop mix in response to the market and consumer demands,'' Boschwitz said. He and Lugar said farmers are happy with the 1985 law. Both senators said their bills would basically extend that law. An aide to Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., chairman of the agriculture committee, said many committee members will be introducing farm bills this month. They all will be placed together for review of the committee and debate over which provisions from each should be part of the final bill voted on by the Senate, the aide said.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Move Lower
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates throughout with closing data; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices closed lower after an unsettled session on London's Stock Exchange Friday. Traders said there was widespread nervousness over a decline in the pound and the failure of the Bank of England's intervention to curb the currency's fall. The traders blamed the government's continuing political problems for the weakness in sterling. There were even rumors, which were swiftly denied, that Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher had resigned. At the close, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was down 15.7 points, or 0.7 percent, at 2,234.3. The Financial Times 30-share index was off 10.6 points at 1,763.8 at the close. The Financial Times 500-share index fell 6.46 points to close at 1,212.72. Volume reached 546.8 million shares, compared with 439.4 million shares Thursday. Dealers attributed the increased volume to a large program trade.

DOC.HEAD: Oversight Panel With Creditor Input To Run Company
DOC.TEXT: Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc. creditors will receive confidential company information but no veto power over asset sales under a bankruptcy court agreement reached Friday on managing liquidation of the collapsed Wall Street firm. Also, attorneys for Drexel's unsecured creditors said they would oppose a move by the Securities and Exchange Commission to join their committee. Drexel still owes the SEC $150 million from its 1989 settlement of securities fraud charges. Opposition to an SEC role on the committee centers on $500 million Drexel already has paid the government that creditors have said they may seek to recover for repayment of debts. But U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Howard Buschman III indicated the SEC, which has the largest claim against Drexel, necessarily would have a role in the case even if it was not on the creditors committe. ``It is very hard to imagine a ... Chapter 11 case disaffecting the single largest unsecured creditor, regardless of what hat they wear,'' Buschman said. Under the oversight scheme approved by Buschman, a panel of three Drexel board members would oversee the firm's liquidation of about $1 billion in junk bond holdings and other assets. A subcommittee of four creditors would attend daily meetings of the group, receive ``highly confidential commercial information'' about planned transactions by 6 p.m. and attend a meeting the following morning on sales. The creditors will not have veto power over deals but can contest sales with the bankruptcy judge. Drexel creditors had sought and then dropped a request for an examiner to run Drexel during the bankruptcy proceedings, which the firm said would have hampered such operations as the time-sensitive sale of securities. Creditors wanted access to Drexel's inner workings because of concerns the company is not receiving fair value for its assets. The creditors also will have access to information about past transactions, including nearly $200 million in cash bonuses paid in December and January. The compromise applies to the parent company and to its subsidiaries, including the brokerage unit Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., which are not subject to the bankruptcy case. All asset sales by the parent company still must be approved by Buschman. By granting creditors a role in the firm's operations, the deal apparently forestalls for now any bid to force the subsidiaries into a Chapter 7 liquidation, which would be monitored by the court. Drexel attorney Alan Miller said the arrangement ensures ``the process has integrity and every effort is being made to do the best possible job in the wind-down of these entities.'' The three-member Drexel panel is company chairman John S.R. Shad, a former SEC chairman; Roderick Hills, a Washington lawyer and former SEC chairman; and Ralph Saul, a former American Stock Exchange president. The three, who will be paid $190,000 a year, were named as an oversight committee to Drexel as part of the firm's settlement of civil securities fraud charges with the SEC last April. The four creditors on the subcommittee are First City Bancorp. of Texas, Home Capital Services Inc., Equitable Capital Management Corp. and Copenhagen Handelsbank. Drexel filed for bankruptcy protection Feb. 13 after defaulting on $100 million in short-term debt and failing to obtain new credit. The firm was hard-hit by a drop in the junk bond market and its own legal problems. The SEC was not included on the 17-member committee representing Drexel creditors. It has filed a motion to be appointed and has been negotiating a place on the committee, a move opposed by the creditors. The committee has granted another large creditor, the California Employees Retirement System, a non-voting place on the committee. Lead creditor First City has said it may seek repayment of Drexel debts from money the firm paid the government last year in resolving criminal and civil insider trading and other fraud charges. Of the total $650 million in penalties, $300 million was paid in fines to the Justice Department and $200 million to an escrow account to satisfy possible investor claims against the firm. Drexel still owes $150 million to the account.

DOC.HEAD: Soybeans, Corn Advance
DOC.TEXT: Futures prices for soybeans and corn advanced, but wheat was lower at the close Friday on the Chicago Board of Trade. A resurgence of export business and an active soymeal cash market overseas supported soybean futures, said Joel Karlin, an analyst with Research Department Inc. ``Also South American rains could delay the start of the harvest there,' said Karlin. ``The soybean advance spilled over into corn and gave that market a boost.'' Wheat prices were depressed by rain forecasts for this weekend over U.S. growing areas, said Walter Spilka, analyst with Smith Barney Harris Upham & Co. At the close, wheat was { cent to 3 cents lower, with the contract for delivery in March at $3.83 a bushel; corn was { cent to 1 cent higher, with March at $2.43{ a bushel; oats were 1 cent to 2{ cents higher, with March at $1.46} a bushel; and soybeans were 1{ cent to 4{ cents higher, with March at $5.86 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: California Areas Among Leaders in Home Building Permits
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Three California metropolitan areas _ Riverside-San Bernardino, Los Angeles-Long Beach and Sacramento _ were among the top five in the nation in single-family home building activity in 1989, the National Association of Home Builders reported Friday. The Riverside-San Bernardino area, with 38,200 building permits, topped the list for the second straight year. It was followed by the Los Angeles-Long Beach area, with 23,640 permits; Washington, D.C., with 22,360; Atlanta, with 21,750, and Sacramento, with 16.540. The Home Builders said 938,000 single-family building permits were issued nationally last year, down from 1,005,000 in 1988. Multifamily permits dropped from 458,000 in 1988 to 403,000 in 1989. ``High interest rates at different times during the year coupled with a sluggish economy, affordability problems and consumer hesitance caused total permits for single-family and multifamily housing to drop from 1,463,000 in 1988 to 1,341,000 last year,'' said Home Builders president Martin Perlman. ``This is the lowest number of permits issued since 1982, during the most recent recession, when 1 million units were authorized,'' he said. ``Although at present we expect housing activity in 1990 to closely mirror last year's performance, it could drop considerably if interest rates continue to climb as they have in recent weeks.'' The housing and manufacturing industries were hardest hit as the Federal Reserve raised interest rates as it sought to stem inflation last year. Fixed-rate, 30-year mortgages rose to an average 11.22 percent in March before dropping into the single digits in July, according to weekly surveys by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. Rates surged back over the 10 percent threshhold in mid-August, dropped back into the single digits in October and remainded there until January when they topped 10 percent again. They stood at 10.29 percent on Friday. ``Another factor that could cause housing activity to drop off is the availability of funds for acquisition and development of land and construction of new homes,'' Perlman said, noting the savings and loan bailout law limits the amount of money thrifts can loan. Despite heading the single-family list, the number of permits issued in the Riverside-San Bernadino area was 11.2 percent below that of 1988, the Home Builders said. Permits were up 34.2 percent in the Los Angeles-Long Beach area and down 23.6 percent in the national capital area and 23.7 percent in Atlanta. Sacramento posted a 16.8 percent increase. The Los Angeles-Long Beach area recorded the most multifamily permits, 24,590. That was down 23.6 percent from 1988. Also in the top five of multifamily permits were Seattle with 24,840, a 5.9 percent decrease; Las Vegas with 11,820, down 30.3 percent; Atlanta with 11,740, down 26.6 percent, and Washington, D.C., with 11,610, a 12.2 percent gain.

DOC.HEAD: Pere-Smoke-a: `Gorbachev' Cigarettes Launched in West
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A Swiss company launched a cigarette named for Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Friday, figuring that a popular Kremlin leader might be just the guy to knock the Marlboro man off his horse. The company plans to invade the U.S. market next with the cigarette, which it calls ``Gorbatchow,'' enticing smokers with its slogan, ``A Taste of Freedom.'' The World Health Organization was less than enthusiastic about the launch of the new brand. The U.N. agency estimates that nearly 3 million people will die this year from tobacco-related illnesses such as cancer and heart disease. Peter Studer, owner of the small company that introduced the brand in Geneva on Friday, said the name ``Gorbatchow'' was formed by mixing spellings of the Soviet president's name in various languages. The medium-strength cigarette is a blend of 21 types of tobacco _ some Soviet, some American. Studer said in an interview that cigarette smokers need ``a new image.'' ``We think people are bored with a tired cowboy on an almost dead horse,'' he said, an apparent reference to the advertisements for Marlboro cigarettes, which are popular in the Soviet Union. He said he had not sought permission from Moscow to use the president's name. Studer plans to travel to the United States on Saturday in preparation for the launch of Gorbatchow International in North America, and he said he has high hopes for sales. Posters announcing the cigarette's debut on the Swiss market Friday heralded: ``Gorbatchow International Breaks Through The Wall'' _ joining the ranks of Western companies rushing to capitalizing on the crumbling of the Berlin Wall. ``Just as Gorbachev is changing the world, so the new Gorbatchow heralds Perestroika on the international cigarette market,'' gushed the accompanying publicity material. The cigarette was first sold in duty-free shops in Hungary and Bulgaria last May. Ironically, Soviet smokers are as yet unable to sample the cigarette named after their leader. But Studer said he has plans to introduce it in hard currency shops in Moscow, aimed chiefly at American tourists. Gorbachev has never been seen smoking in public, although he reportedly once took a puff in Canada. Cigarette use is widespread in the Soviet Union, which has only a mild anti-smoking campaign. The Geneva-based WHO is urging its member countries to ban promotion of all tobacco. ``We are against anything which leads to an overall increase in consumption of cigarettes,'' said Dr. Clare Chollat-Traquet of the Tobacco or Health program.
