DOC.HEAD: Gun-Propelled Vaccines a Hit on Feed Lots, Wildlife Ranges
LaserPhoto MP1 of March 6
DOC.TEXT: Shooting ``bio-bullets'' at diseased big horn sheep wasn't exactly what Fred Paul envisioned when he began tinkering with a new idea for BB guns. As a researcher for 3M Co., Paul was experimenting with a ``safe-shooting'' water-filled BB when he casually splattered a shot on his office wall. ``Suddenly it hit me,'' Paul said. ``What I had wasn't a gun. It was a long-range delivery device.'' Fifteen years and more than $8 million later, Paul's privately owned Ballistivet Inc. is arming ranchers and wildlife veterinarians with guns that shoot soluble bullets packed with freeze-dried vaccines. If his vision materializes, bio-bullets will dominate syringes in the $1 billion vaccine sector of the animal health industry. The company also is targeting the $4 billion market of antibiotics, wormers, fertility drugs and other pharmaceuticals. ``This is a real Buck Rogers deal. It's goofy,'' said Dr. Jerry Swanson, veterinarian for Hitch Enterprises, a 160,000-head feed lot business in Oklahoma and Kansas. ``But it's really taking off. Pretty soon every cowboy in the high plains will have one of these guns sticking out of his truck window.'' For now, the company has only 14 employees, controls less than 1 percent of the animal vaccine market, and isn't expected to make a profit until 1991. But Paul, who extracted the technology from 3M in 1983, expects sales to triple this year to about 3 million bio-bullets. In addition, the company is moving to a new plant capable of making up to 100 million doses a year. Swanson said the bio-bullet has distinguished itself by adding speed, comfort, dosage uniformity and sterility to the vaccination process. The units, fired rapidly from up to 50 feet away, penetrate flank muscles and dissolve. Most important, Swanson said, bio-bullets spare cattle the stress of syringe inoculations because heavy handling can disrupt a bovine's eating habits for up to three days. Dr. David Jessup, wildlife veterinarian for the California Fish and Game Department in Rancho Cordova, said the patented invention has vastly improved the fight against a pneumonia-producing virus killing large numbers of lambs in a herd of big horn sheep ranging the Santa Rosa Mountains near Sacramento. ``For us this is a godsend,'' Jessup said. ``Any alternative to having to catch animals is quite useful.'' Ron Eis, project manager of bio-production development at rival SmithKline Beecham Animal Health Products in Omaha, Neb., said bio-bullets are a well-crafted alternative to syringes when used on wild or unpenned animals. ``It's not going to revolutionize the market, and I don't think you are every going to replace the syringe,'' Eis said. ``But it is quite quick and quite easy, and there is a niche in the market for that.'' In western Wyoming, game wardens are aiming bio-bullets at a herd of 22,000 elk to vaccinate against brucellosis, a bacterial disease that kills unborn elk. ``It's the biggest wildlife disease program in North America,'' said Tom Thorne of the Wyoming Game and Fish Department. ``The Ballistivet gun is kind of the lynch pin to the whole thing.'' The system also has been used on wild game in Africa and South America, but its biggest potential as a money-maker is in the domestic beef industry, which includes 110 million cattle. Paul and Ballistivet President Donald Sturtevant wouldn't disclose sales projections, but their product now sells for 47 cents to 53 cents apiece, about four times as much as syringe doses. Paul said 3M invested $2 million to $3 million to develop bio-bullets, but decided in 1983 that they didn't fit with its business. Instead of killing the project, 3M accepted royalties from Paul, who raised $500,000 in a private stock offering to form Ballistivet. A year later he kept the company alive by taking out a second mortgage on his hobby farm. ``We laughingly said at the time _ and it was true _ that we bet the farm on it,'' Paul said. Since then, the company has raised $6 million in private stock sales and has avoided sizable bank debt. It is marketing the product through distributors who handle other veterinary products. Keith Eastman of Northstar Ventures Inc., a Minneapolis-St. Paul venture capital firm with a 20 percent stake in Ballistivet, said Paul has operated the company as a ``classic entrepreneur.'' ``He developed a dream and knows all the reasons that it will be successful and he refuses to give up on it,'' Eastman said. The payoff may not be far away. Sturtevant said major drug manufacturers have shown interest in purchasing the company, which would bring a windfall to Ballistivet investors and executives. ``Fred's early-on dream is very, very close to being a complete reality,'' Sturtevant said.

DOC.HEAD: British Firm Buying American Home Products Unit
DOC.TEXT: American Home Products Corp. has agreed to sell its Boyle-Midway home products business to Reckitt and Colman PLC for $1.25 billion, the companies announced Friday. The acquisition by Reckitt and Colman, which makes Colman mustards and other products, is part of its strategy to increase its household products operations and expand in the United States and Europe. A joint statement from the companies gave no reason why American Home Products decided to sell Boyle-Midway, whose products include Woolite laundry soap and Easy-Off oven cleaner. However, the division was outside American Home Products' core pharmaceuticals business, and contributed less than 10 percent of its $6.75 billion sales in 1989. Proceeds of the sale conceivably could be used to reduce the debt American Home Products took on last year in its $3.2 billion acquisition of A.H. Robins Co. John Considine, a company spokesman, was not in his office when a reporter called for comment. Reckitt and Colman has acquired several other U.S. businesses in recent years, including the Durkee foods business and Airwick air fresheners operations. ``We think it's a very attractive deal,'' Ian White, an analyst at the London investment firm Kleinwort Benson Ltd., said of the Boyle-Midway purchase. ``It would have been hard to think of anything which would fit better.'' Reckitt and Colman spent four years trying to persuade American Home Products to sell the operations, White said. Steve Plag, an analyst with Barclays de Zoete Wedd Ltd., said such a move is necessary for Reckitt and Colman ``if it wants to make double-digit growth'' in the years ahead. The British company's existing products are in mature, slower growing sectors of their markets. Boyle-Midway is about half the size of Reckitt and Colman's household products and toiletries division. It had pretax profit of $91 million in 1989 and its $667 million in sales were spread through the United States, Canada, France, West Germany and Spain. Similar Reckitt and Colman businesses had pretax profit of 117 million pounds, or $191 million, on sales of 817 million pounds, or $1.3 billion, last year. The company did not provide aftertax profit figures. Reckitt and Colman said the purchase was to be funded in part by selling to existing shareholders 200 million pounds, or $326 million, in bonds which are convertible into stock. The balance of the acquisition's cost will be financed through bank borrowing and the sales of assets valued at about $50 million, the company said.

DOC.HEAD: Spokesman Denies Bush is Angry at Fed Chairman Over Interest Rates
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The White House on Friday emphatically denied a report that President Bush was ``mad as hell'' at Alan Greenspan, but some private economists said the Federal Reserve chairman was being given a blunt message to lower interest rates or risk losing his job. The Los Angeles Times in its Friday editions quoted a ``longtime Bush adviser'' as saying Greenspan's refusal to further lower interest rates made it extremely unlikely Greenspan would be reappointed Fed chairman when his term expires in August 1991. The unidentified adviser said Bush was ``mad as hell'' over Greenspan's position and the adviser was also quoted as saying, ``I can't believe (Bush) will reappoint him and I don't know a soul in the White House who thinks he will.'' White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater denied Bush was angry with Greenspan. Michael Boskin, the president's chief economic adviser, said there was no foundation for the story, which he termed ``out of left field.'' However, Boskin stopped short of endorsing the Fed's current policies and he also refused to say whether he would recommend that Greenspan be reappointed, calling that question premature. Various administration officials have publicly criticized the Fed over the past several months, but the Times story was the first to suggest Bush was so upset that Greenspan's reappointment was unlikely. At the Fed, spokeswoman Marci Schneider said Greenspan would have no comment on the Times story. But many private economists said they believed the unnamed Bush adviser was sending a clear warning that Greenspan needs to relent his tight-money policies in order to spur economic growth, which dipped in the last quarter to its most sluggish pace in more than three years. ``The administration thinks that Greenspan is screwing up the economy. They believe that if only Greenspan would lower interest rates, we would have faster growth, a lower budget deficit and everybody would be better off,'' said Michael Evans, head of a Washington forecasting firm. Former Federal Reserve Chairman Paul Volcker, Greenspan's predecessor, was the target of similar barbed comments in 1983 when his first term as chairman was expiring. ``You never know on these whether they are trial balloons from some disgruntled element in the administration that wants to get rid of Greenspan or whether Bush is really mad,'' said David Wyss, chief financial economist at DRI-McGraw Hill. ``I remember a lot of similar stories right about the time Reagan reappointed Volcker.'' But other analysts said Reagan was forced to reappoint Volcker in 1983 because jittery financial markets had a lot of faith in Volcker's ability to manage the economy. They said Greenspan may not command the same amount of respect. U.S. financial markets seemed to ignore the entire flap on Friday, preferring to focus instead on the unemployment report, which showed the jobless rate holding steady at 5.3 percent as job growth registered its biggest gain in 20 months. Analysts said the job growth supported Greenspan's current view that the danger point for a recession has passed and the economy should exhibit a modest rebound in coming months. ``Why would you lower interest rates when the economy seems to be pushing ahead? You would just be running grave risks'' of making inflation worse, said Robert Dederick, chief economist of Northern Trust Co. of Chicago.

DOC.HEAD: Unemployment Holds at 5.3 Percent
DOC.NOTE: EDs: CORRECTS last graf to show that rate including military is less than civilian rate; moving general news wires also.
DOC.TEXT: Unemployment held at 5.3 percent in February while the economy produced the most jobs in nearly two years and factory payrolls swelled for the first time in 11 months, the government said Friday. Private economists and the Bush administration said the report was fresh evidence that the economy is rebounding from its anemic 0.9 percent growth rate in the final three months of last year, as measured by the gross national product. ``We believe the economy, after a period of slower growth, is likely to show progress'' in 1990, said Michael Boskin, President Bush's chief economic adviser. He noted that the unemployment rate for black Americans, 10.5 percent, was the lowest since August 1974. A Labor Department survey of households showed a seasonally adjusted civilian jobless rate of 5.3 percent, the ninth consecutive month at that level. The rate has ranged between 5 percent and 5.5 percent since mid-1988 and is in the lowest range since the early 1970s. A separate survey of employers showed a non-farm job gain of 372,000, the largest since June 1988. The department revised its figure for January to an increase of 332,000, up from an earlier estimate of 275,000. Manufacturers added 90,000 workers, the first increase since March 1989. However, Labor Statistics Commissioner Janet L. Norwood cautioned that February gains were inflated by temporary factors. All of the increase at factories was attributed to the return of temporarily laid off auto workers. Other types of manufacturing were sluggish. Also, construction payrolls grew by 60,000 employees, the result of unusually mild weather in February, she told Congress' Joint Economic Committee. Economist Rudy Oswald of the AFL-CIO warned that the strong dollar, by increasing the price of U.S. goods on overseas markets, will dampen prospects for much improvement in manufacturing payrolls, which are down 199,000 from a year earlier. Layoffs by Wall Street brokerage houses and job losses at other service firms such as AT&T and IBM haven't been reflected yet in government reports, he said. Nevertheless, most private economists, who as recently as two months ago were expecting a recession this year, said the economy is beginning 1990 with more vigor than anticipated. ``Right now the recession fear has been pretty well put on the back burner,'' said economist Robert G. Dederick of Northern Trust Co. in Chicago. ``This is an economy which, unless it's hit over the head, just keeps going.'' Stock and bond prices both turned down after the report. Brokers said it seemed to dim whatever chances might have existed for any decline in interest rates from the Federal Reserve. The central bank has been keeping interest rates relatively high in order to slow the economy and curb inflation pressures. It began nudging rates down last June after signs of an impending recession emerged. However, it's left monetary policy unchanged since December and Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan indicated in recent congressional testimony that central bank policymakers have once again focused policy on dampening inflation. ``It's hard for me to see why they would ease in the near future,'' said economist David Wyss of DRI@McGraw Hill, a Lexington, Mass., forecasting firm. ``We're going to see the Fed holding monetary policy stable in the next few weeks.'' Overall, total civilian employment edged up to 118 million. The jobless numbered 6.6 million, about the same as January. The service sector of the economy added 221,00 jobs, including a gain of 47,000 for health services, 28,000 in government, 17,000 in retail trade and 15,000 in finance, real estate and insurance. The addition of about 20,000 census workers over the past two months is bolstering the government number and several hundred thousand additional workers will be added in the next few months, Norwood said. In other details, the department said average hourly earnings posted a 0.6 percent rise in February to $9.87, up from $9.52 a year earlier. Also, the average manufacturing work week held steady in February at 40.7 hours. Overtime fell slightly from 3.7 hours to 3.6 hours. The unemployment rates among major demographic groups last month were: _Adult white men, 4.1 percent, up from 4 percent in January. _Adult white women, 4.1 percent, up from 4 percent. _White teen-agers, 13.0 percent, up from 12.7 percent. _All blacks, 10.5 percent, down from 11.3 percent. _Adult black men, 9.2 percent, down from 11.2 percent. _Adult black women, 9.4 percent, up from 9.2 percent. _Black teen-agers, 28 percent, up from 26.7 percent. _Hispanics, 7.8 percent, up from 7.1 percent. In a separate calculation of unemployment that counts members of the armed services stationed in the United States, the February jobless rate was 5.2 percent, the same as January.

DOC.HEAD: Sentencing Postponed in Stock Manipulation Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf pvs, GAF and... to RESTORE first reference to Sherwin.
DOC.TEXT: The sentencing of GAF Corp. and a top executive on stock manipulation and other charges scheduled for Friday was postponed until March 30. The sentencing was postponed because U.S. District Judge Mary Johnson Lowe was ill, lawyers for GAF said. GAF and Vice Chairman James T. Sherwin were convicted last December on eight criminal counts of manipulating the stock price of Union Carbide Corp. in 1986, in a bid to get more money for GAF's Carbide stock following a failed takeover of the larger chemical company. The case marked the first conviction of a non-Wall Street company in the government's white-collar corruption crackdown that centered on former speculator Ivan Boesky, who paid $100 million and was sentenced to three years in prison for his role in insider-trading related activity. Two subsidiaries of GAF, a Wayne, N.J.-based manufacturer of chemicals and building materials, were acquitted. The case went through two mistrials last year. GAF and Sherwin on Thursday resolved related civil charges with the Securities and Exchange Commission in which the company agreed to pay $1.25 million in penalties.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Rises On Employment Data
Precede LONDON BC
DOC.TEXT: The dollar moved mostly higher Friday in quiet trading on world currency markets, bolstered by a better-than-expected U.S. employment report. Gold prices slipped worldwide. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold settled at $399.80 a troy ounce, off 20 cents from Thursday. Republic National Bank of New York later quoted a bid of $399.75 a troy ounce, down 5 cents. The dollar got a boost from a U.S. Labor Department report showing non-farm payrolls gained 372,000 jobs in February, the largest increase since June 1988. Most estimates had called for a gain of roughly 250,000 jobs. ``The data gave the dollar good background support,'' said Marc Chandler, an analyst at MMS International in Chicago. ``The numbers gave greater credence to the soft-landing scenario and reduced lingering hopes of a near-term easing'' of interest rates, he said. The Federal Reserve keeps the economy from overheating by keeping official interest rates at current levels or by raising them, as some analysts have suggested the government might be considering. Higher interest rates enhance the value of dollar-denominated securities. Despite the bullish sentiment surrounding the dollar, Chandler noted that the fear of central bank intervention prevented the currency from rising further. Several central banks stepped in to sell dollars in European trading, but they did not follow through in domestic markets. Because of nagging political and economic problems in Britain, analysts predicted the pound would continue to weaken against the dollar. The pound lost nearly 2.5 cents amid anxiety over recent demonstrations against a new tax imposed by city halls across Britain. In addition, opinion polls show the popularity of the Conservative government and of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher is at an all-time low as inflation rises and interest rates remain high. Earlier in Tokyo the dollar rose to 151.15 Japanese yen, from Thursday's 150.83 yen. Later in London, the dollar closed at 151.32 yen. In New York the dollar closed at 151.27 yen, up from 151.09 yen on Thursday. In London, one British pound cost $1.6183 late Friday, cheaper for buyers than Thursday's late $1.6427. In New York, one pound cost $1.6170, less expensive than $1.6385 on Thursday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Thursday's late rates included: 1.7025 West German marks, up from 1.7008; 1.5095 Swiss francs, up from 1.5080; 5.7560 French francs, up from 5.7495; 1,257.50 Italian lire, up from 1,255.25, and 1.1804 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1807. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with Thursday's late rates included: 1.7040 West German marks, up from 1.7015; 1.5115 Swiss francs, up from 1.5080; 5.7615 French francs, up from 5.7525; 1.9150 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9164; 1,258.75 Italian lire, up from 1,255.75, and 1.1792 Canadian dollars, unchanged. Gold closed in London at a bid of $399.05 a troy ounce, down from $401.95 on Thursday. The closing bid in Zurich was $399.50, down from $400.75. DOC.HEAD: Millions of Americans Affected Indirectly by S&L Bailout
With BC-S&L Crisis
DOC.TEXT: Aftershocks from President Bush's savings and loan bailout are rippling across the financial and political landscapes, touching _ for better or worse _ millions of Americans. Taxpayers are hurting, even if they don't know it. Money spent on savings institutions won't be available for education, the drug war and other worthy purposes. In its first six months, the new bailout agency, the Resolution Trust Corp., has spent $24 billion, and that's just a down payment. Sophisticated savers who put their money in shaky S&Ls paying high interest rates are hurting, too. An infusion of government money into S&Ls has pulled those rates down. Others are benefiting, however. A booming new scavenger industry is rising from the ashes of the savings and loans. Although the RTC aims at a payroll of 4,800 people by the end of the year, up from 2,300 now, most of its work will be performed by private contractors. More than 10,000 accountants, lawyers, real estate brokers, appraisers and property managers have queried the RTC and are waiting eagerly for the spring, when the agency begins awarding an estimated $1.5 billion worth of contracts. The pickings are particularly juicy for lawyers. The RTC already is involved in 40,000 lawsuits, inherited from its bureaucratic predecessors or the S&Ls it's taking over. According to RTC Chairman L. William Seidman, that likely will double, requiring help from 500 outside law firms. Commercial banks are beneficiaries of the bill as well. In the vast majority of government thrift deals to date, banks have been the buyers, expanding their retail branch networks. Also, as S&Ls make fewer loans, banks have moved to replace them. In the third quarter of last year, residential mortgage lending at banks surpassed S&L mortgage lending for the first time. Banks had 38 percent of the market, compared with 35 percent for thrift associations. Both banks and S&Ls, but not savers, are being helped by a program to reduce deposit rates paid by the institutions under government control. The RTC has replaced $9.2 billion in high-cost deposits with government money and expects to spend another $3 billion in March. As a result, pressure has eased on healthy S&Ls and banks once forced to offer high rates to compete against insolvent, but open, institutions, according to an Office of Thrift Supervision study. Meanwhile, developers complain that one provision of the legislation is having the unintended effect of choking off credit for worthy projects. The law sharply reduced the maximum loan an institution can make to a single lender from 100 percent of net worth to 15 percent. It was intended to force thrifts to diversify their risks, but builders say even good loans aren't being made. The culprits of the crisis, both politicians and S&L executives, also are beginning to suffer. The RTC has referred 1,200 cases of suspected fraud to the Justice Department. In Texas alone, 500 individuals are targeted for investigation, according to Mark M. Richard, deputy assistant attorney general. Meanwhile, five senators who intervened with regulators on behalf of millionaire Charles H. Keating Jr.'s Lincoln Savings and Loan Association are sweating through a Senate Ethics Committee investigation. At least one, Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., the No. 2 Democrat in the Senate, is fighting for political survival with voters in his home state. Rep. Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, chairman of the House Banking Committee, is keeping the heat bipartisan. His investigation of the Lincoln debacle forced top thrift regulator M. Danny Wall, a Reagan administration appointee, to announce his resignation. Now, he plans to focus on the connections between S&Ls and Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s indicted junk bond chief, Michael Milken. Among the S&Ls coming under scrutiny will be Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association of Denver. The president's son, Neil Bush, served on the failed thrift's board. The younger Bush is fighting conflict-of-interest charges leveled by the thrift office and the House probe will keep that controversy simmering.

DOC.HEAD: Pan Am Posts $178.3 Million Fourth-Quarter Loss
DOC.TEXT: Pan Am Corp., which has been seeking a merger partner to pull it out of financial trouble, on Friday reported a fourth-quarter net loss of $178.3 million. The loss, amounting to $1.21 a share, widened from a net loss of $51.7 million, or 36 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1988. Revenue during the quarter rose to 6.9 percent to $897.9 million from $839.9 million a year earlier. New York-based Pan Am, the nation's eighth-largest airline, said its revenue was ``severely impacted'' by declining passenger traffic on its trans-Atlantic routes. The airline blamed a 10.3 percent jump in operating expenses largely on soaring fuel prices. It said its jet fuel costs rose to $174.7 million in the quarter from $129.4 million a year earlier. Pan Am has lost around $2 billion since 1981 and is saddled with $841 million in debt. A year ago, Pan Am Chairman Thomas Plaskett said the airline needed to merge with another carrier in order to survive. Pan Am offered about $3.3 billion last May for NWA Inc., parent of Northwest Airlines, but was outbid by a $3.65 billion offer from a group led by investor Alfred Checchi. Pan Am and the larger Northwest have held discussions in recent weeks, but a source familiar with the talks said they have stalled. A merger between the two airlines ``just doesn't make sense,'' the source said. But he added that some sort of joint marketing arrangement between the two still could emerge. For all of 1989, Pan Am had a net loss of $336.6 million, or $2.31 a share, compared with a loss of $72.7 million, or 51 cents a share in 1988. The 1989 results include a gain of $110.5 million from the sale of Pan Am World Services, a contract subsidiary for security and other services. The 1988 results included an $89.1 million gain from the sale of delivery positions for Airbus jets. Full-year revenue declined to $3.56 billion from $3.57 billion in 1988. ``Despite the severe setback in our 1989 financial performance, we continued implementing our plans to provide high-quality customer service,'' Plaskett said in a news release Friday. ``The positive traffic results in recent months are most encouraging, and serve to support our belief that consumers are recognizing the improvements we have made in our service product.'' Pan Am said its passenger traffic in January was up 23 percent over the same month last year, followed by a 26 percent jump in February. Some airline analysts believe that, short of merging with Northwest, Pan Am might sell some of its prized trans-Atlantic routes or other assets. Pan Am spokeswoman Pamela Hanlon confirmed this week that the airline has held preliminary talks with Lufthansa German Airlines on a possible sale of Pan Am's internal German service. Last week, Pan Am said it reached agreement with two unidentified creditors to defer about $106 million in payments. The first scheduled repayments are due in this year's fourth quarter and will extend through the fourth quarter of 1991. In exchange, the airline agreed to pledge additional assets, including spare parts, as collateral.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices slumped Friday after unexpectedly strong employment news touched off new interest-rate worries on Wall Street. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials slipped 12.84 to 2,683.33, cutting its gain for the week to 22.97 points. Declining issues outnumbered advances by a little less than 3 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 602 up, 876 down and 484 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 150.41 million shares, down from 170.90 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 180.54 million shares. The Labor Department reported that the civilian unemployment rate held steady at 5.3 percent in February, while nonfarm payroll employment swelled by 372,000 on top of an upward-revised increase in January. The pace of job growth substantially exceeded advance estimates, suggesting that the economy had regained more momentum than many analysts had thought. That was interpreted as a plus for the outlook for corporate profits, which have been weak lately. But brokers said it also raised new worries about upward pressure on interest rates, and seemed to dim whatever chances might have existed for any easing of the Federal Reserve's credit policy. In the credit markets, prices of long-term government bonds fell about $7.50 for each $1,000 in face value, raising their yields to the 8.62 percent-8.69 percent range. NCNB fell 2[ to 41{. The company said it might see an increase of as much as 25 percent in its problem loans during the first quarter of the year. Among actively traded blue chips, International Business Machines dropped { to 106{; American Telephone & Telegraph } to 41; Philip Morris ~ to 37\, and General Electric ] to 62|. The Gap Inc., which chalked up one of the strongest gains among retailers announcing February sales results on Thursday, rose 2\ to 61{, trading at new 52-week highs. General-merchandise retailing issues finished mixed. Sears Roebuck was unchanged at 41\; K mart rose [ to 34, and J.C. Penney dropped { to 68]. Hilton Hotels rose ~ to 51{, rebounding from a 10]-point slide Thursday after the company ended its quest for a possible acquirer, saying it hadn't received any suitable offers. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $16.34 billion, or 0.50 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dropped 1.17 to 186.18. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 2.67 to 390.35, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was down 2.34 at 337.93. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market rose .26 to 436.76. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 361.15, down .36.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Futures Continue Decline
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices extended their losing streak Friday to four days as demand for refined products remained sluggish. The contract for April delivery of home heating oil fell sharply, slipping 1.48 cents to 53.86 cents a gallon on the New York Mercantile Exchange, bringing the contract's losses since Tuesday to 4.13 cents. Subsequent contract months also declined Friday. The April contract for unleaded regular gasoline dropped 1.15 cents to 54.99 cents a gallon, bringing its losses over the last four sessions to 4.31 cents. Later months also settled lower. Andrew Lebow, an energy market analyst with E.D.&F. Man International Futures Inc., said slowing demand for heating oil and gasoline brought prices for those products lower, and also took a toll on crude oil futures. The contract for April delivery of West Texas Intermediate, the key grade of U.S. crude oil, fell 35 cents to $20.43 a 42-gallon barrel after skidding 80 cents the previous three days. Subsequent contract months also fell Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Coffee Futures Tumble
DOC.TEXT: Coffee futures tumbled Friday on speculation that Brazil was ready to pour more of its crop on the world market. On other futures markets, soybeans and corn rose while energy products, gold and pork prices fell. The March futures contract for coffee dipped to nearly 95 cents a pound on the New York Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange. Bert Ruiz, a vice president of Balfour Maclaine Corp., said the big decline in heavy volume followed an estimate Thursday by the Brazilian coffee agency that it has more than 16 million bags of coffee on hand. ``That's a lot of coffee, but very little of it is the finer, exportable type,'' said Ruiz. It was apparently enough to scare traders, who also felt coffee futures rose too much earlier this week when it went to over $1.05 a pound, he said. Coffee settled 4.25 cents to 7.32 cents lower, with the contract for delivery in March at 95.18 cents. Futures prices for soybeans and corn advanced, but wheat was mostly lower on the Chicago Board of Trade. A resurgence of export business and an active soymeal cash market overnight in Rotterdam supported soybean futures, said Joel Karlin, an analyst with Research Department Inc. ``Also, South American rains could delay the start of the harvest there,' he said. ``The soybean advance spilled over into corn and gave that market a boost.'' Wheat prices were depressed by forecasts of rain this weekend over U.S. growing areas, said Walter Spilka, analyst with Smith Barney Harris Upham & Co. Wheat settled unchanged to 2\ cents lower, with the contract for delivery in March at $3.83{ a bushel; corn was { cent to 1{ cent higher, with March at $2.43\ a bushel; oats were \ cent to 2 cents higher, with March at $1.46 a bushel; and soybeans were 3{ cent to 6 cents higher, with March at $5.87{ a bushel. On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, pork futures were lower and cattle prices mostly higher. Buying interest in cattle was generated by active feeder cattle sales at higher prices and expectations for higher feeder prices next week, analysts said. Pork prices were weakened by anticipation that many farmers, who have spent the past week at home because of bad weather, will be out marketing their animals on Monday, according to traders. Cattle settled unchanged to .35 cent higher, with the contract for delivery in April at 77.62 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent lower to .40 cent higher, with March at 82.10 cents a pound; live hogs were .15 cent to .30 cent lower, with April at 51.92 cents a pound; and frozen pork bellies were 1.00 cent to 1.43 cent lower, with March at 50.95 cents a pound. Precious metals declined on the Commodity Exchange in New York. Gold was pressured by the U.S. dollar firming against foreign currencies and lower-than-expected February unemployment data, analysts said. The dollar and unemployment data usually move in opposite directions from gold. Gold settled 20 cents to 50 cents lower, with the contract for delivery in March at $399.80 a troy ounce; and silver was 1 cent to 2 cent lower, with March at $5.10 a troy ounce. Energy products futures sank on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Peter Beutel of Elders Futures Inc. said light refiner buying interest weighed on futures prices. Crude oil settled 23 cents to 35 cents lower, with the contract for delivery in April at $20.43 a barrel; heating oil was 1.42 cents to 1.70 cents lower, with April at 53.86 cents a gallon; and unleaded gasoline was .75 cent to 1.74 cents lower, with April at 54.99 cents a gallon.

DOC.HEAD: Creditors, Shareholders Approve Northeast Reorganization Plan
DOC.TEXT: Shareholders and creditors of bankrupt Public Service Co. of New Hampshire have approved the $2.3 billion takeover plan proposed by Northeast Utilities, the company said Friday. ``It's a major milestone,'' Public Service spokeswoman Elizabeth Lavallee said after votes were tallied. ``The approval of shareholders and creditors wtll be a factor in the bankruptcy judge's decision on the plan.'' ahe Fo{{zzzues representing investors and creditors approved the plan in November and the state Legislature followed, more than a year after Public Service filed for bankruptcy protection in January 1988. Northeast won the bidding over three other bidders, including Public Service itself. All classes of secured creditors approved the acquisition of New Hampshire's largest electric utility by the Berlin, Conn.-based Northeast. All the unsecured creditors, except a group of independent power producers, approved the takeover, as well as Public Service's preferred and common stockholders. Another group that rejected the plan was the holders of $13.4 million in outstanding warrants to buy Public Service stock, for which they would get 10 cents a warrant under the plan. The group is the lowest tier of investors involved, and the last to get paid, under the reorganization plan. ``O_$@o__?8|ooOe vote represents another major step toward resolving our bankruptcy,'' Public Service Chairman John Duffett said in a statement. Northeast spokesman Jeffrey Kotkin also called the vote a big step. ``If the major creditors and shareholders rejected the plan, you'd go back to the drawing board,'' he said. Public Service mailed 150,000 ballots in January to be returned by Tuesday. whether to confirm the plan. The next immediate step will be hearings in early April in U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Manchester. Judge James Yacos then must decide whether to confirm the plan. Federal and state regulatory approvals also are required before the takeover is complete.

Unemployment held at 5.3 percent in February while the economy produced the most jobs in nearly two years and factory payrolls swelled for the first time in 11 months, the government said. Private economists and the Bush administration said the report Friday was fresh evidence that the economy is rebounding from its anemic 0.9 percent growth rate in the final three months of last year, as measured by the gross national product.

American Home Products Corp. has agreed to sell its Boyle-Midway home products business to Reckitt and Colman PLC for $1.25 billion, the companies announced. The acquisition by Reckitt and Colman, which makes Colman mustards and other products, is part of its strategy to increase its household products operations and expand in the United States and Europe. Boyle-Midway's products include Woolite laundry soap and Easy-Off oven cleaner.

The White House denied a report that President Bush was ``mad as hell'' at Alan Greenspan, but some private economists said the Federal Reserve chairman was being given a blunt message to lower interest rates or risk losing his job. The Los Angeles Times in its Friday editions quoted a ``longtime Bush adviser'' as saying Greenspan's refusal to further lower interest rates made it extremely unlikely Greenspan would be reappointed Fed chairman when his term expires in August 1991.

The Securities and Exchange Commission's attempt to gain jurisdiction over stock-index futures is a ``power grab'' by an agency that lacks the expertise to effectively regulate those securities, said Rep. Glenn English. Instead, problems in the futures markets can best be solved by strengthening the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, said English, an Oklahoma Democrat who chairs the subcommittee that oversees the CFTC. Speaking Friday at the Futures Industry Association's annual meeting, English also said he may reluctantly support a ``user fee'' on futures transactions to fund a beefed-up futures regulator.

Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc. creditors will receive confidential company information but no veto power over asset sales under a bankruptcy court agreement on managing liquidation of the collapsed Wall Street firm. Also, attorneys for Drexel's unsecured creditors said Friday they would oppose a move by the Securities and Exchange Commission to join their committee. Drexel still owes the SEC $150 million from its 1989 settlement of securities fraud charges. Opposition to an SEC role on the committee centers on $500 million Drexel already has paid the government that creditors have said they may seek to recover for repayment of debts.

Processing of 171,000 federal tax refunds has been delayed a week because of a faulty computer tape, the Internal Revenue Service said. That will mean 31,000 people who filed electronic returns and 141,000 who used paper forms will have to wait a week for refunds, IRS public affairs director Ellen Murphy said Friday. The returns were filed to the IRS service center in Ogden, Utah, from 25 states in the Midwest and Northwest.

Hughes Aircraft Co. has admitted that it unlawfully obtained classified Pentagon budget documents and agreed to pay the government $3.67 million, officials said. Hughes, which pleaded guilty Friday to two felony counts, is the fourth major defense contractor to admit to such charges. Three to six other Pentagon contractors remain under investigation, said Michael J. Costello, special agent in charge of the Defense Criminal Investigative Service's Washington field office.

Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher, preparing to lead a high-level trade delegation to Tokyo, said he believes America now has a real chance to reduce its huge trade imbalance with Japan. Mosbacher said Friday he was carrying a ``caseload of cases,'' which would give the Japanese a chance to demonstrate the new spirit of cooperation evident in last week's summit meeting between President Bush and Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu.

Exxon Corp. shareholders and environmentalists said that their attempts to prod the giant oil company into a more environmentally sensitive direction could include a call at Exxon's annual meeting to oust its chairman. Six shareholder proposals on environmental issues have been cleared by the Securities and Exchange Commission for inclusion in Exxon's proxy statement and will be voted on at the company's April 25 annual meeting, the groups said Friday. The company opposes all the proposals.

Stock prices slumped Friday after unexpectedly strong employment news touched off interest-rate worries. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials slipped 12.84 to 2,683.33, cutting its gain for the week to 22.97 points. Bond prices dropped sharply on the unemployment news. The dollar moved mostly higher in quiet trading. Gold prices slipped. Coffee futures tumbled, soybeans and corn rose while energy products, gold and pork prices fell.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Prices Tumble
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices fell sharply Friday, knocked down by news of strong employment growth in February. The Treasury's closely watched 30-year bond tumbled } point, or $7.50 for every $1,000 in face value. Its yield, which rises when the price falls, surged to 8.62 percent from 8.55 percent late Thursday. Analysts attributed the market's weakness to a Labor Department report showing non-farm payrolls expanded in February by the largest amount in 20 months. After the report was released in the morning, ``It was put your helmet on and get in the foxhole,'' said John Sebastian, executive vice president of Clayton Brown & Associates in Chicago. The seasonally adjusted gain of 372,000 jobs was the largest since June 1988. In another sign of strength in the labor market, the department revised the non-farm payroll gain for January to 332,000, up from an earlier estimate of 275,000. The overall unemployment rate held steady at 5.3 percent. ``These numbers show an economy that's considerably stronger than some would have thought,'' said William Brachfeld, an executive vice president at Daiwa Securities Inc. in New York. That interpretation reinforced the widely held perception that the Federal Reserve has insufficient cause to pursue a more generous credit policy and push interest rates lower. In fact, Brachfeld said, some traders now have begun to ask whether the Fed might be more inclined sometime in the near future to tighten its grip on credit in a stepped-up effort to squeeze inflation out of the economy. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, prices of short-term government issues declined \ point to ] point, intermediate maturities lost 7-16 point to 17-32 point, and long-term issues fell 23-32 point to 13-16 point, according to figures provided by Telerate Inc., a financial information service. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Hutton Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, was down 4.41 at 1,147.97. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 91 19-32, down 3-16 point. The average yield to maturity edged up to 7.45 percent from 7.44 percent late Thursday. Yields on three-month Treasury bills rose to 8.23 percent as the discount jumped 7 basis points to 7.97 percent. Yields on six-month bills soared to 8.30 percent as the discount advanced 7 basis points to 7.87 percent. Yields on one-year bills increased to 8.43 percent as the discount rose 8 basis points to 7.83 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, was quoted at 8 5-16 percent, unchanged from late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Boeing Cuts Number of Layoff Notices by Nearly Two-Thirds
DOC.TEXT: The Boeing Co. issued layoff notices to about 600 workers Friday, roughly a third as many as anticipated nearly two months ago, but a company spokesman said employment forecasts for the year remain unchanged. About three-fourths of the two-week notices were for workers at the 767 and 747 plant in verett, with the remainder scattered around the rest of the Puget Sound area, Paul Binder said Friday. In January, Boeing said it expected to cut its Seattle-area work force by 5,000 people in 1990, but hoped that half those lost jobs could be absorbed through retirements or resignations. The company said it anticipated laying off 1,700 hourly workers by April, and another 800 later in the year. Binder said the overall forecast for the reduced work force, with about half the reductions accomplished through layoffs, remained unchanged. He said he did not know the reason for the apparent delay in layoffs but added that 200 to 300 more employees would get pink slips in about two weeks and another 200 or so about a week and a half after that. Under federal law, Boeing was required to give 60-day notice to all workers who could be affected by the layoffs. Binder said the two-week notices are a more definite indication that workers will lose their jobs, ``but even if they do get the notice ... they still might not be laid off.'' About 1,400 of those facing layoffs are in Everett. Boeing has been trying to reassign as many of the workers as it can to other plants and has set up centers to help them find new employment. Binder said that in the time since the initial notices were issued, more people may have retired or taken other jobs, especially those who knew their jobs were threatened. In Wichita, Kan., Boeing's second-largest employment center, 91 workers have been laid off since January and as many as 100 more may get pink slips by the end of the month, said Pete Dakan of Boeing Military Airplane Group. Boeing employment in Wichita has been reduced from about 24,000 people to about 23,500 so far this year, Dakan said. He added that more layoffs in Wichita, which are separate from those announced by Binder, may be announced early next week. Boeing employed about 106,700 people in the Seattle area at the end of 1989, and employment has since shrunk by about 800, Binder said. Worldwide, Boeing employs about 163,000. The layoff notices come at a time when Boeing has a record firm backlog of more than 1,700 commercial jets, with the Everett plant alone booked through 1996. Boeing hired about 10,000 additional employees last year and was so strapped for production workers that at one point it borrowed 600 employees from the Lockheed plant in Marietta, Ga. Mandatory overtime was a major issue in the 48-day Machinists union strike against Boeing last fall. Last year Boeing fell behind schedule in introducing and certifying the new 747-400 jumbo jet, which was brought out in four different versions. Now, with startup and certification work done, company officials say the extra 747 workers no longer are needed. Boeing said earlier it had hoped to absorb those workers in defense contracts such as work on the B-2 stealth bomber, for which it is a major subcontractor to Northrop, but warming East-West relations and the fall of Communist regimes in Eastern Europe have cast doubt on the future of many military projects.

DOC.HEAD: Experts: It May be Too Soon to Launch The Hunt for Red Investor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5 grafs for grafs 7-8 pvs, `The SEC's... to UPDATE with Breeden comment, EDITS to conform; PICKS UP 10th graf pvs, `Administration officials
DOC.TEXT: The Securities and Exchange Commission, the bastion of law and order on Wall Street, is forming an advisory committee to help Soviet bloc countries keep their infant stock markets orderly and honest. But securities and Soviet economic experts in this country are divided over whether it's too soon for emerging Eastern European economies to launch The Hunt for Red Investor. ``They want to run before they can walk,'' said Ed A. Hewett, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution in Washington. He and other experts on Eastern European economic affairs said developing a banking system might be a better course of action. But they agreed it was important for the U.S. government to take the initiative in guiding the way to capitalism despite market drops and junk bond scandals. ``Whatever our problems are, theirs are greater,'' said Marshall I. Goldman, associate director of Harvard's Russian Research Center, adding ``... I think the last thing they want is a series of Drexel Burnham Lamberts popping up.'' Last Tuesday, SEC Chairman Richard C. Breeden, who has met recently with high-level financial officials from the Soviet Union, Hungary and Poland, announced that the SEC is forming an Advisory Committee on Emerging Securities Markets in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. ``Obviously they need a banking system,'' Breeden said in a telephone interview late Friday. ``But I disagree that you should do nothing but focus on banks and ignore the development of a capital market.'' He said bank loans alone could create ``a greater dependency on debt financing than might be desired, if we can also create equity markets.'' Breeden said the Soviet delegation sought his advice during a visit that included a tour of the New York Stock Exchange and major securities firms. ``They said equity was something they would like to move toward,'' he said. ``They obviously are not going to go from zero to the New York Stock Exchange in the next six months, but they are looking for systems with low volume that can be expanded.'' But a source familiar with developments leading up to the formation of the SEC comittee said the idea grew out of the Malta summit meeting between President Bush and Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev. Administration officials saw the creation of stock markets in the formerly Communist-dominated countries as ``symbolic of democracy,'' said the source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Despite the frenzy over newly won political freedoms, however, experts contacted this week said Eastern Europe may not be quite ready to shift from Das Kapital to venture capital. ``The first step is not going for a sophisticated stock market,'' said Stuart Brown, an assistant professor of economics at Georgetown University. Most experts thought it was a great idea for the SEC to be involved at such an early stage, but questioned how ready Moscow and Warsaw were for leveraged buyouts and real estate investment trusts. ``Their questions are not about junk bonds, but `What is a stock? What is a bond? How do we move money around?''' said Hewett. ``The securities markets are really only a small part of the economic system,'' said Alan Bromberg, a securities law professor at Southern Methodist University. ``My guess is they must first have a banking system that will provide seed money for private enterprise.'' If the Federal Reserve Board has any plans for Eastern Europe, the nation's top economic policy-making body is keeping them close to the vest. The central bank said in a statement Friday: ``In the course of our ongoing relationship with officials of foreign economies, it is not uncommon for them to visit fellow officials of the Federal Reserve. And in recent months these visits have included officials from some East European countries.'' The advisory committee, which may meet as soon as next month, will recommend what action the SEC and the financial industry can take to help create organize securities markets in Eastern Europe, said Breeden. ``I hope they have somebody in there who knows something about the Soviet Union,'' said Goldman. ``There can be a real danger to thinking it operates like a normal economy.'' Because of official corruption, oppressive laws and a huge black market, the Soviet Union is ``a crime-ridden society'' that needs advice on regulations, he said. Breeden said there was no more fitting manner for this country to help economic development in Eastern Europe ``than by assisting in the creation of free capital markets in these countries.'' But some critics have noted that a system that has seen a stock market crash, a steep drop in the junk bond market and the collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the securities firm that pioneered the high-yield, high-risk bonds, may not be the best example to emulate. ``I think just the opposite,'' countered Arthur Mathews, a prominent Washington securities attorney. ``Don't you think the fact that our markets could survive a crash and the collapse of Drexel without a depression shows their strength.''

DOC.HEAD: Pathe Makes First Down Payment on MGM-UA
DOC.TEXT: MGM-UA Communications Co. said Friday it had received a $50 million deposit from Pathe Communications, which has agreed to acquire MGM-UA for $1.27 billion. Last year, Qintex Group's $1.5 billion offer for MGM-UA collapsed after it missed a down payment of the same size. Qintex had outbid Rupert Murdoch's News Corp. for the company. MGM-UA officials said this week that they were more confident that Pathe, controlled by Italian financier Giancarlo Parretti, would be able to finance a buyout. Pathe agreed Wednesday to buy MGM-UA, and said it would make three more monthly deposits of $50 million each into an escrow account, bringing the total to $200 million. It is to commence a tender offer of $20 per share for up to 100 percent of MGM-UA's common and preferred stock by March 14, an offer that would amount to the $1.27 billion if all shares are tendered. Pathe also inherits $400 million in MGM-UA junk bond debt as part of the deal. Further cementing the deal are guarantees that MGM-UA will get at least $75 million from distributing upcoming Pathe movies.

DOC.HEAD: Video Outfit Buys National Lampoon
DOC.TEXT: A home video company headed by founder of Disney's home video operations has agreed to acquire the struggling National Lampoon in a deal valued at $4.5 million, the companies annnounced Friday. The video production and distribution outfit, J2 Communications of Los Angeles, said it expected to complete the acquisition in late May. National Lampoon will become a division of J2 under the Lampoon's co-presidents, Daniel Grodnick and Tim Matheson. The pair acquired a controlling stake in the satirical magazine last year and have been trying to rebuild its circulation and advertising, which have faltered in recent years. James P. Jimirro, the chief executive of J2 and the former head of the Disney Channel and Disney Home Video, said, ``The name National Lampoon has been synonymous with satire for the past 20 years.'' ``We look forward to integrating National Lampoon into the J2 operations and providing capital and additional support which will help the magazine and related activities during the coming years,'' Jimirro said. J2 Communications produces such fare as the comedy video ``Dorf on Golf,'' starring Tim Conway, and ``Chef Paul Prudhomme's Louisiana Kitchen.''

DOC.SECOND: AM-Heart Attack Drugs, 1st Ld - Writethru, f0323,0666
DOC.HEAD: Two Heart Attack Drugs Work Equally Well Despite Cost Difference, Study Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS new grafs 8, `Genentech's TPA ...' and 16-18, `G. Kirk Raab ... Roche said' to UPDATE with TPA market share, Genentech official calling for further study, Roche official saying study won't affect merger plans. A version also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Two drugs used to treat heart attacks save lives equally well despite a 10-fold difference in their cost, according to research announced Thursday. The risk of dying before leaving the hospital was the same no matter whether the patient was treated with streptokinase or tissue plasminogen activator, called TPA. When each drug was combined with a second drug called heparin, streptokinase showed a lower death rate. But an official of Genentech Inc., the major biotechnology company that makes TPA, the more expensive drug, said he believes the study was not the final answer for American doctors. The results, released at a medical conference in Florence, Italy, dealt with more than 20,000 European heart attack patients. The researchers were from Italy and elsewhere in Europe. The study found an overall death rate of 8.9 percent after treatment with TPA and an 8.5 percent rate after treatment with streptokinase. Statistically, those rates are the same. Both drugs are designed to destroy blood clots that have caused heart attacks by blocking a crucial blood vessel. Genentech's TPA holds about two-thirds of the market while streptokinase has about a third. Genentech reported TPA sales of $197 million in 1989. But their costs vary greatly. An editorial in the New England Journal of Medicine last year said one treatment with streptokinase costs $78 at a San Francisco hospital, while TPA costs $2,268. A separate report has cited a 10-fold difference. The New England Journal editorial accompanied a study that suggested the two drugs worked equally well, but it looked at the health of the heart's main pumping chamber rather than death rates. The newly announced study ``bears out what a number of cardiologists have been really ... saying for the last four or five years, that there has been absolutely no scientific evidence that TPA was superior to streptokinase,'' said an American investigator familiar with the results, William O'Neill of William Beaumont Hospital in Royal Oak, Mich. But David Stump, director of clinical research for Genentech, said the trial's treatment procedure hampered the effectiveness of TPA. Patients did not receive early intravenous doses of heparin along with TPA therapy, he said. Many American doctors take that step to keep opened arteries from becoming obstructed again, he said. The heparin given some patients in the study was administered much later in the course of therapy and through injections under the skin rather than intravenously, he said in a telephone interview from Florence. The combination of TPA plus heparin in the new study gave a death rate of 9.2 percent, and streptokinase plus heparin yielded a 7.9 percent rate. G. Kirk Raab, president and chief executive officer of Genentech, called for further tests of patients who got early intravenous injections of heparin. The study won't affect a planned merger between Genentech and Roche Holding Ltd., the Swiss pharmaceutical giant that was announced last month, according to a Roche news release. ``Individual trials limited to certain aspects only would not influence such important investment decisions,'' Roche said. The study also found the risk of stroke was greater in patients treated with TPA. The stroke rate was 1.3 percent among the group treated with TPA compared with 1 percent in those treated with streptokinase. ``These stroke rates are within the 1 percent to 1.5 percent range seen in other studies with thrombolytics (anti-blood cloting drugs) and are within the range seen in heart attack patients not receiving thrombolytic therapy,'' Genentech said in a statement.
